The " Musical Fallacy " which I propose to discuss this week is now, happily, almost obsolete, but, as some fifteen or twenty years

ago it obtained very considerable popularity, j

a reference to it will not be out of place

in this series. This fallacy — shall I | say was—that it was not necessary to j play tho piano in order to teach it, indeed, some went' fuTttrer, "and affirmed

that it was a positive advantage for the . teaoher( ? j to be unahio to .playhergalf,. In thoseJ (lays; it may I»o explained. a male teacher was i somewhat of a rarity. I have a very vivid i recollection of at-cortain teacher of this deacrip- j tion--a short, stout, old lady, who always i dressed in black, and who undertook to guide , my youthful fingers through the intricacies of • five-finger exercises and scales, .and tp_iiutiate ^ rue into the mysteries of tho seven letters j which do duty for the names of the notes, i This good" lady, who, by-thfl-wa^. generally employed herself during my lesson rof/ar, dig

her damaged hosiery, had acquired a trernun- . clous reputation in a certain circle, and j was "such a good teacher because, you know, eho doesn't play herself at all," So the story went, and certain it is that no one had ever heard her attempt it. Well, as I re marked before, this idea has now almostdiod

• out, though it may obtain currency in some j

country districts, so scarcely needs any argu- ] mentfl of mine to extinguish it. tttill, it

may be poiu ed out with regard to piano i playing that after the elemonts of music, and the correct positions of the hands and lingers have Iieen mastered, the most vulunblmjn strnction a teacher can impart is througntho medium of his own performances. I do not. of course, mean that the lesson should partake of the nature of a pianoforte recital, but that certain awkward passages, embellishments, and occa sionally whole movements should be played as a model for the student. Indeed, this is the only way in which a correct idea of many passages can bo imparted. Naturally a busy teacher could not be expected to keep up a repertory of all the best-known classics and modern xrolon music, but-he-should-be able to play so as to give a good and correct idea of any passage in the works be undertakes to teach. There is, unfortunate)}, now , a-days a tendency by some who are weak

in "the practical side of their pro fession to discount the value of technical powers in a teacher; who would give you to understand that a good pianist is not likely to Jbe a good- teacher ;-tkat it ia~not_r«aUy necessary. to -be a. bril 1 i an t_pi an i s t i n _o rd or to. teach, etc., &e. This is in the main rank non sense, anrt afteT hearing HUcineTuailrs one is very forcibly reminded of the old fable of the fox and the grapes. Of course it is not neces sary for a man to bo able to pi ay a Liszt Rhapsodiqhrilliantly in order to teach a child —the—elements -of music, nor does it follow

that a brilliant player is of necessity a brilliant teacher. But, it is a dis tinct advantage for a teacher, to be a fine player,- and the better he plays the better ho can teach, if he-wants to. As an ample refutation to any such ideas, let me name four of the greatest teachers the world has ever seen, who likewise took rank as the greatest pianists -of -their time — Liszt, Rubin; —stram;~VVfn Butow. -and "Leschetitzky, ~

His art that holds him: enraptured,. willingly onbchahied:hby its divine melody,its en ohanting harmony, as it floats around him from the fingers of the skilful devotee. ',It is only the enthusiast, with his passionate love:for music, that is capable of, or likely to indulge in, flights of :imagination of this character, and his doing so pre-sup poses 'a. capability of understanding to a certain extent the works of the great masters; a certain modicum of musicianly skill as an' exponent. and musical senes-: bility. It does not, however, always follow 'that such is the case, many having: a re fined nature possess,intuitively and acutely;: an admiration and love of all that is beau tiful and godlike in.every direction of art; and have the keenest susceptibility, of the, pure, and good-the art instinct naturally ,dictating the rejection of the. inferior 'and yet in music..they, unfortunately may not be gifted in the matter. , of ,technical skill nor possess.the;dexterity of the "hammerer-out" of yusic .() so often mot with. Let 'usnowe leave the ethical and view music from its :other,.- side--the purely practical. ' .It has often occutred:?to thawriter.'tliat ??gh.:pbeefit. would.. be derivable, if those who profess -so. much; love,for-tho.musiqal 1pr,.could; srrangf to devote.,tpgether qn:oyening,;in each week for downright honest' and earnest study. Opportunity ,wquld.;·then be afforded of making,;the acquaintanqe 'of works but little?:rsown? .and . pf. .becoming, better acquainted with those., tlat .arc:, already familiar.. Tlhere is so:much of the! "ear tickling"g musip (F) in request. now-a-days that,wheon. a really first-class piece appears on a programme the average concert-goer soonexpresses disapproval: by keeping up a continuoushum of conversation during its performancg,:much to the annoyance of the musician,.who wishes to enjoy:it, and cer tainly'?.ps.equal riglh tp consideration. Adopting a movement of this sort the little Society could gradually.increase its num bera by:bpinging in those who make a pro fession of music, aind thus.,stoep b step educate. the would-'be musical public t bletter things. I would siggest that these meetings :take, the form of lectures or evenings 'with the old mnasters and modern. composcrs that the nemblera. rmake

themselves conversant with the life and. wor..of each. cosmposer, and that practical illustration be'given of -their compositions and various works. Such :gatleripgs, I think; would be a souere of nimich b'enefit and enjoymert to niusicians, and would supplyin a -small. way-the.lack of higher instruction nbt? obtainable 'in so small.a 'community. .If a little of the, energy, that is giveiito'thd ;rasuit if 'a fdotljallto the' drivitg of the leather, etc., or..the .dis cussidn'.'df '.a. suitable, costume, for, .tho coming lall; were devoted to the' study of the theory,ptd practice, of.music. and .the many sister arts; our fair island;I think, would rejoice, in. far better..men, and wome? : .; It would be much,to.the advance ment'of the:rising generation of this colony if' music -'theory and practice -: were taught in our state :ichools and colleges i' not taught to a. few, but considered a necessary part of education.' At home the training-schools 'for" schoolmiasters and schoolmistresses have made the. study of vocal miisic an essential . iart of their curriculum. At' [IM?nich a " Central Singechule," .founded .more than fifty years ago, affords :to children from all parts of the town vocal training, and many of the schools have made the theory of music and singing lessons obligatory. If, therefore,,our Board of Education and principals of colleges and' schools can be brought to perceive the necessity, it would be a red-letter day for Tasmania, if the preliminary, introduction at least of an universal systenimof'vocal teaching and~the theory of music, under the supervision of, able teachers, were an established fact. heading: Nostalgic musical Musical Countdown the Musical
snippet: IT was a case of turning back the clock for a nostalgic hit parade of 1970s and 1980s music in Countdown the Musical at the Comedy Club in Carlton.
articleText:
A singer impersonates Jimmy Barnes during Countdown the Musical.

Nostalgic

musical

Musical

Countdown the Musical

DANNY GOCS

IT was a case of turning back the clock for a nostalgic hit parade of 1970s and 1980s music in Countdown the Musical at the Comedy Club in Carlton.

Produced without the blessing of the ABC, the show is presented as a recording session for the popular TV show, complete with Gavin Wood’s supercharged voiceovers and Michael Veitch’s excellent impersonation of host Molly Meldrum.

A team of talented singers bound on and off the stage in a variety of costumes as they play out the pop classics, mostly with a very authentic sound. In rapid succession we relive the songs of Skyhooks, Suzie Q, Boy George, Mark Holden, Deborah Harry and a

host of one-hit wonders.

Some of the voice impersonations were excellent, others passable as the men donned wigs and tight flared pants and the women hit the stage in mini-skirts and plat

form shoes.

Highlights included an excellent Shirley Strachan impersonation in the opening Skyhooks number, and an energetic Jimmy

Barnes lookalike.

The singers include James Sherry, Wendy Mooney, Steven Judkins and David

Knox.

Veitch looked and sounded the part of the flustered and tongue-tied Countdown host, and his impersonation was excellent. Unfortunately, it soon became repetitive and

what would have been hilarious as a short

Fast Forward segment was drawn out through the musical.

The show is the brainchild of Brian

Mannix (former lead singer of the 80s band Uncanny X-Men) and while many of the songs make great listening, an edit to the length of the show would be beneficial.

A Countdown the Musical is at the Comedy Club, Carlton.

Kirsti Harmes (left) and Jamie Allen in Beatrice and Benedict.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: MRS. W. A. McDONALD, who has been on a visit to her sister, Mrs. E. Gillespie, Goulburn, returns to Sydney on Saturday morning. During her stay Mrs. McDonald has
articleText: MUSICAL. Mrs. W. A. McDONALD, who has been on a visit to her tister, Mrs. E. Gilleapie, Goul- born, returns to Sydney on Saturday morn- ing. During her stay Mrs. McDonald bhas afforded the residents several real musical treats, and it is matter for regret that her magnificent voice will not again be heard here for some time. Mrs. McDonald sings in Mait- land on Tuesday night next at a complimen- tary concert tendered to Miss Beatrice Grif- fiths, the talented pianiste, prior to her departure, in company with M. Kowalski, for Europe. Miss Gritliths is proceeding to Europe to pursue her musical studies, and the people of Maitland (her native town) who are justly proud ol her talents, are giving her a fitting send-off, and have invited Mrs. Mc- Donald and M. Kowalski to assist.

snippet: At the Ashfield E[?] which is being held this week, Miss The[?] Phillips, of Mittagong, won the gold medal for the piano solo open to all c[?] the test piece being
articleText:
Magical.

At the Aihfield Eisteddfod, which is being held this week, Miss Theresa Phillips, sf Mittagong, won the gold medal for the piano solo open to all comers, the teat piece being Aecher's ' Alice.' In the all comers piano solo (restricted) Miss Gladys Stokes, of Bowral, was second with 92 points, the win ing candidate obtaining 94. Both young ladies are pupils of Mr. 6. E. Vincent.

heading: Musical.
snippet: Mr. Louis Luscombe is touring in the provinces with a musical comedy company. Giuseppe Verdi, the veteran Italian composer, is reported by cable to be
articleText:
Musical.

Mr. Louis Lu«combo is touring in t&e provinces with a musical comedy company. Giuseppe Verdi, the veteran Italian cotn« poser, is roported 'by cablo to bo dying. Great regret will be felt In ruu3ical circles at thl3 news. Verdi, who was born In

1814, in tho Ductoy of Parma, produced his first Croat work iu 1839. 'II Rlgolotto,' '11 Trovatoro,' and 'La Travlata,' com posed between 1851 and 1853, were all ex ceedingly popular. Subsequently 'lio com pletely changed his stylo, taking tho world ?by storjn with his opera 'Aida,' produced at Suez in 1871 to commemorate tho open ing of tho Suez Canal. 'Otcllo' and 'Fal- staff,' produced in 1S89 and 1893 rcspcc: Uvuly, 'wcra.hJchly »pprccUte4.

Sir Michael Costa has the following re marks on sieging:— 'Tbo qualities with which a merely correct' Blriger ought to be endowed aro: A Just intonation,' a voice of good quality, a scrupulous precision in the tlmo prescribed by the music, an exact knowledge of all word sounds, and a sym mbtrlc and agreeable form of movement. An accomplished 'vocallnt, besides possess ing tho foregoing qualltlcu In a prepondera ting degree, ought to be ablo to lay claim to an original and olevatcd stylo of sing ing, joined to a natural vivacity of expres sion. Then comes tbo last. and greatest requisite — genius I' ' . Miss Maggie Stirling sang with marked success at a Matinee Muslcalo given on De cember 15 at Madame Marchesl's Ecolo

(Paris) in honor of M. Massenet, who was present, an air from that composer's .'Lo Cld.' M. Massenet was so pleased with tho singing that ho subsequently presented to the Australian vocalist his photograph, with hlrs signature attached and the word 'admiration' Inscribed on It. In November last MIsb Stirling sang at 'Normanhurat' nt a concert given by-Lody-Drassey, who expressed . her satisfaction at tho marked vocal Improvement with kindly emphasis. Mndamo Anna Stelnhaucr gave her second vocal recital last month at the Stelnway Hall, London, tho programmo being entire ly composed of compositions by hor hus band, Mr. Albert Malllnson, lato of Mel bourno, who has boon bailed -by tho entire London PresB as a sbng-wrlter of quite re markable talents. Madame' Stclnhauer was assisted by Miss Rcglna NageJ, of Mel bourno,' who was much applauded for her second set of songs. ? ? ? *?* Mr. Percy Grainger, the young Melbourne pianist nnd composer, who ha3 been study ing on the Continent for some years post, gave a recital at Frankfurt recently, when ho was most successful. Tho four loading journals wore unanimous In their praise of his ringing touch, perfect technique, and splendid musical gifts. Mr. Grainger, ac cording to the latest . 'British- Australa- sian.' will shortlv nnnear in London.

At the Queen's Hall (London) Ballad Concert on December 15 there were intro duced several new songs, among them ono of Interest, 'A Garden Song,' from the pen of Mr. Charles .Wlllbby,. who a few years aso was well known In Australia, and whose wife is a sister of Mr. Fergus Hume. It is a composition, says . an ex change, showing originality of conception and breadth of treatment, nnd on the occa sion in question was fortunato In having Miss Ada Crossley as the interpreter of its finely-colored and most -interesting melody.' . ? ? ? ? ? flclba In America. * Tho New York opera ' season, which Is always regarded as one ot the principal social events of tho year, opened ot the Metropolitan Opera_ House on December 18, amid scenes of unusual splendor. Snys an exchange, referring to tho event:— 'So- ciety was present In full force, and every soat in tho great auditorium was taken. The tiers of boxes were fillca with repre sentatives of wealth and fashion. The women, resplendent in superb costumes and dazzling Jewels, presented a magnificent sight. Present Indications aro that the season will be ono of the most successfn! on record. Mr. Maurice Grau has brought over an unusually strong company, intro ducing established favorites of former sea sons and several new candidates for local honors. Tho opera presented last night was Gounod's 'Romeo et Juliette,' . in which Mme. Melba and Messrs. Saleza, Edouard do Reszke. and Plancon filled the leading rolc3. It was splendidly rendered and en thusiastically received.'

heading: Musical.
snippet: Madame Saville had a unique and amusing experience at the State concert given at the Palace in Vienna recently, on the eve of the marriage of Duke Robert of
articleText:
Musical.

Madame Savillo had a unique. and amus ing experience at tho State concert given' at tho Palace in Vienna recently; on tho eve of the marriage of Duke Robert of Wurtcmburg. The Emperor Francis Joseph and two score Royal porsopngos were pre sent,- besides a brilliant corps of Ministers, dlnlomatists. and service men of high rank.'

Madame Savillo was singing a solo, when suddenly a mouse bolted across the stago. The little creature made straight for the shelter of tho priraa donna's skirts, and. with a skip and a squeal the singer took fresh ground. For a moment she was unable to continuo her song, but as the mouse was nowhere to be seen, she gathered up cou rage, and finished the solo in a voico that had considerably more of tho 'tremolo'' in it than critics appreciate. Just ' after Madame had made her obesiance and re tired tho mouso reappeared, and made a dash across the floor of the hall straight for the seats reserved for the diplomatic corps and their feminine belongings. For a moment the ladies struggled hard to pre vent fear overcoming the demands of eti quette, but panic prevailed, and with shrill cries the blue-blooded dames fled or hopped nimbly on chairs, much to the nmusement of the aged Emperor and his male entou rage. Onco more tbc mouse disappeared, but it was some tlmo before the scared ladles resumed (heir seats and recovered their normal composure.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: It is not, perhaps, generally known that at the conference of Australasian Universities held in Melbourne last April, the subject of music was specially
articleText:
MUSICAL.

It is not, perhaps, generally known that at the conferencc of Australasian Universities held in Melbourne last

April, the subject of music was specially dealt with, and an agreement arrived at providing for co-operation between the universities of Melbourne and Ade- laide, the only universities, so far, that have chairs of music, and that for the present Tasmania shall be regarded as within the sphere of Melbourne and Western Australia as within the sphere of Adelaide. The conference also de- cided that co-operation between all the universities of the Commonwealth and New Zealand was desirable on the gene- ral lines of the agreement between Mel- bourne and Adelaide. In furtherance of the resolutions of the conference, the Tasmanian University has added music to the list of optional subjects for the junior and senior public examinations, the details of the subject and the con- duct of the examinations in it being controlled by the University in Mel- bourne. The first of these examina- tions has just been concluded in Ho- bart, and the University took advan- tage of the presence in Hobart of the two examiners, Professor Peterson, Or- mond Piofossor of Music at the Uni- versity of Melbourne, and Mr. H A Thomson, a prominent member of the teaching staff, for an informal confer- ence for the further discussion of de- tails of the scheme The conference was presided over by Mr Thomas Stephens, M. A., and among the decisions arrived at were that in future the examina- tions, both practical and theoretical, will be hold at the University, and a concession which pater familias will ap- prove, that candidates who enter for the whole junior or senior public ex- amination, and take music as one of the subjects, will be entitled to a sub- stantial reduction in the entry fee; in fact, in regard to these examinations, music will be treated in every respect as it is in Victoria. This seems to be co-operation among the universities on very right lines, and should lead to yet further stops in the same direction.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: A NEW PIANOFORTE.—A useful invention is that of Mr. W. Percival, of Queens-wad, Bayswater, which reduces the pianoforte to portable dimensions, and enables the performer to play
articleText:
MUSICAL.

A NEW PIANOFORTE.-A useful invention is that of Mr. W. Percival, of Queens-wad, Bays water, which reduces the pianoforte to portable dimensions, and enables the performer to play it in the most easy and comfortable position. Instead of the keys being arranged in ahori*

zontal plane, they are placed vertically on each . side of the instrument, which is strong on both sides of the back, and some of the notes are

duplicated, so that forte effects can be readily * produced in the centre of the register.' Tho keys are exactly the same as in the ordinary instrument, tho lowest bass being placed at the bottom on the left hand, and the highest treble note at the bottom of the right -hand clavier. Four and a half octaves are placed on each side, und some of the top keys strike string® in. unison. The compass is seven octaves, as usual, bat about twenty of the upper keys give the same note, so that the instrument can bo played on either side, or on both at once.' The instrument is a novelty, because it is a piano* forte in a small compass, that can be drawn up to the fireside, and is admirably adapted for the singer who desires to face his audienco while playing the accompaniment to his song. Although so small, the tone is good, and tho fingering being the same as on the common form, it will probably find favour with students of the instrument, as well as with the general

public.

-Loudon Echo.

SruoUTiNQ NOVELIST*.-The issued invitation by the proprietors of tho Sydney Mail to Colonial authors and literary aspirants to compete for an award of £100 for tho best serial tale has met with numerous responses. The editor of that journal says, that although the time during which work will be received does not expire until the close of the year, already more than thirty manuscripts have been received, most of which are of considerable length, and.have a very business-like appearance. The labour of perusal has already been . commenced, but necessarily with such a mass of matter to get through will occupy a considerable time. A few of the competitors have omitted to comply with tho condition requiring a sealed envelope with name, &o., enclosed; title of story written exteriorly to be furnished; and it would bo well for them to re pair the omission while there is yet time. At the rato at which manuscripts continue to be received it appears not improbable that by the 1st of Jauuury there will have been forty separate works scut in. It is plain, therefore, that the amount of literary ambition which udequato reward for purely literary labour would evoke iu the Australian colonies is very considerable, and it is reasonable to suppose

among so many" aspirants some of distibot

merits must be discoverable.

-Sydney 3ttn>ing

Merata.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: THE CARANDINI COMPANY.—A most enjoyable concert was given by this company at the Town Hall on Mouday night, when Miss Marie Carandini took a beuefit. The selection, of
articleText:
MUSICAL.

THE CAIIAKDINI COMPANY.-A. moat enjoy able concert wis given by this company at the Town Hull on Mouday uight, when Miss Marie

Carandiui took a beuefit. The selection, of. music was a happy ono, and the several pieces were done full justice to by the perforators. Miss Car&cdini Bang " The song in the heather" eo faultlessly that it was loudly re demanded, the pinger responding with "-It was a dream," which was equally well sung. The . last roBe of summer" was rendered 'so' effec-' tively by Madame Carandini as also to produce 'an encore, when " Jessie the flower of Dum blane" was substituted. The concerted pieces and the pianoforte selections were as effective as usual. A special concert was given in the In stitute, Too wong, on "Wednesday. The chairs and front seats were all full, but as there were no back shilling seats that part of the building presented a bare appearance. The whole, of the well-selected programme was gone through^ and the audience were most appreciative. It is very difficult to point to particular excellencies when all were so good. The duet, " Twine the lily with the rose," was beautifully sung by. Madam and Miss Marie. Mit-a Carandini sang " Didst thou but know," a very pretty song by Balfe, in a most charming manner. Madam's rendering of "Little Nell" and "Home; sweet, home" was most artistic, and elicitcd great applause. Miss Melville's ."piano solos were well received. Tho unaccompanied quartet, 11 Un the banks of Allan "Water," was

deliriously sung, the voices blending in sweet- * est harmony. " She's fooling thoa " as usual was a great favourite, and had quite an instruc tive effect upon the young gentlemen present. This very pleasant concert terminated with the "Merry gipsies* chorus," which obtained an encore. The inhabitants of Toowong are.to be congratulated on having a hall large enough to induce a troupe like the Carandinis to visit the township. .All the arrangements were satisfactory and left nothing to be desired.

MUSICAL ENTEKTAINMKNT.-The concert in

the Temperance Hall onSaturday night, though' perhaps not quite so good as the last one, was nevertheless a decided success. Mr. J. Deigau sang with his usual verve,"Dublin Bay " and. the "Ship on fire," and in the duet,V'fWhat are the wild waves saying," he was very ably assisted by a young lady amateur, who * bias of

late attracted mnoh attention on account' of the

sweet quality of her voice and her sympathetic ' singing. Mr. M'Robbie gave in his usual'ex- . cellent style "The old sexton " and " The'

blacksmith," f#r bosh of which he received ' well.merited applause. " Blue-eyed violets" by

Miss M. Dignan was well rendered and' greatly admired by the audience. The "Swiss

toy girl," by Miss A. Diguan, was . also well ..'

received. Mias Lena Dignan was greatly, applauded for the manner in whioh she played several piano accompaniments. Amongst tho.

delicate morceauxoi the evening were " The * . village blacksmith," duet "Dog and. cat,"-* and "Where has Scotland found her fame,"'

the latter being most enthusiastically, encored* \ Two musical trios, English concerting and a! flute, were also features of the evening.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The Orpheus Society's concert, given in the Town Hall on Friday evening last, was one of an exceptionally attractive character. One element contributing to this
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The Orplieus Society's concert, given in the Town Hall on Friday evening last, was one of an exceptionally attractive charac ter. One element contributing to this re sult was its variety.- -A. cantata, The Lay of the Poppies, by Tinel, a modern Dutch composer, showed 'picturesque or-

chestration, and a fairly satisfactory ren dering was given by orchestra and choir. These combinations appeared to even bet ter! advantage in the devotional selection. The feature of the concert, however, was the reappearance of Mr. Andrew Black, whose fine voice and skilful execution were made manifest in a number of selections, including the Pagliacci prologue, Anthea, It was a Dream, and Q Ruddier than the Cherry. Other songs and encores were also delightfully given. Miss Yetta Davis and Master Aniadeo, a promising young flautist, contributed some items, and Mr. Harold Elvins as accompanist and Mr. Fred Clutsam as conductor, did good ser vice. The final organ recital by Mr. Edwin Lemare was given on .Saturday at the Mel bourne Town Hall, and attracted a large and appreciative audience. The original series and its extensions have undoubtedly helped to enhance musical taste and to strengthen the favor with which organ music is regarded. The fine, instrument to which Mr. Lcniare has now certified ought to become a standard attraction under the manipulation of the new city or ganist, Dr. Price. _ . Mademoiselle Dolores has just finished giving a series of concerts in Adelaide with great success, and during the -week she has appealed before large audiences in Balla- rat and Geelong. She will. give two final recitals in -the Melbourne Town Hall on Thursday evening and Saturday afternoon. As these will be positively the last appear ances of the great soprano in this city dur ing her present tour, she is bound to at tract large audiences. At the conclusion of the Melbourne season Mademoiselle Do lores returns to Sydney and Brisbane, and probably Tasmania. Then follows a tour embracing the whole of New Zealand, at the conclusion of which Mademoiselle Do lores expects to return direct to Europe, in order to sing in Berlin during the early part of the season next year. In 1903 Mademoiselle Dolores will make a tour of Almerica, so it will probably be anany years ere Australian audiences have a further op portunity of listening to .this distinguished artist. . On Shis return : to Copenhagen, after giv ing a series of successful orchestral and chamber concerts in London, Dr. Edward Grieg, the famous Norwegian composer, was interviewed -by - the-— Yortland," and, in the course of his remarks, referred par ticularly to Mr. Percy Grainger,- 'the young Australian pianist. Br; Griegvsaid: — "He is- a young man of genius, possessing a real artist's soul." He paid a very high tri bute" to Mr, 'Grainger for the manner in which he interpreted -his Slatter. He also spoke eulogistically of Mr. Grainger's com positions. More than one distinguished composer has 9poken highly of the Austra lian pianist's genius for composition. Ac cording to !the latest advices from England, Mr. Grainger has been hunting up Folk Songs in North Lincolnshire, and it is his intention to utilise them for the piano. The pianist anade a very successful tour recent ly in Denmark, giving.. recitals in. Copen hagen and other important cities. His London engagements during the past season were of a numerous' nature, aud at his re cital in November, at the Bechstein Hall, he is giving am interesting programme of classical and modern compositions. Bach,

Scarlatti and Beethoven, Brahms, Grieg and Claude Debussy, Cyril Scott and Balla- karew and an arrangement of Stanford's Irish Dances by himself, are the composers represented. Miss Florence Menkmeyer will be heard in both vocal and instrumental items at her concert in the Athenmum Hall on the 6th October. For some time past Miss Menkmeyer has turned lier attention to composition, and several of her works will be beard at her concert for the first time. Miss- Maud Powell, one of the most famous of female violinists, will tour Aus tralia next year, opening in Sydney in May. She has had the honor of playing for his Majesty the King, the Czar of Russia and lesser royalties. She has toured through Great Britain, France, Germany, Russia, Poland, Denmark, Austria, Bohemia, Hol land, Belgium, South Afica and America, and in each country she -has been unanimously pronounced by press and pub lic "the greatest woman violinist of the day." A combination known as the Australian Glee Maidens will commence a short season at the Athemeum "Hall on Monday, 8th October. 'They will be conducted by the organiser, |Mr. Wm. Llewellyn, who will be supported -by a company of leading artists, including Madame Janson, Miss Lizzie Jordan, Mr. Avalon Collurd, Miss Maud Ilarringtou, Mr. Gerald Mussey and others.

The programme, she informed me, was a charming one indeed, From the splendid Wagner overture (which DotbiDg could exceed) To the lovely little scheme and the miuuet for strings And the latest bit of Dvorak, which made

ner sign 101' wings. JThroughout the Grieg concerto her emotion was intense ; It seemed to me at times she held her breath in deep suspense ; She raved of crptrs this and that, of Schubert, Bach aind Lfe't ; BeeciWv'dn, BrttTftrite, Tschaillowski, and a score wh'o'se names I missed. But when at last 'twas over and I led her down the stair I noticed that beneath her breath she hummed a little air, It was not upon the programme, being r>ninnvinn1.iPP. nnrl f.iiir»v

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Music has since our last Summary been in the ascendant in the North. Launceston has received an acquisition in the person of Mr H. J. King, late organist tot the Melbourne Cathedral, who
articleText: MUSICAL. Music has since our last Summary been in the ascendant in the North. Launceston has received an acquisition in the person of Mr H. J.King, late organist to the Melbourne Cathedral, who: has visited the town, and is so taken up with the place and the people that he is inclined to settle here. Mr King has been appointed organist to Trinity Church. He has also given "a taste of his quality" at several entertainments that have been given since his arrival here. Advantage was taken of Mr King's presence to have a popular concert in aid of the funds of the Mechanics' Institute, on the 26th May. Miss Amy Sherwin was the only lady vocalist, but there were two male debutantes, Mr S. R. Ken nedy and Mr J F. Moles, who were very suc cessful. Mr King played some selections on the organ. Rev. Mr Law, President of the Insti- tute notified that two or three further concerts had been arranged for. A very interesting "Children's Concert" was given at the Institute on the 30th May by the scholars, assisted by the teachers, of the Bris bane-street Sunday School; being in aid of the Organ Fund of the school. Mr H. J.King gave a pianoforte and two organ solos, which were greatly admired. The concert proved so highly successful that it has been determined to give a second at the same place and for the same ob. ject on Tuesday next. On the 6th instant Mendelssohn's oratorio of "Elijah" was performed at the Mechanics' In stitute in connection with the Musical Union. Mr Wallace conducted, Mr King was leader, and Miss Hart accompanied: Our favorite ama teurs, male and female, took part; and the per formance was a grand success. `There was a crowded house. A new Choral. Seciety has been .recently formed' at Longford, with ,Mr F.' Ferguson as honorary 'conductor. TeThe first cnicert came off on the 8th, and, proved 'a most attractive' affair.: The programme was well arranged, and the various items were sustained with great ability. It is matter of astonishment 'what good can be done in such a place as Longford by the activity and exertions of such men as Mr F.t. erguson, and those who are- cooperating with him.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: On Thursday night the Town Hall was crowded to hear a performance—the third given in this city—of Gounod's sacred masterpiece.
articleText:
MUSICAL.

On Thursday night the Town Hall was crowded to hear a perform- ance—the third given in this city — of Goumod's sacred masterpiece.

"The Redemption". Among those present were His Excellency the Governor, with Lady Tennyson and suite; the Gover- nor of New South Wales, Earl Beauchamp; the Mayor of Adelaide, and a large number of the most prominent local musicians and music lovers. The whole performance was conducted by Mr. C. J. Stevens, who was warmly congratulated on a most successful rendering of a difficult and exacting work, and the hearty rounds of applause he re- ceived from the audience and the chorus at its conclusion were well earned.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Mr. Percy Grainger's accompaniments to five Lincolnshire folk-songs, rendered by Mr. Gervase Elwes at the Aeolian Hall on, Wednesday, were original arrangements
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Mr. Percy Grainger 's accompaniments to five Lincolnshire folk-songs, rendered by Mr. Gervase Elwes at the Aeolian Hall on Wednesday, were original arrangements

composed oy tne Australian- pianist; and formed an interesting feature of the pro gramme. _ They had been taken down in the first instance with literal accuracy by means of the phonograph, from the coun try folk, who sing these quaint old tunes as they so.about their daily work; but Mr. Grainger had of course added to their har mony, if not perhaps to their local charac ter, by his well-thought-out accompani ments. The Morning Post has a most,fa vourable reference to his other performr ances on the same occasion, remarking that 'he has rapidly acquired a well-deserved re putation as a pianist of exceptional talent, and' plays in a most interesting manner.' His performance of Beethoven's 'Sonata in D minor' was especially- excellent, and he was also applauded in his characteristic rendering of two quaint pieces by Cyril Scott— 'Sphinx' and 'Arabian dance.' The youns pianist has made a large number of engagements for the musical season just setting in. On November 18 he is to play with the London Symphony Orchestra at the Queen's Hall; on the 22nd at the Lon don Broadwood Concert, and on the 28th he wall give a recital in Edinburgh, while he has many other dates booked. Madame ilelba has settled £1.500. a year on her son, Mr. George Armstrong, in an ticipation of his. marriage on December 18 next to pretty Miss Ruby Otway, who has herself a handsome dowry.' The ceremony, which will take place at St. George's. Han over square, is likely, . according to the ar rangements .already made, to be as smart as any of the fashionable weddings cele brated at this most fashionable of churches. The eight bridesmaids will be gowned in white panne, with prey hats, and will have bouquets of roses, and the best man is selected in the person of. Mr. Jack Arm strong, who is a cousin. of, the bridegroom. Melba's son will probably stand for Par liament when a fitting opportunity presents itself. He will, presumably, be one of the youngest aspirants for Parliamentary honours, as at present he is only 21, just two years older than his intended bride, and it is not perhaps altogether surprising that the youth of the pair for a iong while made the bride's mother anxious to postpone the match for a year or so. Aliss Emily Soldene has not lost her one time hold on the affections of the theatre going public, though 30 years have passed

since she first sang ine music oi uiuwu the pastrycook in 'Genevieve de Brabant, which this week she repeated for the last time at her farewell matinee. The former o,ueen of opera. bouffe is now a lady of 60, but she proved not too old to suggest charm as well as pathos by her courageous playing of the part in the original costume of white kneebreeches and coat, with a jaunty flaxen wig. surmounted by a little white cap;- and no less charm was evident in her rendering of the balcony duct. In this connection one cannot do better than quote the sympathetic account by The Morning Post:— 'Miss Soldene entered m t:er white baker's, dress, and having spo ken a few words, imperfectly heard, sang. To say that her voice is all it ever was would be ridiculous, but the method, - the feeling, the intelligence were there, and the voice, admirably supported bv the or chestra, which played no louder than a dis tant sea, was strong enough and sweet enough to give delifzht all over the house. The casement opened, and Miss Violet Ludlow as the Countess responded in kind. The duet finished, the Countess retired to her room, and Drogan stood bowing. There had been great applause on Miss Soldene's entrance; now there was greater. At last the curtain fell, only to rise again after shouts of 'Encore.' It was hardly expected that Miss Soldene. who had hus banded her voice most carefully, would s any more. Yet she sang the whole sonir through a^ain, and perhaps even bet ter than before. That Miss Soldene does not like to say goodby to the public came out again later when Mr. Tree presented . her. still dressed as Drogan, with a cheque for ,C6o3, and in the conrse of a speech informed her and the audience that there would be CloO more to come. Strangely enough. Air. Tree ended his speech without giving Miss Soldene.the cheque, and it was not till she. in making a few remarks, fragmentary and indistinct from emotion, sjwke of having had a 'chequered ' life.' with arch emphasis on the 'chequered.' that Mr. Tree handed her the cheque, which she thrust into her bosom. She was, she said, 'ii back num ber, but not forgotten;' and in broken tones expressed her gratitude to all. The curtain fell as she stood steadying herself with a gilded chair. It did not rise again on. her, but the applause continuing she came before it. and cheerfully remarked that it was nice to appear again, if only for a moment. She then withdrew, and fee programme was proceeded with.'' Signor Zenatello on Saturday night last, when playing the hero in' 'Fedora' at Covenfc Garden, met with an amusing lit tle mishap which might have introduced a damaging element of bathos into the pathetic garden scene had not the famons singer saved the situation by taking it in a most unconcerned manner. He was woo ing Fedora in melting song in the garden, when, retreating a few stops backwards, he unfortunately fell into a rocking chair, which turned completely over. Signor Zena tello broke off his song to perform a somersault, and from the gallery arose a ', single laugh. Tt was the only one, for i the singer picked himself up promptly and went on with his musical courtshin as though the rocking chair act were part of the business.

snippet: Sir Edward Elgar is among the celebrated people who are on the sick list just now. He is apparently suffering chiefly from overwork in connection with his
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Sir Edward Elgar is among the celebrat ed people who are on the sick list just now. He is apparently suffering chiefly irom overwork in connection with his

musical labours, and has been ordered by his medical attendant to take a complete rest. He will therefore not be able to con tinue his lectures at Birmingham Uni versity during the current term. Miss. Amy Simpson, an Australian soprano, till this week was a stranger to .London audience?, but. she scored a decided sncc€?? »* her recent recital at the Stein war HalL, The critics especially noted her rich tone of voice, a merit in which German and Italian sing ers are often deficient, and which, is said to be characteristic of Aus tralian vocalists. ? It seems too' early to decide m which special department Miss fcnnpson is to make her reputation, as her programme on Wednesday ranged from cantata selections to operatic airs

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Rosamund Harriott Watson is responsible for the words to a new song called "A song of London." for which Cyril Scott has written the music. The picutesque
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Rosamund Marriott Watson is responsi- ble for the words to a new song called "A song of London'' for which Cyril Scott has written the music. The picturesque beauties of London have been left for our

subtler artists in pen .and pencil to de- scribe adequately, but there is little doubt that the grey old metropolis has a charm of its own which the true Londoner would not change. This view the fair librettist has emphasized in the song in question, of which the following verse may serve as a fair specimen:— 0 fair shines the gold moon On blossom clustered eaves But bright blinks the gaslamp Beneath the linden leaves. And the green country meadows Are fresh and fine to see, But the grey streets of London Are all the world to me. Mr. Edward German has fitted some excellent music to the comic opera based on Fielding's celebrated "Tom Jones," now being plaved at the Apollo Theatre. The idea of thus dramatizing the famous old novel, coupled with the capable acting that is given at the Apollo Theatre, should suf- fice to complete Mr. German's success. Tuneful, though hardly catchy, the music may not become popular with the average street musician, but it is delightfully in keeping with the old-world style of "Tom Jones." and has the merits of being well phrased. The orchestration is well ar- ranged.

articleText:

Mr C. A. Jarman (Mus. Doc., L. Mus. Doc., L. Mus., Lond.), the newly appointed organist of All Saints' Church, announces that he is prepared to receive pupils for

piano, singing, organ, and composition. Dr. Jarman has been a remarkably successful teacher, many of his pupils now occupying important positions in the musical profession in all parts of the State. Not less than 13 of Dr. Jarman's pujpils were successful last month in Goulburn in obtaining suc cess in the Associate, Licentiate, and Teacher's diploma exams as well as a number in lower grades.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The following, from the Cambridge (U.S.) Chronicle, of November 6, will be of interest to our readers:—The parishioners of St. Paul's Church will hear their
articleText: MUSICAL. The following, from the Cambridge (U.S.) Chronicle, of November 6, will bc of interest to our readers:- The parish ioners of St. Paul's Church will hear their new organist, Prof. George G. McConnell, of Syracuse, N.Y., for the first time at the services to-morrow. He comes to take the place of Prof. Bartschmid, who was select ed by thie archbishop out of all the organ ists of the- archdiocese to direct the sanc tuary choir at the Cathediral, Boston. Prof. McConnell was chosen out of a dozen appli cants for the position left vacant by the advancement of Prof. Bartschmid. Prof.   McConnell brings with him the highest re commendations as a musician. For the past five years he has been choir director and organist in St. Lucy's Church, Syracuse, which is one of the largest parishes in that city. Professor McConnell was born in Goulburn, N.S.W., Australia, and was educa ted at Holy Cross College, Sydney. He completed his musical education under the late Auguste Wiegand, on ,whose rccommen dation he was appointed organist of Ss. Peter and Paul's Cathedral, N.S.W., at the age of 19, which position he filled most sat isfactorily for ten years, when he left on twelve months' leave of absence to accept a similar position at St. Lucy's, Syracuse, N.Y. On thIe eve of his departure from his native land, at a mass meeting of citizens in the town hail, hIe was presented by the MIayor \:ith an illuminated addtress ind " purse of sovereigns. Professor McConnell has had many pupils for organ insttuction, and one of them succeeds him at St. Lucy's. -He is also an accomplished violinist, and one of his first efforts in St. Paul's Church will be. to form an orchestra from the young men of thIe parish, having the promise of the hearty support of Fatlher Ryan. The city of Camlrrdge will be the gainer 1by having Professor McConnell as a citizen, and musical circles will welcome his coming.

Replying to Mr. Wade, Mr. Griffith states that on every one of the 14 uncompleted railways passengers and produce are being carried as far as the rails are laid, and that this could not have been done under the contract system. To make up to postmasters for the loss of electoral remuneration only 5 per cent. of their salaries will be deducted for house rent instead of 10 per cent. as hitherto. Regarding an arrest at Middle Park, Mel bourne, in connection with the Eveloigh rob bery, detectives recovered £300 in £5 banknotes. They were discovered in a jam preserving jar after a fire-jlace had been dlismantled. After Ilyan's arrest on Wednesday an exhaustivo search of the house was begun. Further arrests are expected in Melbourne and in Sydney. The detectives are practically certain that the whole of the money is hidden somewhere in Melbourne. Melbourne, Thursday.-A glowing tribute to the universal training system is paid by the Governor of Queensland in a letter to the Com nmandant of the northern State (Colonel G. I. Lee), expressing his appreciation of the manner in which the exercises were carried out on the occasion of the recent senior cadet competitiones at Brisbane. - The 5edeorated Enceinedrivers and Firemen's Association of Australasia and the Federated Carters and Drivers are to consider Mr. Hughes' conference proposal to hlave one big union. Martial lanw has been proclaimed throughlout Bosnia and Herzegovina. Bombs lave bcen found in the trees along ieth route followed by tie Archduke on the day of the assassination. It has transpired that a secret committee pro vided Cabrinovic and Prinzip with bombs and pistols. General Hertzog made a speech at Southfield at the inauguration of the new National pal ty in South Africa. He strongly condemned tie Imperial views of the Prime Minister, General Botha. Vancouver, Junoe 30.-Jack Kong, a Chinese youth, has benu sentenced to imprisonment for the term of his natural life for murdering Mrs. Charles Millard in April, and afterwards ercca ting the bodly in a furnace. An ordinary son tenco of life imprisonment would bring Kong out in 20 years, but a "natural life" sentence means that he will never be released from the penitentiary. The whole of the ferry cervices on tihe Swan River at Perth are to be national.ed. There are ?33,2221 trade unioniots in Australia, the number in New South Wales being 192.620. The death is announced of the Earl of Wecmyss, at tle advanced ago of 06 years. Mr. Stanley Poreteel iatt, autlor, died o0 Tuesday aged 317 years. c Despite the continued expression of hope that the plans of the mediators for theo settlement of the Mexican situation will not fail, consilderablei apprehension is shown in o-cial quarters. Sir E. Groey, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, says that President Wilson took action on his own initiative, with regard to urging the repeal of the exemption clause in the Panama Canal toll regulations.

Mr. John Lemmone was asked by a 'Sun- day Times' representative If the accusa- tion's which had been made against Madame Melba of want of interest towards Austra- lians at home had any foundation. 'Not the slightest,' he replied. 'My experience, as well as that of several others, shows that she is exceedingly kind, and anything that lays in her power within reason she will do. Of course a woman in her posi- tion is so flooded with requests from all kinds — good, bad, and indifferent — that it is impossible to help everybody. Another thing, it is not to be expected that a wo- man who is worked to death while in Lon- don, as she is, could have time to devote to all who wish to call on her.' articleText:
MUSICAL

Mr. Daniel Mayor has been appointed manager for the Australian tour of M. Padorewski, a brilliant pianist, who

made his debut in London in the 1890 season. The season will commence in July, 1892.

(A musical authority, speaking of this brilliant performer, says :-"The most bril- liant of the absolutely new comers was M. Paderewski, a pianist whose power and facility were calculated to surprise even

those whose experience of the modern school have created the belief that they were never likely to be again really astonished."]

snippet: Lovers of the better opera music will welcome the announcement that arrangements have been made to produce a series of opera pops at Messrs.
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Lovers of the better opera music will welcome the announcement that arrangements have been made to pro duce a series of opera pops at Messrs. J. and N. Tait's new hall— the Audi torium. Arrangements have been made to instal an orchestra. The first performance of the series will be given on Saturdav, July 5. Bosses-o'-th'-Barn Band is making arrangements for another foreign tour, and it is said that their itinerary

this time will include the l'aciic Coast. At one time before (1906) thp hand had aspirations to visit the ' slope,' but the 'Frisco earthquake made them say ''Pass I' They hope to sail in September. It was some time ago that, acting upon the recommendations embodied in a report by a military commission, tho French Government reached the conclusion that the drum was no longer a necessary article of military equipment. The report set forth that the drum was a serious en cumbrance in marching; that rain impaired its usefulness; that its calls could not b» distinguished in time o!

two years to turn out an efficient drummer; and that by abandoning the use of tho drum many thousands of youths and men would ho released for active service. Since the decision of the French Government other Euro pean Powers have followed its example in decreeing that the 'drum must a.0.' The history of the drum is both ancient and honourable. The Egyp tians employed it, and the Greeks as cribed its invention to Bacchus. _ The Spanish conqueror Pizarro is said to have found drums in South American temples. The snakes of Ireland, we are told, fled from the Emerald Isle before the drum-beats of St. Patrick. The Puritans of New England used the drum as a church hell, and it fig

ured frequently and romantically all through the wars of the Revolution and Rebellion in America.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: MISCELLANEOUS ENTERTAINMENT.—An entertainment consisting of songs, recitations, and addresses, was given in the United Methodist Church, Ann-street, on Wednesdaynight, under
articleText:
MUSICAL.

MISCELLANEOUS ENTBHTAIKMENT.-An enter tainment consisting of songs, recitations, and addresses, was given in the TJnitfed Methodist Church, Ann-street, on Wednesdaynight, under the auspices of the TJnited Lodge, No. S3. The Bev. E. Turner, occupied the chair, and the meeting , was addressed by Bros. AI'Lean, AI.L.A., and C. AUwood, whose remarks were received with enthusiasm. The building was crowded, and the musical portions of the pro gramme were warmly applauded. "We under stand that this is the first of a series of concerts which the lodge propose to hold. One or two hitches, of an unimportant character, which a little extra practice might have prevented, occurred in the carrying out of the programme.

PiukA DONNE.-The celebrated impresario Luigi Biccaboni, who, in 1716, went to Paris at the direct invitation of the Regent, paid his first stars, the Flaminia, Sylvia, and Violetta, twenty sous per diem each. Of course they participated in the receipts besides, and as the first representation, which took place on May IS, 1716, resulted in a yield of 4,06S livres, they certainly obtained a tolerably good income. Napoleon I., who, personally, wa« not very fond of music, was, nevertheless ex ceedingly liberal to singers. Cattalini sang twice before him at St. Cloud. He sent her 5,000 francs for the^o performances, conferred upon her a pension for life of 12,000 francs per ituuuw, and placed the Opera Houso ut her disposal for two concerts, the net profits of which were 50,000 francs. The diva was not, however, quito satisfied with this. After Napoleon had heard her in Sfc. Cloud, ho called upon her in her dressing room, and ashed, " Where are you going to, Madam r" " To London, sire." u Kemaiu in Paris, and you shall have 100,000 francs, and two months' leavo of absence." The lady bowed quietly and-went to London, where she had engagements. She was there engaged for tha season at 250,000 francs, and her leave of ab scnce gave hor as much, and she was paid 5,000 francs to sing " God Sava; the King" at soirtcs. Bias;?, a relatively obsciirepiiuiadonna, was engaged at the Parisian Opera in, 1827,

with an aunual salary of 36,000 franca for life, \

. She died young. Gloslop had a similar con

tract "with the Paris Opera, viz., 25,000 francs per annum. During a period of three years she only sang once, and thus, one evening, earned 75,000 francs, perhaps the highest sum which a single performance erer yielded to a singer. The largest receipt that Itldlie. Son tag ever took was in London, where, on the occasion of her benefit, £2,000 was handed over to her. In Paris she received 36,000 francs for the season, and a benefit night. Malibran had, in Pari*, a salary of 75,000 francs, a benefit night, and a leave of absence, during which she earned as much as her salary amounted to. In 1823 she was engaged at Drury Lane for forty representations, for which she received £3,200 and two benefits, with a'guaranteed re ceipt of £2,400, or altogether £5,600 for ten weeks. Shortly before her death she signed an agreement for 600,000 francs, which is more than Patti ever received.

heading: MUSICAL
snippet: Melbourne is always prepared to be enthusiastic over a great singer. We welcome them cordially in anticipation, and are generous in applause when their abilities
articleText:
fvlUSlGAL

(Melbourne is always prepared to be en thusiastic over a great singer. We welcome them cordially in anticipation, and are generous in applause when their abilities are made evident. But with Mdlle. Dolores

there is something more than this; a note of personal friendship is introduced into our appreciation. The woman as well as the artist is taken into our hearts. Beyond the admirable quality of her voice and her singing she possesses a special charm of manner which bring9 her at once into mag netic sympathy with the audience. - From the artistic standpoint alone she ia worthy of all praise; but the combination is wholly- irresistible. With every visit her popu larity becomes more strongly established.- Tbe Town Hall at the opening concert of the present series. was filled to overflowing, and her' appearance on the platform was the signal for demonstrative recognition. Mdlle. Dolores quickly proved that She had lost nothing of 'her former attractiveness. Since she left us she has won fame in the art centres of the world; but she needed jio hall 'mark . of the kind to secure our suffrages. An- artist she left us four years ago, ami the- same high level is maintained with conspicuous ease. There is no straining after effect, no forcing of the voice, and -no exaggeration of emphasis. Her aim is to truly interpret the meaning of the composer and to. reproduce the beau ties of the music. She accomplishes this purpose with grace and delicacy, and the highest compliment that can be paid to her art is the absence of any impression of difficulty. The programme on -Saturday night was selected with nice -discretion. "The open ing number was the aria from Gluck's Al- ceste, wherein is embodied the appeal of sacrifice. The charm, of melody and feeling was eloquently expressed, and established the truth that against bhe immortality of art time's effacing finger is powerless. Old time melody was again exhibited in the bracket of lyrical effusions which included Lucca's Non posso disperare,' - Pureell's I Attempt from Love's Sickness to Fly, one of the most beautiful of love madrigals;, Sebastian Bach's Willst du deih Herz mer Scherken, and a song minuet by ah anony mous author . of the eighteenth century. All of these were admirably given, ' espe cially Pureell's amatory poem, .and the last number, of -which an encore was rapturous ly demanded. In response to further de mands M-dlle. Dolores sang Rubinstein's Dewdrop. Other numbers contributed 'were Schumann's Mondaclit and Friihlingsnacht and a theme and variations by Moreau. The brilliancy of vocalisation displayed by the artist in this piece electrified the" audience, who would not he satisfied until after re peated recalls she sang two encores, Kjer- ulf's Oh, to Remember, and a serenade by Massenet. The final bracket comprised Kjerulf's Afar in the Wood, Lisa Leh- mann's Within a Rose, of which a repeti tion .was required, and two songs by Goring Thomas. Even then the audience were un willing to be gone, and Mdlle. Dolores re sponded to the evident desire by singing Away, Away, bjr Lee, an admirable nld bal lad; and Home, Sweet Home. - Mr. Franz Wells showed excellent capacity 'as accom panist, . and his solo contributions, which included illustrations from Schubert, and Chcupin, were marked by artistic refinement and skill. The second of the Dolores concerts was not less marked by an exuberance of en thusiasm. The accomplished singer de lighted her audience by the purity of her voice and her excellence in vocalisation. Beyond the gifts of nature and the skilful accompaniment of art, there is the delight ful association of feeling and intelligence i#i her rendering of the songs. In the Shadow Song, from Dinorah, Mdlle. Dolores proved that. she is supreme in all the requirements of brilliancy; but the special charm of her singing was manifested in numbers like Wilson's Take, Oh Take Those Lips Away, The Lass of Richmond Ilill and others where sympathetic treatment is an all im portant consideration. Among the finest items "in the programme were Schubert's

Du bist die Rul, a romance by Tseliai- kowslcy and Massenet's Elegie. In her gene rous acknowledgment of encores, Mdlle. Dolores pleased her hearers by some popu-. lar favorites, as Gomin' Thro' the Rye and

Love Was Once a Little Boy. Mr. Franz Wells filled very effectively the dual parts of solo executant and accompanist. The third concert was on Thursday-night, and it has been resolved to add to the season besides the Saturday engagement another concert next week. , . Acts from grand opera will, form the chief attraction at the farewell matinee to be tendered Mr. Hal Cohen at the Prin cess's Theatre on Saturday, 45th September. They will be rendered by the Melbourne Cbhservatorium, on similar line3 to one of their annual operatic performances. The gems of the last four years' programmes have been chosen, and they will include acts from Carmen, La Boherae, Otello and The Merry Wives of Windsor, with cos tume, Bcenery nnd full orchestra, conducted by Professor Marshall-Hall. Other interest ing items will be rendered by Madame Elise Wicdermann, Mrs. Charles Heath, M. Napoleon Bollard, Mr. Harold Elvins and several principals of the Royal Comic Opera Company (through the courtesy of Mr. J. C. Williamson). The box plan will open at Allan's on Monday, 10th (Septem ber, at 9 o'clock. Madame Blanche Arral, the French so prano, will open her Sydney operatic re citals with orchestra at the Town Ilall .on Friday, 14th September.

snippet: Professor Davies, of the Adelaide Conservatorium, was in Bunbury yesterday conducting music evaminations for the Australian
articleText:

Professor Davies, of the Adelaide Conservatorium, was in Bunbury | yesterday conducting music evam- 1 inations for the Australian univer- ; sities. Eleven children sat for the

examinations in Bunbury, and . all j passed. j In the evening, Professor Davies gave a most interesting lecture on music in the Council Chambers. : Lovers of music in Bunbury have had the opportunity of hearing two ' professors lecture lately. Mr- Gos- : telow the Trinity College examiner, t spoke a few weeks ago, and Profes- sor Davies' remarks might almost have been a "follow on" lecture- Mr | GoBtelow spoke from the technical, j and perhaps oue might almost call ; it, the material plane and musical education. Professor .Davies was . more on -the aesthetic and spiritual ( side, which can only be developed j through the former.

i | After the lecture, Mr. and Mrs. i Duce entertained the distinguished ! visitor and one or two musical | friends, until time for the late train i when Professor Davies left for Perth i.en route for Kalgoorlie where he will be examining for two and a half days.

heading: MUSICAL
snippet: AUSTRALIA’S biggest spy saga, — the Petrov Affair forms the basis of a new musical which will premiere at the Victorian Arts Centre on Wednesday January 29.
articleText:
j'J JJ3J GAL

AUSTRALIA’S biggest spy saga, — the

Petrov Affair forms the basis of a new musical which will premiere at the Victorian Arts Centre on Wednesday January 29.

Eva Petrov, the reluctant defector, will be played by Helen Noonan. Brad Daley will play Vladimir Petrov. The role of Bialogusky will be taken by Grant Smith, while Rhonda Burchmore will play the mysterious Nina. Other cast members include Bruce Kerr, Peter Adams, Kirk Alexander, Terry Gill (as Evatt), Terry McDermott, Deidre Rubenstein, Peter Blizzard and Ernie Bourne.

In the 1950s, Australia was rocked by the Petrov spy scandal. The defection of Vladimir Petrov, Third Secretary at the Soviet Embassy and the last minute rescue of his wife, Eva, at Darwin Airport as she was being forcibly returned to the USSR, made

world headlines.

It led to an historic confrontation between the Prime Minister of the day, Robert Menzies and Opposition Leader Dr H.V. Evatt and allegations of conspiracy and manipulation.

Tbe drama forms the basic of the musical

Petrov by composer Michael Easton and scriptwriter Alan Hopgood.

snippet: Madam Bellmont, who recently decided to dispense with her Melbourne connection and take up her residence in Horsham, has had her Bechstein
articleText: MUSICkL. Madam Billmont, who recently deci ded to dispense with her Melbourne connection and take up her residence in Horshaim, has had her Bechitein concert grand'piano delivered. at her studio in the Temperance Hall, and her pupils are to have the benefit of tuition. upon the magnificent instru ment. The piano, which was bought oy Madam .Bellmont about n year ago, is one of the best ever .landed in t'ictoria; and contrasts markedly with bmy of the upright pianos in Horsham. It is the intention of the owner to give recitals at the Temperance hall, 'hen, doubtless, she will introduce some of the best work of the. great masters, as it can 'only be produced on the horizontal instrument. It is her intention, also, to call the niusi cal folk together it. an early date with the object of raising a fund for the purchase of a first-class concert piano for the Town Hall.

articleText:
MUBICAT,.

Tue Vernon-Prince Musical Comedy Company said adien to us on MoDday night when ' Have you seen tJimson ' wes presented. The piece is one in which much drollery is introduced, and is on the lioes of ' The Gay Parisian.' The plot, if such it can be called, is, as

nents me surronnoings, oi i ne nimsiest. Bat if ' Simon ' is not 18 cant in situa tion, we have something to be thankful for iu musical comedy, for the dialogue I Is beyond the ordinary. Mr Victor Prince (who, by the way. is tbe libretteat) bore off tho honors of the production, but it Is regretfully added that there were no calls for 'author.' Mr Howard Vernon, Mr Valentine, and the Misses Brooke and Gray also put in admirable work, and the incidental songs were capitally rendered. The following were the most notable (— ' Sunshine on the hill,' by Mise Gray ; ' My little diary,' by Mr Prince, the vocalist having per force to submit to an encore, for whioh he gave ' Matrimonial bliss ' ; ' Butter

fly shooters,' by Mr Valentine ; comic duet, ' A kiss my boys,' by Mibb Brooke and Mr Vernoa ; ' Left to tbe court ' and ' Oock-a-doodle-do,' by the Com Sanv; ' Britannia's bundle of keys,' by [r Veroon, who sang with great spirit; ' First and third class,' by M!sb Brooke and Mr Prince; 'Sister Mary Jane's top note,' by Miss Vance ; ' One heart divine,' ' by Miss Gray. It miy be added that Mr Frankhard's pianoforte playing was much appreciated, and won frequent applause, and this young gentleman wnen his interpretation of music equals his mechanical skill of nArfnrmnnfta And A hrtmth nf tfymnnnUnn

comej with axe, will undoubtedly be heard of in a place much more exalted in his profession. The company, which left for a Nor' -Western trip, made many friends on Lyell during a short season.

snippet: On Sunday afternoon last at the Footscray Presbyterian Young Men's Class meeting an instructive and interesting paper was given by Mr Alf.
articleText: MUSiC'AL. On Sunday afternoon last at the Footscray Presbyterian Young Men's Class meeting an instructive and inte resting paper was given by Mr Alf. Bishop, the subject being The Life and Works of Charles Gounod, one of the greatest of modern composers. The essayist dealt with'the great composer's life from every standpoint, and his ef forts were greatly appreciated by a large audience. The works of the com poser were illustrated in a very effect ive manner by the following ladies and gentlemen, who admirably displayed the beauties of the various compositions in solo, duet and quartette numbers:- Miss Hunt. "Ave Marie,", violin obli gato Mr Weisheit; Mr James, "Lend mneyour Aid": Miss Gullock. "There is a Green Hill"; Mr Appleton, "Thy Loving Smile o' Sister Kind"; Mr Jlas. Bislop and - Bramle'. "Glory to thee my God, this Night.'' Accompanists, Misses Hunt and Burrows and Mr Morrison.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Mr. Percy Mavon Ibbs, at one time organist at St. Saviour's Cathedral, writes us from the Carlton Hotel, Edinburgh, under date October 23, that he is now touring as
articleText: MUSICAL. Mr. Percy Maveon Ibb, at one time organist at St. Saviour's Cathedral, writes us from the Carlton Hotel, Edinburgh, under date Oc tober 23, that he is now touring as accompan ist with Madame Clara Butt and Mr. Kenner icy Rumford. lMr. Ibbs says he would like to re niew his acquaintance with all his friends at Goulburn, and perhaps he will at no distant dlate. The company is having packed houses everywhere and great ouccess. Madame Clara Butt is in magnificent voice, and is marvellous. Mr. Ibl d adds--"After the coacert on Saturday Mrs. Montigdmery. (MBiss Hunt, of Goulburn) came to greet me at the artistes' room, and it was so delightfnl to meet with an old friend up here." Our correspondent states that he is play iug also for Miss Hetty Holoyd (Esta d'Argo) on this tour, and she is having great success. Mr. Ibs' Goulburn friends will be pleased to have this intimation of his progress. The bankruptcy matter of R. W. Ttveedie was called on to-day (Thursday) beforo the Regisn trar, Mr. Boileau, and on the application of Mr. Thomas was allowed to stand over until December 20. At the Moss Vale Police Court on Wednes day, before Mr. Maitland, a boy of 15 yea named Charles L. Flint. was committed t trial at the Central Criminal Court on Decem' ber 3 on a capital charge. The Victorian strikers intend to appeal to workers throughout Australia for financial as sistance. Referring to the concluding work of the ses sion, the Premier said on Tuesday the Lotteries Bill would receive attention after some altera tions in it were completed. Up to June 30 the e)penditure on the Central ITailway Station amounted to 3575,000. The total cost of the entire work as now proposed is estimnated at 8718.000. Thie Evangelical Churches in Wellington anl Dunedin have started an active anti-gambling crllesalo. The buslls fires inl the western district are as sumillg alarming dimensions. A Weentworth cor respondent says that many settlers who bIraved seven ycars of drought will now be brought to ruil or stlarvation. Floods in thle Murray and Darling have caused mucll damage by tile destruction of dams and bridges. Altholghl it is the date fixed for the Common wealth Federal elections, Wednesday, Decem ber 12, will not be a public holiday. The Sydney Hlerald reporter says ttat the contest in tile Gwydir Is very severe, and tilat Mir. Cunnllngham, tile Anti-Socialist candidate, Is lsrogresstlng well. It Is ireported thalt in South Sydney efforts have been made to cause a loss of votes to Sir tamnes Grallam by telling electors they are not ctsrcited. Dr. Llddell Is conductllg a very successful campaign on the Hunter, but there is consider able apathy among a large section of voters. MIr. Ramsay Macdonald, S.P., admits tllat 1tr. Deakin's olbjection to his interference its tus tralian politics Is a sound one. "But," Otr. tMacdonald adds, "I wish Mhr. Deakln had re frainedt from interfering in our politics wsled we were in the midst of an election." SIr. Deakil, in reply to a protest by Senator 'Pulsford regarding the shippwrecked .Chinese, said, "stlnable action was taken when Informa tkLn reached tile department." Senator Pulsford ltas wrcitten to tile Prime Minister stating tllat all the mischllef. had been done before the men were finally permitted to land. A complalnt Is made that tile administration of thie Trades Marks Act Is theltg unduly con tralised Inl Mlelbourne. Fees for registration of accepted application for trades marks are re fused at the Sydney oilice, and are only pay able in ltelbourne. Tile Premier of Tasmania says that an over wselmlng vote against federation would ise given In every State If a referendum were taboo. Tile price of sllgar will be reduced t0s per ton from to-day (Thursday), making a reduc tlon of £5 per ton wltllln six months. A depultatlon from ilthe Sydney Labour Conncll uirged the Minister for Works to appoint a Royal Commission to- inquire into . sweating. They also asked tbat the navigation law' should ie amendled as regards tile proportion of olfcers emiloyed on coasting vessels. A further request was that the control of cabmen should be ilaced under the City Council. Mr. Lee replied that a very strong case for Inquiry had been made olt, and he would biring it under tile notice of tihe Premier. The Federal authorities by proclamation are prohibiting the eaport of arms. ammunition, or spirits to tile Noew lebrldes. C. B. IKellow and W. H. Grimwade, competl tors in the Dunlop reliability test race. have been fined at Melbourne for furiously driving. One of thie men Injured in the disaster at Calliope Does. Auckland, died on Wednesday. A meetilg of manllfacturers and business men was held it Sydney on Wednesday night to consider wssat action should ie taken ih refer once to the uniont label. It wses resolved to resist tile application for the label on the ground that the law was ultra vires, and ex ceeded •tle powers of the Commonwealth Con nlltutlon. A meeting of persons interested In coursing was held in Sydney on Wednesday to cohslder the question of having the sport placed on the same footing uinder the Gaming Act as horse raclng. About a dozen members of Parliament were present, and It was agreed that they shiould confers wliti tile Attorney-General on the subJect. Yass. Wednesday.--At the residence of Mr. II. Slewart. North Yass, tills afternooin, a kerosene stove exploded with a oltd report, whlelch was Ioardd a considerable distance away. Nellie Hlodge, a domestic servant, was seriously burnt Iy tile steam, and tile interior of the ktllchei was damaged.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Mr. Percy Mavon Ibbs, at one time organist at St. Saviour's Cathedral, writes us from the Carlton Hotel, Edinburgh, under date October 23, that he is now touring as
articleText: MUSICAL. Mr. Percy Maveon Ibb, at one time organist at St. Saviour's Cathedral, writes us from the Carlton Hotel, Edinburgh, under date Oc tober 23, that he is now touring as accompan ist with Madame Clara Butt and Mr. Kenner icy Rumford. lMr. Ibbs says he would like to re niew his acquaintance with all his friends at Goulburn, and perhaps he will at no distant dlate. The company is having packed houses everywhere and great ouccess. Madame Clara Butt is in magnificent voice, and is marvellous. Mr. Ibl d adds--"After the coacert on Saturday Mrs. Montigdmery. (MBiss Hunt, of Goulburn) came to greet me at the artistes' room, and it was so delightfnl to meet with an old friend up here." Our correspondent states that he is play iug also for Miss Hetty Holoyd (Esta d'Argo) on this tour, and she is having great success. Mr. Ibs' Goulburn friends will be pleased to have this intimation of his progress. The bankruptcy matter of R. W. Ttveedie was called on to-day (Thursday) beforo the Regisn trar, Mr. Boileau, and on the application of Mr. Thomas was allowed to stand over until December 20. At the Moss Vale Police Court on Wednes day, before Mr. Maitland, a boy of 15 yea named Charles L. Flint. was committed t trial at the Central Criminal Court on Decem' ber 3 on a capital charge. The Victorian strikers intend to appeal to workers throughout Australia for financial as sistance. Referring to the concluding work of the ses sion, the Premier said on Tuesday the Lotteries Bill would receive attention after some altera tions in it were completed. Up to June 30 the e)penditure on the Central ITailway Station amounted to 3575,000. The total cost of the entire work as now proposed is estimnated at 8718.000. Thie Evangelical Churches in Wellington anl Dunedin have started an active anti-gambling crllesalo. The buslls fires inl the western district are as sumillg alarming dimensions. A Weentworth cor respondent says that many settlers who bIraved seven ycars of drought will now be brought to ruil or stlarvation. Floods in thle Murray and Darling have caused mucll damage by tile destruction of dams and bridges. Altholghl it is the date fixed for the Common wealth Federal elections, Wednesday, Decem ber 12, will not be a public holiday. The Sydney Hlerald reporter says ttat the contest in tile Gwydir Is very severe, and tilat Mir. Cunnllngham, tile Anti-Socialist candidate, Is lsrogresstlng well. It Is ireported thalt in South Sydney efforts have been made to cause a loss of votes to Sir tamnes Grallam by telling electors they are not ctsrcited. Dr. Llddell Is conductllg a very successful campaign on the Hunter, but there is consider able apathy among a large section of voters. MIr. Ramsay Macdonald, S.P., admits tllat 1tr. Deakin's olbjection to his interference its tus tralian politics Is a sound one. "But," Otr. tMacdonald adds, "I wish Mhr. Deakln had re frainedt from interfering in our politics wsled we were in the midst of an election." SIr. Deakil, in reply to a protest by Senator 'Pulsford regarding the shippwrecked .Chinese, said, "stlnable action was taken when Informa tkLn reached tile department." Senator Pulsford ltas wrcitten to tile Prime Minister stating tllat all the mischllef. had been done before the men were finally permitted to land. A complalnt Is made that tile administration of thie Trades Marks Act Is theltg unduly con tralised Inl Mlelbourne. Fees for registration of accepted application for trades marks are re fused at the Sydney oilice, and are only pay able in ltelbourne. Tile Premier of Tasmania says that an over wselmlng vote against federation would ise given In every State If a referendum were taboo. Tile price of sllgar will be reduced t0s per ton from to-day (Thursday), making a reduc tlon of £5 per ton wltllln six months. A depultatlon from ilthe Sydney Labour Conncll uirged the Minister for Works to appoint a Royal Commission to- inquire into . sweating. They also asked tbat the navigation law' should ie amendled as regards tile proportion of olfcers emiloyed on coasting vessels. A further request was that the control of cabmen should be ilaced under the City Council. Mr. Lee replied that a very strong case for Inquiry had been made olt, and he would biring it under tile notice of tihe Premier. The Federal authorities by proclamation are prohibiting the eaport of arms. ammunition, or spirits to tile Noew lebrldes. C. B. IKellow and W. H. Grimwade, competl tors in the Dunlop reliability test race. have been fined at Melbourne for furiously driving. One of thie men Injured in the disaster at Calliope Does. Auckland, died on Wednesday. A meetilg of manllfacturers and business men was held it Sydney on Wednesday night to consider wssat action should ie taken ih refer once to the uniont label. It wses resolved to resist tile application for the label on the ground that the law was ultra vires, and ex ceeded •tle powers of the Commonwealth Con nlltutlon. A meeting of persons interested In coursing was held in Sydney on Wednesday to cohslder the question of having the sport placed on the same footing uinder the Gaming Act as horse raclng. About a dozen members of Parliament were present, and It was agreed that they shiould confers wliti tile Attorney-General on the subJect. Yass. Wednesday.--At the residence of Mr. II. Slewart. North Yass, tills afternooin, a kerosene stove exploded with a oltd report, whlelch was Ioardd a considerable distance away. Nellie Hlodge, a domestic servant, was seriously burnt Iy tile steam, and tile interior of the ktllchei was damaged.
