snippet: Miss Florence Schmidt was the vocalist at a concert at the Queen's Hall, London, last month, given by the Stock Exchange Musical Society. The "Daily Mail,"
articleText:
Musical. :-'''[\ ??'??',';? '-';

Miss Florence Scumid't was the vocalist at a concert at tho Queon's Hall, London, lost month, given by the Stock Exchange Musical Society. The 'Daily Mail,' refer ring to the event, say3 that Miss Schmidt's success in England is assured. '

The 'Era' say3 that the absence of Mr. V,'. S. Gilbert's name from .the list of thoso who attended tho funeral of the late Sir iuihur Sullivan. is aecouutc-i for by uhe fact i!hai iir. Gilbert is ait present in Egypt seeking health. He was represented by his brother.

Mdlle. Trobeill, or, .as uhe talented voca list now styles herself, Mdlle. Dclorea, wile commence another Australian tour about tho first week in April. Mr. John Laurt has received a letter containing the wel como fntelligence. ' Arrangements aro being made in Mel bourne to tender Miss Bertha Bird a faxu woll concert in tho Masonic Hall on FeD ruary 13. Miss Bird will sail for, London or March lu. ''' At tho smoke concertlof tho Sydney Pro fessional Musicians' Benefit Society on Sun day las-t Mr. .1. R. Keer3, leader of tho Ti voli orchestra, particularly distinguished himself in Vieuxtemps' Violin Concerto, and called forth encomiums from the guest of the evening, Professor Marshall Hall. Ono of the many stories told of tho late Sir Arthur Sullivan's humor concerned an Incident which happened- at a rehearsal of one of the early Savoy operas. Sir Arthur, ?was not feeling well, and his temper was just the least bit Ices genial than it usually was. One of tho actors had a bad cold, and persisted in singing out of tune. Sir Ar thur bore it as long as ho could, but his good nature gradually evaporated until none ot it was left. 'Mr. So-aud-So,' he exclaimed, kcepinc as calm and cool as possible under the exasperating circum stances, 'thero Is something radically wrong with that cons. Either you dori't understand it or I do not.'' 'I think I understand it, Sir Arthur,' replied the vo calist, on hl3 dignity. 'Ah, no doubt,' said Sir Arthur, acidly, 'that's tho worst of being a composer. Ono always begins ai Ihe wrong end of tho stick. . For the future 1 shall start at the other end. I'll get you to sing my songs first, and then I will com pose them afterwards.'

Why Amy Castles Left Madame Marches?. With reference to the recent retirement of Miss Amy Castles from the tuition ot Madame Marches!, tho Bendlgo 'Adver- tiser' writes as follows: 'On the recent ar rival of Mrs. Castles in Paris her daughter gave up Marchosl. Madarne's statement was that the young Bendigo singer had

ueen given up oy tier, as sue declined to give any further lessens to one who wished ty be a di-amatic soprano against her wishes. Marchesl denied ev.ir having said that tho voice was a magnificent one; sho asserted that Amy's voice \va3 perfectly tired when heard Iirst by her; it was only a sweet little voice; she was too small to Hlng in opera (this much insisted on)' and sho had no high notes in hor voice, it. betas only a mezzo soprano — In fact, madame as serted that the young lady could not sins up to B flat ! It has been freely asserted by many professional musicians, and by critics quite us capable of judging voles ns Marchesl, that the voice of Miss Castleo was a pure dramatic soprano, which would be displayed at best In opera, so that this judgment ot hera was quite wrong. It U also well known in Australia that it is untrue the voice is a small one— it' filled tho great hall of the Exhibition so that ovcry one of tho 14,000 peoplo in the audlenco ht-ard quite perfeotly. As for tho state ment that she was unable to sing up to B fiat, she sang up to D fiat at her own con cert in Melbourne, and no ono found fault with the quality of the note ? Though Madame MarcliosI declined (when she knew It was all over) to Rive further Icsson3 to Miss Castles, she said nothing about returning to her the balanco of thy money paid hi advance for lessons which nre not to bo given. Moreover, tho lessons already given lasted often only 10 minutes instead or the stipulated half-hour. 'Miss Castles has h ,-w been placed with a M. Bouhy, who has t)v greatest reputation of anv teacher In Paid, not excepting Mar chesl' herself, and ho ilcciarcs the voiuo lo be a magnificent dramatic soprano. Ho placed her at once In v.he opera class. Mlso Ca»tlc3 was moved to go lo him by some Australian singers, who wcro forcou to leave Marchosl, and who aro doing wen with him.' ? ^ ^ ?

heading: MUSICAL
snippet: The concert series by Miss Marie Narelle was opened on Monday evening under weather conditions the reverse of favorable. But the audience which assembled in the
articleText:
MUSICAL

The concert series by Miss Marie Narelle was opened on Monday evening under wea ther conditions the reverse of favorable. But the audience which assembled in the Town Hall was proof of the interest arous ed in the singer, and the continuous ap plause she evoked showed that her abilities

were appreciated. Miss Narelle, who is Australian by birth, lias a very pleasing mezzo soprano voice, and its sympathetic quality finds excellent expression" in the Scotch and Irish ballads in which she makes appeal to the patriotic sentiments of her hearers. She has obtained recognition in London, and has sung with success in England, Ireland, Scotland and America. On Monday evening national melodies were strongly represented, Moore being laid under frequent contribution for Irish songs, while the Scotch craving was satisfied with Loch Lomond and the Hills of Skye. Mr. Chester Fentress displays an agreeable light tenor, which lie uses with discretion, and his contributions were favorably re ceived. Miss Constance Brandon-Usher as solo pianist exhibited distinctive quality, and her selections were deservedly appre ciated. Miss Sheilah O'Donnell acted as ac companist. Concerts were also given on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday. Miss Una Bourne's recital will take place on Thursday evening, 14th inst. Hcrr Louis Hattenbach, the well known cellist, will assist Miss Bourne at her recital, and Mr. Harold Elvins will be the accompanist. Miss Bourne will play W, F. Bach's Or gan Concerto, Nocturne and Prelude by Chopin, the brilliant Faust Valse, arranged by Liszt, and also some Brahms variations on a theme by Handel. By the German mail steamer Bulow, which reached Fremantlc on Monday, the principal artists of Mr. George Musgrove's Grand Opera Company arrived. Mr. Mus- grove has received the following telegram: — "On arrival upon Australian soil, your very kind welcome greeted us, for which we express our thanks, and the sincere hope that the Australian public will be

equally cordial in welcoming us and our art.— Your Opera Soloists." A farewell complimentary , concert is to be tendered to Miss Carrie Haase, the well known elocutionist, at the .Masonic Hall on Monday, 25th -March. Miss Haase will be assisted by Miss- Ida Osborne, Madame Oharbonnet Kellerman, Miss Lilian Reid and others. Spain's oratorio Calvary will be per formed by the Melbourne Philharmonic Society on Gbod Friday night in the Town Hall, with full orchestra and chorus, un der the baton of Mr. Geo. Peake. For this concert Miss Martha Bruggemann, a highly spoken of vocalist, of Adelaide, is being specially brought to Melbourne by the -society. The other principals are Miss Grace Kemp, Miss Celia John, Mr. Gregor Wood, Mr. Horace Stevens, Mr. A. C. Bottoms and Mr. H. J. Floyd. Df. Grieg, tho "great composer, has lately honored the Australian pianist, Percy Grainger with an invitation to visit himself and Mrs. Grieg at their lovely country home, "Troldhangen," Bergen, in Norway, next summer. He also expressed his desire that the young Australian should be chosen for his piano concerto at the Leeds Festi val when he (Dr. Grieg) comes over to conduct.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The Marshall-Hall orchestral concert on Saturday afternoon owed its chief interest to the Wagner excerpts. The Prelude to Parsifal has not been heard here in its
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The Marshall-Hall orchestral concert on Saturday afternoon owed its chief interest to the Wagner excerpts. The Prelude to Parsifal has not been heard here in its original form since Cowen and the Exhi- bition days, which is going back more than

eighteen years, though a very effective transcription for organ was played by Mr. Lemare. The work, which had evidently been carefully rehearsed, was conducted with insight and played with marked suc- cess. The intonation of the brass at times left something to seek; but the general performance was of a high standard. From the same music-drama we had also a deeply interesting extract known as Charfreitags- Zauber, or the Spell of Good Friday. Like the Prelude, this, too, was finely inter- preted by a specially augmented orchestra. The remaining Wagner item, the introduc- tion and closing scene from Tristan und Isolde, was really well done, and served to bring the concert to a brilliant conclusion. Max Bruch's Romance for violin and or- chestra was played by Mr. Albert Zelman, whose full, pure tone is more suited to a broad cantabile bit of melody than to music which approaches to violin gymnastics. Mr. Marshall-Hall did not get all the effect there was to be obtained from the Scotch symphony, which contains musical beau- ties apparently quite unsuspected by the late Ormond professor. A new tenor, Mr. Edgar Marsden, made his first appearance with the Philharmonic Society on Tuesday evening, when Cole- ridge-Taylor's compositions, Hiawatha's Wedding Feast and The Death of Minne- haha, were performed by the society's chorus and orchestra. The other soloists were Miss Eileen O'Brien and Mr. Horace Stevens. The long expected Melbourne season of the Besses o'" the Barn Band begins to-day (Saturday, 27tli July), at the Town Hall, and an imposing welcome has been ar ranged for the Lancashire Lads, whom Messrs. J. and N. Tait introduced to Aus tralia. They reach Melbourne by the Sydney express about midday, and "will be met at Spencer-street station by the whole of the members of the two metropolitan band associations, representing no fewer than 33 bands. To the number of nearly five hundred these instrumentalists will play tlicm through the streets in procession to the Town Hall, where the civic welcome will take place. It was at first intended to begin their season with a matinee per formance, but this has been changed and the evening will see the first appearance with a programme that ranges through a wide selection of pieces. Among the items will be their own particular fantasie on the music of Tannhauser, their rendering of which so enchanted the late Sir Arthur Sullivan that he declared that it was the best thing lie had ever heard. EJgar's Pomp and Circumstance march, the Turkish Patrol, a selection from The Pirates of Penzance, Reminiscences of Tschaikowsky (introducing bits of the famous 1812 over ture), Poet and Peasant overture, and Estudiantina are all included, as well as a cornet solo on The Lost Chord, and n trombone solo Lend Me Your Aid, ac companied by the Besses as orchestra. The Australasian season of Miss Marie Hall finishes in New Zealand this week, and the brilliant young violinist takes her departure for England once more. Messrs. J. and N. Tait have already discussed with her the prospect of a return visit, and though no definite time was fixed there is every probability of licr coming back in the earlv future. Madame Clara Butt and "party" left Lon don on Friday last week for Australia, and according to a private cablegram . received by Messrs. J. and N. Tait, the farewell ac corded her by her personal friends and her host of admirers was of a most cordial description, hundreds of people assembling to give the diva a send off worthy of her fame. The late Alfred Collier's charming comic opera Dorothy renewed its fascination over Sydney audiences last Saturday, 20th inst., when the Royal Comic Opera Company re vived it for a limited number of nights. A crowded house welcomed the old favorite with unlimited approval, applauding all its tuneful numbers and laughing as heartily at the humor as though it were the first production of the piece. Miss Florence Young repeated her former success as Dorothy. Miss Nina Wood, a newcomer to the ranks of the company, made an excel lent first impression as Lydia, and Mr. Geo. LaurL was as irresistible as' usual as Lurcher. There has again been trouble with Mr. Musgrovo's Grand Opera Co. At Auck land one programme was abandoned, and arrangements . for others were altered at the last minute.

snippet: Miss Ethel Morcombe, a young Bendigonian singer, gave a vocal recital on Saturday afternoon in Gien's concert hall.
articleText:
MUSICAL.

f BY "SANCHO/'l

Miss Ethel Morcombe, a young Bcndl- gonlan singer, gave a vocal recital on Saturday afternoon In Glen'n concert hall. ItecltalB of young vocalists and

pianists have become quite an institu tion In Melbourne. They havo their usea and advantages, and in thoee caws where young performers, by a well cho sen and praiseworthy executed pro gramme. prove talent, Industry, and high ambition, they are sure of a kind reception by public and press. There Is, however, the danger that premature ap pearances are encouraged by this sys tem. The public cannot be expected to to engrossed by promises alone, and to i>?nignantly listen to the rudimentary performances of evory fairly talented student. Miss Morcombo's public ap pearance furnishes a case In ix»lnt. The young lady promises n soprano voice, which, although undeveloped, dlreloses a sweet nnd ringing upper register. She. evidently, Is no; without musical gifts, or even emotional qualities. But, then, e?he is not mlstresr of her voice, and in tho effort to manifest sentiment, grows sentimental. Moreover, she was ill nd- vlrod In selecting for performance num bers like FergolCRl's Nina. Handel's Ombra ma! fu, nnd Bohm'a Still as tho Night, all of which, to be effective, de mand a full mezzo-soprano voice. At her best, sho appeared In Tosti's Mattl- nata, a song that brought out the young singer's pleasing qualities, and showed that If she has much to learn, she ccod not despair to sUU conquer fame and fortune. Miss Morcombo bad the assistance o! several well known porformors. Mr A; C. Bottoms, rendered Schubert's Erl Koenlg. and was heard, to advantage' In four characteristic songs by MncDaweU. Miss Olga Zlchy-Wolnarskl, tho tnlcntcd violinist, played Barcarole, by Spohr, and two Hungarian pieces by M. Haurcr, to Mra Chas. . Heath's pianoforte accom paniment. Master Adrian Amadlo, the clever boy flautist, played n couple of brilliant morccaux by Fritz Dopplcr and Edward German. A large audience,, consisting prin cipally of ladies, showed Its Interest in tho' performance by hearty applause.

snippet: Mr. J. Prout, a vocalist from Ballart, has met with an unexpected stroke of good fortune. He had resigned himself to what appeared to be the inevitable necessity of
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Mr. J. Prout; a vocalist from Ballarat, has met with an unexpected stroke of good fortune. He had resigned himself to what appeared to be the inevitable, necessity ot

returning to Australia, and was prepared to relinquish the great opportunities of mu sical training afforded by the metropolis, when a friend asked him to sing at an en tertainment, to which request he accede I. His effort so pleaserl a musician present that he. obtained for Mr. Prout au offer ot a position in tlie choir of St. George's (.'Impel. Windsor. The salary being sati,, tory, Mr. Prout at once concluded an en gagement, which will allow him aa.ple time for study and training. Madame Clara Butt's projected tour in tho antipodes will keep !-er away from England till Easter of next year, 'as she will not leave till July ' 19. - This prolonged absence from the mother country lias decided the great ballad singer to give a special farewoll con cert at the 'Albert Hall on June 20. She is now quite convalescent from the relapse which prostrated her recently. The se:i voyage and change will doubtless com pletely re-establifli her normal good health. Dr. Rappoport has licen explaining to other members of the Playgoers' Club that, in his opinion, 'actresses with ordinary talents should marry, a* marriage enhances their acting, but if there is an actress on (lie stage who is a real genius she should1 remain single.' As a general rule he thought that this was liceausa 'an artist without human attachments is unable to render certain human emotions, and an aetre.« who is not married cannot suc.-eed in her art like a woman who has faced Uie responsibilities of married life.' 'I have noticed/' continued Dr. Rappo port. 'that actresses act better after mar rage than before, having acquired thereby a certain seriousness, a grandeur, and a certain -rrip which make their emotions much stronger.''' Dr. Rappoport. how ever. ;mvo a word of warning about the evils of ''mentally consanguineous'1 mar vianf-s — actresses, he said, should not marry actors, but rather literary men, bewu.-c oprrosites most attracted each other. He added that he could name some . LoivT-;n actresses who owed their success to their husbands.

heading: Musical.
snippet: Miss Eileen Furner, eldest daughter of Mr. Arthur Furner, has returned to Goulburn, having completed her musical studies in Sydney. For the last fifteen months Miss Furner has
articleText: Musical. Miss Eileen Furner, eldest daughter of Mr. Artlhur Furner, has returned to Goulburn, hav ing completed her musical studies in Sydney. For the last fifteen months Miss Furner has been receiving tuition from Miss Florence Taylor, the brilliant young pianiste whose per formances recently electrified local audiences. Miss Furner desired to study under the late Mr. Sydney Moss. That teacher had no vacant cies, but he undertook to supervise Miss Fur nor's studies until a vacancy presented itself. This promise he duly fulfilled, and Miss Fur ner had the advantage of his oversight up to the time of his death.

articleText:
Musical

LONDON, Wednesday (AAP). — Michael Craw ford, whose acting, singing and dancing talents have made the West End musical 'Billy' a smash hit, is to leave the show on May!.

The comic star of the TV series 'Some Mothers Do Have 'Em', says he is tired of the part of Billy Liar. His two-year contract with the show expires on May 1 and he'll be replaced by English actor and singer Roy Castle.

articleText:
Musical.

Miss Vora Eyton leaves for London by the Cuzco to-day. Her. farewell' concert at the Centenary Hall, at which Mr. Tapley as sisted, was a success. The young vocalist will carry with her the best wishes of many friends.

Mdllo. Antonia Delores (Trobelli) la a passenger by tho San Francisco mall beat Sierra, duo here to-morrow. ? Mdlle. Dolores commences her tour In Sydney, on April 10. Owing to the Town Hall being encaged for State- functions, no concert will be given in Melbourne until May 14. Mdlle. Dolores will be in Melbourno during the Commonwealth Celebrations, and will pro bably be engaged for the State concerts. Mr. Robert Clarence Newell, a young American plp.nlst, accompanies the- great prima donna. ? ?

heading: Musical.
snippet: Miss Florence Schmidt, the Queensland soprano, continues her splendid career of success. She has been engaged as sole vocalist for the English provincial tour of the
articleText:
Musical.

Miss Florence Schmidt, the Queensland soprano, continues her splendid career of success. She has been engaged as sole vo calist for tho English provincial tour of the great Ysaye and Slgnor Busoni, and later on she will make her debut at the London Crystal Palace Saturday Orchestra Con certs, being also sole vocalist on that oc casion.

Miss Bertha Rossow was to have sung at two concerts in Lancashire on March 4 and 5, when her compatriots, the Misses Beatrice, Muriel, and Bessie Griffiths, were also to have been on the programme. The Misses Griffiths glve a recltal at the Birk beck Institute on March 21, when the whole programme will be supplied by the three sisters. Mdme. Antonio Dolores (Antoinette Tre belli) was to have left 'Frisco on Wednes day last for another Australian tour. The talented soprano will bo cordially welcomed back. The late Sir Arthur Sullivan, as all his frlends well know, was one of the most obliging and willing of men, and yet one of the most modest and retiring. Not many months before his death the great composer was spendingr the evening at

the house of a musical friend of his, who, much to Sir Arthur's horror, chanced to have four musical daughters — "quite prodi gies, Siv Athur," said the hostess; "quite wonders, I assure you." Directly after dinner these prodigies commenced show ing their musical abilities. First one sang; another played tho piano; a third the violin; the fourth the mandoline. Sir Arthur listened patiently for two hours to thoevery indifferent performances of these four "wonders." Presently the hostess came up: "Oh, Sir Arthur," she said gushingly, 'we will glve the dear children a rest now, so what will you play for us ?' "Madam,'"said Sir Arthur, quite worn out, and utterly wearied, "I will go on playing what I have been playing the whole evening with your permission." "Indeed ! Sir Arthur !" said the hostess, very surprised. "What have you been playing, may I ask?" "Second fiddle, madam!"' bluntly said Sir Arthur, "second fiddle!"— "Cassell's Saturday Journal." The meeting of the Vera Eyton compli mentary concert committee, held at the Australia on Friday night last, made final arrangements for tho concert, which takes place at tho Centenary Hall on March 20. Mr. Southwell, who is arranging the pro gramme, has secured the services of some of Sydney's leading artists. The perform ance will bo held under the patronage of Sir Frederick Darley, the Lieutenant Governor, and other distinguished citizens. Tickets are being disposed of at a rapid rate, and the committee expect a crowded house.

articleText:
flusica!.

A nablo received yesterday stated that: Madiinie Melba appeared at Covcivt Gardeit on, Saturday night as Mlml, her perform ance of I'ho character being a triumph. It is: probable that the cable refers to a cha racter. In one of Puccini's new operas, which the prlma donna told an interviewer recently she was studying.

Mme. 'Al.banl, after a successful tour iu' Soift-h Africa, has roturncd to London. / A London critic, speaking of Mdmo. Mel ba's appearance In 'Romeo nnd Juliet' at the Covent .Garden, says:— in tho walt?. spng in the first net nhe was Incompara iiblo as over. She alone, ot all modern singers, has the pure 'timbre' of quality ?which, iu Its simplicity, conquers all cri ticism. Mme. Molba sings with such trans parent case, with such, perfect art. 'Ars est celare artem' is now an obsolete Latin Proverb for many reasons; it has been quoted too freely. Nowadays wo realise that art— pure and' simple— needs neither concealment nor artifice. There aro those who say that 'Mdme. Melba's voice Is cold. It is not. It is resonant, wonderful, pure— a voice of the present century.

articleText:
MUSICAL. '

We understand that Miss L. Tlmbs, of Albion Park, has definitely decided to relinquish her profession of music teacher, as she contemplates leaving the district. She has been a most successful teacher and, In addition, did splendid service as organiser of concert!., etc., 1 in aid of various ob

jects, particularly patriotic efforts during the war. Since the war she has not rested on her laurels, but has assisted both the Albion ' Park A., H. and I. Association and School of Arts by organising efforts on behalf of the funds. She -also organised an orches tra to play at dances and balls, , which appeared at many of the more Import ant functions along the coast . We

understand what a movement #3 on lo&J to siitably rbcognisie Miss Timbs's service for tlie town and dis trict. She richly desreves it.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Mr. W. T. Boat concluded his series of 12 organ recitals at the Centennial on Tuesday, September 2, and two days later left for Melbourne, where he will give several performances prior to his visit to
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Mr. W. T. Boat concluded his series of 12 organ recitals at the Centennial on Tuesday, September 2, and two days later left for Melbourne, where he will give several performances prior to his visit to Chicago. To the last he continued to draw enormous audiences-the attendance being always numbered by thousands. Admission to the first recital was by invitation only. For the rest the highest charge has been no more than 2s. Yet the large sum of nearly £1775 was received from the sale of tickets, resulting in a profit, after the payment of all expenses, of nearly £845. Between the time of Mr, Best's arrival and

the opening of the organ there was an interval of rather more than four months, and the City Coun- cil, though it acknowledged no legal liability in the matter, has voted a special honorarium of £200 as some compensation for his long detention, Mr. Best is to give four more recitals here before he

sails for Amerioa.

Handel's oratorio of " Judas Maccabaeus, " that was produced by the Sydney Philharmonic Society on the 20th of last month, was repeated on the 2rd instant, with the same solo artists as before. An audience of 3500 attended the repetition per- formance, which was, from first to last, a pro-

nounced success.

the Hazon Orchestral Concerts have been revived

and two excellent performances have already been given. The ovortures played have been " Oberon," " Rienzi," " Prometheus,'' and " I Promessi Sposi," and movements have been given from the Sympnonio Dramatique, " Romeo et Juliette," of Bernoz, and from Raff's .* Im Walde " sym- phony. One of tho Hungarian rhapsodies of Liszt and Greig's " Peer Gynt " suite for orchestra have also had prominence on the programmes, in which have been included other compositions by Handel, Mendelssohn, Wagner, Gounod, Delibes,

&c.

way -from Tasmania, where they go after a short .season in Sydney ' (vherfl thoy grSTai; present) , to Western Australia, ' where' their Australasian tour finishes in November. Miss Ada Crossley's success at the Gloucester Festival on' 10th and 14th Sep tember in Elgar's The Kingdom, the Elijah and The Messiah is recorded by cable. She will also sing at tlie Leeds Festival, 9th-12tk October, at which Sir Hubert Parry's The Love that Casteth Out Fear is to be the novel feature. The departure of Madame Clara Butt has given the Australian singer tlie offer of many more engagements than she can accept. In an interesting record which is given iri the "Sydney Morning Herald" it is stated that for several months, until March, 1908, Madame Cross- ley will be on a starring tour with lier own party, consisting of Miss Evangeline Flor ence (soprano), Mr. John Harrison (tenor), Mr. Hamilton Earle (bass), Mr. Percy Grainger (solo pianist), M. Leon Sainctini (violinist) and Mr. S. Liddle (accom panist). ;' , ' , . Miss Lalla Miranda has been appearing in opera at Nice, Monaco, Pau, Biarritz and Ostend for several years past. She is, now visiting her mother and sister in London. Madame Gvossley placed Miss Beatrice Miranda under Madame Minna Fischer, and also took her to Mr. William Boosey, wlio, after hearing lier in the Mad Scene from Hamlet, engaged her for two of the forthcoming Chappcll ballad concerts at Queen's Hall. Madame Crossley says that tlie younger sister also sings with beautiful finish, and that the timbre is very sweet, pure and boyish. _ The famous violinist Jan Kubelik has ar ranged to make a tour through Australia and New Zealand next year, commencing at tlie end of May. Miss Erna (Loviej Mueller, formerly of Bendigo, who lias com pleted her musical education in Europe, has been engaged as vocalist for the (our, dur ing which a total of 35 concerts will be given.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The first of the Marshall-Hall Orchestral Concerts will be given in the Town Hall on Monday evening, with an orchestra of 65 performers. The programme will
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The first of the Marsliall-Hall Orchestral Concerts will be given in the Town Hall on Monday evening, with an orchestra of 65 performers. The programme will in clude Schubert's C major Symphony, Bee thoven's Coriolaii overture, and Weber's Freiscluvtz overture. Miss Una Bourne will supply the pianoforte part in a fan tasia, A. Northern Ballad, by Miss Mona M'Btirney.

Mine. Mclba's future plans include prob able appearances at the Paris Opera in April, and a certain appearance at Covent Garden in a new role as "La Tosca" on 6th May. This she will further study in Italy. On 24th May the diva will celebrate the 20th anniversary of her life at Covent Gar den — 20 consecutive seasons! It appears that there is more than oiie Tctrnzzini. It is stated, on the authority of Col. Maplc-son, that the prima donna hitherto known as tlie celebrated Tetrazzini is not tlie artist who recently took London by storm, but her elder sister Eva, who has achieved re markable European triumphs in conjunc tion with the De Keszkes and other great singers. Regarding the relative artistic

merits of the x'ivnl sisters, Colonel Maple-- son, who has heard them both repeatedly, declares that the elder sister has the bet ter voice. There is a good deal of hick in achieving sensational fame. The Sydney .. "Morning Herald" adds: — "Undoubtedly one of . those (admittedly fine) artists who ought to have won it, yet remained just outside the charmed circle, was Mme. Clem entine de Vere (Sapio). In a private letter from a very distinguished artist, who is also a sober and competent critic of musi cal affairs, the opinion is expressed that Sapio's 'Mimi' ('La Boheme') is in every way more attx-aetive than Melba's, and the writer had seen both within four weeks of one another!" When Madame Melba was here she was much pleased witli the singing of Mr. Alex. E. Wotherspoon, whose voice she described as a pure basso cantan'te, with evenness and beauty of tone. Expressing tlie opinion that the possessor of such an organ would find a favorable reception from any of the world's great singing masters, she advised this young singer to proceed to Europe for tx-aining as, soon as he conveniently could. A number of his friends has resolved to aid him in carrying, out this recommenda tion, and arrangements are being made to secure for him a finishing course under .Jean de Reszke, in Paris. It is proposed to organ ise a concert to assist a fund with this ob ject. Mr. Wotlierspoon has been under the tuition locally of Herr Himmer, whose me thod of gradual development, has so pre served the voice that its natural sweetness and rotundity are retained. The New Zealand tour of Madame Clara Butt, which has been a wonderful suc cession of triumphs, comes to a conclusion this week, and the great contralto returns to Australia for her farewell tour, which begins at the Sydney Town Hall next Saturday, 14th March. Max Schluyter, the brilliant Danish violinist, commences his second Australian tour, which Messrs. J. and N. Tait ax'e managing for him, at the Melbourne Town Hall on 14th March. Thirteen years ago almost to the very day Max-k Hambourg took the first step upon the career that has proved such a triumphant progress all over the world. It was at Vienna that the brilliant young pupil of Leschetisky made his initial ap-

peal to the artistic sensibilites of an audi ence, and his handling of Chopin'p E Minor Concerto, with Dr. Hans Riehter conducting the Vienna Philharmonic Society for his "accompaniment," stamped him at once as another genius in the musical world. Such an introduction, followed up at once by the frank appreciation of the best critics of the most critical city in Europe, reaped its own reward, and the young pianist found himself much sought after when he returned to his London home. But a turn of fate's wheel contrived that Austi-alia should be even before London in its recognition of his genius, for he was almost immediately engaged for a tour of this country— and the extraordinary en thusiasm that followed on that tour will be well remembered. On his return, fresh from his Australasian success, the gates of London were at once opened to him. His first series of recitals there established his fame, and Germany, France, Austria, Bel gium, Holland, Switzerland, Italy and Rus sia were all eager to lieai tlie new star, and his first appearance in those countries have been followed by others many times since with ever increasing success. This was but the beginning of a widening circle, for America and South Africa both claimed their right to hear Jiim. In his dozen years of active concert work he has been round the world twice, visiting practically every country in the globe, and making his ad mirers acquainted with everything that ranks as the best in pianoforte litera ture. The Hollanders, a novel concert company of eight members, who, garbed in the picturesque Dutch costumes, give a. most delightful entertainment of vocal and in strumental .selections, have been engaged by Messrs. J. and N. Tait for an Austral asian tour, commencing in ..Sydney next month. Miss Ruth Lincqln, who is now on her way to Australia to play tlie principal part in Messrs. Meynell and Gunn's production of Miss Hook of Holland, is of a dark and pale order of beauty. Her voice is said to be rich and sweet, and is well trained, and she is credited with a captivat ing 'simplicity. Miss Lincoln started her professional career about five years ago, having previously been in Brussels, where she studied singing for two years. She won a scholarship at the Royal College of Music, and then took instruction from the famous professor/Mr. Henry Blower, under whom Madame Clara Butt studied. After leaving the college, Miss Lincoln was en gaged by Mr. George Edwardes for two years, and after a time created and play ed the principal part in Madame Sherry, where she made her first big success at the Apollo Theatre, London. Since then she has successfully toured with the principal company of Veronique.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: At the second of the Schluter concerts on Wednesday evening, Max Bench's Concerto in G minor, a work whose brilliant opening movement,
articleText:
MUSICAL.

At the second of the Scliluter con certs on Wednesday evening, Max Bench's Concerto in G minor, a work whose brilliant opening movement, tenderly melodious adagio and impetuous finale ili-e well known here, was given. The first two movements were delightfully done, the second being specially good, and the performer had to respond to t.wo re-

calls 011 the conclusion of his task. Han dcl's Sonata in F, with its fine opening adagio and impressive largo, was admir- 'ably rendered. Other pieces were Schu mann's Traumcrie, Wieniawski's Kuia- wiak and an efi'eetive Witches' Dance by Nnrdatzceck. Miss Gladys Ivingsley sang the page's song from Verdi's Ballo in Masehera, Bishop's Love Has. Eyes, and Liddle's In My Garden. Chopin's Chant Polonais and Liszt's Yalse Impromptu were deftly play- oil" by Mr. II. S. Elvins. Mr. Sehluter'3 final concert takes place this evening. Mr. Max Schl liter's final concert was given at the Town Hall 011 Saturday even ing. So fine an artist deserved better sup- | port than has been given by the musical public. He, without doubt, ranks among the very best violinists who have visited Australia, and it casts reflection. 011 the sincerity of oik professions, when half-filled

. "... houses are the welcome given to such 'a per former. On this occasion he gave a master ly exposition of Bach's Chaconne, a work which bristles with technical difficulties. In addition to tlie Chaconne, the Danish violinist gave Locatelli's sonata in F minor, and among the shorter pieces, d'Ambrosio's graceful canzonetta, Wieniawski's- Le Mene- ' trier, Svendsen's delightful Romance, Hubay's appropriately named Scherzo Dia- bolique and Franz Neruda's happily con ceived Berceuse Slave. Miss Gladys Kingsley's contributions were Spohr's Rose, Softly Blooming, Dvorak's Songs My Mother Taught Me, Tito Mat ters Niente per Farza, and Ellen Wright's Violets. Mr. Harold Elvins play ed a Liszt Rhapsody with much success, and ably supplied the needed accompani ments. Mr. and Mrs. Gregor Wood gave a song recital at Glen's on Thursday night, and provided quite a number of new sensa tions. The songs by Charles Willeby are strikingly original settings of- two dainty ditties from the pen of the late W. E. Henley. Five Greek love songs, by Liza Lebmann, are undeniably clever, but are not as attractive as many songs which she has previously indited when fYee from the shackles of almost antediluvian "Modes." Coleridge Taylor's Sorrow Songs fully maintain his repute. The words are in each case by Christina Rossetti; perhaps the most poignant of the three settings is that entitled Unmindful of the Roses, wherein, by "-the way, the words help the music least in telling its tale of woe. Villiers Stanford's treatment of a duet from Lord Tennyson's Beeket is remarkably well written for the two voices, and made a decided hit. Mr. Al/ bert Zelman gave a clever and ' at times a moving performance of the fine adagio from Rie's Suite in G; and Mr. Horace Gleeson efficiently discharged a rather arduous series of tasks in supplying the- needed accompaniments. A vocal recital was given at Glen's "Bi jou" liall on Monday evening by Miss Lilian Osmond, whose name may be re membered in connection with a certain his toric occasion in Sydney, when she sang Senta in the Flying Dutchman, literally at

a moment's notice, and without rehearsal. Miss Osmond's toice is a soprano of the forcible and ringing sort, but a little hard and unsympathetic for 'solo work. In soft er passages, however, it is very agreeable. I-Icr attack, too, is at times lacking in crispness. Her rendering of Hear Ye, Israel, from Mendelssohn s Elijah-, was generally commended, .and in Dvorak's Songs My Mother Taught Me, and in Brahm's Wiegenlicd the softer tones of the singer's voice were effectively shown. Miss Violet Somerset has a pleasing voice of the velvety quality of the mezzo-soprano, though of limited range.- Besides some solo numbers, she,' in conjunction with Miss Lilian Osmond, took' part in two of _ Rubin stein's best known duets." Miss Minnie C. Bull figured as solo pianist- in pieces by Brahms, Tschaikowslty and. Liszt. Madame Ada .Crossley . will have a pav- ticularly. strong company to- support hex- when- she' enters , upon;, her Australian tour under.. the J. C. Williamson .direction in October next . - r . She herself , of course, will be .the .great draw, for she lias never suug better than she is; doing at present, and in a recent comprehensive tour- of the British Isles she'earried all before, her in.-the way of ' musical enth.usiasm. - . With her will be another Australian, Mr. Percy : Grainger, the young -pianist about, whose powers. both as an'- executants aiid-. a- composer .we -fre quently iieair. M. Leon Sametini,;a Dutch violinist, will be the .other sblo.rinstrUmeii- talist, and he, too, has won a high reputa tion from the day he made his' debut as: one of the great Sevcik's "wonder chil dren." Mr. John Harrison, the tenor, has already attained the highest distinction in' England as a cultured singer of deep dra matic perception; and Mr. Hamilton Earle, the baritone, has a voice of great range and i-obiist timbre, combined with a most cultivated style. Both Mi-. Earie and Mr. Harrison have sung a.t Covent Garden, the. latter making a pronounced . success in the part of Heinrich in Tannhauser. Alto gether the party will .be a quintet of real autistic pre-eminence. A farewell complimentary concert will be given to Madame Blanche Arral at the Town Hall 011 Saturday evening. This charming artiste, coming to Australia un announced, quickly uon her way into pub lic favor by sheer force of merit. The second of tlie Marsliall-IIall orches tral concerts will be given in the Town Hall an Monday evening next. The pro gramme includes Beethoven's Symphony in A major, No. 7; Dvorak's Legenden, Nos, 1 and 4; the introduction to third act, Tris tan and Isolde, and the Meistersinger over ture. Madame Clara Butt l-eturned to Sydney last week, where her farewell series of- con certs were attended by audiences quits as immense and even more enthusiastic than those which welcomed her there before. This week she iias been to Bx-isbaiie, and next week she begins her good-bye season in Melbourne. Before he leaves London for America, 011 liis way to his Australian tour, under tlie direction of Messrs. J. and N. Tait, Mark Hainbourg is to -be farewelled in the Albert Hall, London, which lately seems to be the favorite place to say good-bye in with all the big artists visiting Australia. During the present amisical season Mr. Charles Saunders, the well known English tenor, who paid us a visit a few years ago, will open with a series of toncerts at the Melbourne Town Hall ab8ut the 5th May next. Mr. Saunders, who is travelling by the Ormuz, will be assisted on his tour by Miss Clara Rolxson. a lady with a fine con tralto voice, who has sung in the London concert halls with muclr success, and their forthcoming series of concerts promise to be exceedingly interesting. Mr. Saunders has been doing a good deal of oratorio work during tlie' last few years, as he has sung the tenor parts in the recent Handel Festivals, receiving high praise for his work.

Many teachers before accepting s[?] for pianoforte or violin tu ition make a [?] exanination of each intending pupil's hands. They

Know, that Ungers, wrists, cud palms '•.aro in connection with .Lusic, and that the hand which .lacks symmetry and good ■ propori . tion 1 ca;\.<ot, as a rule, achieve much i .with the pianoforte or the violin, no i:.utter bow great may be the owner's ‘. musical appreciation. 1 When the span , between the first : ngcr ' and thumb is lengthy, the 'yidujforte is the best instrument to • learn.- Chords and octaves are more . easily played on the keyboard, since .. nature has arranged lor roominess at this . particular part of the band. ■ Octave playing .is most laborious to people with short thumbs, since their curtailed length lessens the necessary ■ span. ‘ . Contrary to popular belief,? tong, tazering fingers are undesirable for pianoforte work. Skill in this direc . tion is easily attained' when the .length of thesecond finger from the base of the tip is eipial to the dis tance between the base of-that finger and the wrist. Flat palms often prevent an en enthusiastic pupil. from ever "becom ing a proficient pianist,-. Arched palms,, on the other hand, arec ex tremely.helpful in mastering difficult Vansagesl Pronounced filbert finger tips . are not ideal for the :planlst, .despite the poetic exultation of them* Those : subtle, changes ol tone (Which, make pianoforte solos so.'-delightful !arc drawn 'from the'instrument by ■finger., tips which are' moderjfitely domed. ' ' The Ideal hands (or the vtallnifit differ from those ol the pianist., In stead of the wide span between '.first finger and thumb, there. should he rather an abnormal distance between : the third and little fingers. Width' in -this direction is also necessary,/lor, playing the violoncello. Strong fhut shapely fingers are those which pro duce good music from this imstn. meat.' . ’ ’ ■

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Mr. J. Wilcher, teacher of the violin, piano, and singing, has announced himself in our business columns as having taken up his residence in Lithgow for the practice of his profession. This
articleText:
MUSICAL.

_ Mr. J. Wilcher, teacher of the violin, piano, and singing, has announced himself in our business columns as having taken up his residenco in Lithgow .for tho practice of his profession. This gentleman lias received considerable inducement,

not only from the" town, but from the district and mountains, to permanently settle here. Mr. Wilcher was for a number of years following his profession in Penrith, and, later, for seven years in Orange, from both of which towns he brings the highest credentials and press notices. Being an excellent all-round musician, and seeing a splendid opening' in Lithgow, ho made a start some five weeks ago, and has already worked up a snug business, with others coming on almost daily. As this town lias long felt the need of a professional musician who is a thorough teacher of the violin, able to conduct orchestras, repair and adjust all musical instruments, Mr, Wilcher will find plenty- to occupy his time.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: It will be noticed by advertisement in our business columns that Mr. W. F. Jones, violinist, of Goulburn, intends visiting Crookwell next Monday, in order
articleText:
MUSICAL.

It will be notload by advertisement in our buaineaa columns that Mr. W. F. Jones, violinist, of Goulburq. intends iaitinc Orookwell next Mondev. In order

to interview intending pupils. Mr. Jonea is recognised as one ot the leading violin, ials of tha State, and has received many flattering compliments from world-famous artists. It is hoped he will reaetvo suf ficient inducement to justify regular vis its to Cruokwell. Mr. Jonea has had a great deal of valuable experience with muaioal badiei, and la leader of Goulburn Liedertafol orchestra. A musical society or orchestra would add much to the social life of tha town, and tba visits ot suoh an artiat aa Mr. Jonea undoubtedly should do muoh to encourage some movement of this kind.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: By advertisement in this issue it will be noticed that Miss Frances E. Walsh intends opening classes in Crookwell for music aud harmony on and after
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Bx advertisement in this issue it will bo.noticod that Miss Francos E. Walsh intends opening classes in Crookwoll for music aud harmony on nnd aftor

1-lth Juno next. Miss Walsh presents high ' credentials, and should receive good looal support and encouragement. She is a composer of considorable merit, being tho author of the " Ilka Waltz," of which the Parkes " Western Cham-

pion ' says, " Tho pieco is clever, well- written and catchy— not by any means simple — nnd should prove a valuable addition to tho ball-room music of the day." Other journals, including the Sydney dailieB, speak in equally high terms of tho piece. " The Nationnl Grand March" is another of Miss Walsh's compositions, and is also highly spoken of. There is no doubt that Miss Walsh is a musician of the highest merit and should prove agrent acquisition to our town.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Mr. Percy Grainger is at present in Scotland, where his professional engagements are so many that he may be unable to come to London to-morrow to hear
articleText:
irosidAL. ,

Mr. Percy Grainger, is at present in Scot land, 'where;' Ms professional;; : engagements are so. many that he 'may be unable to come to London to-morrow to hear De

bussy, the celebrated composer, conduct his own works at the. Queen's Hall. The entertainment; nevertheless, is one of spe cial interest to the South Australian pianist, ? whose connection with Debussy dates from the period when Mr. Grainger first., introduced London audiences to the peculiar excellencies of lus compositions by playing them in his inimitable style. Mr. H. Brewster- Jones . spent Christmas in Yorkshire with friends, awl enjoyed some, good skating, as a result of the re cent frosty weather. While in Glouces tershire he played at a recital at Newn ham, near the county town, and the local critics were enthusiastic in their remarks upon, the performance of the South Aus tralian musician. . His. repertoire included; selections , from Schumann's 'Novelktten,' Chopin's 'Nocturne in E major,' Liszt's 'Concert etudyi No. 3.' 'La 'Campahella' (by Liszt-Paganini) . ^and for each item the Gloucester press had'a warmly appreciative word. The Gloucester Chronicle, for in stance, remarked that in Mr. Brcwster Jones the audience were treated to a cbaTn ing musician, and that his various items were executed. with, a brilliance evidently born in the artist rather than merely ac quired. The same paper made special re ference to the excellent flexibility displayed by the pianist in the Schumann 'Nqvellet- teh,'' .where, as The Chronicle put it, the notes ;'werc given with a clearness and due regard to. light and shade in expression, alike charming to the ear.' Chooin'a 'Nocturne' was described as beautifully played and most, enjoyable, as was also the fBaUad m A flat' which' followed. ,Mr. Brewster- Jones's., brilliant performance of the : 'Campanella' gained for him the spe cial encomiums of the local papers and the applause of the audience, which, literally enthralled by his execution, v/as not to be denied in its enthusiastic demands for an encore. The possession of originality' as well as ability was accorded to the pianist by Gloucester'* musical critics. The Glot.. cester Journal- laid special stress upon his considerable powers as an executant, ami reminded its readers that he won Sir Thomas Elder's scholarship before he en tered upon his three years' training at the Rnyal College of Music. Lady Halle, who lately has been making frequent appeaninces before London audi ences, much to their satisfaction, .on Tues day joined with Mr. Donald Francis Tovev in.* a highly successful recital at the Bech 6tein Halk Of Lady Halle's part in the .programme the critics spoke with unstinted praise. ' Her contributions included Brahms's 'Sonata in D '? minor'- and the weird 'Trillo delDiavolo,' by Tartini. to which her perfect technique as well as her 'thorough appredation of the meaning of the piece gave unusual inteiest, and warm applaiiee was evoked. In the encore aelee ;ion — oneof Bach's- violin solos— her pure

tone came out' with marvellous etfect. Signor Toselli, husband of the Princess Louise of Saxony, has had to suifer for public interest in' their romantic stor-', for he recently received a discourteous rtep tioh at a Concert in GenoJ, where, contrary to the announcement, his bride did not. put in an appearance. . The disappointed audience absolutely refused to listen to the pianoforte recital' begun by Signor Toselli. and the storm of hissing and shouts was kept up so vigorously that he had to aban don the entertainment altogether. The death of August Wilraelmj at 63 not only deprives the world of one of the ncat est violinists of the o^e. and the Guildhall School of Music of a valuable teacher, hut destroys one of the few remaining link:; with Wagner, who counted Wilhclmj amon-; his intimate friends. Wagner, in fact, stood as Wilhelinj's professional sixmsor at the Bayreuth Festival.-), where the latter acted as lender of t.he orchestra at the owning festival, and repaid his patron's aid by popularizing Wagner' p strange com positions in various countries. Wilhelmj was so delighted with London's apprecia tion of his violin solos at Queen's Uall that he decided to settle in the Ensh'sli metropolis. His own province of Xa--&3U. however, did not forget him. and when Wilhemj attained his sixtieth year, the anniversary was -commemora-t-cd b.r th-? erection of a monument in hid honour .it his native town of Usmgen. The older generation of- South Australian music lovers will TecoUect his visit to Adelaide and the stronz interest it excited.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The Australian pianiste, Miss Elsie Hall, has made her first appearance in public in Berlin. She won hearty plaudits, and her
articleText:
MUSICAL.

A musical entertainment was given by Miss Keuny's pupils at her residence on Thursday oveling to celoebrate the close of the year's tuition and also the cditribution of the prizes to the succees ful studouts. An interesting programme of vocal and instrumental music was given, after which parlour games were indulged in. Special prizes were awarded to the following pupils who success fully passed the Trinity Ollege and Sydney College examinations in theorotrical and practieal divisions: -Ida Gale, gold-faced medal; Harold Newman, gold-faced medal; Irene Askew; Beryl Korshaw, and Mary Ryan, souvenirs; four being successful in Triniy College theory and fivo in Sydney College practical, which speaks volumes for Miss Kenny's ability ao a teacneher.

articleText: MUSICAL,. Mliss Eva Champion, the promising contralto, who created such a favourable impression by her singing at St. Saviour's Cathedral on Sunday last, has been en gaged by the Goulburn Musical and Opera tic Society to sing at their grand concert on the loth of next month. An opportunity will thus be affotded the subscribers and the public of hearing the prdmising singer, who is undoubtedly the possessor bf a voice of very raie and excellent quality. The cociety are also negotiating with the famous Melbourne singer, Mr. A. E. Bot toms, who is recognised to be the finest baritone in Australia. His appearance here is almost assured.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The Sydney Herald of Thursday says:—Miss Ella Caspers joined last night with other artists and amateurs in a concert at the Concordia Hall in aid of "Our Lady Nurses for the Poor"
articleText: MUSICAL. The Sydney Herald of Thursday says:-Miss Ella Caspers joined last night with other artists and amateurs in a concert at the Concordia Hall in aid of "Our Lady Nurses for the Poor" (Coogee),when a capital entertainment attracted a large audience. The contralto, who now tem porarily resides at Goulburn, but canie down to the capital in the cause of charity, rendered "Red Rose of England" (Oliver) with "At Dawning" as encore. Her reception was of a most enthusiastic character, and she especially realised in the purity and devotional warmth of lher oratorio style theltendelly insistent qualities of Gounod's "O Divine Redeemer." Mr. Marsh Little introduced his own taking baritone song, " Fragrance" (encored), and Mr. Syd. Macdonald was called upon to repeat twice "So-Long," Mr. J. Barr's spirited patriotic lyrics to May Summerbelle's animated march-music.

It is Illegal In Boston to play secular music on che Sab bath. Mr. Godfrey (according to .an ex change) did not know of this particular rule, and ono Sunday afternoon sandwiched a stirring military march between some sacred selections. He was marched off to the police-station,' his name, age, address, ?and occupation wore duly recorded on the charge-sheet, and ho was informed that a cell was In readiness for him unless he could find substantial security for his ap pearance at the Boston Police Court on the following morning. Tho required ball was forthcoming, and when Mr. Godfrey appeared before t'he judge next day he was let off on promising not to offend in the same way. again. Miss Clare Scarr has arrived in England from Sydney. According to the 'British Australasian,' she . is the possessor of a good mezzo-soprano voice, and means to have an extended, course ot itralning with a view to an operatic career. ' ' Many people aro enquiring why Mdlle. Antoinette Trebelli (as wo used to call her) should. havo found ic necessary to alter her professional name, and to nnnear -? in.

tonia DolofoB. Tho necessity for some change (says Saturday's 'Age') was ?brought about by the confu sion which arose between herself and her d 1 s t ihguished mother, the great contralto, who died some few years back. In tho Western States of Ame rica many cele ?brated ' ai-tisfa had been tour ing, such as Santloy, Fbli,

?Atfranl, and others of that generation, 'Whose voices had — to put it. mildly— lost the flrst fresh bloom of youth; and when a concert trip by our present visitor was announced, people said that they had had enough of o|d and passe sihgors— that Tre belli, as all tho reference boolts had It, was born in 1888, and that however good she might have been once, her day was (or ought to be) just about ovor; and they left her severely alone. heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: A grand complimentary concert was given on the 18th instant to Mr. Charles Santley, who will shortly leave Sydney for a musical tour through New Zealand. The concert was attended by his
articleText:
MUSICAL.

A grand complimentary concert was given on the 18th instant to Mr. Charles Santley, who will shortly leave Sydney for a musical tour through New Zealand, The concert was attended by his Excellency the Governor and Lady Carrington, the Earl and Countess of Kintore, Sir Alfred Stephen, and a large number of other important persons, the list of " patrons " being altogether unprecedented and the audience larger than has been seen on any similar occasion in Sydney. The Philharmonic, the Metropolitan Liedertafel, and the Orpheus Societies all gave their services by way of compli- ment to the great English baritone, and the vocal and instrumental performer! were of the best and most esteemed in the colony.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: At the monthly concert of the Orpheus Society the piece de resistance was Beethoven's Opus 16 in E flat, as arranged for pianoforte, violin, viola, and violoncello. The other instrumental selections
articleText:
MUSICAL.

At the monthly concert of the Orpheus Society the piece de resistance was Beethoven's Opus 16 in E flat, as arranged for pianoforte, violin, viola, and violoncello. The other instrumental selections were The " Andante Cantabile," from Tschaikowsky's string quartette in F) (op. 11) ; Sarasate's "Airs Espagnole," for violin; the first movement of Chopin's E minor Concerto, for pianoforte i an "Andante" of Mozart, and an "Intermezzo" by Poussard, for violin. Vocal compositions by Gluck, Handel, Gounod, c were also presented. Miss Florence Menk-Meyer has given another pianoforte recital, and there has also become more of the series of organ recitals at the University.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Mr. Percy Jones is to judge the band contest' at Ararat ;on New Year's Day. The annual entertainment in
articleText:
USICAL.

. Mr. Percy Jones is to judge the band contest' at Ararat ;on New Year's Day. • The annual entertainment in connection with St. Mary's School football team was held in St. Mary's Hall on Saturday week, and attracted a crowded audience. Pennants won by the school in the football competitions were prominently displayed. The programme was varied and interesting, and encores were the order of the . evening. The contributors were Misses M. and N. Bayley, G. Martin and Kathleen Gill, and Messrs. D. Moreton, A. McCartin, J. Munday, J. Stretch and Len. Martin. Miss Parker's pupils also gave their recent Ballarat success, "Jack's the Boy." Under the, direction of Mr. Jos. Jennlhgs, St. Mary's boys gave recitals, part songs, and elocutionary displays in excellent style, the performance being distinctly meritorious, and evoking loud applause. In the absence of Mr. A. T. Curran, president of the St. Mary's Old Boys' Association, who was in Queenscliff, the trophies were presented to the team by Mr. A. McCartin, whose complimentary remarks concerning the boys and respected teachers were applauded to the echo. Mr. D. Moreton acted as musical director, and Mr. Ralph Fraser as piper. At the close, Mr. Jos. .Jennings, in an eloquent speech, thanked the contributors to the programme, and all who took an active interest in the school. He mentioned that, though the school had not won the football competition this year, it had come out splendidly on the scholastic side. Mr. Jos. W. Dobbyn carried out the secretarial duties with conspicuous success.
