heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: At the Marshall-Hall orchestral concert given in the Town Hall on Saturday afternoon a demonstrative welcome was given to Mr. Marshall-Hall on his return from
articleText:
MUSICAL.  

At the Marshall-Hall orchestral concert given in the Town Hall on Saturday after- noon a demonstrative welcome was given to Mr. Marshall-Hall on his return from his European trip. There was especial cor- diality shown on account of his restoration to health after a trying and painful illness. Welcome was also given to Miss Florence Ballara, warmly remembered here — in her student days — as Miss Florence Towl.

The two items for orchestra, The Flying Dutchman overture and a move- ment by Tschaikowsky, were exceedingly well played. The lovely andante from Tschaikowsky's E minor symphony, too, was given in true musicianly style through- out, Mr. White deserving a special word for his playing of the important horn solo. Miss Florence Ballara sang Beethoven's exacting and highly dramatic scena Ah! Perfido. She has dramatic power, but she seemed to be afflicted with nervousness. The next concert is announced for 15th June. Madame. Albani will pay a return visit to Melbourne on the 12th June, after an absence from this country of something more than nine years. She sailed from London by the R.M.S. Marmora on the 26th ult., and after two months concertis- ing in Australia and New Zealand she will go to the Orient with her company, pro ceeding homewards via India, Malta and other Mediterranean ports, Cairo and Gibraltar, concerts being accorded each im portant city. Her world's tour, includ ing the second and farewell Australian tour, is under the direction of Mr. C. H. Gibbons. Madame Albani brings with lier a large and distinguished' supporting com pany, including Mr. William Green, the foremost English tenor; Miss Mildred Jones, a contralto, who during the past few years has made lier way with rapidity; Mr. Hadyn Wood, a favorite English violin ist, who was with Madame Albani on her last season's tour; and Miss Myrtle Meggy, solo pianiste, a'gifted musician, born under the Southern Cross, and who was sent to England to complete her musical education six years ago by generous subscription of the people of Sydney. She is the daughter of a Hobart journalist. Of the star her self little need be said to Australians. Her life history is a record of successive triumphs. The letters "O.M." which now follow the name Albani (although they did not on her previous visit to this city) are for the "Order of Merit," which was con ferred upon Madame Albani three years ago by his Majesty King Edward. Miss Marie Hall is already in Melbourne, the Moana having arrived duly to time in Brisbane on- Sunday. The young violinist, whose fame as an artist has preceded her to Australia, rested a day or two after establishing herself at Menzies', where, with her chaperon and her pianist (Miss Lonie Basch) she has taken up her resi dence, but she will start rehearsing with Professor Marshall Hall and his orchestra almost immediately, in readiness for her first concert, which takes place in the Town Hall on Saturday next (1st June). Messrs. J. and N. Tait have made all ar rangements for what will be a notable event in the annals of Melbourne music. Either the Tschaikowski or the Max Brusclx concerto will be the most import ant work done, and in addition Miss Hall will play several solos. In the following week she will give two recitals on Tuesday and Thursday, and then leaves for Ade laide, returning thence to Sydney. All .expectations regarding the Besses o' th' Barn hand have been realised since they opened in Sydney, where every one of their performances has been marked by absolutely packed houses and extraor dinary enthusiasm. Among many fine num bers t'lieir interpretation of tlie Tannliauser music seems to be one of the most finished in their repertoire, for it aroused intense appreciation whenever it was played, and it carries with it the commendation of Sir Arthur Sullivan, who, in spite of the fact that only brass is used, and the strings, upon which Wagner depends so largely for his effects, are wholly absent, declared that the rendition by the Besses was the best he had ever heard. The band will next week be on tour through northern New South Wales en route for Brisbane and other Queensland towns. When the last mail left London, accord ing to letters received by Messrs. J. and N. Tait, Madame Clara Butt was in Ire land following out the farewell tour mapped out for her. She and ' her hus band, Mr. Kenncrle.v Rumford, had just given three phenomenal concerts at Dub lin and Belfast, and while in the former city they were both guests of the Lord- Lieutenant of Ireland, dining at a State dinner, and afterwards lunching privately with their Excellencies, and accompanying them to the far famed Punchestown races. Mr. Williamson's musical comedy com pany will contain in the two Miss Murphys, of New Zealand, who will both be members of it, a ease parallel to that of the Castles sisters. Miss Amy Murphy and Miss Amy Castles each possess a glorious voice, which

they devote to the interpretation of the more serious class of music, while the younger sisters have a leaning towards the lighter parts of comic opera. The younger Miss Murphy has already proved her worth in that type of character, and her Ser- polette is very highly spoken of in New Zealand. — Mr. Mark Hambourg — who really ought to know— has been discussing the question, "Does it Pay to be a Pianist?" No general isation on such a subject can be of prac tical value, but very safe advice to give to any aspirant for professional honors as a pianist would certainly be, "Don't make the experiment unless you possess very ex ceptional talent 'and an immense capacity for work and patience into t'he bargain." Mr. Hambourg tells of many would-be pian ists of merely ordinary capacity who can not earn .more than £1 a week. And he goes on to say that the pianoforte artists who are malting good incomes are extreme ly few in number, whilst many of the lesser lights 'do not make more than £3 a week in the year, and some a- great deal less. The case of a man who is always hoping to be come some day a great star is very com mon; liis hopes are never realised, and as he makes up his mind apparently never to try to do anything else with his musical gifts but strive to win a big public reputa tion, he often falls into dire necessity. He may be met with singing in the street, or playing the piano at threepence an hour in some public house in the East End.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Right up to the final concert, and beyond it, to the very time that she left Spencerstreet station for Sydney on 27th September, Madame Clara Butt's popularity with
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Right up to the final concert, and beyond it, to the very time that she left Spencer- street station for Sydney on 27th Septem ber, Madame Clara Butt's popularity with the Melbourne public remained absolutely unshaken from the high, altitude it reached during the last few days in that city. The

.famous contralto's final concert aaras attend ed by an audience even larger than that of the previous matinee, and her depart- ture from the hall afterwards Avas made in the midst of hundreds of cheering and handkerchief Avaving admirers. Though Madame Butt and Mr." Ivennerlay Rumford Avent by train, the children preferred the steamer, and Avent over two days previous ly in the Britannia, so that they might settle into their n-3Av home at Potts Point before their elders arriA'ed. Australians, though they are perfectly ready to acept a visiting artist on a Euro pean reputation, prefer, after they have heard him or her, to form their orvn judg ment. That is the reason Avhy Madame Clara Butt can noAV boast of a double fame, -for Melbourne has giA'en her an Australian one,, in addition to the English reputation she had aa'hen she arrived. Her popularity, great, though it Avas aa'hen she arrived in the CommoiiAvealth, increased enormously during her season in Melbourne, and to all .appearances she lias gone to Sydney Avith the combined prestige to start with; in other Avords, she begins in Sydney where she left off in Melbourne. At all events, the box office record goes to sIioav this, for from the first day it opened in the capital of the mother State the booking has re mained consistently seA'eral hundred pounds better than the Melbourne aggregate, extra ordinary though the latter Avas, so that it Avould seem certain that from the financial aspect the Sydney series, which commences ou Thursday, 3rd October, Avas to be better than the Melbourne one. Artistically, of course, it Avould be impossible to improve on the latter. After the Sydney visit and tAvo concerts in Brisbane, Madame Clara Butt returns to Melbourne for a holiday at. Cup time, and Messrs. J. and N. Tait have seized on this opportunity to arrange another con cert, to be giA'en on 7tli November. Messrs. J. and N. Tait gaA'c a benefit to the Besses o' th' Bare Band in Sydney last; Aveek, in some recognition of the splendid Avork this most popular organisation ha.\

done throughout Australasia, and it is grati fying to be able to record that a very sub stantial result aa'as realised therefrom. An interesting concert was giA'en by the Orpheus Society on Tuesday evening in the Toaa'ii Hall, under the direction of Mr. Frederic Beard. This is an amateur or ganisation, hut on this occasion the orches tra Avas strengthened by professional talent. The programme included TschaikoAvsky's Mart-lie Solenelle, given for the first time in Melbourne. It requires more frequent hearing to obtain appreciation. The- Death of Minnehaha, by Coleridge-Taylor, is not exhilirating. The performance Avas not AVitliout merit, both instrumen tally and a'ocally, and the principals, Miss Ledwidge and Mr. LedAvard, obtained the apprecia tion of the audience for their rendering of the solos. Other numbers presented aa'cre the Rienzi's Overture and Wagner's Kaiser Marseh by the orchestra; Wagner's Trauine, played by Mr. Louis Ilattenbach, and Don Juan's Serenade (TschaikoAveky)' sung by Mr. LedAvard. The chorus did some effective work, and Mr. Beard proved his capacity as conductor. Mr. Percy Coward's Saturday night con certs at the Toaa'ii llall are Ave 11 liked. The audience on the last occasion was large and appreciative. Tuneful part songs Avere con tributed by the Harmonists and a party of boy choristers, an excellent series of moA'- ing pictures Avas shown, and songs Avere sung by popular performers. " According to the. Sydney "Morning Herald," one of the earliest arrivals for the aa'inter concert season of next year should be the violinist, Kubelik, supported by Miss Erna Mueller, a Victorian contralto. In June Mr. and Mrs. Albert Mallinson Avill open their season. Mrs. Mallinson will be remembered in Sydney about a decade ago as Mdme. Anna Steiuliauer, a fair-haired Danish soprano of some eminence. Her husband, Avho resided for two or three years in Melbourne, composed the male- voice cantata, Balder the Beautiful, Avhieh Avas produced by the Sydney Lieder- tafel. Messrs. Meynell and Gunn Avill direct the Mallinson tour, and their concepts will be purely, classic in character,

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: In its composition the Royal Artillery band differs materially from the Besses o' th' Barn, which was composed entirely of brass instruments. The
articleText:
MUSICAL.

In its composition the Royal Artil lery band differs materially from the Besses o' th' Barn, which was com posed entirely of brass instruments. The Royal Artillery Band, which consists of 30 performers, is a combination of reed and brass, reinforced with a double bass fiddle and- one or two other orchestral instru ments, enabling it to adequately render Wagnerian and other high class composi-

tions and at the same time to enhance the effect of simpler and more familiar music. The concert on Monday night was a re velation of the possibilities of instrumen tation. Nothing better, and certainly noth ing quite like it, has been presented here before. The combination of instruments gave wonderful variety and fulness of tonal effect, ranging from the bird like fiutings of the piccolos, through the rich, sweet voices of the clarionets, and the golden notes of the cornets to the deep under tones of the trombones. The famous Tann- haiiser march of Wagner was a masterly performance, and so also was the interpre tation .of Tschaikowsky's Overture 1812, while the selections from Maritana re vealed the powers of the instrumentalists in solo parts. A. W. and A. Arlorn (father and son) scored a triumph in a descriptive piccolo duet entitled Two Nightingales, by Roe. Mr. Robert Smith, junior, displayed the potentiali ties of the clarionet in Bender's Fourth Air Varie, and Mr. J. E. M'Evoy, showed himself a perfect master of the cornet in Gounod's beautiful serenade. Every item with .the exception of the last was encored vociferously. The conductor's baton seemed like a magic wand which picks the music out or subdues it to silence, now shading it down to the softest tonal effect and anon rousing it into a cataclysmic volume of sound. The initial concert of Signora Revillo, the Spanish soprano, will take place in the Town Hall this (Saturday) evening, 6th June, and there will be another concert on the. Monday following. The fifth of the series of- Marshall-Hall orchestral concents will he given at the Town Hall, Melbourne, on Saturday after noon next, at 3 o'clock. Two symphonies will he performed — Schubert's Unfinished Symphony, and The Clock Symphony by Haydn. The programme also includes two minuets from the Serenade (Brahms), a concerto for flute and orchestra by Mr. Aniadio, and a concerto for cello and or chestra by Mr. Ilattcnbaeh. A concert of music for piano and violin given last week by -Miss Una Bourne and Miss Nora Kyfiin Thomas was of ex ceptional quality. Miss Bourne has given frequent evidence of her ability and ranks high in the list of Victorian artists. Miss Thomas is an Adelaide girl and lias proved herself a violinist of both gifts anl attain ments. The most noticeable ebaracteristie of her workmanship is her tone, which is extraordinarily full and vibrant. Her into nation is practically faultless, and lier double stopping remarkably good. Mr. John Lcmmone lias received a letter from Madame Melba, in which she confirms her arrangements (made with Mr. Lem- monc before leaving Australia last Febru ary) to visit Australia early next year. This will probably be in April, and via America. It is understood that the great magnet is Madame Mclba's father, now in his 81st year, and the wish to sing all over Aus tralia whilst still in her prime. Madame Melba's secretary finds these two causes a strangely powerful attraction with the prima donna. And lie writes: " What a strange world this is. Hero are both New York opera houses claiming her services; India offering her a season at a guarantee of £800 a night; Canada a season at £500 a night, and a percentage; South America — after a six years' wait — still ready with £1000 a night; and the whole Continent clamoring for her reappearance; yet she will listen to nothing but Australia." Miss Amy Castles, the distinguished Vic torian soprano, is making arrangements to visit Australia with a concert company dur ing next year. The Ada Crossley concert party sail from England on 7th August. The Australian contralto will be accompanied by her hus band, Dr. Muocke, and the other members will he Mr. Foray Grainger, whose mother will also journey to Australia with him; Mr. Leon Sanietini (violinist), Mr. Hamil ton Earle, and Mr. John Harrison. The solo violinist with the Ada Crossley Concert Company, to tour Australia under the J. C. Williamson management in a few months, is Mr. Leon Sanietini, who

boasts, as does Kubelik and other virtuosi, the advantage of Sevcik's tuition. He was horn in Rotterdam in 1886, and be fore he had entered his teens had already made his_ first public appearance. He went to Prague when he was fifteen, celebrating the occasion by composing a fantasia for -violin, and piano. He studied two years under Sevcik, winning universal praise when he appeared with the Philharmonic Society in Prague at the end of his years of study. He gave his first English reci tal in the Bechstein Hall, London, in 1904, and for the best part of last year he was touring with Madame Ada Crossley, al ways making a profound impression wher ever he played. Mdlle! Dolores is continuing her wonder fully successful, career in Europe, and her plans ahead contain so many important en gagements, extending over' such a consider able time, that, so she wrote to her Aus tralian managers, Messrs. J. and N. Tait, a few days , ago, she is quite unable to fix a date for another visit to this country, although she has forborne months now had such a trip in contemplation. Messrs. J. and N. Tait have received news that Mark Hambourg followed up bis success in the Albert Hall, London, with a flying visit of farewell to Paris, Berlin and other musical cent-res of the Continent. He leaves England next week for his Aus tralian tour, which is fixed to commence in Sydney about the middle of July. The Royal Welsh Male Choir, which Messrs. J. and N. Tait are bringing out to Australia in September next, began life under the modest title of the Treorchy Male Choir. But their fame grew and spread with such rapidity that it was not long before they received a command to appear before Queen Victoria at Windsor. They sang there, to a remarkable audience, in which nearly every ruling house -in Europe was represented, and they made a most striking impression. It was after that visit that they received permission from the Queen to call themelves the Royal Welsh Male Choir.

heading: MUSICAL
snippet: Mdlle. Antonia Dolores made her final appearance in Sydney on Saturday at the Centenary Hall, where she had not appeared for many years. She sang I Know
articleText:
MUSICAL

Mdlle. Antonia Dolores made her final appearance in Sydney on Saturday at the Centenary Hall, where she had not an- peared for many years. She sang I Know that my Redeemer Liveth, her devotional rendering of which & famous, and the bril liancy of her bravura style was dis played in the Shadow Song from Dinorak. The programme also included four of TK'nwVa frinsv enntra nnrl rvflinn ninnna

Mdme. Amy Sherwin, who is now touring South Australia on her way to Broken Hill, will open in Sydney on 10th November. Her stay at the Antipodes will cover a period of six months, as she intends to visit all the principal cities of New Zealand. Heix Gorlitz reports to the Sydney press the sweet singer as in excellent voice, and adds that Mr. Arnold Gange, the new basso, lias quite sung up to the splendid press .notices he brought with, him from London.- . Mr. Clement Harvey is.a very .animated pianist, who studied under Teiebmuller at Leipsic, and then, under Sgambati at Rdmel Herr Gorlitz launched him ih London- three. years ago at Qpeens Hall (with full orchestra)-, and . the young pianist " then returned to- Rome to take holy orders.-: However; ! dur- ' ing big. two years'- stay there his piano playing made, such an impression that the Pope expressed the kindly; opinion that he 'would; be justified in following a musical career; The new pianist brings with him an open letter of recommendation from the. Duke of Norfolk. She will -be obliged, owing; to previous fixtures at the Town Hall, to postpone her first appearance in Melbourne until Friday, 30th November. . . .A comic opera, The Emperor, lias been written and composed by W. J.: Curtis- and Arundel Orchard. It will be produced' at the Palace Theatre, Sydney, on Wednesday, 7th November. The scenes -are laid in- a- school of sculpture in ancient Rome and in a Roman grove at sunset, where revels are held in honor of the Festival of Apollo.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The Philharmonic concert in the Town Hall on Tuesday evening was rendered memorable by the production of Elgar's oratorio "The Apostles."
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The Philharmonic concert in the Town Hall on Tuesday evening was ren dered memorable by the production of Elgar's oratorio "The Apostles." This composer takes high rank among living musicians, and his fame has spread widely over the world since the

Dream of Gerontius declared the measure of his ability.- His later work will strength en and maintain his reputation, for though it may not be wholly free from blemish, and furnishes evidence in places of lack of inspiration, the general conclusion will be that its acceptance as a substantial contri bution to musical art is fully warranted. Sir Edward Elgar has treated the theme he has chosen for illustration in its spiritual as pect, and has sought to give expression to the emotions of moods. He has been won derfully -successful "In conveying his mean ing. Apart from the principals, it cannot be said that the production of the oratorio was wholly satisfactory. The ambition of the Philharmonic Society and its honorary conductor, Mr. George Peake, can be com mended, but it "has to be admitted that in this instance execution was not equal to intention. The composer often suffered at the hands "of his interpreters, especially in the chorus and -orchestra. Air. Andrew Black gave a splendid rendering of the part of Judas, and Air. and Airs. Gregor Wood, Aliss Lilian Reid, Air. Horace Stevens and Air. A. C. Bottoms also did satisfactory service. Air. Lemare at the organ redeemed some of the orchestra fail ings. The Philharmonic Society need not, hoAvever, be -discouraged at achieving only a partial success. The opportunity is be fore it to improve on its record. Aladame Blanche Arral, a French prima donna of established repute visiting Aus tralia, who offered a taste of her quality at the Alarshall-Ilall orchestral concert . on Saturday afternoon, will give a song recital and scenes from some of the operas at the Princess's Theatre on Saturday next. The representation should he one of great in terest. Aladame Arral has appeared with sustained success in Paris and other Euro pean centres of art, and in the United States. The last of the Alarshall-Hall orchestral ' concerts for 'the season was given in the Town Hall on Saturday afternoon. Al though the novelty promised— Strauss's Don. Juan— could not be given OAving to lack of rehearsals, an attractive programme was presented, including the Prelude to Lohen- 1 grin, the Leonore Overture and Beethoven's Eighth Symphony. A notable feature of the concert was the appearance of Aladame Blanche Arral, who, unheralded, quickly es tablished acceptance of her artistic capa city. She has a pure soprano voice, admir- ably trained, and she sings Avith dramatic sympathy. Her further appearances vvill be welcomed. On Saturday Aveek a complimen tary concert will lie tendered to Air. Mar shall-Hall. Tlie continuance of Mr; Lemnre's recitals on the ToAvn Hall organ will be much, ap preciated. The performance last Saturday evening quickened the appetite for more, and it. is in. response to general demand that the City Council has arranged for four more to be given, the first -of Ai'hicii— a ma tinee — was on Wednesday afternoon. . A tremendous ovation from an" absolutely packed house greeted— Mdlle. Dolores as. she stepped on the stage -of the Sydney Town Hall for her first concert on Thurs day last week. Nearly every seat in the large building had been reserved days be fore, and every part of the hall was crowded to its capacity. It really seemed as though the audience were never going to let the recital proceed, so long did the applause and cheering continue, and even when it died doAvn every subsequent oppor tunity saw it break out with redoubled vigor. Aldlle. Dolores Avas recalled again and again nt the end of each of her appear ances, and bad to add seA-eral numbers to her programme of English, French, Italian and German songs — in all of which she sang with her customary perfect technique and delicate charm of manner. Thousands of people waited outside the hall at the conclusion of the concert, and Aldlle. Do lores was literally rushed by her Avorship- pCrs as she forced her A\'ay to the waiting carriage, which she reached bereft of many of her costly bouquets, which had been scattered far and wide to satisfy the crowd's anxiety to secure mementos. The second concert, . on the Saturday evening, Avas scarcely, if at all, les3 enthusiastic, and the famous; soprano's Australusian tour un der the direction of Messrs. J. and N. Tait promises to be one -long triumphal pro gress. . .

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Bast Monday evening the young ladies connected with the Central Wesley Church gave a delightful little concert in the hall, Miss Anderson
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Last Monday evening the young ladies connected with the Central Wesley Church gave a delightful little concert in the 'hall, Miss Anderson

occupying the chair and Miss Ringer accompanying. Opening with the chorus, "Come Sweet Morning," songs were sung by Miss Howell, " Love and Hope" ; Miss Nicholas, who sang a beautiful serenade exquisitely, and Miss Lamphee, " Sunshine and Rain." Miss Webb's " Song of Returning " was rendered with fine effect, this song, with which Madame Clara Butt has charmed so many audiences, being by no means easy to give with the exactness it demands. Miss Lou Lou's character song was very amusing, the presenting of her with a bouquet of greenery and carrots affording much merriment : whilst Miss Brockway's impersonating of " An Irishwoman's return from the Dentist," and Miss Hicks' " Rags and Tatters " were recitation items considerably above the average. Miss Symonds also gave a recitation in distinctly meritorious style. Miss Brockway's musical monologue was forcibly reminiscent of Albert Chevalier's " Fallen Star " and she is to be congratulated on her musically artistic powers, The piece de resistance of the evening was the Japanese song and chorus " Chou Kina," by Miss E. Hicks and young ladies. Miss Hicks has a sweet voice if not very powerful, and one felt quite inclined to agree that she was indeed "The Sweetest Little Geisha in Japan." Another item which appealed immensely was Miss Doyle's story of the mischievous school girl who went to purchase a pair of gloves. The last event on the programme was a series of tableaux, illustrated by songs and rendered very effective by illuminations from various colored limelights. Of these " The Rosary " was easily the best. The programme concluded with the National Anthem, following which refreshments were handed round.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: WE are pleased to notice that in connection with the recent Trinity College Musical Examinations, Miss Annie Hartigan, youngest daughter of Mr. P. Hartigan, of
articleText:
MUSICAL.

WE are pleased to notice that in connection with the recent Trinity College Musical Examinations, Miss Annie Hartigan, youngest daughter of Mr. P. Hartigan, of Yass, who is a pupil at the Convent of Mercy, Pairamatta, secured a pass certificate in elements of music, senior grade. The above speaks well for the teaching at the local Convent of Mercy, where Miss Hartigan received the ground-work of her musical education.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: “Are there any musicians in your family?” “Rather. My father is adept at blowing his own trumpet. Mother is equally expert at harping
articleText:
MUSICAL.

"Are there any musicians in your family?" "Rather. My father is adept at blowing his own trumpet. Mother is equally expert at harping on one string. Ma-in-taw has to play second fiddle. Grandpa gives us a solo on his nasal organ without tfee stops, every night. Uncle spends his time whetting his whistle. Harry fa fond of his pipe. Gertie fa forever the changes on her lovers; I'm a bit of a lyre myself."

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The appearance in Sydney of Sir Charles and Lady Halle has naturally outshone all other musical events of late. These great artists gave their first performance here on Wednesday evening,
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Tho appearance in Sydney of Sir Charles and Lady Hallé has naturally outshone all other musical ot'outs of late. Theo great artists gavo their first performance hero on Wednesday ovening, Juno 2 lat. On tho following afternoon, thuy attended, by spcoial invitation, at tho Town Hall, where they woro formally received and wolcomed by tho Mayor of tho city, by whom a largo numbor of prominent citizens and musicians wero subsequently pro-tented to them. Shortly after arrival Lady Halló was unfortunately attacked by rheumatism in ber loft hand, which compelled tho postponement of three concert;, thus causing an interval of eight days between tho first and seeeud performances. Sir Charles Halió has opened eich of the four concerts already given with a Beethoven sonata, having produced those iu C major, D mijor, and O sharp minor, known resjioo'ively as tho " Waldstoin," " Pastoral," and " Moonlight," and that in E fiat catalogued as No. S »f opus 31. Two of the piano aud violin ducts lave also been by Beethoven, namely, the Sonata iu G minor (op. SO, No. 3) ond that in A minor uni Vffsally known as tho " Kreutzor." The most pnmment of Lady Hallo's other selections havo beei Viouxtemps' " Fantasie Caprice," in A, and \" A> Varié," in D ; Spohr's " Dramatic Concerto "

Good appreciation has been shown by to largo audiences assembled each night, und the pulic has shown n discriminating taste, in genorally prferring the host compositions to thoso of lessor woi*i. Miss Annis Montaguo and Mr. Chas. Turnor, who boast considoiablo reputations throughout Aierica and Australia, h aro enlivened tho concerts byvoc.il selections.

heading: Musical.
snippet: The Albury Daily News reports that at the Trinity College musical examinations in Sydney Miss Agnes Caspers, eldest daughter of Mr. H. Caspers, was the only student to attain an
articleText: Musical. The Albury Daily News reports that at the rinity College musical examinations in Sydney Miss Agnes Gaspers, eldest daughter of Mr. H. Caspers, was the only student to attain an advanced pass in the violin classes. Miss Ag nes Caspers and her sister, Miss Ella Gaspers, contributed to the programme at a "continent al" concert given in the sports ground, Albury, on New Year's Eve. The News says:"The chief interest, however, centred in the first public appearance of Miss Ella Gaspers, who won pri mary honoursatthelate Trinity College exami nation in Sydney. This child-she is only 14 years of age-has been trained at the Goulburn Convent School, and th'e musical gifts posses sed 'by the family seem to have reached the level of real genius in her case. Miss Caspers sang 'Asleep on the Deep,' creating such a dis tinct impression that an uiideniable' encore re sulted, and in response she gave 'Out on the Rocks.' Her singing was received with min gled feelings of surprise and delight, thUe great power and beautiful quality of her contralto voice-prich, deep, mellow, and of wonderful compass and evenness of tone-appealing to everyone present There is no doubt that Miss Gaspers is rarely gifted, such power and exqui site quality of voice being seldom fiund in combination, and with fair treatment she should be assured of a brilliant future in the world of music. Up to the present the girl's training has evidently been excellent, her modest and easy bearing on the stage being in itself a passpori to the good graces of any audience of taste."

articleText: MUSICAL. On Friday last Miss Nellie Goodhew sat for an associate examination in violin playing, held by the Sydney College of Music. The young studnt passed with honors, and was com plimented on her work by the examiners. The list played included the andante and finale of the Mendelssohn "Concerto," Vieuxtemps "Reverie," and other difficult works. Miss Goodhew is a pupil of Mr. F. Howard Ussher.

heading: Musical.
snippet: Miss Florence Schmidt, the Queensland soprano, continues her splendid career of success. She has been engaged as sole vocalist for the English provincial tour of the
articleText:
Musical.

MiS3 Florence Schmidt, the Queensland soprano, continues her splendid career of success. She has been engaged as sole vo calist for tho English provincial tour of the great Ysayo and Slgnor Busoni, and later on she will make her debut at the London Crystal Palace Saturday Orchestra Con certs, being also sole vocalist on 'that oc casion.

M'Iss Bertha Rossow was to have sung at two concerts in Lancashire on March 4 and 5, when her compatriots, the Misses Beatrice, Muriel, and Bessie Griffiths, were also to havo been on the programme. The Misses GrimHis give a recital at tihe Birk 'beck Institute on March 21, when the whole programme will he supplied by the three sisters. ' Mdme. Antonio Dolores (Antoinette Tre belli) was to have 'left 'Frisco on Wednes day last for another Australian tour. Tho talented soprano will be cordially welcomed 'back. The late Sir Arthur Sullivan, as all h'13 friends well know, was ono of the most obliging and willing of men, and yet one 1 of the most modest an'd retiring.- J Not many months before his death tho 'groat composer was spending the evening .at tho house of a musical friend of his, who, ?much to SIt Arthur's horror, chanced to have four musical daughters— 'quite prodi gies, Sir Artihur.'t said the hostess; 'quite wonders, I assure you.' Directly after dinner these prodigies commenced show ing their musical abilities. First one sang; another played tho piano; a third ?the violin; tho fourth the mandoline. Sir Arthur listened patiently for two ?hours to the very indifferent performances of these four 'wonders.' Presently the hostess came up; 'Oh, Sir Arthur,' she said gushingly, 'we will give tho dear -UilliiwAn n iioct Tirtn* on fiu'Vinf wMl vnil T»lnv

for us ?' 'Madam,' said Sir Arthur, quito worn out, and utterly wearied, 'I will go on playing what I have been playing the ?whole evening with your permission.' 'Indeed ! Sir Arthur !' said 'the hostess, very surprised. 'What have you been playing, may I ask ?' ? 'Second fiddle, madam !' bluntly said Sir Arthur, 'second fiddle !'— 'Cassell's Saturday Journal.' The meeting of tho Vera Eyton compli mentary concert committee, held at the Australia on Friday night last, made final arrangements for the concert, which takes place At the Centenary Hall on March 20. Mr. Southwell, who is arranging the pro gramme, has secured the services of somo of Sydney's leading artists. , The perform ance will bo beld under the patronage of Sir Frederick Darley, tho Lieutenant Governor, and other distinguished citizens., Tickets ' are being disposed of at a rapid rate, and the committee expect a crowded house.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Mr. W. T. Best the ominent organist, by whom the grand organ in the Centennial Hall was opened on August 9, left Sydney on Monday, October 13, on his homeward passage to London by the s.s.,
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Mr. W. T. Best the eminent organist, by whom the grand organ in the Centennial Hall was opened on August 9, left Sydney on Monday, October 13, on his homeward passage to London by the s.s. Oroya. He was escorted to Circular Quay by several musical and other friends, and on board the steamer there was a large gathering to do him honour and to bid him farewll. During the fort , night Madame Patoy baa aung at a Earles [ of oonotsrts in tbo Centenary and subsequently in

the Centennial Hall. The audiences have, nineo the oponing concert, grown both in numbers and onthusiasm, and so successful have been the results that an extension of tho season is contemplated. The Sydney Philharmonic Society, under the comluctorehip of Slgnor Hazon, gavo a thoroughly artistic rendering of Haydn's " Seasons" on October 8. Miss Lilian Troc, Mr, Armos Beaumont, and Signar Buzzi we're the principals. The orchestral concerts, directed by Signor Hazon, are still main- tained, performances being givoa each week.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Mr. Chas. Santloy and Mt. W. T. Beat have recontly returned here for the purpose of giving farewell performances prior to leaving for Europe, Mr, Santley generously gave his services
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Mr. Chas. Santley and Mr. W. T. Beat have recently returned here for the purpose of giving farewell performances prior to leaving for Europe, Mr, Santley generously gave his services to a special benefit concert last week, organised by Madame Christian in aid of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. He has also given a concert in Goulburn, an inland city some 130 miles distant, where he met with an enthusiastic reception. His real "farewell" takes place this evening.

Two more orchestral concerts have been given since the date of our lost summary.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: ARABELLA GODDARD.—The second Philarmonic Concert of the season took place on the 28th February, at which the appearance of Madame Arabella Goddard was (says Public
articleText:
r MUSICAL

Abasslla GODDARD.-The second Philar monic Concert of the season took place on the 28th February, at which tbe appearance of Madame Arabella Goddard was (says Fublic Opinion) tbe event of interest. Heard in London Or late years but'seldom, her throne of right "that of English queen pianiste-strangely vacated, Madame Goddard's re-assumption .of ber position was an incident of welcome impor tance to the musical world of England. With what perfection of exactness and artistic grace ehe played her faToorite concerto Xo. 4, in F Minor* for pianoforte and orchestra (Sterndale Bennett), it is needless to state. Foreign artists may come and go, always hospitably received and generously appreciated; none the less have we oat own princes and princesses of art, amongst whom Arabella Goddard holds fore most rank. For her charming performance, applauded to the echo, Madame Goddard found lier place still in our hearts, reserved for her too, as long as she may care for it.

FOB. SUSTAINING THE SOUNDS ON THE PIAKO. -Acontri vance for sustaining the sounds on the pianoforte, without interfering with the usual form of structure of the in strument, has (reports the Academy) been invented by Luigi Caldera, of Turin, and recently patented by Messrs. TviyVman & Son, of London. The mechanism consists of a simple and ingenious arrangement of small hammers, attached to a cylinder which is set in motion by a pedal. During the rotation of the cylinder a continuous vibration of &e strings is producied.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The first of the weekly concerts to be conducted by Mr. Percy Coward, late of the Westminster Glee Singers, was held on Saturday evening at the Town Hall, and at
articleText:
MU8ICAL.

The first of the weekly concerts to be conducted by Mr. Percy Coward, late of the Westminster Glee Singers, waB held on Saturday evening at the Town Hall, and at once achieved a success. The programme is popular, and so are the prices. The com-

pany is a good one, and there is great variety in the entertainment. .Nearly every thing given was encored. The new male quartet was much appreciated; so also were the efforts of its individual members — Messrs. P. Coward, S. R. Kimber, E. Grain ger and J. R. Riddell. Mr. Avalon Col- lard's humorous sketches were highly en- ioyed. Miss Elsie Warman, a young Mel bourne soprano, created a favorable impres sion; and the songs rendered by Miss Hilda Green, an Adelaide contralto, were also en joyed. The entertainment was varied by a series of interesting and diverting biograph pictures. The sixth of the Marshall-Hall orches tral concerts will be given at the Town Hall on Saturday afternoon. The chief fea ture of the programme will be the great tone poem Don Juan, by Richard Strauss, given for the .first time in Melbourne. A complimentary concert will be tendered by tlie Philharmonic Society to Mr. Geo. Peake on Tuesday evening next. Messrs. J. and N. Tait have completed tlieir arrangements for the Australasian tour of Madame Clara Butt, who is already in Commonwealth waters, and is due to ar rive in Melbourne on Monday next, the 28th inst. She will .rest a few days after arrival, and will begin her concerts in the Town Hall on 10th September, fol lowing the initial appearance up with four others, one of winch (on the 19tli Septem ber) will be a matinee one. The same pro gramme (four evening and one afternoon concert) will be adhered to for the Sydney season, commencing on the 3rd or 6th Oc tober, and then Madame Butt will go to Brisbane for a very brief sojourn. These journeyings will occupy , her until the end of October, and, with the object of a holi day week at Cup time, Madame Butt re turns to Melbourne in pursuance of her de termination to make her present visit one that will combine both work and play. After the great racing carnival is over the remainder of November will be devoted to Adelaide, Western Australia and Tasmania, and about the beginning of December she will begin her tour of New Zealand. Exist ing arrangements provide that after finish ing her visit to that colony she will return to Europe via Amei'ica. The expenses of the tour will be very great, for Madame's concert party is a very complete one, in cluding Messrs. Carl Barre (violinist), Frank Merrick (pianist) and Arthur God- fray (accompanist), as well as Mr. Kenner- loy Rumford, and, in view of that fact, and the artistic importance of the visit, Messrs. J. and N. Tait have . decided to charge a guinea, half a guinea and five shillings for scats— the same tariff as prevailed for the Melba and Paderewski visits. The effort which Messrs. J. and N. Tait made to have the homeward route of the Besses 0' th' Barn Band altered has been successful, and tlie remainder of their term in Australia may now be apportioned. After the Broken Hill (whither they go at the end of this week) and return Adelaide seasons they will appear at the Exhibition Build ing, Melbourne, during show week for a series of recitals at popular prices (1/ being charged for general admission). A tour of Victorian country towns, with possibly a hurried visit to Sydney, will intervene be fore the band takes its final departure from Melbourne homeward bound. Miss Lallu Miranda, the famous Mel bourne prima donna, has just terminated a strenuous season of grand opera in Nice and oilier leading musical centres. Nineteen years ago Mdme. Melba made her first appearance in England as an oper atic artist in a performance at Covent Garden of Lucia di Laminermoor. By way of commemorating her long association with Italian opera in London the Covent Garden management, writes our London corre spondent, gave a special performance of this classic composition on tlie 17th of last month, and proof of the interest taken in the event was shown by the crowded audi torium. Stalls, indeed, were being sold at £-1 and £5 apiece, so great was the demand for seatB. At a meeting held at Allan's on 10th August by the Friends of Miss Ethel Mercer, violinist, who intends visiting Euroiie to further pursue her studies, it was decided to lender her 11 farewell complimentary concert at the Masonic Hall on Monday evening, 9th September. Offers of assistance were re ceived from a number of prominent mem bers of the musical profession, and a pro gramme is in course of preparation. _.. ;

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The New Zealand tour of Madame Clara Butt is finishing in the usual blaze of triumph which accompanies her wherever she goes. Messrs. J. and N. Tait have had
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The New Zealand tour of Madame Clara Butt is finishing, in the usual blaze of triumph which accompanies her wherever she goes. Messrs. J. and N. Tait have had to arrange for a long list of extra concerts in all the big centres, and if time permit ted would have undoubtedly been able to travel over the same provincial routes as

the famous contralto had already traversed, with the certainty of the same success at tending her. But her stay in Australasia is growing short, and before it ends she lias to give a farewell season in all the Com monwealth capitals, beginning with Sydney from the 14th to the 21st March. Then after a few days in Brisbane she goes to Melbourne, where her visit will commence | on 31st March, and thereafter to Hobart

and Launceston. Adelaide and the West! will be taken on her way homeward, andj she leaves Perth on 4th May, after a tourj of 75 concerts instead of the 25 originally | arranged — truly a marvellous record. I Madame Ada Crossley coming to Aus tralia on a starring tour next September I is confirmed by a letter from the distin- j guis'hed contralto dated 10th January, ex-j pressing her delight at the prospect. Asj soon as Madame Crossley had signed the j contract she received nearly two score of j applications from artists of position for j places in her concert party. Nothing will i be decided in a hurry, however, as j Madame Crossley intends to take the great- j est care to form a strong combination. In | order to carry out her Australian tour (states the "S.AI. Herald") the contralto j has just cancelled Oetober festival engage- ! ments for Norwich, Birmingham and Shef- j field, as well as .about 40 other oratorio J appearances during the (English) winter. Mark Hambourg, whom Messrs. J. and N. Tait have secured for an Australian j tour, commencing about the middle of this year, tells many good stories about his trip to the United States last year, several of I them ilustrating the quickness of the j American intellect to see money in any- thing. It appears that he and Paderewski were travelling through the country at the same time, and as a natural consequence ( their routes occasionally intersected, so | that their respective recitals in a town! sometimes took place 'within a few days of j each other. The inevitable result -was that! both the artistic treatment and the techni-f que of each in regard to the other came in j for a considerable amount of discussion — j the more so as the same pieces frequently j figured on the programme of both. Music critics indeed in some cities raged furiously together concerning the. playing of the twos famous performers, and divided themselves! into Hambourg and Paderewski camps. | This pronounced partisanship of one or thet other gave the manager of a big New York! music hall a Napoleonic idea. He offered E tliem both a most flattering fee if they | would consent to appear for one week at e his theatre and play the same piece within | half an hour of each other. It is presumed j that they would toss for positions, and per- j haps as a finale play at the same time — a j kind of competition in chords. Unfortu-j nately for the business .of the music ball j the. suggestion of its manager was not en- j tertaineil. Others of' a different nature had | also to be declined with a good deal morel reluctance by Mark Hambourg. He was! due in London for a Queen's Hall conecrt j on the 4th January, and consequently had j to: refuse a fee in. all totalling £1200 — once of £400, four others at £200— from multi-S millionaires,- who wanted him to play atf big Christmas week functions they were, giving: . . | According ' to -the "Sydney Morning . Herald," the' musical season of 1908 will be | opened bv the return of Mr. Philip New bury and Madame Emily Spada, who were I to sail for Australia on 24tli January. Their | scheme -is to give a lew concerts in each of | the lavge' towns, returning to London via | the -United States, in time for the English | autumn season. According to the Bri- 1 tish Australasian," the New Zealand tenor is singing better tliau ever, and Madame 8 Spada is also completely restored to health, I so that their prospects of a successful tour : should bo good. Mr. Newbury will bring! with him to Sydney, as organist and | pianist, Mr. Sydney Scott, F.R.A.M., a | professor at the Royal Academy of Music, E London, to which, institution he is oigan | examiner, as well as to the Guildhall School I cf Music. .He is-said to be a brilliant play- E er, and should notably strengthen the! party. jj Mr: W. V Murdoch, the holder of thet Clarke scholarship, who "is pursuing hisj musieal studies in London, appears to bej making remarkably good progress. He was| recently offered a salary of £20 a week! by America's prima donna . to go on tours with her in that country," as her accom-E panist, but had to decline on account of | his scholarship obligations: For a similar | reason he refused an offer from Miss Ada| Crossley to accompany her as solo pianist e during - a three months' tour of Great Bri-r tain Mr. Murdoch has appeared as solo pianist in different parts of England lately most successfully. As he is only 20 years of age his future career appears bright and promising. , ,, j Dr. Edward Woodall Naylor, the winnei i of Messrs. Ricordi's £500 prize for an opera in English % a British born composer, is a son of tlie late Dr. John Naylor, of York Minster, and was born at Scarborough in 1867. He took the degree of Doctor of Music in 1899, and is lecturer in music and organist at Emmanuel College. With re gard to the prize opera, The Angolus, Dr. Naylor says one of the conditions of the competition was that the opera should be lyrical. This he interpreted to mean that the principal musical interest should be in the voice parts allotted to the various char acters, and that the orchestra should be kept in its proper place as a time accom paniment to the action. But he has not relapsed into the old method of writing separate lyrical numbers. The acts are practically continuous from end to end, ex cept where the dramatic situation pre scribes a pause. MM. Messnger and Broussan, the new managers of the Paris Opera, having an nounced that they will open their season with a new setting of Gounod's Faust, seve ral Montmartre poets propose a parody of Faust, with all the characters brought up to date, in aid of charity. Faust would be represented as an elderly rake in a silk hat and frock coat, and a monocle; Marguerite would be dressed in a tailor made costume; Siebel would be a young hooligan, and Valentine a reserve officer, in civil life a grocer. Mepliistophles would be a quack ' doctor, who rune a marriage agency. The scenery would include the interior of an I American bar, a music hall foyer and a 'police station.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The return of Madame Arral to Melbourne, and the resumption of her operatic recitals at the Princess's Theatre for another brief season, has been the
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The return of Madame Arral to Mel bourne, and the resumption of her operatic recitals at the Princess's ' Theatre for another brief season, has been the occa sion of unbounded delight. The only regret felt is that the opportunity of pleasure should be so limited. Madame Arral lias re-

turned from her Sydney tour in better voice, and her capacity as an artiste of the highest quality is even more strongly manifested than before. At the perform ance on Saturday evening there was an audience enthusiastic in appreciation and ready to acknowledge the attraction of the entertainment provided. Good taste had been shown in the selection of the num bers, and there was ample scope given for displaying the variety and the versatility of Madame Arral's accomplishments. The technical difficulties which some .of the pieces presented were so easily overcome as almost to appear non-existent. She has au unrivalled facility of execution, and is ex pressive both in the interpretation of the music and in the histrionic rendering of the character. What she gives us makes us wish for more and regret that there is no possibility of seeing her in opera, with all the advantages of suitable environment. In her opening recital she sang very finely Salome's air from Massenet's Herodiade, also Adam's Si J'Etais Roi and a number of other attractively delivered excerpts. But her crowning triumph was obtained in the selection from Delibes's Lakme, which enabled her to disclose a fine perception and discrimination. The well known Bell Song was given with wonderful effect, and the ardor of the audience could hardly be restrained. The orchestral accompaniments were not equal to the high standard of the entertainment. The second recital was given on Monday evening, and was equally deserving of ap proval. The most interesting item was the selections from Masse's Les Noces de Jeanuette, wherein expression is given to some of the varying moods of love afflicted people. In the Romance, the Song of the Needle and the Nightingale's Song Madame Arral was eloquent in interpretation. Other numbers in the programme which pleased were the waltz song from Audran's Grand Mogul, the Page's air from The Huguenots and the Neapolitan song of Saint-Saens. The orchestra on this occa sion did much better under the direction of Mr. G. Rivers Allprcss. On Wednesday evening there was another fine performance, and the audience was not less enthusiastic in appreciation. Among the selections given were the reci tative and aria from Gounod's La Reine di Saba, . the grand air from Meyerbeer's L'Africaine and a Tyrolean waltz. Micaeli's song in Carmen and the waltz song in Romeo and Juliet were delight ful numbers, and an air from Girolle Girofla pleased greatly. There were nu merous encores. The orchestra played brightly the selection from The Merry Wives of Windsor and the Mignon Gavotte. The farewell appearance of Madame Arral was on Friday night, when in response to many rctjuests the selec tions from Mignon, including the Polaecu, were repeated. We have reason to be thankful for the visit of this cburniiiig French artiste. Dr. Price's organ recitals at the Town Hall, given on Wednesday and Saturday evenings if the building is not otherwise engaged, are a source of pleasure to those who appreciate organ music. The program me is made popular as well as instructive. Madame Maggie Stirling will give a con cert at the Town Hall on Monday evening next. A feature of tlic programme will be the Rhapsodie by Brahms, in wfiicli work Madame Stirling will be assisted by a double quartet of male voices. Haydn's oratorio The Creation will bo given by tbo Philharmonic Society on Thursday next in the Town Hull. Mr. Andrew Black will take part in the -per- fbrmance. A claviola rceital was given dn the Town Hall on Tuesday.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: THE programme, she informed me, was a charming one indeed, From the spiendid Wagner overture (which nothing could exceed)
articleText:
them back now, if you can." MUSICAL.

THE programme, she informed me, was a charming one iudeed, From the spiendid Wagner overture (which nothing could exceed) To the lovely little scheme and the minuet for strings And the latest bit of Dvorak, which made her sigh for wings. Throughout the Grieg concerto her emotion was intense; It seemed to me at times she held her breath in deep suspense; She raved of opus this and that, of Schubert, Bach and Liszt; Beethoven, Brahms, Tschaillowski, and a score whose names I missed. But when at last 'twas over and I led her down the 6tair noticed that beneath her breath she hummed a little air, It was not upon the programme, being commonplace and tuney, And I wondered at the sudden drop from Bach to " Annie Rooney. 1 '

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: "Touch, Phrasing, and Interpretation," by J. Alfred Johnstone; .W. Reeves, Charing Cross. road, London.—Here are combined a series of essays on the subjects
articleText:
MUSICAL.

'Touch, Phrasing, and Interpretation ,' by J. Alfred Jobnstone; W. Reeves, Char ing Cross . road, London.— Here axe com bined a series of essays on the subjects

indicated in the title, with 'Hints on the right interpretation of Bach's Woltempi rirte-CIavier on the Piano,' and 'educa- tional editions of piano classics.' The wri ter apologizes for a seam of levity which runs through his entertaining music mat ter, and he doubly apologizes, for the light treatment of 'so classical a subject is an obvious trap to hold the interest of his readers. Such tactics were unnecessary. The subjects are popular in themselves, and Mr. Johnstone's opinions thereon too appealing to permit a rambling interest. No pianoforte student would be the wors-? for .perusal of these sentiments, and sen dble pianists could be benefited by it. In his earliest phrases Mr. Johnstone rudely unmasks those fetishes which cloud the real understanding of 'touch' as applied to the keyboard. Such misapplied non sense as the 'caressing touch,' 'liquid,' 'entreating,'., 'lingering,' '.'paBaionate,'' 'devitalized,' and 'floating ^touch,' and 'willing of tones from the keys,' are hunted from the lips of all whp read; and the whole 'mystery is exposed1 in. this rational creed:— ^l -believe that, given equal force and rapidity in depressing a key, no varia tions in the manner of its depression, in the modes of touch, can in anywise alter the quality of, ite tone,' Yet the author has ? ae« a pianist of worfd-wide repute

working his fingers hysterically ton the key after depressing it. fully, when the. hammer must' have already left its 6tringr in a manner i similar to that adopted by a vio linist to procure a vibrato -from his string! This was evidently done with the confident hope - of equalling the violinist's effect, whereas, it snowed the folly of study with out, a clear knowledge of the limitations of touch.' In that latter comment is the reason why teachers of the maturest expe rience and students of the slightest, may be advised to read Mr. Johnstone's expo sition of 'toudi.' In dealing with those two all-important features of piano playing —phrasing and interpretation— the author, advances equally 'compiling reasons whf he should be listened to. Students of Ba«h and Chopin, too, will find in him an inte resting friind.

snippet: The concert recently given in Adelaide Town Hall for Miss Eva Champion, the young contralto, who is being trained in Sydney, and who appeared at the last
articleText: IMUSICAL; The concert recently given in Adelaide Town Hall for Miss Eva Champion, the young contralto, who is being trained in Sydney, and who appeared at the last con cert of the Goulburn Mlusical and Operatic Society, was a great social event, and most successful financi lly. Mrs. Bruce, the Mayoress of Adelaide, being the sister of Mrs. Quesnel Isho teaches Miss Cham pion), took a personal interest in making tite affair a semi-public event. Several pro mising singers from Adelaide Conservator ium took part. Mliss Champion, who is a granddaughter of Captain Champion, R.N., Is going to England to study singing after further concerts in Goulbmrn (where Bishop Barlow has promised his support) and New Zealand (her birthitlace). Tue Girls' Realm Guild makes Miss Champion a small al lotance from London, htaving promised to do so if an expert should pronounce her voice a really good one. This was done by Mliss A~da Crosslev.

articleText: MUSICAL. The results have been made known of the Trinity College examinations held in the colonies on 5th June for senior honours (theory.) There are forty-eight from Sydney, five from Adelaide, two from Melbourne, four Brisbane, four Newcastle, three Hobart, two Launceston, and one each Armidale, Ipswich Lismore, Wollongong, and Goulburn, The Goulburn candidate is Miss Kate O'Heir of Braidwood, corresponding pupil of Mr. Percy Hollis.

snippet: The results of the recent musical examinations conducted in Quambatook by Dr Alderson, an examiner under the Associated
articleText:
Musical.

The results of the recent musi cal examinations conducted in Quambatook by Dr Alderson, an examiner under the Associated Board of the Royal Academy of Music, of London, show that the following candidates received the requisite number of marks to en ' itle them to pass certificates : — Elementary Grade DivisiDn — Emily Suttie, Beryl Tinkler, Philo mena O'Brien and Alice O'Neil (piano), Cornelias O'Brien and Harold Williamson (violin). Pri mary Division — May Cottrell, Olive Davis, Phyllis Redgen, Ida Davis and Henry Whitehead (piano) (the last named is only a little fellow eight years of age), Edward F. Ryan, William Ryan, and Colin Cameron (violin). The first named in each division re ceived the highest marks.

Failing; to Enroll.

Three persons qualified for en rolment under the provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, resident at Murtoa, were success fully prosecuted during the week ended the 30th ult., by the Di visional Returning Officer for Wimmera at the Murtoa police court and were fined amounts ranging from 2s Gd to 5s for ne glecting to secure enrolment under the compulsory provisions of the Act.

The late Mr M. Cummins.

A Sandhill Lake correspondent writes Touching the sad cir cumstances surrounding the death of the late Mr Michael Cummins, of KorrakKorrak, a word of praise is due to the heroic part played by three ladies, Mrs Rattray and her two daughters (Mrs Pitt and Miss Rattray), who, not seeing the deceased call fir his paper for some time decided to go to his place and see if anything was wrong. Arriving there just about nightfall Mrs Pitt and Miss Rattray went to the door of the hut and called out if anyone was in, and not receiving a reply they decided to go inside and investi gate matters. After completing thj search with some difficulty, and satisfied by general appear ances that something was wrong they came outside and continued the search for some ,clue, and came upon the dead body. The three ladies then drove to Mr T. F. Hogan's residence, which was 7 miles distant, and informed him of what had happened. Those ladies deserve the highest com mendation for both the benevol ent spirit and heroic courage dis played by them, and our corres pondent states, ho was prepared to say that scores of men would fail under the circumstances de scribed.

Dentistry.

Mr M. L. Thomas, dentist, notifies in our advertising columns that he will visit Quambatook to morrow (Thursday), and Lalbert the following day (Friday).

"Turn Him Out."

We would direct attention to the entertaining drama, "Turn Ilim Out," which will be staged at the local Mechanics' Hall on Tuesday night next in connection with the Church of England. This will be followed by a social evening, with guessing competi tions and supper. The prices are

2s and Is.

Seed Wheat for Farmers.

In a report submitted to the State Cabinet last week by Mr John Gray, honorary Minister, who is chairman of the Mallee Relief Board, it was stated that 2113 applications had been re ceived for seed wheat and fodder in the new and older parts of the Mallee country. Of these, 1218 had come from the newly-settled northern districts. The farmers here were desirous of putting about 400,000 acres under cultiva tion in the coming season, which would involve assistance to the extent of 270,000 bushels of seed wheat and 7000 tons of fodder. The requirements of about 400 new settlers, whose cases were being investigated, were not yet

known. Some of the applicants from the older settled districts in the Mallee, it was said, would probably have their requests for seed refused, as they were well able to manage for themselves. A Distressing Fatality.

On Friday afternoon last George Dawkins, who is employ ed as boundary rider at Juno out station on Canally run, was cart ing wood with a horse and dray. Dawkins put his little daughter, eight years old, on the seat of the dray prior to getting up himself. He found he had forgotten his axe, and went back to get it, when suddenly the horse, which was usually quiet, must have worked the winkers loose, as it bolted with the load. The little girl held on to the reins, but was unable to hold the horse, which pulled the child off the seat, and capsized the dray and the fire wood over her.' When the horse bolted Dawkins rushed up to stop it, but in his endeavor fell, sprain ing his ankle. When he got to to where the dray had capsized, he found his little daughter dead He then carried the corpse to his

home. The body was taken to the morgue at the Balranald Hos pital, and the coroner gave an

order for burial.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The month of January is always an off season in respect of music in Sydney, and there are rarely any important concerts at this hot period of the year. The only event of any note that has
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The month of January is always an off season in I respect of music in Sydney, and there are rarely

any important concerts at this hot period of the year. The only event of any note that has trans- | pired during the past fortnight is the concert of the Orpheus Society, at which a good programme was presented. The two chief pieces of the concert were Beethoven's string trio in G No. 1 of Opus 0, and Rubinstein's Sonata in the same key for violin and pianoforte, catalogued as Opus 18. They were both adequately performed. The programme also included Chopin's 2nd Scherzo for pianoforte solo, and tongs by Schumann, Pinsuti, Blumenthal,

and Salamis.

The work of erecting in the Centennial Hall the grand organ, which was heard in London last year when it was in the factory of Messrs--. Hill and

Sons, is progressing satisfactorily. Most of the heavy work is already in position, and the organ is expected to be ready for the tuner about the end of Match. The formal opening of the instrument by

Mr. W. T. Best will probably be arranged to take place

in June.

articleText:
A " Grand Monster Concert" wis given by Mr Stotieliam of this Town, on Monday, the lstli ult, at the Mechanics' Hall. It was a great .success in every respect— the music guotl, the attendance crowded, and the pro ceeds satisfactory. The Geelong Philhar

monic Society lues not given any public con- ! certs lately, but we believe the usual rehear sals are kept up with spirit, and that the society, although a little crippled for want of funds, is otherwise in a flourishing state. The only new incident in life musical world during the V'yr.iu is the. appearance in Mel ; houvuo of the Misses Mucarthy, two sisten,

I who' are said to possess considerable vocal

talent.'

The last attempt to get up complete ope ratic performances in Melbourne was, like many previous attempts, of the Kind, 'abandoned ; the alleged cause being vjaut of ailllicient patronage, and for this certain ad verse criticisms iu lire Melbourne papers vie re blamed. With a lull perception of tho power of the Press in musical as in other affairs, we take leave to doubt whether; it be

pcssible here, moro than elsewhere, to "w r.te .do\vn" a _ really good performance. At. nil events the gctters-up of the Operas might safely have shown a little more per sistency. very likely the salaries of the artistes were arranged in too high' a key; for, though real musical talent is highly appre ciated here, the colonists cmiuot afford to pay those who 'minister to our amusements iit rates current- in London, l'aris, Vienna, and St. Petersburgh, or even New York or New Orleans.' We have not got the means, and cannot, for many years yet to conie, pretend ability to outbid older countries iii this particular.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Opera is "in the air" from more than one direction, as, according to the "Sydney Morning Herald," Mr. J. C. Williamson is corresponding with Mario
articleText:
I taSICAt.

Opera is "in the air" from more than, one direction, as, according to the "Syd ney Morning Herald," Mr. J. 0. Williamson is corresponding with Mario

Lambardi's Grand „ Opera Company, now appearing at the Teatro Colon, Guate mala, Central America. The impresario on that side offers to send a double cast of principals/ chorus, two conductors, chorus master, ballet master, tailors, dress makers, and a whole staff to the number of 90 people. The combination has an excel lent name in that part of the world, where it has been appearing for some years, but the matter is one that is not likely ,to be settled hastily. The scenes of the arrival of the Pericles in Melbourne were repeated in -Sydney, over 500 Welshmen assembling on the wharf to welcome the Royal Welsh Male Choir, who have had" a most glowing time of it ever since ait' the hands of their fellow country men of the principality. Their. first con cert took place in the Town Hail, Sydney, on Tuesday, and would cer tainly test their powers, for a most varied programme had been arranged foi it, comprising not only several solos by in dividual members/but also such exacting choruses as The Destruction of Gaza, The Tyrol, An Italian Salad, The March of the Men of Harlech and the Soldiers' Chorum from Faust. After the Sydney season, Messrs. J. and N. Tait are sending the Royal Welsh Male Choir to Brisbane. The Melbourne visit commences on 1st October, and their Ade laide one on 17th October. Miss Katharine Goodson will follow up her orchestral concert in the Town Hal), Melbourne on 12th September with two pianoforte recitals in the succeeding week, under the management of Messrs. J. and N. Tait. Mdlle. Dolores was approached by Mr. J. N. Tait almost as soon as he arrived in London, as to whether she could again visit Australia. She replied, however, that at the present time her work in Europe and Great Britain was arranged for so far ahead that she did not care to make any definite plans to come back to Australia. In connection with' the approaching visit of Leo, Jan and Mischel Cherniavski, the publication of a letter from Ysaye, .who is acknowledged to be the foremost and most brilliant violinist of the day, will prove especially interesting. II? says: — "Having had the pleasure to hear the trio Cherniav ski, as virtuosi and musique de chambre, 1 am happy to affirm that never in my life have I heard any children so completely gifted in every artistic respect. I am con vinced that they will go very far and will be artistes of the first rank in the near future." The Harmonists Male Quartet will, give their first invita tion concert "in the Masonic Hall on Wednesday, 16th September. Amongst the artists assisting will be Miss Louise Croucher, the clever Leipzig violin ist, Miss Elsy Treweek, Miss Ruby Drew and Mr. Jas. H. Davey.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: At Mr James Orr’s Emporium, Burt-street, Boulder, there is to be found as fine a collection of musical instruments as is to be seen in any shop in Western
articleText:
honored. MUSICAL.

At Mr James Orr's Emporium, Hun street, Boulder, there is to be found as fine a collection of musical instruments as is to be seen in any shop in Western Australia, and at (.rices that simply astonish the expert. This Ims been brought about mainly by the fact that Mr Orr imports direct, and has all his goods purchased in London and oil the continent by his own agents. Yesterday afternoon in making an inspection in company with Mr W. L. Harris, who is first violinist in Heinick's orchestra, Adelaide, and gained second place for the Elder scholarship of music at the Adelaide University, that gentleman was simply astonished at the excellence of the tone, workmanship, and all rouud quality of the violins in stock, and assured Air Orr that the music shops in Adelaide did not sell so reasonably. There is also a wide selection of mandolines, banjoes, concertinas, flutes, clarioneltes, tifes, and violin furnishings. Mr Harris, who is a first class musician, expiessed the highest approval of the assortment and our musical representative quite agrees. Mr Orr is launching out into lints hitherLo untouched on the fields, and is giving to the Boulder all the advantages cf a metropolis
