MUSICAL

••Nuclear”, an all Australian musical will open in Sydney In March of next year, starring Australian artists Carole King end Rodney Stewart

Musical director, Brian King, husband of the leading lady, had handled all arrangements for the

show.

Stage Director, Ronnie Arnold, is promising a "spectacular to take Sydney theatregoers of all ages by storm.”

Carole King established her reputation hi 1966-67 when three of her hit songs made the top ten. She was a member of the "Executives” singing group, formed by her

husband.

The group travelled all over Australia, spent two months in America at the end of 1969, and then returned to Los Angeles to take up a recording con tract, in September 1971.

Rodney Stewart, born in Sydney, has' spent the last three years, writing music and plays. “Nuclear” will be the first recording and theatre production.

“Nuclear” came to the backer’s notice when it was presented as a workshop production by Pact, the Experimental Theatre Group in December 1971.

heading: Musical.
snippet: M. Czerby, whose compositions for the pianoforte are well known and highly esteemed by connoisseurs all over Europe, has published a Pianoforte School, on a very large scale, which, while it will
articleText: M. Cierny, whose compositions for the piano forte are well known and highly esteemed by con noisseurs all over Europe, has published a Piarrnfurte School, on a very large scale, which, while it will add very much to his own reputation, must be a most valuable acquisition to all who study that in strument, whatever their degree of proficiency may be, and whether they cultivate it as amateurs or as professors. The work extends to three volumes, of which the first is devoted to a course of lessons, commencing with the easiest and most simple, and proceeding by careful gradations to that degree of mechanical skill which is requisite to a certain command over the instrumenft, and as a preparation for the higher departments of study. Each lesson is accompanied by descriptions calculated to meet every difficulty by which the learner can be en countered, all remarkably clear and intelligible. Nearly the whole of the second volume is devoted to the art of "fingering," and demonstrates how in dispensable its entire mastery is to the attainment of any thing like perfection in the player. However dry and repulsive it may appear-whatever time and labour may be required, and these are immense-the ordeal must be passed through. Of Mr. Czerny's merit in this part of his work it may be enough to say that he has adorned this purgatory of the musical artist with all the graces of which it is susceptible. It is his third volume, however, which more par ticularly distinguishes him, and will make his " pianoforte school" the most refined in Europe. We may recommend to special notice, as illustra tions of this remark, his chapters on the proper manner of studying a piece, and on the execution of slow and brilliant movements, on impassioned and characteristic movements, and on playing in public. But the whole of this volume, which leads into the absolute arcana of the art, if the student have genius and industry enough to follow in the path pointed out, must be daily and nightly perused and exer cised in. It is evidently a frank disclosure of all that the writer knows, and a boon to his profession which will cause his name to be borne in grateful recollection.-Times. IsTrrTUTIro OF MýUSICAL DonREEs.-The era in which, in this country, the science of harmony be came raised to such estimation as to be ranked among those mental acquisitions which entitle their pro fessors, not merely to the character of learned men, but to high academic honours, will by all who have sense aridd taste enough to give music its due value be considered as very important. In the year 1463 Heury Habington was admitted to the degree of Bachelor of Music at Cambridge; and about the same year Thomas Saintwvix, a Doctor in Music, was made master of King's College in that univer sity.-The Mllusical lVorld.

heading: Musical.
snippet: At the Trinity College examination, held at Clare on July 10, 1905, the following pupils of the Sisters of St. Joseph, Kooringa
articleText:
Musical.

At the Trinity College ex amination, held at Clare on

July 10, 1905, the following pupils of the Sisters of St. Joseph, Kooringa,

were successful : — Intermediate grade (harmony) Miss Hettie Perkins, pass ; Miss N. Melligan, pass ; preparatory division, Miss Alice Hiddle, having obtained 95 marks. The meritorious achievement of these young musicians tell how carefully and well they have been trained by the Sisters, who have had a series of triumphs by all pupils sent from the school for examination.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: On the present occasion of our monthly budget of Australian news, we have a greater number of interesting musical items to chronicle for the information of our European readers than has been our lot for some months
articleText:
MUSICAL,

On the present oooaslon of our monthly budget 01 Australian news, we havo a greater numbetof interesting musical items to obronlole for the information of our European readers than has been our lot for Borne month* past. From the time of the cessation oi the Italian opera, no opportunity was afforded of hearing anything approaching to a good muBioal entertainment ; but sinoe the departure of the last mail tbe presence in Sydney of many vocal and instrumental performers, ad led to the unattractiveneBB (»xoept on ocoasions) of tbeatrloal en- tertainments, have given an impetus to musical events far above their usual powers of allurement. On the 23rd ultimo, Mr. Frank Howson oommenood a serien of operatic concerts ; the first part consisting of the first Act of Balfe's opera, "The Rose of Castile," oomplete, with solos and oonocrted mueia; the seoond partf mieoellaneouB oporefio selections, rendered by the Mieses1 Emma and Clelia Howson, Madame Sara Flower, Messrs. F. Howson, Sussmilch and Grossi. The Miases Howson have had the advantage of oonstant praotiae undor tho eye and oare of their father. Their pleasing voices, adapted to tbeoonoert-room of moderate size, and their remarkably oorreot intonation, enable these dover young ladies to bo a oradit to their well known parent. Madame Sara Flower's assistance was invaluable, and tbe conoert was, in evory way, a aucoess; but muoh inoonvenienoe was experienced for want of a oonduotor. Vocalists are at a nonplus when illness or other cause prevents the attendance of Charles Packer, the only valuable accompanyist in Sydney : at home in every kind of music, and ready for the caprice or the peculiarities of any vocalist on any occasion. The seoond of tbeao oonoerts was given on the 6th instant, with the same company, and inolnded the first and seoond aots or " The Rose of Cattile" and a seleotion. The third will take place to-morrow, and oonsist of the

entire opera.

Master Alfred Anderson, our juvenile but talented native pianist, gave his first concert at the Exchange, since his return from the Royal Academy of London, on the 30th ultimo. The programme was very excellent ; good music, and well performed ; and a large audience repeatedly testi- fied their entire approbation. The executants (in addi- tion to the beneficier) were Madame Sara Flower, Mr. F. Ellard (tenor), Signor Grossi (basso buffo), Charles Packer (pianist), and Mr. D. Callen (bandmaster and violinist); the band of the 12th Regiment also played some of their excellently arranged selections, with their usual precision ; and, what is more, for a military band, gave the overture to Mendelssohn's "Midsum- mer's Night's Dream" very skilfully. The opinion ex- pressed by those who had heard Master Anderson pri- vately, as to his real genius, was fully confirmed ; he played classical and light music, solo, and in a duet with Packer (" L'Etoile da Nord", Osborne), and a duet for pianoforte and violin (by Dussek), with Mr. Callen. All that is wanted is maturity of his young powers, and the knowledge-only to be acquired under the greatest masters-how to use them to the best advantage,-together with that hearing of the execution of artists of various schools, not to be obtained in this oountry; we are therefore pleased to bear tint some of our connoisseur! have a plan on foot for raising a purse to enable Master Ander- son to pursue his studies In Europe.. We may mention with the greatest praise the exeoution at tbii eonoert or " Ah'quel giorno," by Madame Sara Flower, and of "Durch die Wälder," by Mr. F. Ellard.

Signor E. Grossi, a favourite vooalist of the Bianchi opera company, who has constantly assisted at the en« tertaiaments of others, himself gave a miscellaneous vooal and instrumental entertainment on tbe 9th in- stant, wbioh, as waB its due, waa well patronised. All the artists already named assisted, in addition Mr. Brooks, the harpist, and Mr. Farquharson. A long pro- gramme of popular muelo was sung in a manner far abovo mediocrity.^

During thtfl period various musical intermezzos were held at tbe Victoria Theatre, for individnal benefits; at these appeared Mr. Farquharson, not only the brst basso wo have had in Sydney, but a true artist. Some enemies (possibly) of Mr. Farquharson, had brought into circulation a report likely to injure him, as to certain remarks represented to have been made by bim, and an attempt was made to oppose his appearing in public. But the publio, always on the ti io of justiop, gave so determined an opposition to this attempt, that the en- thusiasm in Farquharson's favour was boundless,-an enthusiasm that also shewed that the publio who vi lit our places of amusement bave no wish to be annoyed ty interruption from the few who make these places the orena for bringing forward private resentments. Since thon Mr. Farquharson gave successful entertainments at the Australian Library, and during the past week, at i the Theatre, his benefit having taken plaoo last

evening.

Tbe Philharmonic Sooiety, whioh, sinoo its last ap- pealing report, seems to have beoome quito renovated, and to praotiso unflinchingly under the new conductor, Mr. Callen, gave one of the best concerts of tbo season on the 13tb ; the orchestra (strengthened by members of the military band) per- formed four pieces (including a symphony of Haydn's) with good precision. It is a pity that moro instrumental amateurs cannot be induoed to join ths society, so that their material moy be equal to the execution of the best music, without having recourse to the " popular " school. The German Glee Club sang two pieces; Madame Sara Flower, Beethoven's ''Adelaide," and a oavatlna bv Meroadante ; Sir. Farquharson, an aria by Handel, end Master Anderson played a fantasia (Maritana) by Prudent. This catalogue evinces tho improved tone of muslo adopted by the Rooiety.

Oa the lOtb, tho Vocal Harmonic Society, taking advantage of the presence in Sydney of two snob voaalists as Sara Flower and Farquharson, gave an e-xtra ocnoert-Mendelssohn's "Elijah"-which, notwithstanding its length, was listened to with un- wearied attention and admiration throughout. The singing of Farquharson in the " Elijah" muslo ii above praise, and will almost render a future representative diBtosteful to the general publio ; Sara Flower sang the oontralto SOIOB; Miss Brady, an agreeable native vocalist, the soprano air "Hear ye Israel;" Mr. F. Ellard, the tenor solos (very tastefully); and tho princi- pal parts wore further sustained by Madame Flora Harris, Mrs, Cordner, and somo amateurs ; the ohoras, exoellently trained under Mr. Cordner, and bril, liantly nsaiBted by Mr. Packer as organist, is fully equal to any body ef amateurs of equal standing.

The Misses M'Carthy, whose debut wo noticed in our loBt summary, are still in Sydney, but have not sinoo then appoared in publie.

Madame Carandini arrived in Sydney yesterday from Hobart Town, and there is somo hopo that we shall have operatio performanoos, snpportcd by Mesdames Carandini, Sara Flower. E. and C. Howson ; MossrB, Farquharson, Ellard, Howson, and Grossi. At all eventB tho very general wiBb is father to the thought.

snippet: THE programme, she informed me, was a charming one indeed, From the splendid Wagner overture (which nothing could exceed)
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The programme, she informed me, was a charming one iudeed, From the Bplendid Wacner overture (which nothing could exceed)

To the lovely little scheme and tlio minuet for strings And the latest bit of Dvorak, which made her sigh for wings. Throughout tho Grieg concerto her emotion was intense; It seomed to mc at times sho held her breath in deep euspenso; She raved of opus this and that, of Schubert, Bach and Liezfc; Beethoven, Brahms, Tschaillowski, and a score whose namea I miseed. But whan at Inst 'twas over and I led her down tho stair I noticed that beneath her breath she hummed a littlo air, It was not upon the programme, being commonplace and tuney, And I wondered at tho sudden drop from Bach to " Annie Rooney."

snippet: Miss Addie Hamilton, a Sydney vocalist, sang at Madame Nevada's concert at the Crystal Palace, and met with a good reception.
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Miss Addie Hamilton, a Sydney vocalist, sang at Madame Nevada's concert at the Crystal Palace, and met with a good reception.

IMPERIAL PARLIAMENT. During the current session of the Imperial Parliament private bills relating to railways, canals, tramways, gas, electricity, and water number 214, involving £95,744,257 of capital. Railways and canals account for 70, against 82 a year ago, and cover 713 miles of now line (against 705), estimated to cost £41,332,081, against £40,484,570 last year. Tramway bills number 37, relating to 205 miles of line, and requiring £3,550,447. Electricity is represented by nine bills, only four of which state the proposed capital, which is £0,125,000. The D5 gas and water bills involve the outlay of £44,738,749, or £34,758,324 more than similar hills in 1898, the London County Council's Welsh water scheme largely contributing towards this increase.

AITLY NAMED. Speaking to a San Francisco reporter recently concerning the death of Lieut. Angel Hope Freeman, of H.M.S. Tauranga, at Samoa, Mr. James MacMahon, who was a guest on board the Tauranga during an island cruise of over a year ago, said " We went from Australia to the New Hebrides, thence to New Caledonia. It was while we were at Tanna, the notorious home of cannibals, that Freeman earned a sobriquet. There had been a murder or two ashore, and we had, as a matter of course, to support our end of "the white man's burden by burn- ing a few villages and arresting some native chiefs. Freeman went into the business with unusual vigour, and as Captain Brown stood on the bridge of the Tauranga beside me he exclaimed. "We must call him the destroying angel in

future."

Poia-AiiLi: RAILWAY TELEPHONES.

The railway authorities in Auckland have now completed a railway telegraph along the whole line from Aue I; fund to Pareroa and the Thames. They have a portable telephone on each train, from Morrinsville to Rotorua, so that in the event of any accident on the incline from N gate. to featuring telephone communication could be established, and similarly on the eastern side of the ridge. A telegraph line has also been carried along the North Auck- land railway, from Auckland to Helen, ville, and a portable telephone by train for communication between Helensvale and the Waitakere tunnel. These steps will increase the safety of the working of the lines, and will be especially useful in the case of running night trains to Rotorua.

COST OF FEDERATION.- The Sydney Daily Telegraph, constant in antagonism to the Federal movement, says that the Finance Committee reported 3-5. 4' The primary cost of Federation to her (New South Wales) would be about £232,000Jover and above present expenditure, and 2. "The secondary cost would be increased taxation through the Customs of between £130,000 to £1,480,000." Mr. Wise calculates the " primary " cost (as we do at 3/7 per head of the population ; we also calculate the " secondary " cost at 18/11 per head. The totals are, of course, the i Finance Committee's, the percentages are ours and Mr. Wise's, and may be easily worked out by any member of the public from the committee's own figures quoted above. The position of New South Wales, therefore, is as under :-" Primary cost of Federation," £232,000, or 3/7 per head; secondary cost," £1,250,000, or 18/11 per head. Together, £1,48 2,0s), or 22/0 per head.

TniitHTY ORATORS! - Parliamentary government is not taken too seriously either in Austria or Hungary, and a wager made last month in the Hungarian House of Deputies is not likely to increase the respect in which it is held. The Cabinet Minister Visontai was to speak first at the sitting, and as he is usually long-winded, a special request was made to him to cut his speech short. M. Gyori.an Opposition deputy of the Extreme Left, undertook to give the Minister a bottle, of champagne for every minute which he cut off from the half hour allotted to him for his speech. On the other hand, M. Visontai promised to give the deputies of the Extreme Left a bottle of champagne for every minute over the half-hour. When he was on his legs, however, he forgot the wager', and spoke for an hour and twenty minutes. Consequently he had to hand over 50 bottles of champagne to the members of the Extreme Left. As soon as M. Visontai's speech was over the restaurant of the House was full of excited deputies bent on a carousal at the expense of the long-winded minister

COME u LfiOUY VOTING.-Thecoiwmttceof the Landtag (Provincial Assembly of Lower Austria appointed to draw up a scheme of franchise reform, has unanimously recommended that the exercise of the suffrage should be made compulsory on all qualified electors. It is proposed that a fine of £2/10/ should be imposed on every elector who, without adequate reason, does not vote at a Parliamentary or local election.

articleText: MUSICAL. Successful competitors for the Grace scholar ships at the State Music Conservatorium gave a concert oa Friday. Miss Dulcie Huxtable, win ner of the Singing Scholarship, carried off the honours amongst the seniors by the charm of her voice in an expressive rendering of "Softly Sighs." Strictly ipeaking, the famous aria demands a voice of grand opera calibre, but though on the stage this singer would please in comic opera she contrived to use the vocal means at her disposal with so much judgment that the few connoisseurs present were as pleased as the general body of the audience.

articleText: MUSIBIAL. Readers attention is drawn to Mies Amy Castle's appoearance at the Oddfellows' Hall, Golbourn to-morrow evening. This young lady who has had magnificont receptions in Melbourne and Sydney will elg Tosti's Good-bye, Qoi La Voee and by epecial riqeest Home Sweet Home. Mtle Elgenie Boland and Miss Jessie McKellop from Bydney also will sing. Mies Boland is asid to possess a rich contrallo voice and in merit comes close to Miae Ada Crossley. Leading looal artiste will also appear. In their report of Miss Amy Castles' mati. nee at the Sydney Town Hall yester. dsy the Sydney . Morning Herald says : -Those who arrived at the Teon Hall at hallfpast two found closed doors and a dnase ?ass of people that extended book to the pavement in George. street. The side ,ntranees were available for the holders of reserved places, and here, again, a awaying crowd jostled on the ample space of the atnir w,,ya outside and filled the cerridors inside the hall. Alth-ugh Mr. F. Aegenhbayater (honorary manager), with the energetic as. aistaoce of Mr. M. Meagher. did all that was osesiblh to meet the oevenie-nv ol sedat J sun,- aenu=,on was unavoidable. The wonder is that there was not more. T'he general determination to be present led to such an nadience as has hardly yet been seen at the Town Hall, oeen at politiosl gatherings -certainly at no afternoon meeting of any hiod. Not only was every seat filled, but people blocked many of the gangways and in the gallerie' the people clustered like been against the white aorhways and even stood or sat "(as in the eastern gallery) on the window-sills and in the niches intended for statnary. The choir-seats were thronged, ladies preponderating there as elsewhere. Three or lour girls eat upon the top of the harmonium and others upon the grand piano. If 5000 people can be squeezed into. a chlm. her intended to hold barely 4000, they may be supposed to have found standing room. Mise Osatlos has been feeling keenly the strain of the past two months no that daring her stay in Sydney she has been frequently indisposed; but she past sueoeessully throegh the ordeal of facing snoh a vast audience, She sang Coenon'e Lavely Spring with sweet. noes and power, and being warmly encored gave a pleasant rendering of Winds sn the Trees (Goring Thomai). Later, Miss OCatles who was loaded with flowers, rendered with feeling Toati's Good-bye, with Home, Sweet Homoe as eoere. Miss Castles will arrive in Gonlburn by' the afternoon train to-morrow. The MoAdoo Georgia Minelrels, who are now playing to large audiences in the Palnee Theatre, Sydney, are billed to appear in the Oddfellowe' Hall, Gonlhorn, in about a fort night.

snippet: Miss Sylvia Blackstone, Miss Maud Fitz-Stubbs, and Mrs. R. J. Hogg played several extras at the Masonic Ball at the Town Hall on Wednesday night. Master Raimund Pechotsch, the young Australian
articleText:
Qfftu0ica£ *Bc$oe#*

Miss Sylvia Blackstone, Miss Maud Fitz-Stubbs, and Mrs. R. J. Hogg played several extras' at the Masonic Ball at the Town Hall on Wednesday night. Master Raimund Pechotsch, the young Australian violinist, takes a grand benefit to-morrow night (Sat- . urday) in the Town Hall, prior to his departure for Europe. The principal artists of Sydney have kindly consented to appear.

The Musical programme for the first afternoon at the Shakeperian Fair is to opened with a Piano Solo by Miss Sylvia Blackston. Miss Marion Llewelyn is to sing *' Swiss Echo Song ' by Eckert ; Herr Rud Holken renders w The Wedding March' from ' Mid summer Nights Dream ' ; Mr. Paul is down for a song and Miss Aida Hatchwell a recitation. A brief Farce ' Who's who ? ' is also on the list ; the parts being1 taken by Messrs F. L. Hodgkinson, Hodge, and C. W. Anson, Miss Mabel Hogg and Miss Lulu Waters. The fourth annual concert given by the pupils of Mr. Frank E. Downs attracted a crowded audience at the Y.M.C.A. Hall on Wednesday evening. Miss Flo Shepherd carried of the honors by the musical quality of her mezzo-soprano voice, her easy production, and refined taste in ' The worker.' After three recalls the young lady repeated a portion. Miss Harrie Lipman, was very successful in her rendering of the famous aria. Miss Sara Isaacs, rendered admirably the difficult ' Regnada nel Silenzio,' from ' Lucia.' Miss Ada Charlesworth sang with taste ' Softly Sighs, and Miss Daisy Davies, although suffering from a cold, gave very pleasingly ' Nobil Signor.' All these singers were recalled. Misses Timbury, Ray, Josephs, Messrs. Alfred Mitchell, J. Bonnington and L. Johnson also contributed to the programme.' Professional assistance was accorded by Mr. Laurance Phillip and Mr. Harry Leston. Mr. Phillip was recalled for Tsarf's ' Reverie,' in response to which he gave his own transcription of 'Oh, Promise Me.' As an encore to Raff's beautiful 'Romance op. 26,' Mr. Phillip added Tsarf's 'Russian March.' Mr. Harry Leston contributed Sir Edwin Arnold's ' He and She,' in his best manner, and, as an encore, ' A Smart Family,' to which he imparted many droll touches of humor. Mr. E. E. P. Truman accompanied the majority of Mr. Down's pupils. When Handel was blind he composed his ' Samson,' in which is the most touching of songs-, 'Total. Eclipse.' He sent for Beard, the most popular singer of the day. 'Mr. Beard,' lie said, ' I have made a song which I cannot sing as it ought to be sung, but I can tell you how it ought to be sung.' And then he sang it with most impressive pathos. Beard stood listening in silent wonder and admiration. When it was ended, he said with tears in his eyes, 'Mr. Handel, I can never sing it like that.' This anecdote, not recorded in common biographies of Handel, used to be told by the late Edward Fitzgerald, whose letters have recently been published. :

Bumor has it -that the names of the first couple to use the new chuppa are known.

articleText:

Mr.SlmsReovos, Who has been granted a Civil List pension of £100 per annum in recognition of :his vocal ability, commenced his career as orcanist of North Crny Church/ Kent, at' fourteen years of ago; His, first operatic success in England was at Drury Lane in 1S47, when he appeared as Edgardo in Douizcti's 'Lucia,' having performed the same part In Italian at Mi lan.' His splendid singing in Handel's ora torio, 'Israel ' In Egypt,' at tho Norwich Festival in 1S4S, at once secured him the fbremost'positlon as a singer of sacred mu sic, -and as. an operatic and ballad. vocalist ho has been unrivalled for nearly halt a century..1 Mr. Sims Reeves, who is eighty one years of age, has been seriously ill tor some months past.

It is;a- curious coincidence (says London I'SUge'.') that the name of an Australian singer: recently added to the Covent Garden company should be Miranda, as that is tho name of the Spanish grandee,, the Marquis Casa-Miranda, who married years ago one of the greatest- of the century's prlmo donne, tho Swedish nightingale, Christine Nllsson. riadame Alelbn Divorced from Her Husband. Tho San Francisco 'Call' of April 11 con tains the following:— GALVESTON, Texas, April 10. Charles F. Armstrong, tho husband ot Madame Melba, tho famous opera singer, obtained a divorce in the Stute District Court-.on Thursday. The proceedings were conducted very quietly, nnd every effort was mado to keep them from thonows naner' men. ' Tho plaintiff in his petition

alleges that he has boon an actual bona llde inhabitant of Texas -County and of Gnlve'ston since May; 1S95;, that the plain tiff and defendant were lawfully married in December, 18S2, in Australia, and lived together as husband and wife until 181)4, when the defendant roluntnrlly, without cause, left him. with tho liitoiition.ofaban donmont, then and there declaring, that she would not live with him -any longer. Armstrong also alleges that ho has Invited her to live With him .as hls::wlfe, and that sho has refused to do so' He snys ho has obsorved his marital obligations,, and al ways supported defendant In good style, and conducted himself 'lovingly .' towards her. Tho only child born ot the marriage is a son, 10 years old, now, living with the plaintiff. - '- ? ? ' Through her counsel Madame Melba made a denial of the allegations 'of the plaintiff. Sim was not nrcsont In person, and -her

counsel was appointed by the Court.1 After the dcnlnl was filed tho^Court entered a decree of divorce in favor ot tho plaintiff. Armstrong is tho owner ot-lhe Buena Vista Rancho, in Kansas County.. He1 is the son of the late Andrew Armstrong, of King's County, Ireland. By the decree of divorce the Kansas County Rancho is adjudged tho separate property of Mr. Armstrong, and the custody of the boy awarded to him.

JEAN GERARDY'S RECITAL. In tho majority of instances when wo havo been visited by stars, liberal allow ance has invariably been necessary for the 'nii-fllnf' nrn

pensitics of the man in advance. In the case of Jean Gerardy, the 'cellist, who made his ap pearance at the Town Hall last uight, however, the artist fully carao up to ex pectations, than which no greater praise

coum do awara ed. Gorardy is certainly a wonderful master of his Instrument, and each of his contribu tions created tho wildest enthusiasm. No pcnulno lover of music should fail to hear him. for his playing is an artistic feast. M. Gnrardy was assisted by Miss Kingston, an accomplished soprano, an;1. Herr Edouard Scharf, solo planlEt end accompanist ?' The career of our distinguished visitor has been a remarkable one. He has been on tour ever cinco ho was twelve years of age. At seven years old he began studying the violoncello with Bollman, of the Hcckman Quartet, of Cologne, who is the only teacher from whom young Gerardy has ever taken a lesson. At hardly eight and a half years of ago ho won the sceon'd prize for progress in his art, and three years later, tho first prize medal was voted to him by acclamation. Jean made his first public appearance in Liege in 1SSS. Direct^ ly after he played at Spa, Lille, Alxla Chapelle, and in Antwerp, where he per formed the trio of Rubinstein, in. conjunc tion with Paderawokl and Ysaye. ?'?'? When only thirteen years old he played with the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, of which Hans Kichter is tho conductor, the youngest artist ever adjudged worthy, of tho honor, and all musicians know that RIchtor de mands absolute perfection. Six ycarj ago Gerardy made his American debut in New York. \ ? . ' The second concert will be given to morrow nigh't. . ? * *^ * - ?

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: At the two orchestral concerts given during the past fortnight several important works have been heard, the following being the most notable:— Beethoven's grand "Eroica" symphony was
articleText:
MUSICAL.

At the two orchestral concerto given during the past fortnight several important works have been heard, the following being the most notable: Beethoven's grand "Eroica" symphony was performed in its entirety, as well as the Allegretto from the Eighth Symphony (in F) of the same composer. Of Wagner there has been produced the " Tannhauser " Overture, and the Prelude and Entr'ncto from " Lohengrin." Of Mendelssohn, the Scherzo from the music to "A Midsummer

Night's Dream " ; of Weber, the " Oberon " overture ; of Rossini, the overtures to " William Tell " and " The Siege of Corinth " and of Liszt, the arrangement of his " 14th Hungarian Rhapsody." Max Bruch Violin Concerto in G minor (op. 20 has also been very successfully produced. Other compositions, by Ponchielli, Delibes, &c, have been included in the programmes. The performances have been generally excellent, and the concerts have attracted large audiences.

The monthly concert of the Orpheus Society was also successful The principal works performed were Tschaikowsky's string quartette in D (op. 11 and Beethoven's " opus 16 " piano quartette in E flat- that arranged from his original quintette composition. Other instrumental and vocal selections by Handel, Beethoven, Mendelssohn, Sterndale Bennett, Kowalski, etc, were included in the concert

The Metropolitan Liedertafel Society gave a concert last week, at which Morcadante's " Mass " for male voices and orchestra, and various part songs and solo selections were performed. The Sydney Liedertafel also gave a concert last evening, being the first concert of its ninth year of existence. Besides several part-songs contributed by the male choruses, the amateur orchestra of the society played the Adagio from Mendelssohn's "Scotch" symphony.

noted makers. American Stanway's, famed Krard's, , and other popular pianos, are to be seen in handsome and various designs. 'A showcase, containing a collection of Unosey's band instruments, stands near the entrance,

and close by other cases containing dainty music folios and artistic music stools in plush. The latest songs in single copies, or made up in handsomely bound volume. You are recommended to call and inspect this grand display.

snippet: St. Augustine's Band played selections at the Mount Moriac sports on Saturday, and also gave a delightful concert on Sunday &t Queenscliff.
articleText:
MUSICAL.

St. AUgustKne's Band played selec tions at the Mount Moriac sports on Saturday, and also save a delightful concert on Sunday at Queensclifl. Mr. Percy Jones has returned from Sydney, where he judged the band contests under the auspices of the New South Wales Bands' Association.

There were three grades, ana nis awards pleased the bands and gene ral public. Mr. Jones' comprehensive judgments were also of great value to. the bands. Rozeille Band wop the A grade contest, South Sydney Band the 13 grade, and Goulburn Light Horse Band the C grade. Gus Cerezo and T. Hatherton, formerly ot St. Augustine's Band, are now members of the South Sydney Band. Another old St. Augustine's boy, Harry Lar sen, isi §lso in Sydney, and is doing well. He is regarded by Mr. J ones as the finest euphonium player in Australia.

snippet: We have received from Mr Bradshaw Major one of his latest compositions, “ A Romance for the Pianoforte.” Mr Major has
articleText:
Musical.

We have received from Mr Bradshaw

Major one of his latest compositions,

“ A Romance for the

Pianoforte.” Mr Major has composed

several pieces before, but this

decidedly eclipses all hie past efforts.

Mr Major has a soul, and he succeeds

in inoculating it into hie compositions.

“ The Romance ” has been

played in public several times and

accorded an excellent reception. It

is dedicated to Miss Mary Strickland,

and was played at Government

House on two occasions. It contains

a flowing melody in the bass, and

this melody is constantly being repeated.

It goes beyond saying that

“ The Romance ” will be popular.

Teachers who have played it say it

is an excellent piece for pupils. The

piece may be obtained at Messrs.

Walch aud S oub’ aud Hood’s.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: An Australian national song has long been needed. Many have been written; some very excellent productions, but none have caught the public taste as
articleText:
MUSICAL.

An Australian national song has long boon needed. Many have been written ; some very excellent productions, but none have caught tbe public taste as an expression of national sentiment. The Musical Association of New South Wales, having received a donation of £250 from Farmer and Co., are offering two priaes of £100 each for (3) verses, and (2), musical setting of those verses,

suitable lor the purpose. Conditions for the first competition can be soon at the office of this paper. Adjudicators at Welsh band contests have something to contend with if they arc strangers to the language of the principality. At the annual contest at Carmarthen tlie winning bands in Class A were: -Gwaen-cal-Gurwen (1) and Ystnlyfera (2); in Class B. Pontvates and Cwmanmian bauds cam^ second and third; and in Class C. Llanelly, Llanndilo. and Rhosyberem came in tliat order. Other competing bands were -- Mynyddygareg, Brynamman, and Tondypandy.

The Mayor of Oakleigh (Councillor A. C. Westley). on behalf of the resi dents, on Saturday afternoon presented tho Oakleigh company of Senior Cadets, area 47a, C battalion, with a full com I dement of instruments far a drum and tuglo band (four kettledrums, two dragoon drums, one bass drum and four bugles). Additjsses were also given by Councillor J. T. Stoke (president of the Shire of Muigrave), Councillor W. J. Andrew (Oakleigh), and Mr. A. G. Han son. Captain A. H. Wilmott, officer commanding the company, received the gift. The cadets, headed by the Oak leigh Brass Band and the Drum and Bugle Band of the A and B companies (Caulfield, marched to the Parfc Reserve, where there was a large and representative assemblage. Among the officers present were: —Captain Durrant. brigade major; Lieutenants McDonald. Pratt, Cobby, Benson, Hamilton, Jones (company com mander), and Captain E. E. Bryant, area officer, Tbe company, which num bers close upon 200. marched past, and executed various evolutions.

Beltana is getting quite a name for really enjoyable music. Tbe last concert in the schoolroom drew a packed house. heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The Marshall Hall orchestral concert on Saturday afternoon was memorable for the farewell appearance of -Fraulein Heinze, a member of the last German opera company.
articleText:
MU8ICAL.

The Marshall Hall orchestral . concert on Saturday, afternoon wnsriemp'ralfiq-fbr the farewell- appearance: of Fraulein . Heiiize, a roeniber of the' last German opera company. She has a glorious voice, one, that lends it self specially to emotional expression; and

she is in every sense of the term artistic. Tschaikowsky's Fantaisie de Concert was capably treated by the 'orchestra, and mag nificently played by" tlie pianist. _ Herr Scharf's main opportunities are in the cadenza, of the opening movement— which literally bristles with executive difficulties — and in the opening of the andante. At the close of his task the pianist was recalled again' find again— a compliment richly merited. The set of variations by Brahms on a ;'theme of Haydn bears repetition, not once only, but . again, and yet again. In genuity of rhythm, felicitous orchestral color, delightful harmonic changes- -every device, in fact, of tlie art whereof Johannes Brahms was such a past master — combine to make this work a rich mine of wealth to all who will study it, and a glorious boon to those whose knowledge of it is derived merely from listening to its per formance. Mr. Marshall Hall and his orchestra gave a fine -rendering of a fine work. Mozart's Jupiter Symphony was. not quite so successful in : performance, goiqe of the more delicate "embroidery" which ornaments the lovely andante missed, its wonted effect, and tlie con trapuntal work in tlie glorious finale might at times have been clearer. The accom paniments to' the vocal numbers were well done; and the whole concert, "which was liberally patronised, proved one of the best: that has yet been given under this manage ment. The seventh concert is fixed for Friday evening, 10th July. . 'A new company has been selected by Mr. George Musgrove for the production of light operas in Australia. Included in tlie company, which has sailed for Aus- traliaj are Miss Stella Gastille, Messrs. Wilson, Enbroke, Snazelle and Clements. The operas will be produced under the direction of Mr. Locknane. The ( com pany is under engagement to Mr. John Wren, who lias . completed ar rangements for the production of a series of the best of the light operas which are recognised in the musical world as works of established reputation. When inter viewed concerning the new company, Mr. Wren said:"Mr. George Musgrove left here for London a few months 'back with a commission from me to secure the services of a number of artists fully capable of sustaining leading parts in a revival of opera bouffc, and the best of the more serious works of the eompose're whom the present generation designate as tlie 'old masters.' The season will open in Les Cloches de Corneville, and Mnritana. La F-ille du Madame Angot, The Lily of Killarney, The Bohemian Girl, and others of equal fame, will follow in duo course. In this venture the Theatre Royal firm is not concerned. I have "personally ' undertaken it, ' and the interests involved are mine alone. The company will he known as the National Opera Co., and with the exception of seven English artiats engaged by Mr. Musgove. it will be mnde up of our own people, every one of whom will be afforded opportunity of advancement. Tin's, statement applies to. .every individual member filling subordinate positions in any one of the separate departments, but par ticularly to the chorus, for it is in that direction that recruits will be looked for, with whose aid the musical direction, is sanguine enough to believe it may be en- abled to build up a company which will be .national in every sense, and from every point of view." Miss Eileen Hodgson, ii well known Eng lish- operatic artist, has been engaged as prima donna of the National Opera Com-: pany. Miss Hodgson is said to possess- high merit as a singer, , and has held lead--

Mai— BO— — B— g— — — MB ing positions in English opera organisations. At the London Royal Academy she secured some of the most coveted honors for opera tic singing. Miss Eileen O'Brien, a young Victorian soprano, lyas tendered a farewell concert in the Town Hall on Tuesday night-. She leaves for Europe about the begin ning of September, to place herself in the hands of Madam Marchesi, to whom she is recommended by Madame Melba and Madame " Clara Butt, both of whom hold the opinion that the Melbourne soprano will attract an unusual amount of attention on the Continent. At Eastertime Miss O'Brien appeared successfully in thivElijah production with Madame Clara Butt, and, besides being well known on the concert platform, she has for some years filled the position of soloist in St. Francis's choir, a position she relinquished' on Sunday. Madame. .Ada Crossley is telling some ex cellent : stories about her experiences, on tour in Great Britain in the early part of this year. One of the best relates to an ingenuous letter she received from an auto graph hunter, who wrote her as follows: — "If you autograph "post cards of yourself, will you please autograph enclosed? I have a collection, ..which includes all the best actors and actresses, but few singers. . I received the -autographs of the following ladies for 9d. (and then follows, a list of names), but I am enclosing 1/ to. you, as .oratorio singers are generally considered a little higher than actresses"! . . Madame Crossley, indeed, gets a good deal of fun out of her correspondence, for she is al ways being addressed in some queer way. She has been called "Mrs. Mutiny"- (the nearest approach to Muecke. an Irishman could, achieve), Madame Grosslej'rMuleke Ladyships and Madame Francisque Minclc- er. - "'"/ . Madame "Clara Butt (Mrs. Rumfoi'd) and Mr. Kennerley Rumford, who recently returned ' to London after, a highly successful tour in Australia and New Zealand,. appeared at a concert in the Albert Hall on 'Saturday, evening, and were given a great welcome. The programme included Mr. Rumford's Maori stJng, Wai .ata Poi, which he sang with much success during the Australasian tour. According to a . London paper, the seventy-two concerts which Miss Clara Butt gave with her husband, Mr. Kenner ley Rumford, in Australia and New Zea land brought, in £51,000. Miss Lalla Miranda, , the Victorian soprano, who was recently engaged for the grand opera season at V Coven t Garden Theatre, made her appearance in a leading role on Saturday evening, and was .accorded an enthusiastic reception. Mark Hamboui-g considers that the life of a concert grand piano is, ox' should be, a re-,- markably short one. "I would never play \on the same piano in public more than fif teen times, and occasionally I have only been able to use an instrument at half- a dozen recitals," lie told an interviewer re cently. Some of the eulogies passed upon the. Royal Welsh Male Choir, soon to be intro duced to Australia by Messrs. J. and N. Tait, by prominent musicians are worth quoting, as showing' the unanimity of opinion which obtains concerning it. "I' have never heard the National Anthem sung with such feeling" (Sir Walter Parrat, .organist to the. King); "The best perform ance by a male choir . I have ever heard" (Professor Atkins) ; "The voices were rich and powerful, intonation , perfect, profound fce.ling and tlie -rendering compact and in spiring" (Dr. Frost), are three of the most striking enconinnis passed upon the choir's performance at different times. Mr. Joseph Bennet, musical critic to the London "Daily Telegraph," wrote:— "Your blending ot" voices is .marvellous'; and Signor Randcg-' ger supplemented .this with, "I have never heard better voices in England or on the Continent. The tenors especially were magnificent.' Sir Joseph Barnby once re ferred to. their efforts as "the finest speci men of singing I ever heard in xny life," and that famous Welsh writer, Maelgsvyn, called it "overpowering in its magnifi cence." The box plan for Mr. A. C. Bottoms' farewell concert - at the Masonic Hall on Tuesday, 7th July, is now open at Glen s. An excellent programme has been prepared, in which he will have the assistance of Miss Edith Fowler, of Tasmania, Miss Mercy Fiitton, Mr. Harold C. Smith and Jlerr Louis Hattenbaeh. Advices, received from Sonth Africa state that the Cherniavski . Brothers, the Russian musicians, who are to. give a series of con cert recitals in Melbourne in August, have had to extend their stay three times the length originally ai-rangod. The houses they are drawing eclipse those of any other attraction that has been put before the South - African public. The three brothel's are members of a famous Russian family who have had. tq flee from their native country for political reasons. Mr. Edward Branseombe is directing the company, and the Melbourne music lovers will no doubt be given a treat. Their Excellencies Lady Talbot and Sir John Madden have granted their patronage to the Melbourne Chamber Concerts, which will be given by Madame Christcsen, Mr. Geo. Weston, Mr. F. 0. Schieblicli and Mr. Herman Schraedev in Glen's Hall, com mencing on Wednesday, 8tli July. Miss Una Bourne and: Here Louis Hattenbaeh will also assist. The box plan is at Glen's. Miss Ruby Sainton-Dolby's concert will take place at the Town Hall on lGtli" July. Miss Sainton-Dolby is to be assisted by Madame Maggie Stirling, the full strength of . the Lyric Oehestra ' and other Well : known:- artist3'i".!i'.".: /'/;

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The Royal Victorian Leidertafel gave a smoke night concert at the Athenaeum on Monday, evening. It was a very pleasant entertainment, and some of the solo
articleText:
MUSICAL

The Royal A'ietorian Leidertafel gave a smoke night concert at the Athenaeum on Monday, evening. It was a very pleasant entertainment, and some of the solo vocal ists were to lie specially complimented. Mr. G. T. Morplict lias a remarkably good baritone voice, and he uses it well. Mr. R. AA7. Millar, too, is an exceptionally fine bass, anyl he was perhaps tlie most striking success of the evening. The tenor soloists were less successful . (an exception being

made in the case Of Mr. A- Wiftton Jack, a veteran, who fitly and capably "kept his end up" in Abt'a charmingly conceived, part song On the AVater, with its effective hum ming accompaniment by the choir). ' llerr llattenbaeh 's cello was in frequent and de lightful evidence. The part ' songs .were, without exception finely sting; , with ad mirable effects of light and shade, and with generally unimpeachable intonation! Mr. Ernest AArood conducted with marked effi ciency, and Mr. Mansley Greer! ,riiade a helpful accompanist. ' - The next concert of the Philharmonic, So ciety will be given in the -Town -Hall on Monday evening, 10tli August,_when Sir Edward Elgar's latest oratorio; The King dom, will bc performed by the society's chorus and augmented orchestra. The principals engaged- are Miss Liilian Reid, Aliss Elva Rogers, Mr. Jas. Wade and Mr. Horace Stevens. Kubelilc, whose tour in New Zealand has been a, series of- triumphal successes, cables that he returns to Melbourne on 22nd'inst., and that lie is looking forward with keen pleasure to his reappearance before the Melbourne public at his concerts on 25tli,' 27th and 30th July. i On an application by Hugo Gorlitz that Jan Kubelik be made to give , security that lie would not leave New Zealand without leave of the. -Supreme Court pending the hearing of an -action hi which plaintiff claims £3000 damages for breach of con tract, the judge' held- that it had hot been showq that defendant's absence would pre- verit plaintiff carrying oh the action, and the motion was dismissed. . . Mark. Ilambourg,' now well on his way to Australia for his tour under the direction of Messrs. J. and N. Tait, is such a bird of passage that no city sees him for long; but ho has a home of his own, to which not so. long ago he added that essential re quirement " of domesticity, a wife, the daughter of Sir Kenneth Muir Mackenzie. In' his home he has had one room set apart wholly for his own use. It is on the first floor, and in order that lie may practise at any hour of the day or night without dis turbing the sleeping members of" the house hold, it is shut off from . the rest of the house by padded double doors. On the walls are pictures in oil and water color, as well as in. black and white, the gifts of many friends; and in the, room, too, are preserved, the pianist's -treasures .gathered from all corners of . the world.- ' The greatest is a manuscript of Beethoven's, the out line of a composition with notes as to what, lie intended to do with it. Originally it belonged to Liszt, who gave it to Madame Marie Brandt, and Madame Brandt in her turn gave it to Mark- Ilambourg. ; The London press criticising Victor Busst's first pianoforte recital, refer to him as another of Australia's gifted sons, with a perfect command of the keyboard, excel lent touch, and as playing with marked in telligence. ' v "o- . Mr. A. C. Bottoms, a- promising singer about to visit England, gave his farewell concert at the Masonic ITall -on Tuesday night, .assisted by Miss Edith Fowler, of Tasmania; Miss Mercy Flitton, Mr. Harold C. Smith and Hcrr Louis llattenbaeh. Mr. A. G. Bottoms has a naturally good voice, and has been through a sound and wise course of training. lie should there fore profit largely by his proposed visit to the old world centres of art. In his sing ing at- his farewell concert Mr. Bottoms achieved a genuine artistic success. Miss Edith Fowler, a Tasmanian singer, showed tlic possession of a clear soprano voice. Miss Mercy Flitton sang a Hindu Song, by Bemberg; Herr llattenbaeh gave 'pieces by Haydn, Popper and the quaintly- named Drdla. Mr. Harold C. Smith not only supplied the ' piano accompaniments throughout the evening, but likewise played the Liszt paraphrase of Schubert's Hark! tlie Lark, and I'aderewski's Polonaise. Miss 'Frances Allitsen, one of -the most modest aud retiring of women, albeit the composer of such splendid ballads as The Song of Thanksgiving, has written a new. song for Madame Ada Crossley, which the Australian, contralto will sing .out here dur ing her forthcoming tour under the .1. C. AAfilliamson direction. AVriting to Madame Crossley the other day to thank licr.for in cluding her new composition in her pro grammes, Miss Allitsen said, "It is a great- joy to me. to have my songs sung in Aus tralia. I always find the people so kindly, genial and human—and you, dear friend, are just the happiest sample of them. You have given me great joy in my friendship with you." Another famous musician to in terest himself in Madame. Orossley's tour is Sir Charles Santley, who has written ai% Ave Maria specially for her to sing. . Record houses have been the rule wher ever tlie clever Russian musicians, the Cherniavski Brothers, have appeared. The season in South Africa brought in nearly £10,000 in six weeks, and, their utay there has had to be even longer extended. Tlie Australian season will commence in Mel bourne in the middle of September. We have received the prize list for the Grand National Eisteddfod of Australasia (South-street competitions), which will be held at Ballarat in October next. The cash prizes total £1400, appropriated as follows: —Band contests. £500; choral contests, £300; vocal and instrumental music, £200; open seenes, elocution and calisthenics. £225; Highland pipe hand contests and Scottish events, £50. The entries close on '8th August, and prize fists, text books audi all information can be had on application to Allan's Music AVarehouse, Colins-fltrect. .

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The first of two concerts given by Madame Melba takes place at the Town Hall to-night. The programme will appeal to lovers of music. The great soprano will
articleText:
MUSICAL

The first of two concerts given by Ala dame Alelba takes place at the Town TT>11 to-night. The programme will appeal to lovers of music. The great soprano will sing The ATad Scene from Hamlet-, Am-

broise Thomas; Chanson-Soir Paien (with flute obbligato), Georges Hue; The -White Sea Alist, Landon Ronald; Nymplies et Syl- vains, Bemberg; and Ave Alaria (with cello,, piano and grand organ), Bach-Gounod. Air. Andrew Black will sing The Prologue, from Pagliacci; Lassen's It Was a Dream; Kor- bay's Hungarian song, Had a Horse; and Gia la luna, Rossini. Aliss Una Bourne will play piano solos Barcarolle, -Schytte; and Polonaise in E, Liszt. Ilerr Louis Hat- tcnbach will give a cello solo, Hungarian Rliapsodie, Popper; and Mr. John Lem- mone will play the flute solo Wind Among the Trees, Briceialdi. Kubelik, whose wonderful mastery of the violin has made him one of the greatest figures in the world of contemporary musi cians, is back again in London after a long absence. There is the same feminine in terest being displayed in the young Bo hemian, notwithstanding the fact that he is married and the father of twins. Kubelik is the essence of discreet gallantry. Once he was asked by a reporter, inquisitive for "copy," if he was mobbed by females wherever lie went. AYith a sigh of resigna tion tlie violinist confessed that this was so. "And what country have you found the worst?" asked the journalist. Kubelik smiled and refused to be drawn. "Well, tell me where the women are most atten tive?" put the reporter with Alachiavellian subtlety. The violinist looked .at his ques tioner humorously. "The most courageous women I have ever met with were in America," was his diplomatic reply. "But since you have married?" "It has made no difference," answered Kubelik, with an other sigli. According to the "Sydney Aloming Herald." Herr Emil Grcdor and Fran Gred- er, of the German Opera Company, intend settling in Sydney. Herr Greder joined Herr Slapoffski in rehearsing the chorus for nine operas in about six weeks, a feat lie has never seen performed in other parts of the world. Encouraged by the musical talent on all sides, which yet needs instruc tion of a highly specialised character, Herr Greder now proposes to settle in Sydney, and with the assistance of his wife, who has had four -years' experience in opera at "Vienna (her native city) and Berlin, he will organise, some kind of up to date operatic selib'ol on the best Continental system. A favorable account is given of the artis tic progress of Aliss Rita Hope, a young Victorian of musical ability, and not so long ago a member of the Alelbourne Con- servatorium. The "Daily News" of 1-lth October states that at the Bcchstein Hall Aliss Rita Hope, a pupil of Leschitizky, gave a most promising pianoforte recital. The young Australian pianist has tempera ment and unquestionable technical gifts, and her touch is sympathetic. When she reaches maturity an an artist Aliss Rita Hope should have a well defined place as pianist.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Kubelik will give the first concert of his Melbourne season on 29th May, to be followed by two more on 1st and 10th June. He will be accompanied by his wife,
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Kubclik will give the first concert of his Melbourne season on 29th May, to be followed by two more on 1st and 10th June. He will be accompanied by his wife, the Countess Czalcy, a member of one of the oldest families in the Bohemian nobilitv.

It is only six seasons ago since he. made his London debut as a pale-laced youth just out of his teens. No one knew hint, and he was practically unheralded. He. is de scribed as having made his appearance with modesty and shyness — not the result of nervousness, but from humility. At the end of his first season he had won Lon don; at the termination of his second sea- Son he was acclaimed one of the most ac complished violinjts the world had ever s«en. He has gone on making steady pro gress with his art, "and he comes to Aus tralia at the very zenith of his fame. Mr. Charles Saunders, the English tenor, gave another concert at the Town Hall on Tuesday night, when his programme included, a number of popular selections, such as My Queen (BlumentliaJ), Sicilirma, from Cuvalleria Rusticana, and The Mac- gregors' Gathering. Miss Clara Robson also appeared. A matinee concert .was given on Wednesday. The recital given at Glen's Hall on Thursday evening showed that Mr. Ernest Toy has improved out of all knowledge, and is now undoubtedly a violinist of ad mirable quality. His double stopping in the Porpora Sonata was wonderfully good; and the difficulties of Wieniawsky's Sher/o Tarantellc were skilfully overcome. Spohr's dramatic concerto was excellently done, and Beethoven's Romance in G was a really good piece of classical workmanship; and the added number, by Drdla was given in finished style, also another encore item by Cowell. Ernest Toy is a local product of which Australians may feel proud. Mr. Ernest Toy, the well known violin ist, who nic-t with much success at liis first recital, again appeared at Glen's hall on Wednesday evening, when lie played Clio- pin's Nocturne in D flat, Vieuxtemps'a Con certo in A . minor, Bach's Prelude and Fugue in G minor (for violin only) and other interesting works. Mr. Laver'a invitation concert, given at the Town Hall on Monday night, was an interesting performance. His pupils showed many evidences of ability and good train ing. Miss Lois Zttckcr did well in the first two movements of Rubinstein's Concerto in D minor, but the third was palpably beyond her powers, bliss Minnie Bull put some really good work into the Concerto in G minor by Saint Saens, but Mr. Harold Smith did not quite come up to expecta tions in Grieg's work in A minor. Miss Lois Zucker showed a nice touch in the second movement of the Rubinstein, but in the second subject of the andante her ar peggio embellishments lacked clearness. Miss Bull and Mr. Smith displayed great

talent, but there was a general impression- that a little too much was attempted. The orchestra did more than respectably in its share of the performance, especially in the overture of Beethoven, entitled Weibe des Houses. The fourth of, the season of Marshall- Hall orchestral concerts will be given at the Town Hall on Saturday at 3 p.m. The programme includes Beethoven's No. 3 Piano Concerto (with Miss Emily Dyason as pianist) and variations on an original theme by Schubert, which is to be per formed for the first time in Melbourne. Two popular overtures — Midsummer Night's Dream of Mendelssohn and Leon ora No. 3 of Beethoven— will also be per formed. On 24th May Aladamp Melba will cele brate the twentieth anniversary of her first appearance in opera at Covent Garden— the beginning of a brilliant career happily- still in its zenith. She means to keep the occasion by "giving a popular concert in some big London hall to -the poorer people of the great city." The King and Queen will be present at this historic concert, their Majesties having graciously informed Madame Melba to that effect. Madame Clara Butt telegraphed to Messrs. J. and N. Tait from Fremantlo on the day the Mongolia left that port:— "Fare well Australia and New Zealand; we shall never forget your kindness, and we hope to renew the friendship some day.'.' Signora Revillo, the brilliant soprano, who is to be introduced to Australians by Messrs. J. and N. Tait in the Melbourne Town Hal on 6th June, was married in the Philippines, whither she was sent out bv her parents after their final discovery that she was determined on a stage career. She was in Manila at a time when the Ameri cans were engaged in subduing the insurgent bands under Aguinaldo. Mark Ilambourg's farewell concert at the Albert Hall, London, so Messrs. J. and N. Tait have been informed by cablegram, was a tremendous success, the young pianist coming in for a perfect ovation. He is leaving immediately for Australia via Van-

couver, whence he is due to depart on ISth June. The Royal Welsh Male Choir, to visit Australia in September next under Messrs. J. and N. Tait's direction, consists, it is in teresting to note, entirely of young miners. It was from that class that the choir was first formed in 1885, and their numbers have been kept tip ever since by recruits from tne same ranks. Mr. Albert Mallinson, with his talented wife, Madame Anna Steinhauer, the lead ing Danish soprano, will give a series of song recitals in the Town Hall, Melbourne, commencing on 20th June, with seasons in the other States to follow. Mr. Mallinson probably holds the record as a composer, with over 300 songs to his credit, many of them being world famous. Both artists have appeared before Queen Alexandra at Buckingham Palace, and their recitals, which are under, the patronage of her Majesty, have been a notable feature of the London and Continental musical world for years. The Sydney "Morning Herald" an nounces that Mr. Williamson has now de finitely decided that Puccini's fascinating opera Mine. Butterfly shall be performed here in English as soon as the necessary, and rather difficult, arrangements can bo completed. This now famous yvork was hissed at its first performance at La Seal a, Milan, four years ago, but fras made an extraordinary success both in England and America. Mr. William-son saw the work at Philadelphia last year, and was so cap tivated by it that he hastened on negotia tions with G. Ricordi, the great music pub lisher and connoisseur, of Milan, aud has now secured the Australian rights. Much interest has been aroused in Lon don by the appearance at the Alhambra of L'incognita, the masked lady, who has made a popular success in Ah, fors e lui and The Shadow Song, with full orchestra. According to the "Sydney Morning Herald" this singer is Miss Violet Mount, the com petent soprano with the high register who for several years figured constantly in Sydney concert rooms. She' was always an earnest and capable artist, never weary of hard work, and everyone will congratulate her upon her success. Mr. Thorold Waters, the Australian tenor, who was at one time on "The Age," is making good headway in England, lie recently collaborated with Miss Theurer in a programme consist ing almost entirely of the best modern songs in groups. The critics of the leading Lon don dailies seem to have appreciated the artistic enterprise thus displayed, and the notices arc favorable. Concerning him it is said "his voice is not large, but it is natu rally of a very fine quality." The next evening Air. Thorold Waters sang with suc cess at the Crystal Palace in a Philhar monic performance of Carmen, directed by the conductoi' of the London Choral So ciety.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Mr. Robert Cunningham, a native of Victoria, who has for some years been resident in England, where he has achieved considerable success as a vocalist, has been
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Mr. Robert Cunningham, a native of Vic- toria, who has for some years been resident in England, where he has achieved con- siderable success as a vocalist, has been en-

gaged (a London cable message states) for the German opera season at Covent Gar- den in January next. At the London Ballad Concert, states a cable message to "The Age" from London, three well-known Australian singers took part in the programme. They were Miss Ada Crossley, Miss Amy Castles and Miss Kate Rooney. Miss Gertrude Alger received some en- couragement - from the London" musical' critics as the result of her first violin re-, cital, giveu iu the y-Eolian Hall, but they ! agree that she' needs to overcome some noticeable defects of style aud expression; by further study. There -can bono doubt,; says the "Times,"- that Fliss Alger has "a musical temperament which deserves com plete training." Her bowing is "often stiff, and her left hand cramped, so that passages which should be perfectly-1 within her powers of execution ; are - scrambled," but "at her best she "produces a rich and pure tone,- which; again, more study ''would, make " unfailing." Madame Melba, who is again appearing in grand opera as the leading member of the San Carlo Company, intends to add Puc- cini's La Tosca to her varied repertoire in the near future. She has been at work for some months on the beautiful music of the name part, and now regards herself as al- most perfect in it. Whether her first ap- pearance in the opera will take place before the close of the autumn, or be postponed until the next summer season at Covent Garden, has not yet been decided. In either case it will be an event of somewhat- unusual interest, because her chosen role will make a larger demand on her abili- ties as an actress than any that she has hitherto appeared in. With one or two exceptions, her chief successes up to the present have been achieved in what are known as purely lyrical roles. Information has been received at Bendi- go that Madame Benda (Miss Kate Samuels) made her appearance in opera at Saarbrucken, Germany, on 39th September, and scored a big success. Madame Benda, who is a native of Bendigo, is a daughter of Mr. L. A. Samuels, sharebroker, and for- merly studied for five years at the Mel- bourne Conservutorium.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: There are two chances just now for musical people to earn money and reputation. Madame Melba has offered to sing an Australian song at
articleText:
MUSICAL. /

There are two chances j ust now for musical people to earn money and reputation. Madame Meiba has of fered to sing an Australian -song at

the opening of the Federal Parlia ment in the new Australian Capital, Canberra. That is,, of -course, if a "suitable" song is forthcoming. The

, Duke and Duchess/of York Avill be there, and the highest dignitaries — - Church, Political, Business— will jbe present. : It will be a great occasion; and the song will also have, to be majestic to appeal to Madame Melba's ear. 'Prizes have been offered and won previously for alleged; Austra lian national songs,' but there ' was no inspiration in them and they died soon aftei' (birth. Melba is a true Australian p-atrdot, and if she ac cepts a song it will be a wonderful compliment to the composer and the

song may assist to "make a nation." Another opportunity - is offered hy the Sydney "Sun," which will give £100 for the best song on "Sydney," to be sung at the Avelcome to the Duke , and Duchess in Sydney. No doubt there will be numerous com petitors for -this prize, because poets there are in plenty, and they can collaborate with 'musicians. There will probably be a lot about "mag nificent Sydney" and "our glorious 'Arbor," but the 'song will -naturally be only of sectional interest and may live for . a -week or two. Anyhow, the prize -is Avorth -winning, but there will be a lot of 'disappointed comp etitors.

snippet: Miss Ida Stewart, aged 13 years, a native of Melbourne, Victoria, has passed the examination in music conducted under the auspices of the Royal

heading: Musical.
snippet: MRS. W. McDONALD, the talented amateur vocalist, who is at present on a visit to Goulburn, intends giving a grand concert in the course of a week or two in aid of the debt on the Patrician
articleText: Musiocal. Mns. W. McDonALD, the talented amateur vocalist, who is at present on a visit to Goulburn, intends giving a graud concert in the course of a week or two in aid of the debt on the Patrician Brothers' School in Bourke-streot. This acom plished lady, who has not inaptly beeoon termed "The Nightingale of Australia," is too well and favourably known to need a single word in praise of her great ability, save to add that a rich treat is in store for Goulburn in the musical feast abouot to be tendered, and as the object for which the entertainment is given is in every sense a worthy one there is no doubt but it will be well and liberally supported. The date of the event is to be the 22nd instant. Mrs. McDonald will be assisted by a number of talented artistes from Sydney and elsewhere, whose names will appear in due course; but the chief attraction will be the silver-throatod song-. stress herself, who has already won more laurels than sohe counts years. Popular prices will ob tain, and the event comes off in the Odd fellows' Hall. A great esuccess may be antici pated.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: A proposal was brought forward at a recent meeting of the Goulburn Liedertafel which should undoubtedly receive the enthusiastic support, not only of members of the
articleText: ivUSICAL . A proposal was brought forward at a recent meeting of-the Goulburn Liedertafel whichl should undoubtedly receive the enthnsiestic asliubrt, not only of members of the Lieder tafel, but of overy one interested in the adl vancemnnt of musical culturo and art in Goal burn. It :was suggested that the society, with thie assistance of otl?hir -msical bodies, should organiso a visit to Ballarat in October next, to pc.rticipate in the famous musical competitions and \?tho national eisteddfod of Australasia. The ocoinpotitionls are recognisel as the greatest of their kind in the world, and, in addition to' various valuable tlrophies, prize money to tihe extent of nearly t2O000 is distributed, and ad judicatous are brought.specially from,Eurpeo. It is, proposed that a strong effort should l~e made to conduce all the leading performers in Goulburn to make the trip, and that entries should be made in the choral contests for mixed voices, the female claoses, the male classes, operettos comedies, elocution, vocal and instru. mental solos. Possibly one of tihe local bands might also be able totako part, and this would add greatly to the general interest. There is cer tuinly plenty of talent in Goulburn that is worthy of recognition in the best musical'circles of Australia,; and . the chansco offered. of ap pearing at the celebrated Ballarat competitions should-bae a wonderful incentiv-e in the develop ment of local' musical ability. Special cheap fares are available on 'all the railways, and ar rangements are usually made by representa tive citizens of Ballarat to entertain the ladies of visiting choirs duorin their stay in the city, so that the expenses ..are thus considerhhably lightened. With an active comminittee working throughout tihe winter, no douct considerable sums could be raised by means of a musical ball, and various socials, and .these might be supplemented by concerts tit say, Yi?as, Wagga, and Albury on tie journeya-ross td Ballarat, uwhich is 'one of the show places of Australia. Nothing defiinito whatever has been decided upon; but'it is hoped that the proposal will reesive.the practical support 'of all re eidents,, especially musicians, and that it will eventually be brought to a succesoful termina tion.

snippet: Dick Powell and Ginger Rogers make a happy pair in the Warner musical, "Twenty Million Sweethearts," which will open at the Roxy Theatre next Wednesday
articleText: Musical. Dick Powell and Ginger Rogers make happy pair in the Warner musical, "Twenty Million Sweethearts," khich will open at the Roxy Theatre'next Wednesday evening, and screen for three days. Powell I is offered a life-time job as radio enter tainer, accepts, but does Ginger like it? \Well, wouldn't you be jealous if your boy I friend had twenty million other sweet hearts? As announced elsewhere in this issue, the Roxy's birthday will take place next Wed nesday. "Twenty Million Sweethearts" was booked for this one occasion, "The Kansas City Princess" being dropped back. "Here Comes the Groom" is a very clever Para mont comedy, and Jack Haley lends the fun, opposite Neil Hamilton and Patricia Ellis, who provide the romance. It tells of a woman who took a man for better or for worse, and got the worse. This comedy will also screen next Wed nesday, Thursday and Friday. Two special stage presentations will be added to Wed nesday night's programme, and other short novelties. The shosw will finish at mid night.

The latest London papers bring very glowing accounts of the doings of the Na- tional Opera Company at the Dublin Gaiety. This will be welcome news here, for most of the members of the combination are colonials, while several others have visi-   ted us at different periods, and left pleasant remembrances behind them. The opening production was 'Faust,' referring to which the 'Era' says : 'Miss Alice Esty gave an admirable rendition of the part' of Margue- rite, earning a tumultuous recall in the Gar- den Scone. Mr. Cunningham was a grace- ful and effective Faust, and proved that his managerial cares do not interfere with his singing and acting, both being of high class. Mr. Alec Marsh put into his im-   personation of Mephistopheles his very best dramatic and lyric effects. Miss Cecilia Staunton, a contralto also from N. Zealand, made her first appearance on this side as Siebel, and revealed, besides a lino stage presence, a pure contiiiUo voice of admirable tone and power, which won from the crowded houso two enthusiastic encores.' This was followed by 'The Bohemian Girl,' in which Mr. William Walshe made his appearance, and the tenor's 'remarkable purity of tone' greatly pleased the critics.

Our Now Zealand correspondent writes lo cay that Mrs. ,\V. 'Manson, well-known In Duncdln-' musical . circles,, who shortly. leaves for Europe to complete her 'musical, studies, is, to bo tendered a complimentary concert by the lending, vocal aud instru mental talent in 'Duucidin ;on March' 15. Us is nearly CO years old, but hale and hearty, though his voice Is gone. His downfall is said to be largely due to betting lossci. Tho 'score of 'La FIllo do Madame An got',' i3 tho Sultan's fa\ontc composition. Miss Maggio Sterling, tho Well-known Victorian vocalist, loft for London jester day. Prior to her dcparcuio slie uas pre sented by Lady Brassey'witl the proceeds of her recent benefit concert, amounting to over' £300.

They evidently have discovered a young musical genius in Melbourne. Ills name 'Is 'Kri:/. Mueller, and ho Is only 11 years old. Writln's to -the 'Argus,' a muclcal en thusiast -says: — 'I was recently asked to hoar him play, and to apply t'flo various tests for- determining his musical know ledge, tand found that as a pianist he has a beautiful natural touch of rare quality, and, as a composer, ho Is tho possessor of excel lent Ideas,, and already Meats them l in a truly artistic 'mariner. His memory Is phe nomciml, and his ear is all that could bo desired. If this child were In a position to roceivo a thorough.Europcan musical tiain ?lug, living 'In musical centres, whore ho coiild.'hear dally, the .best works performed by tho leading orchestrtuj and soloists, I feel confident tiiat lie would develop into u musician of the first rank, both as a pianist ami. composer, and one of whom the Aus tralitui. public would have every rcaeon ,to bo. proud.' Since this lotter' appeared on Friday . loot, ^several other well-known people have confirmed the ; impressions therein expressed, and It is probable the TMlo fellow will receive a benefit in order to ralso funds to let 'him go home. The 'Illustrated Sporting and Dramatic News,' lefcrrlng to the recent bencht to Slms'Iteovcs,' iKiys:—'T'he crowd ot eminent artists ? who gathered round tho v--~ «' ?—

assist ?' Mm in his concert at the St. James' Hall caused a faint sprinkling of stalls to be the only . unocoupied seats in the build lug. Nor could one even see, with indiffer ence, the figure from whose lips half a. ceh turv tt song held a listening world, al . though tho principal emotion stirred must have been that of regret for circumstances which caused Che well-earned rest of a voice or the past to bo broken. Yet, as of eld his art had all its elusive 'infinite variety.' One, of the principal features of the evening was the' Romeo ot Juliet duet, 'Va ! Je t'ai, pardonrie,'- brilliantly rendered by Md.lamo :Albani and Mr. Ben Davios; while Mr. San tie jr gave the 'Erl King' with all his familiar wcirdness and pathos in tlils song.' . heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Miss Florence Menk-Meyer has given four pianoforte recitals here during the past fortnight. The advent of this young pianiste was heralded by a variety of flattering press notices called from newspapers
articleText:
Miss Florence Menk-Meyer has given four pianoforte recitals here during the past fortnight. The advent of this young pianiste was heralded by a variety of flattering press notices culled from newspapers published in such cities as Paris, Berlin, Vienna, and St. Petersburg. Her performances have evidenced the possession of considerable talent, but at the same time it has been found impossible to avoid recognition of the fact that her powers are as yet but imperfectly developed, and in consequence general surprise as well as regret has been expressed that European critics or paragraph!«!« should have written about an immature student as if she were already a finished artiste. Her programmes here have contained but few great com- positions, and those have only served to show her inability to rise to the level of great conceptions. For the rest, the recitals have been composed of comparatively insignificant works of a class that demands no exceptional executive skill to do them justice.

The University Musical Society has performed Cowen's "Rose Maiden." Several miscellaneous concerts have been given, and there have been two organ recitals by well-known local players. These recitals took place at the University, where there is a three manual organ by Foster and Andrews. The grand organ for the Centennial Hall is still a long way from completion, but the work of erection is now progressing rapidly

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The musical event of the fortnight has been the first production of Sir Arthur Sullivan's cantala, "The Golden Legend. The interpretation of the work was undertaken by the Philharmonic Society,
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The muelen! event of the fortnight has been the first production of Sir Arthur Sullivan's cantata, "The Golden Legend. The interpretation of the work was undertaken by the Philharmonic Society, and it was listened to by a crowded audience in the Centennial Hall on the night of Wednesday, February 11. The performance was of such general excellence as to secure high encomiums. The society numbered over 400 performers vocalists being 318, and the orchestra 05 performers. The orchestra included Mr. Rivers Allpress (leader of the violins;. Messrs. EchtnelUtaohelt, Willimoff, White, Jacques, C. H. Tice and many other well-known performer, t while M solo vocalists the society had the assistance

of Signora Antonietta Link, Mrs. Vnndervoor Green, Mr. Wm. Walshe, Monsieur Deslouis, Mr, A. S. Demo, Mr. Boa presided at the great organ, and Signor Hazon acted as conductor. After the "Golden Legend" the programme was made to contain the following miscollonooUB items: " The Spinning Chorus" from Wagner's "Flying Dutchman," for orchestra, ladies' chorus, and solo (entrusted to Mrs. Vandorveor Groen) : " Cielo o Mar," a romanza from Ponchiolli's " Gioconda," sung by Mr. Walshe-, the well-known duet, " La, 01 dancer da mano," contributed by Signora Link and Mons. Desloma and the popular chorus, " See the Conquering Hero Comes," These items were rendered in a satisfactory manner, and gave many foot pleasure to such of the audience as remained. A further opportunity of honoring the cantata was afforded on the following Saturday, An enormous audience gathered, and the second presentment met with the utmost appreciation.
