The latest London papers bring very glowing accounts of the doings of the Na- tional Opera Company at the Dublin Gaiety. This will be welcome news here, for most of the members of the combination are colonials, while several others have visi-   ted us at different periods, and left pleasant remembrances behind them. The opening production was 'Faust,' referring to which the 'Era' says : 'Miss Alice Esty gave an admirable rendition of the part' of Margue- rite, earning a tumultuous recall in the Gar- den Scone. Mr. Cunningham was a grace- ful and effective Faust, and proved that his managerial cares do not interfere with his singing and acting, both being of high class. Mr. Alec Marsh put into his im-   personation of Mephistopheles his very best dramatic and lyric effects. Miss Cecilia Staunton, a contralto also from N. Zealand, made her first appearance on this side as Siebel, and revealed, besides a lino stage presence, a pure contiiiUo voice of admirable tone and power, which won from the crowded houso two enthusiastic encores.' This was followed by 'The Bohemian Girl,' in which Mr. William Walshe made his appearance, and the tenor's 'remarkable purity of tone' greatly pleased the critics.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Miss Florence Menk-Meyer has given four pianoforte recitals here during the past fortnight. The advent of this young pianiste was heralded by a variety of flattering press notices called from newspapers
articleText:
Miss Florence Menk-Meyer has given four pianoforte recitals here during the past fortnight. The advent of this young pianiste was heralded by a variety of flattering press notices culled from newspapers published in such cities as Paris, Berlin, Vienna, and St. Petersburg. Her performances have evidenced the possession of considerable talent, but at the same time it has been found impossible to avoid recognition of the fact that her powers are as yet but imperfectly developed, and in consequence general surprise as well as regret has been expressed that European critics or paragraph!«!« should have written about an immature student as if she were already a finished artiste. Her programmes here have contained but few great com- positions, and those have only served to show her inability to rise to the level of great conceptions. For the rest, the recitals have been composed of comparatively insignificant works of a class that demands no exceptional executive skill to do them justice.

The University Musical Society has performed Cowen's "Rose Maiden." Several miscellaneous concerts have been given, and there have been two organ recitals by well-known local players. These recitals took place at the University, where there is a three manual organ by Foster and Andrews. The grand organ for the Centennial Hall is still a long way from completion, but the work of erection is now progressing rapidly

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The musical event of the fortnight has been the first production of Sir Arthur Sullivan's cantala, "The Golden Legend. The interpretation of the work was undertaken by the Philharmonic Society,
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The muelen! event of the fortnight has been the first production of Sir Arthur Sullivan's cantata, "The Golden Legend. The interpretation of the work was undertaken by the Philharmonic Society, and it was listened to by a crowded audience in the Centennial Hall on the night of Wednesday, February 11. The performance was of such general excellence as to secure high encomiums. The society numbered over 400 performers vocalists being 318, and the orchestra 05 performers. The orchestra included Mr. Rivers Allpress (leader of the violins;. Messrs. EchtnelUtaohelt, Willimoff, White, Jacques, C. H. Tice and many other well-known performer, t while M solo vocalists the society had the assistance

of Signora Antonietta Link, Mrs. Vnndervoor Green, Mr. Wm. Walshe, Monsieur Deslouis, Mr, A. S. Demo, Mr. Boa presided at the great organ, and Signor Hazon acted as conductor. After the "Golden Legend" the programme was made to contain the following miscollonooUB items: " The Spinning Chorus" from Wagner's "Flying Dutchman," for orchestra, ladies' chorus, and solo (entrusted to Mrs. Vandorveor Groen) : " Cielo o Mar," a romanza from Ponchiolli's " Gioconda," sung by Mr. Walshe-, the well-known duet, " La, 01 dancer da mano," contributed by Signora Link and Mons. Desloma and the popular chorus, " See the Conquering Hero Comes," These items were rendered in a satisfactory manner, and gave many foot pleasure to such of the audience as remained. A further opportunity of honoring the cantata was afforded on the following Saturday, An enormous audience gathered, and the second presentment met with the utmost appreciation.

heading: MUSICAL
snippet: Whatever be his particular taste, the music lover of Australia is not likely to cavil at the arrangements made for his entertainment this year by Messrs. J. and
articleText:
MUSICAL

Whatever be his particular taste/ the music lover of Australia is not likely to' cavil a't the arrangements made for 'his: entertainment this year by Messrs. J. and N. Tait, comprising "as they do visits from a brass band, a violinist; and -two vocalists (to take them in their chronological order) , — all of whom rank with the world's best'

in their special branches ot music. The first named— the Besses o' th' Barn Band- has already added New Zealand to the list of its conquered" countries, and will em bark on a similar mission as regards Ausv tralia next month. A few weeks later Miss Mhrie Hall, the most accomplished violinist of -her 'sex in -the whole, of Eur ope, will commence her Australian toiir, and in September Madame Clara Butt and Mr. Kennerley Rumford, both of whom are at the top of their profession, will ar rive. - ' . : . : The Besses o' th' Barn Band proved a great success- in New Zealand. Messrs. J. and N. Tait brought them out originally for a quick tour through Australasia, be ginning with an appearance at the Christ- church Exhibition. But from the first their reception was so enthusiastic, and the eagerness on the part of New Zealanders to hear -them was so pronounced, that their visit to that colony "had bo be considerably : extended. Since then their tour , has " been a triumphant progress. They are now in the last weeks of . that trip, and on the 11th of next month they are announced to 'commence their Australian campaign in" Sydney. Following : upon that they will go to Brisbane, and other Queensland towns, and in July they are due in--Mel- bourne. ' The Marshall Hall orchestra has been engaged for the first concert of Miss Marie Hall in Australia, which takes place at the Melbourne Town Hall on "the" 1st June, and Professor Marshall Hall himself will conduct on that occasion. The visit of Miss Marie Hall to these parts is being anticipated with very considerable eager ness, for everyone familiar with the course of musical events in Europe has been struck with the remarkably rapid rise to favour of this noted violinist— a rise, more over, in no way dependent on outside in fluence, but due solely and entirely to sheer artistic eminence. No matter where Miss Hall appeared — in Great Britain, in the musical centres of Europe, in the United States or Canada— the verdict was always the same. Madame Clara Butt on her forthcoming visit to Australia will be accompanied, not only by her husband, but also by their three children, the youngest -of whom has the distinction of having Princess Christian for a godmother. :

heading: MUSICAL
snippet: Mrs. Alfred H. Bowden, who comes of a well-known and very musical family (the late Professor A. J. Dentith, who studied with Sir Michael Costa, and for
articleText: MUSICAL Mrs. Alfred H. BOWDEN, who comes of a well-known and very musical family (the late Professor A..J. Dentith, who   studied with Sir Michael Costa, and for some years at the Conservatoire of Music, Hamburg, being her father), late ly decided to publish some of her musi cal works. The "Melody in A Flat," now on the market, is a simple, melodi ous composition for the piano, in ternary or song form. Part I is gentle, flowing, and attractive, while part II forms an excellent contract (sic) in its bright, rhythmic swing. The whole piece is well bal anced, and being technically easy, will prove not only educational, but also a boon to young players on the look.out for a pleasing drawing-room piece,

snippet: That very great artist, Mr Leonard Borwick, the most celebrated English pianist of this generation, will pay a return visit to Australia this year. On
articleText: MUSICAL. That very great artist, Mr Leonard Borwick, the most celebrated English pianist of this generation, will pay a retur4 visit to Australia this year. On the occasion of his former tour, Mr Bor wick was limited by his Englih .nagage ments to a very hurried visit. Hie had barely time to appear in Melbourne, Adelaide, and Sydney, with the four cea tres of New Zealnnd. On the present tour, Mr Borwick has given himself ample time to visit all the Australian States, as well as New Zealand, on his way to the United States, where he is booked for a4 extensive tour late in the year. 'There is littie neod to say any thing in praise of the great ]inglisl in terpreter of Beethoven. Mr Borwick won, wherever he played in Australia, imrmediate recognition as one of the modern princes of the piano. One lead ing critic described ITeorard Borwick's art as" More fascinating than Padereski, moie artistic than Hambourg, more brilliant than Carreno," and the general opinion was that in addition to his re ,7arkable technical endowment, Mr Leonard Borwick had the rarest of ar tistic gifts, ard temperaments. He gave us not merely a perkcri.ance, but pi interpretation. Mr lorwick' wiU Xef. Melbourne towards the end of April. -...?"'-t . -

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: It is with the greatest diffidence that I approach the subject of the system of musical education in our island, because I feel that there are those among us far
articleText: MUSICAL. From Tiles Tasmanian. THnE MUSICAL wTunsx or TASMANIA. It is with the greatest diffidence that I appioach- the subject of : the system .of musical education in our island, because I feel that there are thosde ainong us far better qualified to write on such an impor taut subject, still, no harm can be done by merely stating my.own impressions on the Ssubject. First then, I remark one great difficulty which our teachers have to con tend with is the very scant opportunity afforded to Tasmanians of listening to *really first-class music, so very seldom do the great artists of Europe visit our shores. No wonder then that in the absence of first-rate we became satisfied with. second rate music. Then again those of us who have had the advantage of hearing, in England and elsewhere, this first-class music, and who know the enormous amount of patient labour and untirifng study neces sary to such excellence,, find it altogether impossible to; communicate their know ledge to their pupils, whose ideas on the subject are on a totally different plane. For instance, a thoroughly' good teacher, who has had the. benefit .of :first-class training and large experience, knows, when a pupil is. committed to his or her charge, that the fingers of that pupil's hand are each possessed of unequal force, somebeing much weaker than others, and that such being the case it is not possible that there should be any smoothness of exe-' cution, as naturally the. strongest fingers will' strike with most force, while the weaker will strike only faintly, if. at all. Hence then, it must be obvious that the very first and most vitally important point is to subject the fingers to the educating influence of exercises specially aiming at strengthening the weak muscles, and so equalising the touch, that gradually theie creeps into oven the most rapid passages that exquisite flowing ripple so entirely free from anything like roughness or inequality,.whieh is termed " technique," and is so utterly different from the ordinary slipshod style of so-called execu tion. Now nothing will promote this but enormous practice atthe special exercises mentioned above, scales alone will not do it, their province is to promote proper re lations..,between . the fingers, not .to st rengthen the weaker fingers, one of which only strikes the note ina, scale about once in eight notes. I consider, therefore, the main thing necessary to a higher musical education is that parents and pupils should have entire confidence in the teacher, pro vided the. latter is a competent one, that the great fact of the preparatory mechani cal training of the fingers should have far more general ,recognition than it has at present, also that in this, as in all else, un bounded enthusiasm and tireless energy is .neeessary,:and by way of improving the Sgeeiral.tone of~education, would it not be .w ell for teachers to study their profession diligently. There . are invaluable little books now making their appearance amongst us,.written by some of the most eminent men in England and elsewhere; also very interesting musical periodicals, which deserve to be far more generally known . and read than they are. But I think that the main thing for us all is to have the very highest respect and love for this our art, to lay down fixed principles for ourselves, which shall .never be sacri ficed either to expediency, public opinion, or anything else, finally to make it our re solve' never to. sink the art in the mere profession... CHORALE. -A: FEW THOUGHITS ABOUT ORGANS. The organ has been called the king of instruments, and not without reason ; for whenwe hear the full majestic tone of a fine organ, and notice the variety of sound produced by the different rows of pipes or stops; we experience very-mixed feelings both of wondermeit and delight. In most churches the organ is theeonly instrument allowed, and it seems to have been used for religious purposes in very early times. The beginning of the organ was the flute not the flauto-traverse blown obliquely down the side, as we see it now-a-days, but a flute blown from one end ; which in itself came from:taking a hollow reed and mak ing notches or holes down one side, to suit the sounds of the particular scale or mode the perfoimer desired. The next advance seems to have been in putting a number of' these reeds together in the order of a scale, tand playing them by moving the -mouth along the row as desired. A relic .of this may still be seen in London in'con nection with Punch and Judy shows. Then the next 'step was, we might say, really the beginning of organ building, viz., putting a'number of pipes in holes on the top of a box, With pieces of skin under neath each pipehole, which skin was con s?ieted with strings. from the outside, and being filled with wind from the opposite side by a hand bellows, the player could use any pipe ad lib. Allthese devicesa were gradually imnproved until we find organs of quite a complete kind. These were divided into two classes-positif or sta tionary organs, and portatif or smiall in struments capable of removal by the aid of two or three men. As before stated, the only. imeans at first adopted foir using any pipe at will were the pieces of skin which were pulled by strings; but after awhile keys connected with the skin - which was now strengthened by small pieces of wood-by lovers were invoeflted. They were large and to us clumsy enough; the white keys were in the shape of huge crosses, and the black keys nearly four times the size of the present ones. They weroprobablyplayed with the clenehedfists. As the study of music and the use of it ad vanced under the Roman Church, the organ was made'to keep pace with it until we find in the 15th century organs of very fair tone and mechanism. One great im provement has sincethen been effected in the bellows, which before had only been like a large kind of house bollows, very unsteady, and in consequence the sound was very uncertain. This improvement was effected by the introduction of a wind chest. or reservoir, which was filled by small feoders, worked.by a handle, as in our present organs; but in those days they were pressed down by the weight of aman, 'whs was .called the bellows treader-who may still be seen in.a daric corster of some of the smaller continental churches. The early. instruments had: only one manual or key-board, but this was found too loud for accompanying well-trained ehm'ch choirs, and so. a small organ with' a separate row of keys was added. Some builders in the 17th century added an "echo organ," which was a number of pipes placed in a box some distance from the main organ. This in time was modified untilit merged into thb., swell" organ,7 whiah is like the " echo," 'in a' box, the front of which is composed of venetian. shutters, whiel can be opened or closed at will by means of Wpedal:' One great attraction about an organ is the wonderful effect of large deep-tlned' pipes,.actuated by the feet on koyt placed for' that purpose-invented, in the' 15th century. Combination pistons and levers 'whereby the player; by pressing a lever Withl his fo't, can change the combination df steps, and various other improvoments have beena added,. A comparison feom the first bbj of pipes to a modern organ with itiffdur' fdye tows of keys fer the'hands, eal6h row representing a separate organ, with pedal board, pneumatic datiog, and combination levers, and from sixty to eighty 'steps sholies what iinmense strides the building of this instiument has made. ..l': "' In a fut?tire paper 'Ihipe to deal With organ composers and thlir works, .ahd the art of organ playing.. This is only a very brief outline of the history of the.. organ,. tquehhisig uapn those points Which :are of; the most moment/a t'egayds 'its, imiprove mont, ote. ' " .... "ao: L'ALL?EGRO. " oelll,to teliltle truth; papa, I did not thinl stauck' of "the 'close 'f the sermon," said a fashionable young lady. " Probably: you were thinking more of the 'clothes of the congregation," replied her father."

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: SIR,—Two letters have appoared lately in The Mercury suggesting the formation of another musical society here. From my own short experience in this town, I feel
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Sin, Two letters have appeared lately in The Mercury suggesting the formation of another musical society here. From my own short experience in this town, I feet certain that one first-class society is as much as can be managed. '

Besides having an orchestra of about 55 players, the Orchestral Union has a large chorus, including nearly all the best singers in Hobart, and yet there exists a great scarcity of tenors. If the one society of the place has such a want, how will it be possible to form a second ? I believe there are not more than a dozen tenors available ; not enough for one good chorus. A new society must also necessarily include amongst its members a great proportion of those already in the Orchestral Union. And, as one night a week is as much as most amateurs can give to rehearsals, one society would have to suffer considerably in the way of " attend- ance." "Progress" idea as to any new chorus or orchestra (not yet formed being able to give a series of concerts during the coming winter is absurd. If rehearsals commenced

at once I doubt whether more than

one really good performance could be managed. ,

If I thought the suggested movement could result in anything good I would do all in my power to help it forward, but I am perfectly

sure a decidedly "second-rate" society

I would be the outcome.

-Yours, etc.,' L

J MAUGHAN BARNETT.

May 21. A'

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Moss Vale, Saturday.—The Moss Vale Musical Society, under the conductorship of Mr. Colin Ferguson, rendered Sterndale Bennett's cantata, "May Queen," with much success in the Oddfellows' Hall
articleText: MUSICAL. Moess Vale, Saturday.-The Moss Vale Meusical Society, under the conductorship of Mr. Colin Fer guson, rendered Sterndale Bennett's cantata, "May Queen," with much success in the Oddfollows' HI! last night before a large audience. The soloists were the Misseso Emily Taylor and M. Allman, Messrs. Everard Row and P.ýC. Beer. Miss All man was the accompanist. A miscellaneous pro gramme was contributed to by Mrs. J. H. Craig, Mise L Lindsay, and Mr. Colin Ferguson. At the close the Mayor (Dr. Leighton Jones) presented Miss Allman, who is leaving the town, with a purse of sovereigns from the trembers of the Musical Society as a mark of their appreciation of her ser vices since the inception of the society.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: A fine classical concert was given on Wednesday, the 20th ultime, by the Orpheus Society, the scope of whose operations may be understood by likening their concerts to those known as the "Monday
articleText:
MUSICAL

A fine classical concert was given on Wednesday, the 20th ultimo, by the Orpheus Society, the scope of whose operations may be understood by likening their concerts to those known as the " Monday Pops " at St James's Hall His Excellency the Governor and Lady Carrington were present

The music at the opening of the new City Hall was not of a very ambitious stamp, but the selections were good, and the performance highly creditable. The arrangements were made by a committee composed of representatives of the Philharmonic, the University Musical, the Orpheus,

and the two Liedertafel societies. The chorus numbered 455, chiefly belonging to the societies above named, and these were supported by a fine orchestra of 57 performers. The programme was as follows 3-6) The Old Hundredth Psalm, sang by the chorus, unaccompanied; (2), Weber's " Jubilee " overture, by the orchestra 3 Nos. 2 and 3 of Mendelssohn's " Festge sang," for male chorus and orchestra ; (4), the same composer's " Ode to the Sons of Art,'' also for male chorus and orchestra; and (5), Handel's (" Messiah") " Hallelujah" chorus, in which all the performers took part. The performances were directed in turn by the conductors of four of the chief musical societies in the city.

On the 30th the new Hall was again utilised for musical purposes, this time for a grand concert, announced

as Mr. Santley's farewell" to Sydney. The great English baritone proved in grand

i 2 2 2

voice, and opened the vocal portion of the concert with a superb rendering of " Del Meoacciar del Santo," from Handel's "Ottone," contributing later an equally fine performance of " Vulcan's 1 Song," from Gounod's " Philemon et Bauera." He also took part with Madame Christian i in a duet composed by Signor Hazon, conductor

of the orchestra, who, prior to his residence here, was deputy conductor at La Scala in Milan. The programme included an orchestral "Berceuse" composed and conducted by Mr. Santley-a dainty little morceau written for and dedicated to the infant daughter of Lord and Lady Carrington.

During the last fortnight there have been several concerts, etc, of lesser note, and also some important musical services in connection with churches. Spohr's "Last Judgment was performed at St Andrew's Cathedral on the evening of the 30th ultimo and on the 3rd instant, Haydn's " Creation was produced at St Thomas' Church, in the

suburb of St. Leonards.

heading: MUSICAL.

title.value: The Wingham Chronicle and Manning River Observer (NSW : 1898 - 1954)

snippet: Mr. ROBERT KENNEDY, the clever Scotch vocalist, appeared in one of bis admirable entertainments, at the Lyceum Hall, Wingham, last Friday
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Mb., Robert Kennedy, the clever Scotch vocalist, appeared in one of his admirable entertainments, at the Lyceum Hall, Wingham, last Friday and Saturday nights, tp remarkably good audiences, the hill being well filled. On, Friday ..-tbe programme was

a very cnoice one, ana it was capitally carried out... Mr, Kennedy gave the songs of Scotland with verve and a well-toned voice. ' The Land o* the Leal,' ' Sing to me the Old Songs,' ' The Laird ofCockpen,' 'Get up aud Bar the Door, O,' and several other well known songs, were euug thoroughly well. We give a more detailed account of Mr. Kennedy's exhibition of talent in our re marks npon the Saturday's concert. The theme of Mr. Kennedy's musical discourse on Saturday night was that of the 'Jacobites,' and right elo quently and tunefully Mr. Kennedy performed his part. The curtailed description of the political and social events connected with the Jacobite episode were clearly detailed, and the songs the situation brought forth were given in excellent style. Where all was good it is difficult to particularise, but the charming gusto with which 'The Wimmen, the Wimmen,' ' Wha Wouldna Fecht for Chairlie,' ' Hey ! Johnny Cope,' Alister McAlister,' ' Our Guid Mod,' and other characj teristic pieces, were given proved Mr, Kennedy to be possessed of a large amount of talent. The pathos of the rendering of ' The Auld House' was a wonderful revelation of diversity of talent, and that most touching of impressive songs, ' The Land o' the Leal ' was given with extreme doli cacy of expression and sweet tone of voice. Mr. Kennedy is' really worth hearing, both as a delineator of his torical events, and as an accomplished musician. He will bave the satisfac tion of the knowledge that his un doubted ability is well appreciated at Wingham. Many jokes connected with the Jacobite history were given most unctnously. Mr, Kennedy , will re-appear at Wingham next Saturday, and will be cheerfully greeted.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The Orpheus Society's concert was given at the Town Hall on Monday evening. A charming orchestral suite by Grieg, an interesting composition by Saint Saens, for
articleText:
MU8IGAL.

The Orpheus Society's concert was given at the Town Hall on Monday evening. A charming orchestral suite by Grieg, an in teresting composition by Saint Saens, for

solo violin and string orchestra, and a Welsh Rhapsody by Edward German, were the principal novelties introduced by Mr. Frederic Beard, the newly appointed Or pheus conductor. J. S. Bach's choi'us Praise Jehovah was fairly well sung, though some defects were noticeable. Beethoven's Hallelujah Chorus was very creditably done; also the same composer's Egmont overture; but Elgar's pretentious setting of God Save the King came near a breakdown. Tlie Coronation Ode— also by Elgar— went off belter than when last heard hero. Miss Lilian Reid and Miss Elva Rogers were satisfactory in tlio leading ladies' parts. Mr. Oswald ltippon sang conscientiously, and Mr. C. H. Ledward displayed useful quali ties. Coleridge-Taylor's composition Hia watha's Wedding Feast and the Death of Minnehaha will be performed by the Phil harmonic Society at their concert next Tuesday evening in the Town Hall; Concerning the Gorman opera season in Sydney, the Sydney "Morning Herald" ob serves: — "Were it permissible to argue from a single instance, it might be urged that the experience has afforded better all- round musicianship as compared with the best English and Italian combinations, but that the voices have not been so good.

Whilst there were excellent voices ' in the combination, we must hold that they were not equal to those of the best Italian com panies. On the other hand, Mr. George Musgrove's company has given us a record making first production of The Valkyrie, and has also introduced Gounod's Romeo and Juliet,, and Humperdinck's Hansei and Gretel, so as to leave behind abiding memo ries of delight. The man who compares the German company with the last Covent Garden cast he saw is apt to overlook the price lie paid for it. The source of weak ness throughout was, after all, the inade quacy of the orchestra. Herr Slapoffski, a conductor of great talent and energy, was just getting his players into line as the sea son terminated. The system is all wrong, but the cost of carrying about a permanent orchestra is declared to be prohibitive. Official returns give the highest financial support of Faust and The Valkyrie." A respectable share of the passenger ac commodation of the Mongolia, which leaves London on Friday (19th July) of this week, will be taken up by the Clara Butt concert party on their way to Australia to begin tlieir engagement with Messrs. J. and N. Tait in September next. In addition to the Rumford family — father, mother and the three children— there will be Madame's sister, her maid, her secretary, the chil dren's nurse, and the members of the company (three in number), who will sup port Madame Butt during her season. The Queen of Sacred Song is a title that Madame Clara Butt has fairly earned, not only because of her supreme position in the world of English oratorio, but also because of her personal predilection for that class of music. Interviewed recently, she de clared her preference for Eliiah as her favorite oratorio, and "0 Rest in the Lord" as her favorite solo. "It always gives me a delicious sense of restfulness," she said, "and at the same time a vivid reali sation of the message of peace it brought to the distracted prophet." And she car ries this preference out of the domain of oratorio, and of all the songs in her exten sive repertoire she chooses Liddell's set ting of "Abide With Me." How often she has sung that solo she does not know, but few of her concerts do not include it either as a number or as an encore piece. At the Town Hall on Saturday, 27th July, the famous Lancashire band, the Besses o' tli' Barn, will . commence its Melbourne season, under the direc tion of Messrs. J. and N. Tait. This unique band is entirely composed of work ing men, mostly weavers and mill hands, and it seems almost incredible that they should reach the topmost rung of the ladder in such circumstances. Tlie season in Melbourne will be a brief one, and in order to give the public an opportunity of hear ing its huge repertoire, two performances will be given daily. The box plans will be opened at Allan's on Monday next. A Japanese native of Tokio, who has lived in London for more than five years, confesses to be greatly amused at the atti tude of the great British Empire with re gard to the much maligned opera The Mikado. He is sure also that his country men will laugh when they learn that this innocent and pleasing production has been suppressed by the too cautious Lord Cham berlain. The Mikado has been produced in Japan on <morc than one occasion, and has never failed to give much pleasure to those Japanese who are able to appreciate Euro pean music. If The Mikauo is likely tq- give offence in Japan it should have beSn' suppressed years ago. This belated reggrd. for our feelings is an empty conipliined't which will never be understood properlyi; There is a certain popular play in' Ja'i>a"ir" in which one of the characters'-, is '-a. wicked Englishman. "Doubtless, lie suggests, our Government will order its suppression. One good turn deserves another. Tliey know how to applaud at the opera in Spain. Baveclona afforded recently a striking illustration of this on two oc casions, -when Mr. Maurel sang in Rigo- letto and Otollo. When the curtain had been lowered after the performance of the earlier Verdi opera, the audience, not satis-, lied with the famous singer's frequent re turn to the front of the stage to bow his acknowledgments of their ovation, refused to leave the theatre until the triumphant favorite gave a promise to sing once more in the course of a few days. No less than three extra performances were given, and at curtain-fall on the last night Mr. Maurel's admirers once again showed them selves unwilling to get to their homes. Yielding to their fervent demands, the popular baritone "obliged" with a succession of songs, but, even so, his audience con tinued obdurate, and at three in the morn ing the management had perforce to ex tinguish the lights. Not a whit exhausted by tlieir prolonged demonstrations, many of the enthusiasts then made tlieir way to the back of the theatre, and followed Mr. Maurel on his drive to the hotel, cheering him loudly all the way.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The Danish violinist Mr. Max Schluter, whose previous visit to Australia has been held in pleasant memory, has since established his reputation on a firmer footing.
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The Danish violinist Mr. Max Sehluter, whose previous visit to Australia has been held in ipleasant memory, has since estab lished his reputation on a firmer footing. His opening concert given at the Town Hall on Saturday eveninsr showed that he is

in every way well equipped as a solo player. His tone is clear and pure, and his technique remarkably well developed. Mr. Sehluter opened with Dvorak's Soivatine in G, iiis finin, crisp bowing 'being admirably suited to the energetic strain of the' open ing allegro, while he made his violin "sing" the mournful cadences of the succeeding allegretto. The finale, which reverts to the original mood, was given with all the re quisite dash and vim, and the .performer had to respond" to numerous recalls on the conclusion of his task. The Paganini Con certo was a brilliant specimen of flawless double stopping, and in the cadenza, all the resources of the instrument are laid under requisition. Such music needs an almost phenomenally developed technique, and Mr. Sehhvter's performance was loudly ap plauded. In the second part of the pro gramme l,e gave Tsc'haikowsky's tearful la ment, appropriately known as Chanson Triste, and a delightful piece by Ole Bull entitled Solitude. Both were, done with fine feeling arid beautiful ton. Bracketed with these was a Mazurka by Bradyakoff, whieli combines brilliance with legitimate effect. Mr. Sehluter rattled i't off in irre sistible fashion, and was accorded an ova tion; to which he responded by means of Schumann's Traemnorei. This and Cesar Cui's beautiful eavatina showed the violin ist at his best; and his concluding number, the Wfil-o'-the-Wisp of Papini, was a dazzljng bit of display work. Miss Gladys Kingsley chose Sqlveig's Song (Grieg) as her first solo. She, 'though nervous, showed lior-clf the possessor of a charming natural voice, and made a distinctly favor able impression. In Strange's Damon, Miss

Kingsley, having conquered her nervous ness, was far anore successful. Mr. H. S. Elvins played the rarely heard scherzo in B minor of Chopin acceptably, particularly so as regards the melody of the piu lento section. The next concert is fixed for Wednesday evening. Once more Madame Clara Butt is back in Australia, arriving last week in Sydney from New Zealand, where her tour has bec-n nothing short of a triumphal pro gress. The few, days before she began her farewell season to Australian, audiences were spent by lier in a well earned rest, varied by the social calls on her time ren dered necessary by the number of friend ships she has made in the harbor cityi It is possible that even now Madame Butt .will have to forego her visit to Tasmania, owing to the shortness of the time left, and also to the fact that Messrs. J. and N. Tait are . experiencing great difficulty in arranging for suitable dates. The Australian tour of The Hollanders, or, as they are sometimes called, The Merrymakers, will commence under the diection of Messrs. J., and N. Tait in Mel bourne in about three weeks' time. The first of the Mark Hambourg recitals will be given in Sydney on 18th July. The famous pianist leaves Vancouver on 19th June to fill his engagement to Messrs. J. and N. Tait. The public will welcome the return of Mr. and Mrs. Mallinson, who, since their sojourn here some years ago, have in creased their reputation in a wider field. Mrs. Mallinson will be remembered as Madame Anna Steinhauer, the "Danish nightingale," who proved herself a charm ing singer. Mr. Mallinson is a composer whose merit is so remarkable that within, a comparatively brief period he has at tained a European eminence as a composer of songs, which are openly declared by some of the foremost European critics to be fully equal to those of Schubert himself. It is in the school of Schubert that Mr. Albert Mallinson composes, but with a very strongly marked originality of his own, manifested as forcibly in the splendid accompaniments as in the beautiful songs themselves. He has been very fortunate in having as his interpreter so fine a singer as his wife. They were associated in a recital at the Bechstein Hall recently, when no fewer than 22 of Mr. Mallinson's song3 were sung by Mrs. Mallinson and ac companied by himself. The concert consti tuted a genuine and special musical treat. Madame Mallinson's voice has greatly im proved, and her interpretations were per fection. Messrs. Meynell and Gunn will direct a series of concerts to be given. by these two artists, commencing at the Town Hall on Saturday, 16th May. Madame Albani's success in India was so great, "musically, socially and financially," that it is probable that a second visit may be paid to Calcutta at the end of the year. There is in London now a tenor, ah Irishman, who, aeording to Mr. Ernest Gye, "has the best voice I haVe heard for years, not a very strong voice, but very sweet and sympathetic; and he sings splendidly." There can be little doubt that he refers to Mr. M'Cormiek, who made his debut last year. . After leaving Australia Miss Marie Ilall visited the United States with her pianist, .Miss Basche, and arrived in England on 13th September. On 25th January she wrote to Mr. J. N. Tait, from St. John's Wood, that she had 22 appearances already booked before Easter, and was to play the _Brahms Concerto with Henry Wood's orchestra on 21st May. "When do you think I can pay another visit to your country?" writes the violinist, "I hope it won't be long."

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Several thousand people were on the Port Melbourne pier on Tuesday last week, among whom were scores laden with beautiful flowers, to say good-bye to Mr. and
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Several thousand people were on the Port Melbourne pier on Tuesday last week, among whom were scores laden with beau tiful flowers, to say good-bye to Mr. and Mrs. ' Kennerley Rumford, who left in the Mongolia for England. Their farewell con-

cert at the iaxhiblfion on Saturday, 25th 'April, was a tremendous one, over 10,000 people paying for admission to the huge hgll, which was filled to the utmost limits of its great carrying capacity. It was, in short, a record ending to a record tour. From the day of lier first appearance in Melbourne Madame Clara Butt gave 71 con certs in all parts of Australasia— always to crowded and enthusiastic audiences. And, moreover, every one of these concerts were given on the advertised dates. Never once in the whole course of her tour did she dis appoint her public by not appearing — an achievement absolutely unparalleled by any other visiting artist. _ The Royal Victorian Licdertafcl gave a concert in the Town Hall on Monday even ing. Mr. Siede's Hymn to the Niglit, a charming and graceful example of his style;' and Mr. G. B. Fentum'sEvening Song of Normandy Fishermen, were very capably in terpreted by the Licdertafel choir. ' Schu bert's Chorus of Spirits, a veritable inspira tion of genius, was given in a manner that _ calls for the warmest of praise. Dudley Buck's Nun of Nidaros, an effective piece of work, was also capably done. Madame Mag gie Stirling, in Tscluiikowaky's ' Air des 'Adietix, was by turns impressive, imploring and emotionnl. In response to ft well merit ed encore she gave Elgar's In Haven — a good specimen of this composer's art. Three bracketed songs — by Fielitz, Willeby niul Squire respectively — were also contributed. Mr. F. II. Collier gave a good account of liimsclf in the Fagliacci prologue of Leon cavallo, and in Somervell's effective setting of Come Into the Garden, Maud. Mr. Ernest Toy, who lias progressed in his art since he was last here, presented Ernst's Ungarischcn Melodion, and also played Mendelssohn's Andante— from the concerto —with' admirable effect. 'At his opening concert at the. Town Hall on Tuesday night Mr. Charles Saunders ' showed high qualifieatiolis us a singer, but lie fell into error in attempting too much. Mr. Saunders sang a large number of songs, and, at the outset, sang them all well/ H<i

also delivered himself of a lecturette about music and musicians, with special reference to great singers and their songs. The ex cessive strain on the singer's voice, caused by the necessity of making himself heard all over the Town Hall, told on him before the evening was' over. Nothing could have been much better than his opening performance Of Handel's "Where'er You Walk, the softer passages being notably good; and later in Sound an Alarin he sounded one with great effect. But after wards, when he had been talking, all the more delicate effects missed fire. Mr. Saunders comes back to us a fine, intelli gent and most acceptable singer; and if he had been able to sing throughout the even ing as he sang at the start all would have been well. Miss Clara Robson (Mis. Saunders)'" has a serviceable contral to voice, and made a decided hit in Mendelssohn's . O Rest in the Lord, which she sang with feeling and ex pression. Later on she was heard to advan tage in Knight's evergreen She Wore a Wreath of Roses and The Banks of Allan Water. Mr. H. J. Elvins was a competent accompanist throughout. A second concert is announced for Friday evening. The world's greatest violinist, Kubelik, is expected to .arrive in Syduey on the lStn inst. He and bis wife, the Countess Czaky, are on board the Marama, which left Vancouver on 24th April. The Syd ney season of three concerts will begin on 19th May, and at its conclusion the distin guished artist and his party will come on to Melbourne, where three concerts will be given, namely, on 29th May and 1st and 10th June. Kubelik has just finished an extraordinarily successful tour of the United States and Canada. Amongst other notable appearances in those countries, a remarkable one was his concert at the New York Hipprodrome. This building was chosen on account of its size, and the -New York Tribune in its next issue, said: — "Last night Kubelik was the centre of a most ex traordinary scene, the colossal concert room being crowded to the roof and the vast audience listening as if .-spellbound by the genius of the great artist Standing be fore them." There were 5486 persons paid admission, a great number of whom waited after the performance to witness his depar ture. So great was the crush that the aid of a large body of police was necessary to clear the street. An interesting feature of the present tour is that two Australian artists have been chosen to assist Kubelik. These are Miss Erna. .Mueller, mezzo-so prano, who made an excellent impression in England; and Miss Dyason, pianist. Both of these ladies come from Bendigo. Herr Ludwig Schwab will act as accom panist. Emest Toy, the well-known violinist, will commence his Melbourne season in Glen's Hall on Thursday night, when he will per form Porpora's great sonata, Spolir's dra matic concerto, Wieniawski's scherzo taran- telle and other interesting works. The Victorian Festival Choral Society's first concert, Elijah, will be held in the Melbourne Town Hall at an early date. An invitation orchestral concert will be given in the Town Hall by Mr. W. A. Laver, at which one of Beethoven's latest overtures, Weike des Hauses, written about the same time as the great choral- symphony, will be produced. Tlie prosDects of establishing a perma nent orchestra here have been improved by the donation from an anonymous source of a sum of £1000 for the purposes of assist ing orchestral music- in 'Melbourne. It is hoped that this will be considerably added to by the public, the Government, the

municipalities and by private subscriptions, and that in this way it will be possible not only to give orchestral concerts, but to provide outdoor music and other forms of musical development. The donor lias nominated -the following ladies and gentle men as a committee to undertake control / of the fund:— Janet Lady Clarke, Airs. Al bert Miller, Mr. Lee, Mr. K. J. Larking, Professor Harrison Moore, Mr. M. P. Fox, Mr. E. Fitzgerald, Mr. Carl Pinschof, Dr. Hamilton Russell, Mr. S. G. Pirani and Dr. J.W. Barrett, thh lastnamed to be .chairman. Other donations , have' been re ceived "towards tlie fund,, including £100 froih Mrs. Albert Miller nnd>-£100 from Dr. J. W. Barrett. Til alb probability. Messrs. J. and N! Tait will organise an Australian tour for Signora Kuyello, J/the brilliant Spanish soprano, after her first appearance in Melbourne on 6th. Juue. Mark. Humbourg, soon to visit Australia under . the direction of Messrs. 'J. and N. Tait, fluid a great-compliment paid him by the- directors of th<u. Grieg -Festival, which i3 held usually in March every year 4n Paris. The young virtuoso was invited to playi but on account of 'other engagements lie, could not accept. Thereupon the festi val was postponed until Hlie 11th April, when Murk H'antbourg appeared, with Svendoden, the eminent composer, iu the eondiK- tor's chair, at .the concert. In consequence of a false impression hav ing got abroad, Messrs. J. and N. Tait write to say that the management of the Kubelik concert tour is not in their hands. The forthcoming concert season of the Mallinsons opens at tlie Town Hall oil 20th June. Mr. Mallinson, who arrived in Melbourne in 1891, spent five years here, and was recognised as an excellent musician. Since then he has become famous as a com poser. In 1391 he married Madame Anna Stciuliiun, tlie Danish soprano, who is re garded by her own country folk as their finest singer. Their song, recitals in Lon don have been a notable feature of the . musical world for many years. Both have appeared before Queen Alexandra, at Buck ingham Palace. -1'-- r:'"- '".'a

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Signor Enrico Caruso, the fatuous tenor, appeared at Covent Garden this week before a crowded bouse, when the enthusiastic audience included the Duke and Duchess
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Signor Enrico Caruso, the famous tenor, appeared at Covent Garden this week be fore a crowded house, when the enthusias tic audience included the Duke and Duchess of Marlboroogh, Countess Gidogan, and the Duchess of Westminster. The opera 'was ?'Rigoletto,' and Caruso was arrayed .in new costumes, his luggage having beeni burned at San Francisco. '

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Signora Tetrazzini the new Italian, prima donna at Govent Garden, has this week more than sustained the reputation she lias achieved within the past month,
articleText:
ML'SICAL.

Sienora Tetrazzim. the new Italian prima donna at Oovent Garden, has this week more than sustained the reputation she has achieved within the past, month.

ut a rival to l'atti herself. On. WedrCH lay, as Lucia di Lammermoor, she had a sniqne ovation after her rendering of the iifficult cadenza with flute obbligato in the lout scene. In response to the enthusias tic anolause from all part* of the house the Florentine star rendered the cadenza again, and on this occasion snrpassed her self b- sustaining bx wonderful E flat for sevora| seconds. Signora Tetraznm has a eharmin* personality^ which adds to the magic of her voice and acting, and there ires a fascinating southern vivacity in her acknowledgment of the flautirt as partaker t-f her triumph by making lrim a grao-ful little curtsey when «hc was called before the curtain at the end of the scene, while she accorded the sanro compliment to M-v Neil Forsyth. who engaged- her forv the Covent Garden season. : : ' :- - :

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: A WORK, entirely new to this country, by one of the greatest musical writers of this age, whose compositions (except occasional songs0, are likewise as a sealed book here,—Spohi's 'Last Judgment," was given last night
articleText:
MUSICAL,

A wons, entirely new to this country, by one of the greatest musical writers of this age, whose compositions (except occasional songs), are likewise as a sealed book bare,-Spobfa 'Last Judgment." waa given last night for tbs firs' time by the Vocal Harmonio Society. The charaetei of this tnnsio is totally different to everything that has been heard here, totally different to that of the other masters of oratorical music; it becomes all the grand harmonios of tb« aid tcbool with the flowiog melodious harmony of the piesent school ; the entire chorales (whioh constituía tba prinoipal portion of the work), being so fall of molu.iy, that the so os are quite ol eeeondarj consideration in Ibis respect, though tbe diffi- culty of their execution is thereby increased. There are .Iso occasional fine points and peculiar harmonio effects introduced (as in the quartet and chorus ending the first part}, that bear the strongest evidence of the great laboor that the composer haa taken in tba construction of his work,-a labour not equalled by Mendelssohn. Sphor hsa evidently written for tba effect that bis harmonies are intended to produce, he bas (in this piece J given hut little to shower off peculiar powers of particular vocalists; indeed lbs smalt snatches of detached airs often go mach below the register of the voice, for which they are written, tba tenor aira often verging on the baritone register. But th« great test of the peculiar oharaoter of the work ia in th« effect produced on the feelings ol tba audience ; many were .prêtent last night untutored po-sibly in the ?eisuse of musio, but no one failed to rendar that un- mistakable homage which tba tearful eye ia unable to -control. And speaking thus of this evident rosnlt, it

ia neoessary before detailing anything of the work itself, to say a word as to ita exeoution, .and but a brief ona ia neoeaiary. Dissgreeable as fault-finding naturally in, all the greater pleasure is experienced in being afile to bestow unqualified praise, and in the general . good. completely to ignore trifles. From begin- ning to end, the musio wis sung by principals and ohorus, in true appreciation of the oom potition; it was given with a delicacy and refinement that haa not been approached io thia conntry; in a word, tbe mmio had soul, and spoke to the soul ; and, despite etiquette, the applause was loud and oonstant, and an evident desire shown to bear some pleoes re- peated. This is the first time that there has been an opportunity of speaking in terms so high regarding tbis society. The solo vocalists were Urs. Bridson, Mrs. Cordn r, Mr. Ellard, and a gentleman amatfur; and as .ll sang equally well, it will not be necessary again to refer to them by name.

A novelty was introduced by the performanoe of the overture and the symphony anteoedent to the second psrl, à quatre mains, by Slr. Packer, tbe orgsnist of the soolety, end Air. Coroner, ita conductor, the duet having been arranged by tba former gtntlemao. This gave a fullness to - the musio, that greatly enhanced its

beauties.

Thu .' Last Judgment " is, as ita title imports, a con- sideration of the last earthly things. The subjeot of the text is taken principally from the Bo'.k of Bevelations . and one or two other portions of holy writ. After

the overture, a ohorus, "Praise the Lord," intermingled with . ' a . ? few solo passages, introduces the corning of the Lord at the Judgment Day, A short tenor solo describes the twenty-four elders around the throue, end they give praise io one of the il'jest choruses of the work (toking up the air from the tenor), "Holy, holy, holy' is God." Tbli is half chorale, beautiful in form and melody, rich in harmony, commencing pianissimo, inoreasiog in power, theo again diminishing, and fading away. The introduction and worship of tho Lamb is tor solo passages of soprano and tenor, the ohorus uniting in praiss. Continuing this subject is a beautiful and quaint but very difficult .Ito solo, "These are they which esme ont of great tribulation ;" this is followed by the richest and most eflVotive portion of tbe oratorio, the eonelusion of Ibt first patt, s'quartet for solo voices accompanied by fall ohoras, " HsiJ, Lord Almighty I" Tba swell on the word ** Almighty," the alternating responses, both of opposite voioea of the chorus and of oboruB and aol! ; the taking up of the voioes io parts, and tbe obanges from the finest .piano to po wer fal fo,te, produoe an effect that few osn

hear unmoved.'

The second part is Introduced by a symphony played .s a duet, concluding.with a brilliant allegro that moved the audience to enthusiasm. Then follows the largest air of the work, a bass solo introducing the great day of Judgment. The accompaniment of the organ with ita conclusion, introducing the sighing of the winds and the monrning of tbe dead, was auob as to exoita every nerve, .nd to cause every lip to quiver. . A duet, "Lird, re .member my affliction" (soprano snd tenor), waa one of ths loveliest pieces of musio we remember to have heard. A brilliant allegro ohorus annonnoes that "Destruction ia fallen on Babylon," sud" The Lsst Seal is broken." Another very melodious quartette and ohorus, " Blessed for Ever," blending the voices with fall power; and the .concluding choras, " Hallelujah," ia similar in its effect, and terminates the oratorio with a rash of harmonious

sons.

. ORPHEUS.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: English Opera Mouse, Sydney.—The performances of Madame Anna Bishop have consisted of Norma, Donizetti's opera of L'Elisir D'Amore, part of Taneredi
articleText:
MUSICAL.

English Opera House, Sydney. — Ibe performances of Madmuo Auuu Bishop have consisted of Nonua, Douizetti's ope ra of L'hlisir D'Amoiv, part of IWredi and Luciezia Borgia, the challenge sceuo from Lucia di Lammermoor, and tho cel

ebrated Mexican puce entitled La rasa dita. Of tbe Nonna of Madame Bishop wo have frequently recorded au opiuion ; nor have wo reason lo suppose the lyric ulago prodils no perfect an embodiment as that of the high priestess of this dis tinguished aud accomplished artiste. So essential to a finished delineation is the fusion or combination of inusicale with dramatique qualifications, that wo are pre pared to fiu'l many aspirants for public favour fail in their attempted impersona tion of this great character. However exquisite the talents of a vocalist may be, nevertheless, without the aid of certain physical attributes and the genius to feel anj depict the many phnBes of passion which so strongly distinguish tb© role of Norum, «-t) find that success, if attained, is not so decided ns thiit which attends tbe union of those qualifications which, in the aggregate, wo so rarely witness. Of tbe merits of Madame Auna Bishop, whether her Normn is considered, or tlio cluborato and artistic rendering of her Lucrezia Borgia, as performed on tho evening of Thursday last, we may venture tho asser tion that her vocal powers do not nlono call forth the admiration of her audieuce. In thi} picturesque positions — the com manding aud dignified gait— tho rcpobo and easo which characterises her style of acting — the graceful deportment, and in tho facial expression of joy, sorrow, an guish, revenge and despair, we may traco much of tho success achieved by this ac complished lady. Operatic fame is not so simple a matter as is that popularity which is guiucd iu tho concert-room. snippet: One sometimes hears a grumble that nothing in the nature of a good entertainment comes to Zeehan, and if we differ more in that reaped in the future we can
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Ooe sometimes hears a grumble tbat nothing in tbe nature of a good entertain ment comes to Zeehan, and if we eiiffer more in tbat respect in the future we can console ourselves that when a combination as good as the Newbury-Spada Company oomes along they are treated to emDtv

benches. In June last I had tbe pleasure of hearing them in the Centennial Hall in Sydney, singing before 4,600 people, and on the second occasion when I went it took me eight or ten minutes before I could reach tbe turnstiles to get in. The oonoert given last night was in every respect equal to either of these as far as the singers themselves were conoerned. This (Wednesday) evening will, I believe, be tbe last concert, and I hope that there will be an audience, which, even at the eleventh hour, wiligivea tardy recognition to the talent of the company. I should think that it will be the fast occasion we shall ever have. Newbury'e singing last night was magnificent ; in (sot, with the single exception of the late Joseph Mass, I never heard anything better in England. — Youra, etc, MARTIN BCSHTON. Main street ?

heading: Musical.
snippet: Messrs. Beale and Co. have just completed the equipment of a very charming little concert hull on the first floor of their premises in Crown Street
articleText:
Musical.

Messrs. Betile and Co. have just completed the equipment of a very charming little concert hail on the tirst Moor of their premises in Crown Street, U'oltongong. Xlie room (which should be ideal for chamber music) is about 20 feet by

CO feet, and is most tasteiuuy. aecora ted in blue and gold, seating accom modation tor about eighty persons is provided for with seagrass armchairs, and the liighly polished black floor, with blue and gold curtains on the wiu dowsi and blue and gold beaded shades on the lights, presents a most cultured and restful picture. A slightly raised platform occupies the northern end, and the same colour scheme is seen with the addition of soft rugs in pas tel shades with a background of grey. Jiach group of curtains has an over drape with a' golden fringe, and a gol den coloured medallion with the sil houette of an open grand piano in black. The stairs leading to the con cert room are carpeted in a rich blue with' an unobtrusive pattern, and the general effect of the whole upstairs and down is one of good taste and quiet elegance. Speaking to our represnta tive the manager (Mr. Par ry Brown) explained that the ob ject which animated the addition of such a delightful concert hall to the

musical amenities of Wollongong, was to foster and create a love of good music in such an important centre. Concerts will be given on the Beale Re-Enacting Electric Ampico Piano at the end of this month, and then will become a regular monthly feature. The concerts will feature the actual recor ding of such masters as Mosciwitch, Ornstein and Backhaus, and the rec ords of Moseiwitch playing such gems of modern composition as 'Jet d'eaux' (Ravel), 'Cathedrale Edloutie' (De bussy), and others should go far to familiarize Wollongong with the sub tle beauties of the modern school, ' whilst the classical composers are all interpreted -by acknowledged masters.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: A few decades back no more familiar name occurred in Tasmanian musical circles than that of Mr W. H. Spiller, who, as a violinist, took a front rank
articleText:
MUSICAL

' A few decades back no more familiar name occurred in Tasmanian musical circles than that of Mr W. H. Spiller, who, as a violinist, took a front rank among his then co-professionals. Not only as an executant did Mr Spiller shine

in the horizon of harmonics, but as a composer he proved himself above the rank and file. That the musician in ques tion is still as enthusiastic in the 'divine art' as yore is demonstrated by tho re ceiptiof a copy of a new waltz, written for the piano, entitled 'The Chimes,' bearing the mark of his authorship. Aim ing at simplicity rather than superfluous ornamentation, tho composer has opened with an introduction, in which the title of the piece is obviously expressed, and a similar featuro occurs in the coda and in the parts in which the waltz is divided, including No. 1. In, No. 2 there is a beautifully sustained melody, and a pleasing contrast to the fore going is contained in No. 3. Both bright and tuneful, with an absence of sameness, this now ane eloquent local production should be eagerly sought after during the approaching terpsi chorea'n season. It would also make an exceedingly pretty item for an orchestra or a band with 'full parts, as the piano I alone does not do full justice to the vari coloured tints to be found in it. If real merit is to meet with the success it de serves, this latest addition to the list of locally-produced musical pieces should prove a similar triumph.' Mr Spiller is at present in Franklin, and he announces by advertisement in another column that it is his intention to establish his residence here, and give in structions in the violin, piano, and man dolin, if sufficieht inducemsnt offers. Though his residence would be at Frank lin Mr Spiller would visit' adjacent town ships. Thus, it will be seen, Huon resi dents are to bo given the opportunity of securing the services of ? a resident musi cal teacher of proved merit. On the Level. — ' Do you assimilate your food, aunty?' — 'No, I doesn't, sah. I buys it open an' honest sah.' — ' Balti more American.' ? ... i

Music, London, have given their

consent to the establishment of a

immense advantage to have Doctors

of Music from the seat of the

us, year by year. Parents and

teachers in all our districts should

avail themselves of the examination

system at every opportunity at

their command.
