heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: THE MUSICAL UNION.—At a committee meeting held on Monday, it was deoided that two of the works recently added to the library should be put in practice for the concert to be given
articleText:
MUSICAL.

THE .Husicix TJKION.-At a committee meet ing held on Monday, it was deoided that two of the works recently added to the library should be put in. practico for the concert to be given on Mr. JefTeries leaving the colony. It was thought that the publio might reasonably ex pect this, and would prefer the arrangement to a repetition of "Elijah,'' while to the prac tising members it would have the attraction of novelty. The- works are " Acis and Gnlfltca," and Afendels.sohn's u Athalie." Neither of these have bee.i heard in Brisbane. To pro duce them will lay a pleasant tax upon the diligence of both the chorus and the orchestra, Stif-a^ptobably there will be a lull when Mr. Jefferies leaves, a little hard work beforehand will be the less objectionable. We believe that Messrs. Paling, Kaye, and - Jefferies. havo. inexpensivs copies of both musical works, if not sufficient,. very nearly so, for the^ require ments of {.ho chorus, while in the practice-room, there will be some copies available.

THE coocerfc given last' night week, at the Kelvin Grove School, in aid-of the Improvement Fund, went off Tery nicely, and proved a decided success. The attend ance was very numerous/ and the fund consequently received a considerable addition. The songs, &c., .were well rendered by amateur ladies and gentlenum, and drew forth the ; frequent and hearty iipplacuso of the audience. One of the most striking features of the even ing was "The Friar of Orders Grey," sung by Mr. H. Xi. Dinte, in character. The other itemk were satisfactorily given, and the pro gramme concluded, with the glee, "See our

oars."

THE IPSWICB: ilusicAi SocrEiT.-The fourth concert of the second season of the Ipswioh Musical Society took place at the School of Arts on the ISth instant, when AEacfarrea's " May Day," and a miscellaneous selection,

were performed. The lamented death of Mrs. Tozer, occasioned the absence of a great many of the performers, and a noticeable sparse ness^in the audience. The performance of "May Day" was principally remarkable for the open ing chorus, which went wit h admirable spirit, and the singing of Miss Cameron, who led through a recitative, solo, and chorus with an ability* and delicacy of execu tion which - evitSenzed diligence of study and attention to details. The second part opened with that inimitable glee, Bishop's " Chough and Crow," a piece of music, a part of which, for dignity of expression and sweeV ness of harmony, is unsurpassed by any we are acquainted with. Miss Cameron again came to the fore with the song " Once again," and received an encore, when she substituted

Bonny Doon." Miss O'Maliey achieved a similar distinction in the song " Kathleen Mavourneen." Mr. "Weise received liberal applause for his rendering of " The Standard Bearer." And after some Tery enjoyable quar tettes and trios the concert terminated with the

National Anthem.

PATTI IN* FSBNCH OPERA.-A piece of start ling nefrs for operatic circles is, that Madame Adelina Patti has resolved to sing on; the French, lyric stage, and that M. Halanzier has succeeded in securing her to make her debut at the National Opera-house in Paris, in M. Gounod's "Polyeucte," during the yeur of the International Exhibition; the date may ? bo presumed to be subsequent to the close of the lady's engagement at the Jloyal Italian Opera, Covent Garden, next season.

heading: Musical.
snippet: By announcement in our professional columns this issue, Misses Schubach and Watkins announce that they have commenced the practice of their
articleText:
Musical.

]iy announcement in our profession- j al columns this issue, Misses Schubach and Watkins announce that tliey have j commenced the practice of their pro

fession in Armidale, and are prepared] to take pupils for pianoforte.

Both come with the highest creden-j tials. Of Miss Schubach, Mr. War wick M'Kenzie refers to the distinc-. tion which she achieved whilst teach-:

ing at St. Vincent's College, Sydney-' He can speak personally of her "great skill as an accompanist. Mr. Percy French, the renowned tenor vocalist, and teacher of voice production and singing, certifies that he. has , known

Miss Schubach for ten rears. He speaks of her as on excellent accom panist. careful and painstaking. She is a thoroughly conscientious teacher.

The widow of the late R. He Beau pu:s records that Miss Watkins studied with her late hushand for several years and attained marked distinction, not; nnlv as a beginner, hut as an advanced student. Mr. Tj. D'Hage writes that during the two years Miss Watkins 'tudied with him she made considerable nrogress in higher grade piano nlaying She is well aenuninted with the best, class of musical literature, lioth classi cal and modern. Atjss Watkins studied1 with Mr. Prank Hutchens. A.R.A.M.. and he regards her as one who studied well, linth as regards theory and prac tice. and he holds a verv high opinion of lier musical achievements.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: For her initial concert in the Town Hall, Melbourne, this afternoon (Saturday, 1st June), Miss Marie Hall, the brilliant young violinist, has chosen a programme that will
articleText:
MUSICAL.

For her initial concert in the Town Hall, Melbourne, this afternoon (Saturday, 1st June), Miss Marie Hall, the brilliant young violinist, lias chosen a programme that will at once establish her reputation in these

parts of the world. Few artists attempt more than one concerto at a concert, but Miss Hall will play two with the Marshall Hall orchestra, which Messrs. J. and N. Tait have engaged for the occasion. These are Mendelssohn's in E Minor and- Max Brusch's in G Minor, both .most excellent compositions; and in addition she brackets four solos as another item — Ave Maria (Schubert Wilhelmj), The Bee (Schubert), Huinoresque (Dvorak), and Rejere Kati (Hub'ay). The concert will undoubtedly be a red letter one, for the orchestra itself is down to play the Prelude to Lohengrin and Hamish MacCunn's Ship o' the Fiend, which has not been heard here for many years, but which is recognised as being one of the most realistic pieces of descrip tive music ever penned. In her solos Miss. Hall will be accompanied by Miss JLonie Bascli, who is travelling with the violinist on her world tour. Evidently the Besses o' th' Barn Band are known and loved all over the English speaking world, for Messrs. J. and N. Tait are daily receiving from the most unlikely places requests that the band should be sent there, and offers to guarantee any reasonable amount of money as a result of their appearance. More than that, several towns— Perth (Western Australia) in par ticular — are forming Lancashire societies in order that their county representatives may he suitably welcomed on arrival. The Besses finished a very fine fortnight's sea son in Sydney last week, and are at pre sent touring' through northern New South Wales en route to Brisbane, where tli'dy play on the 12tli June. Madame Clara Butt had an exciting time with a motor during her Irish tour. Her secretary writes to Messrs. J. and N. Tait: -—"Mr. and Mrs. Rumford decided to motor to Punehestown, and off we started gaily from the hotel.- .In Graf ton-street we killed a dog. In Marion-square we nearly killed a man, on the O'Coniiell Bridge we collided with, a hay cart, and when we got to, the Exhibition the bally ear smashed the stay rods, and we turned out and had to come back to the city in a penny tramcar and go on by train." Miss Erna Mueller, who went to Europe from Melbourne some time ago to pursue her vocal studies, has already established herself as a singer, and by the last mail Messrs. J. and N. Tail received a budget of press criticisms dwelling very apprecia tively on her singing while on tour with Misclic Elmon. The English contingent of Mr. J. C. Wil liamson's new musical comedy company — Misses Maud Thorne and Daisy Wallace, Messrs. Miles. Clifton and Reginald Ken-

neth— are on the incoming Marmora, due to arrive in Melbourne on 2nd June, and the company is now entirely complete. Miss Amy Murphy and her sister arrived from New Zealand last Saturday, while Mr. Victor Gourlet (the leading comedian), Mr. Harold Parks, Mr. Pat Bathurst (who has been engaged for the company), Miss Celia Ghiloni and the others are all in readiness in Sydney. Rehearsals have al ready commenced in earnest under Mr. Gerard Coventry, on The Blue Moon, with which the company will open at the Princess's Theatre, Melbourne, on 22nd June. For the purpose of freshening up The Spring Chicken for the Sydney season, Mr. Gerard Coventry went to Brisbane last week to rehearse it with the Royal Comic Opera Company. Thr German Opera Company opened in Sydney on Saturday last in: Lohengrin, and were given a cordial reception. . It is stated that Madame Melba, during her" home visit here may' be induced to give an operatic representation of La Boheme, with the aid of the German Opera Company, on their retui'n to. Melbourne, 'about Cup time. Something of the quality of .voice pos sessed by Mr,. William Green, the .distin guished tenor to be. heard here shortly with Mme. Affiant's company, may be gathered fi-om this extract from a late, critique ap pearing in the "Midland Express": — "Mr. William Green, who sings better than, ever, gave Beethoven's famous Adelaida and 0 Vision Entrancing, by Goring Thomas, in his usual accomplished style. . Ih point of the velvety quality, his voice comes nearer that of Sims Reeves than any we ever heard." Besides Mr. Green, there will be heard with Mme. Albani in her Australian concerts, the popular English contralto. Miss Mildred Jones; Miss Myrtle Meggy, solo pianist, and Mr. Haydn Wood, solo violin ist. Mr. Theodore Flint is the accompan ist and conductor. . . Mr. Andrew Black has been astonished at the number of fine voices he has heard in Australia, where the popular baritone is making a protracted tour. "It all comes," he said to a Sydney interviewei", "from liv ing in this atmosphere, which is simply grand for the voice. Australia is Italy with a longer summer." Yet there is only one Melba. What will other aspirants to fame say to this statement? The latest reading of Wagner:— "The Valkyries, with their squeals and shrieks, must have been the suffragists of their period."

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: At the Marshall Hall orchestral concert on Saturday afternoon the programme was in the nature of a Mozart celebration, and, taken exclusively from the
articleText:
MU8ICAL.

At the Marshall Hall orchestral concert on Saturday afternoon the programme was in the nature of a Mozart celebration, and, taken exclusively from the master's works, embraced far more vocal music than is customary at these concerts.

One of thejuost meritorious of the works rendered was the G minor symphony, Even "with orchestral faults, it was refreshing to hoar again this master piece, the spirit of which the conductor was eminently successful in catching, and more particularly so in tlie lovely andante and the rugged strenuous minuet. The overture to Don Giovanni likewise recoiled careful and generally praiseworthy hand ling. The other purely instrumental work / was the fine concerto in D; :'iiiinoi- for piano and orchestra. Mrs. Charles Heath (better known iVqrhaps / as/ Miss Nellie Billings) ;essayed thp_ solo part with a considerable measure "of success/and tlie orchestra was fairly . equal" to requirements, though the time might have been 'more clearly marked in the opening syncopated passages. The vocal numbers comprised the letter duet from Figaro, tlie very familiar La ci Darcm and the big sestet sola from Don Giovanni. Of the singers, Miss Ilcsketh Jones is most to be complimented. Mr. Dunlop's serviceable baritone voice and nice free style stood him in good stead in La ci Darqm; and Miss Carmen Pinschoff and Mr. James Wade rendered useful service in the sestet. Mr. Ure and Miss Marguerite Henderson were, on the contrary, disappointing. The next concert takes place on 20th July, when Mendels sohn's Scotch Symphony will be revived after many years. Miss Jessie Masson's recital at Glen's Concert Hall on Monday flight was ambiti ous in conception. She strove beyond lier powers in attempting to present Liszt's wonderful transcription of the Wedding March and Elfin Revels, which ought to be left severely alone save by players of the very first rank. She was much better in the excerpt from Beethoven, the final presto in especial being finely clone; and in the Schumann Romances she also brought forward a rarely hoard Nocturne of Chopin— that iu F sharp minor; and her rendering of the same composer's Etude in A flat was more than passably good. In the Schumann concerto Miss Masson had the assistance at a second piano of ITerr Scliarf. The next concert of the Philharmonic Society will be given in the Town Hali on Tuesday evening, 23rd July, when Cole ridge Taylor's works, Hiawatha's Wedding Feast and The Death of Minnehaha, will be rendered, with full orchestra aiid chorus. For tlie succeeding concert a plebiscite has been taken, the result, which is interesting, being as follows: — Israel n Egypt (Han del), 99; The Golden Legend (Sullivan), 64: The Apostles (Elgar), 15; The Bohe mian Girl (Balfe), -13; Mors et Vita (Gou nod), 42; Damnation of Faust (Berlioz), 41; The Seasons (Ilaydn), 38; Faust (Gou nod), 3G; Judas Maeeabaeus (Handel), 30; The Creation (Haydn), 30; Elijah (Men delssohn), 30; The Lay of the Last Min- trel (M'Cunn), 30; Eli (Costa), 29; Rutli (Cowen), 27; Stabat Mater (Rossini), 27; The Passions (St. Matthew) (Bach), 23; The Redemption, (Gounod), 21; Ernani (Verdi), 20; St. Paul (Mendelssohn), 19; A Song of Destiny (Brahms), 17; Requiem Mass (Mozart), 1G; Samson (Handel), 15; Mass in C (Beethoven), 15; Tlie Choral

Fantasia - (Beethoven), 14; Xthalie (Men delssohn), 13; The Last Judgment (Spohr), 13; Lobgesang (Mendelssohn), 12; Mose in Egitto (Rossini), 9; Jeptha (Handel), 9; Judith (Parry), 9; Paradise and the Peri (Schumann), 9; The Rose of Sharon (Mac- Kenzie), 7; The Pilgrimage of the Rose (Schumann), G; Stabat Mater (Dvorak), 6; Ruin of Athens (Beethoven), 5; Engedi (Beethoven), 4. The tour of New Zealand upon which Miss Marie Hall entered at Wellington on Thursday of this week will, be even more hurried than her Australian one — and that, too, despite the fact that Messrs. J. and N. Tait were unable to secure dates in Auck land. Barely a month will be spent in the colony by. "the brilliant young violinist, during which time she "will be employed either with recitals or with travelling, and so fine lias the time been cut that she will fce forced to catch the Aorangi at Suva in order to be on hand for her London engage ments in October. The rest, of the Australian tour of the Besses o' th' Barn Band has now been de finitely arranged by Messrs. J. and N. Tait. After playing down from North Queensland, through New South Wales, to Melbourne, they play a season there, com mencing on 27th July, then leave for Ade laide and tlie West. Instead of going straight on to England they will then re turn, giving performances on route to Syd ney, where they are due to leave for Liver pool, via America, at the beginning of Octo ber. If at all possible, they will pay an other visit to New Zealand, but at the" pre sent time they are absolutely "set" upon getting back to their homes in Lancashire in time to eat their Christmas dinner there in, and if they stopped over, even for the next boat, that pleasure would be denied them. On the subject of foregoing it they are at present adamant, pointing out that one consecutive festive occasion is really all that any married man should miss. How ever, it may be that later on other coun sels may prevail, and the country which first welcomed may be the last to speed the parting guest. Last Saturday (29th June) "the farewell concert of Madame Clara Butt, previous to her departure for Australia under engage ment to Messrs/ J. and N. Tait, took place in the Albert Hall, London. For months past great preparations had been made for the event, to appear at which, every front 'rank concert artist iu Great Britain had volunteered, so that tlie occasion must have been really a notable one. Messrs. J. and N. Tait, of .Melbourne, on Monday received a private cable message from London stating- that Madame Clara Butt's farewell concert on Saturday was "a bewildering triumph." The attendance was enormous, and/the receipts were about £3500. The great contralto, who will be accompanied by lief husband, Mr. R. Ken- nerley Rumford, her- three young children, and also her sister, together with the raem- bcis of her concert party, will leave for Australia by tlie Mongolia on 19th inst. The tour opens in the Melbouijj,qJ,„XQyn. Hall on lOtli September. Madame Clara Butt few" .great artists who havefjjfeftfccd to Likcwffi assumed. name for prtff&fWiorMl wgyMia has clung all along up > Km- - patronymip.-? When she- married kQv. ford she even wanted to uBcgMxcr '"/ Usba ndV name in the conventional styTelJui the English public is -a conservative one, and consequently Glara..'. Butt -lias remained- Clara Butt all the:time. Indeed, occasion ally even that short and sweet/name is- ab- breviated--so world wide is lier fame— -and the management" of a Ilandel festival in England felt quite, justified in advertising it with the two words Messiah— Butt, se cure "in the belief that their great attrac tion would be. understood from these pithy words. . . . . At- the - Orpheus Society's next concert the Coronntion Ode "will be repeated, and the society's choir and orchestra will be assisted by a full military, band. ' The conversazione tendered to Madame Charboniiot-Kollermaim will be given in Glen's Concert Hall on 17th July. Madame Kellermann" leaves on the following day: for Europe to join her family! A series of popular concerts is being; ar ranged by Mr. Percy Cpwaixl, late of the Westminster Concert Company, to com mence on Saturday, 17th August. At the Grand National Eisteddfod, to he held at Ballarat by the South-street Debat-' ing Society, the prize money totals £1430 and the trophies amount to over £200. Tlie prize list embraces £500 for band contests, £400 for choral work, £200 for vocal and instrumental music, £175 for elocution, open scenes and dramatic work, and £50 for physical drill, calisthenics and other displays. Mr. J. W. Beswick, of Manches ter, England, is the chief musical adjudica tor, and Mr. Lawrence Campbell, of Syd ney, will adjudicate in the elocution sec tion. Miss Beatrice Miranda, .whose successful debut in London was announced last week, has been away from Australia for just one year. After duo consideration, and acting on the advice of her sister Lalla and Miss Ada Crosslcy, who was charmed with her voice, slio was placed in Miss Mina Fish er's care. Going home after a most suc cessful career in .Melbourne, her appearance in London was hailed with a certain amount of curiosity _ on the part of Australians resident in England. Her voice, it is said, has improved and filled out almost beyond knowledge — so full and strong is it now that she is being strongly advised to devote her attention to Germaii opera. . Her .selections on the occasion referred to comprised Welcome to Hall of Song 1'fom Taniiliaiiser, the mad scone from Iluinlot. the Ballet ella from Pugliaeci, and an aria from a French opera iust pub lished.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The farewell concert given to Madame Blanche Arral on the eve of her departure for Europe proved in every way a success. The Town Hall was well filled, the
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The farewell concert giVen to Madame Blanche Arral on the eve of her departure for Europe proved in every way a success. The Town Hall was well filled, the assist ance of her coadjutors was capable,

and Madame herself, high as the repute she had previously won here as a coloratura singer, came near to surpass ing it on the occasion under review. An extract from one of Adolphe Adam's operas, Si j'etais Roi, was given. The aria sung by Madame Arral was a succession of exercises in agility of throat and larynx calculated to excite astonishment rather than admiration; Madame Arral, however, was rapturously encored for her achieve ment, Ganz's Sing, Swee't Bird, being the added number. Another extract was from Maillart's opera known in French as Les Dragons de Villar.s, and in English as The Hermit's Bell. Alter this solo she was twice encored, giving successively as supplementary numbers the Bell Song from Planquette's Cloches de C'orneville, and (when that did not suffice) Bemberg's Nymphes et Silvnins. In the duet she was happily associated with Mons. Napoleon Boft'ard. An ovation awaited her after Bishop's I.o! Here the Gentle Lark. Verdi's Merce Diletti -Amici, from The Sicilian Vespers, aroused another outburst of enthusiasm, to which she responded with a brilliant Spanish Bolero by Vasseur. Madame Arral wound up the evening's en tertainment with the celebrated Folaeea from Mignon. The rest of the con cert may be briefly dismissed. Miss Carmen Pinschof sang the lovely aria of Saint Saens Moil Cceur s'Ouvre a ta Voix, and in response to fur ther demands gave the Wiegenlicd of Bralnns, in both of which she had been heard at a previous concert the same week. Later on she brought forward two interest ing songs by Guy d'Hardclot — The Dawn and Because— in, both of which she ereated a very favorable impression, an encore, which took shape as Findon's Till I Wake, being again insisted on. Mr. II. S. Elvins, in a piano solo, and Miss Lilian Pricliard, in a recitation, also eontrbuted materially to the enjoyment of those present. The second concert given by the Marshall Hall orchestra was an improvement on the first. Beethoven's Seventh Symphony was given, and the performance of the whole work was brilliant; special mention being due to the delightful scherzo with its finely contrasted trio and to the exhilarat ing finale. Dvorak's Legendcn, represented by Nos. I. and IV., are instinct with life and movement, tinged always with the peculiar -Czechish "flavor" both of melodic device and harmonic treatment. The first is tolerably familiar, tlse other is perhaps more bizarre in conception, but cannot fail to be impressive when capably and intel ligently interpreted. Properly to appraise the opening of the third act from Tristan und Isolde one wants the scenic effects. But the feature of this excerpt was the remarkably fine playing of the solo on the English bora by Dr. lludall. The music is difficult, partly as regards inter vals, but chiefly as an exercise in holding the breath; for, like the oboe, the cor anglais never allows the performer to "expire"— in the classical sense of letting

the breath escape — during the progress of a phrase. Dr.: Rudall, however, not only wrestled with Wagner's merely tech nical 'difficulties, but also gave the music with fine tone— nasal, of course, as befits the instrument, but far less nasal than is customary. It was an exceedingly good performance, for which the player was warmly acclaimed. The concert wound up with Wagner's Meistor- singer 'overture, and this was finely and im pressively given. Messrs. J. and N. Tait evolved an excel lent idea in connection with the big charity concert given by Madame Clara Butt in the Sydney Town Hall last Saturday (28th March). Instead of leaving the audience in the dark as to the way in which the pro ceeds were to be applied, they asked them to decide the distribution amongst them selves on voting papers, and the institu tions which secured the most votes were benefited in proportion. The Melbourne season commences this week. The first of the series will be given on Thursday, and others on Saturday, and on Monday and Friday next week. . It is an interesting fact worth noting that the principal lady vocalist of The Merrymakers, the combination which is to open an Australian tour under Messrs. J. and N. Tail's direction at the end of April, was with The Follies, the band of enter tainers who have madq themselves famous throughout Great Britain, and indeed by repute all over the English speaking world. When the last mails left England Mark Hambourg was in the midst of an import ant provincial tour, undertaken as a sort of farewell before" he left for his Australian visit, under the direction of Messrs. J. and N. Tait. Judging by the press excerpts re porting that tour, he made a profound im pression. Mr. Charles Saunders, the English tenor-, is to visit Australia on a concert tour in the near future. Mr. Saunders, whose fine voice and temperamental - interpretation were the objects of such admiration when lie was out here a few years ago, has risen still further in the musical world since those days, and for the last three Handel Festivals in London he has appeared as the principal tenor. He will be accom panied by his wife. Orchestral and band music has always been popular with the Australian public, and this was never more forcibly demon strated than last year, when the Besses o' th' Barn Band toured the continent .and achieved a triumphant success. This -year Australians will have the opportunity of hearing the Royal Artillery Band from Newcastle-on-Tyne, which has been secured for the Australasian Concert Company, an Adelaide organisation, by Mr. P. A. How- ells, who is well known in connection with the lours in Australia of musical stars. The company is largely indebted for the services of the band to Mr. John Dixon, of Messrs. Boosey and Co., London,, who was in Australia with the Besses o' th' Barn. The band will leave London by the White Star liner Medic on 9th April, reaching Adelaide in the middle of May, and after a season there will proceed .to Melbourne and the other eastern capitals. The party is comprised of 36 members, among them being many instrumentalists who are noted in England as soloists. The band master, Mr. Robert Smith, belongs to a well known English family, members of which have achieved prominent positions in the world of music. The tour of the band will extend over several months, and will include ' a visit to New Zealand. Madame Ada Crossley toured the whole of Great Britain with the concert party which is coming out to Australia with her, and in a letter to a friend in Melbourne she enlarges enthusiastically upon the good fellowship which existed between them all. It was so apparent, she says, that they were a happy, jolly little party, that the excellent terms upon which they were witfi each other were somehow conveyed to the audience — a fact which made 'their hun dred and odd concerts a constant pleasure to performers and hearers both. Now that it has been proved to demon stration that the English language does not offend the ear of opera-goers, it is hoped that Dr. Naylor's opera The Angelus, which recently gained the prize in the eom- getition organised by Messrs. Rieordi, will e produced in the language in which it was composed. One of the terms of the competition was that a public performance would be given under the auspices of the Grand Opera Syndicate in the season fol lowing the announcement of - the award. Moreover, there is a precedent for. opera in English during the grand season at CoveuC. Garden, Dr. F. II. Cowcn's Harold having been given in the native tongue, under Sir Augustus Harris's management, in 1895, with Madame Albani, Mr. Richard Green and Mr. David Bispham in the cast.

articleText:

Music teachers and all music lovers are earnestly requested to attend the meeting which th p. mayor (Ur. Abbott) has con vened for this evening at 8 o'clock in the

Town Hall. Mr. j. suuon urow, ine or ganising secretary of the University Con- servatorium of Music. Melbourne, will put before the meting a scheme -for holding | a series of six-vocal and instrumental con- j . certs of an educational character duringi the "Winter months at the very reasonable | charge of 7s 6d pen-season ticket, provid ing he receives sufficieut. encouragement and support from the Bendigo public to warrant 'him doiuc so. Although these concerts were held last year they were so poorly attended that the result was fin ancially a failure, though there could be no question of iheir artistic and educational value to the musical public. R is sincerely hoped that those citizens who value Ben- digo's reputation as a musical centre will sihow their practical interest by being pre sent at the meeling to-night.

It will be seon by reference to an advertise mont elsewhere that the date of entry for the Sydney College of Music examinations hinae boon extended to Saturday next, September 19. The work of rescue is being pushed forward with all speed at the Huntly colliery, N.Z. Parties of helpers are a orking in relays. It is feared that the total list of victims will in clude the names of at least 41 men. Many more bodies have been recovered. The outstanding feature of the disaster has been the unselfish heroism of the officials and the miners in risking their lives in the hope of saving the entombed men. A contract has been let to instalh the electric light in thle municipality of Katoomba. The estate of the late Sir Normand Mac Laurin has been valued at £68,889 for probate purposes.. The price of bread has been increased by Id the four-pound loaf in Wellington, N.Z. Meat has also been advanced,

The director, Sir Hubert Parry, in his report for the Christmas term (says the 'Age'), speaks of Miss Sin clair as having made great Improvement in the study of the violin and piano and satisfactory development in harmony. Mr. Lachlan G. Sharpe, well-known in Australia as a pilot of various concert com panies, has opened a concert agency in London. Madame Albanl, It is reported, is con

Sir Arthur. Sullivan's Will. Additional details of Sir Arthur Sullivan's will are now disclosed In the London Press.; To Mr: Edward Dlcy, one of his execu tors, he leaves 'a comfortable armchair, and tho 'Encyclopaedia Britannica.' 'V Mr.! Charles Matthews, barrister, another executor, receives 'a collection of framed playbills, with the names of celebrated ac tors and actresses of the eighteenth and part of. the nineteenth century.'1 Mr. D'Oyly Carte is to have 'the auto graph full scoro of 'Iolantho,' an.d ^ an en graving, of Solomon's picture, 'The Judg ment of Paris.' Mr. W..S. Gilbert 1b left tho scoro of .'Ruddlgore.' Tp the Prince of Wales is bequeathed a tortoise-shell and silver carclbox and the clip to match; tho Duke of York, a carved silver-mounted coooanut; and the late.Duko ot Saxe-Coburg, the original autograph full score of 'Tho Light' of the World,' in r'o mombrance of 'many happy hours' spent' with his Royal Highness when he was writing it;- al3o'the' muSlc-sland which be longed to Sir Arthur's' friend, Joseph .Barnby. ? ; ' ' ' '?' ; To his 'devoted servant and good friend Clothlldc Raquct,' who had nursed him 'through so many Illnesses,' £1000 and certain' furniture.

snippet: Madame Laura Carrington, an Australian soprano, made her debit in London last month at the Portman Rooms, at a concert given by Mr. Chas. Santley, under whom
articleText:
Musical.

Madame Laura Carrlngion, an Australian soprano, made her debut in London last month at i tho Portmari Rooms, at a concert given by Mr.. Chas. Santley, under whom she is stud vise.' '??-.?? . '. ?? ? ? ' ? ?Madame Melba's youngest brother, Mr. Ernest Mitchell, has just gone to the front In- South Africa. He was intended for an Australian ' scuatter. but his tenor volco

led him to Italy arid Germany, where h« also Btudied theory and composition,, and later ho travelled wlffi his sister. , Miss-Mabel Manson, the Dunedln (N.Z.) soprano studying under Mr. Charles Sant Iey, ivitb whom sho sang at a concort in London recently, lias gained a further step forward in her career by singing before Mr. Coleridge, at Rochester. The famous composer of 'Hiawatha,' it is reported, sent her a letter, expressing his satisfac tion, and giving her much encouragement.

heading: Musical.
snippet: Mr. Carte has engaged Mr. Edward German to finish the late Sir Arthur Sullivan's score of "The Emerald Isle." which it is , hoped will be produced at the London Savoy
articleText:
Musical.

Mr. Carte hus engaged Mr. Edward Ger man to finish the late Sir Arthur Sullivan's score of 'The iimerald Isle,' which It is hoped will be produced at the London Savoy about Easter. ?. ? ' ? * ? ' A preliminary meeting of the committee for tho Vera Eyton benefit concert was held

on Saturday at the Hotel Australia. It was resolved to nold th« concert at the Cen tenary Hall on March 20. Tho arrange ments for the programme are In the hand3 ot Mr. H. N. Southwell. Miss Eyton (who loaves by the Cuzco on the 27th) Is at pre sent a member of the Hawtrey Comedy Company. Sho i.1 to continue her vocal studies in England. Slgnor Hazon, her late teacher, considers her voice of great promise. Mr. Fink, Mr. Musgrove's representative

with tho Grand' Opera. Company, tells a good story about a man who wont to see 'Lohengrin.' The stranger saw 'Carmen' one night, and then, missing a night, went again when 'Carmen' was Aguin ? being played. Seeing Mr. Fink, he saild: 'Look here. I saw 'Carmine' the night before last and I come again to-night and I see 'Car mine' again. Now,. 'Carmine's' all right, but 1 wanned to see 'Lonnlgon.' ' Mr. Fink' ex- plained thmt they played tho operas on nl tornate mights to rest the artists. Ho said If the patron cume on the following evening he could see 'Lonnlgan,' as ho called It. The man canio, and Mr. Fink, being anxious to hear what ho thought of 'Lohengrin,' went over and Interrogated him. 'Well,' ho remarked, 'tho blokes can sing all right, but lot's go and have a drink; I can't stand 'Lohnigan'; givo me 'Carmine !' ' Mr. Fink then told him tho best was 'to come, explain ed the action of the opera, got the man into the theatre again, and he was so delighted tha!t ho heard the Wagncrion nmsterpleco three or four times afterwards. ? ? ? ? . An amusing incident occurred at the re hearsal of one of the Gilbert and Sullivan operas (says Mr. Grossmiith In the 'Pall Mall Magazine'). Sullivan made us all come in a crowd to the footlights and sing with outstretched arms over, the footlights towards 'the gallery, a la Italian method. Tho composer screwed his eyeglass into his eye, and, addressing us individually, said: 'Don't you understand; I want you to think you are at Covent Garden Opera, not at the Opera Comitiuo ? I yranlt you, Miss — — t to Imagine you are Adelina Patti; and you, my dear Grossmitih, are dreadful — there is not enough Mario about you.' I saw what ?he meant, and exaggerated the Italian mode, and neariy fell over the footlights into the orchestra.. Sullivan, with a smile, said: 'Ah ! 'that's better. Capitol ! Do oven more. You needn't consider your safety.' Verdi, the grand old man ot the musical world, who died a few weeks ago, suffered much at the hamls of organ-grinders, and it is' said that to hoar one of his pwn pieces ground out on thalt terriible instrument of torture, the barrel-organ, was more than 'he could bear. The first opera libretto that Wagner ever wrote, according to a London paper, was so morbid that it aroused his sister's antipa thy, and the piece was never finished, but it could not hold a candle to Ws first lite rary effort, which was a drama penned at the early age of fourteen. In tho first four acts forty-two speaking characters mot with violent dealths, and tho cast was so much depleted that the characters had t» be worked in again as ghosts: Wagner's later works were cheerful in comparison. ? * ? « Miss Beatrico'Grifnths, the Sydney pia nist, h'as several important London engage ments, including one at a forthcoming Patti concert. ? ? .«'»?«' Which is the largest organ in the world ? Most of our readers would unhesitatingly give. the palm to thalt in the 'local Centen nial Hall, which, if we Include the 'thunder atop' and the carillon, can boast of 128 speaking stops. But ait Lib.au, in Germany, they have an instrument, built in 1S85 by B. Grun'eberg, of Stettin, which has 131 stops; and that in the Cathedral at Riga is said to have either 120 or 130. So Cbait merely on the score of hugeness, the Sydney orgaxrr seems only to come third on the list of honor(?). But Oho Americans, with their roverence for bulk, have in contemplation (says the Melbourne 'Age') the erection of en organ larger than any of these. It is about time we heard tne end of this craze for tho gigantic in organs. And many or? gnnists and. persons competent to give on opinion say that some 65 or 70 stops, if judiciously -chosen, will give practically every combination nnd variety of tone that a performer can wish. Anyone can put up a 'bigger building 'than the Parthenon; but he does not thereupon shout for joy at hav ing surpassed Phidias and his contempora ries. ? ? ? ? Anronos of onrans, the following dpsnrin

tion of an organ in Winchester Caidhedral in the 10th century will not come am'iss. This instrument, had 400 pipes, and required tlie united exertions of 70 stTong men to keep it supplied with wind; and though it tad cmly ten keys, it needed two performers to manipulate it. The keys were about three inches wide, and the player used'hls gloved first or his elbow— save the mark ! — to bring out the tones. There has fortunately been many changes for the better since those old days. . * ? ? ? ? * . According to 'Lo Monestral,' a good doal of secrecy is being maintained about Herr Siegfried 'Wagner's new opera, 'Herzog Wildfang.' The score and libretto are printed, but Horr Max Brockhaus, of Leip sic, keeps both under lock and key. By the enterprise of a Dresden Journalist, however — the modern newspaper laughs at lock smiths — tho argument has been given to the world, and proves to be of the lightest and most gossamer-like texture. Siegfried is wiso in not attempting to don thelmantle of immortal Richard; the sons of Tom Hood, Charles Dickens and a host of other celebrities who could be named did not show the same critical discernment.

"Your husband does not seem to have any organic trouble," said the doctor.

"Oh, no," said the wife, "not in this neigh borhood. But the folks that live next door to us have a phonograph that .worries him nearly to death."

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Concerts have been given during the past fortnight by all three of the chief choral societies of the city. The Sydney Liedertafel came first an[?] its concert was in certain respects of most value,
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Concerts have been given during the past fortnight by all three of the chief choral societies of the city, The Sydney Liedertafel came first and I its concert was in certain respects of most value, for at it was produced Felicien David's picturesque .' Symphonic Odo," entitled " The Desert" which has not been heard here since early in 1887. The performance was meritorious, and reflected credit on the conductor, Mr. J A. Delaney. The solo portions were (sung by Mr. Henry Stockwell, of Melbourne. The

concert also included a miscellaneous (election of vocal and instrumental pieces performed by com 1 potent artists, The Admiral and Lady Charles Scott, were present The Metropolitan Liedertafel Society followed a couple of days later with a gentlemen's " smoke " concert On this occasion the work of the society was confined to the performance of male voice part songs of comparatively small importance, and the rest of the programme was made up of songs and violin and violoncello solos. The Philharmonic Society gave its annual performance of "Messiah" on Christmas night under the direction of Signor Roberto Hazon. For many years it has been the custom in Sydney to produce the oratorio the night of the great Festal Day, but there is a growing conviction that the time is not well chosen. The attendance was smaller than usual, and the audience showed a strong desire to get to their homes at an early hour, with the result that a very large proportion left long before the end of the performance Much of the solo music was admirably suit?, the principal vocalists being Miss Frances Saville, Mrs. Yanderveer Greene, Mr. Harry Clinton, and Mr. F. J. Hallewell. The chorus had been well drilled, and most of the familiar numbers were sang correctly both as regards notice and tempo, but the performance as a whole looked spirit. The failings are not attributable to the conductor who, indeed, is one of the most talented who has been in Australia,

but rather to the fact that people are careless

about the rehearsal of a work so well known as this, while also it appears that at such a time as Christmas Night there is but small disposition to set seriously to the work of performing difficult and

elaborate music

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The chief musical event that has occurred during the past fortnight was in connection with the formal dedication of the sanctuary of St. Mary's Cathedral. A chorus of about
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The chief musical event that has occurred during the past fortnight was in connection with the formal dedication of the sanctuary of St Mary's Cathedral. A chorus of about 200 ' voices, comprising the combined Roman Catholic choirs of Sydney, an orchestra of over 60 performers, and a large number of solo singers, were engaged in a musical festival held in the cathedral on the afternoon of the days preceding the formal dedication. On that

occasion Rossini's " Stabat Mater " was performed in its entirety, and other compositions by Handel, Mozart, Beethoven, Cherubini, Rossini, Co,, were

also produced. The performance was very credit

I able to the amateur members of the cathedral and

church choirs, upon whom fell the greater portion of the work. At the high mass celebrated on the occasion of the ceremony of dedication, the music

performed was that known as Mozart's " Twelfth Mass." This was impressively and creditably won dered by the combined Catholic choirs of the city, supported by a small orchestra of string and|\vood."»Vmd, and the organ, the latter being under the charge of Mr. Neville Barnett, F. C.O., the cathedral organist The direction of the performances. both occasions devolved upon Mr. J. A. Delany, the choirmaster of the cathedral, who has gained 1 great credit for the successful results he obtained from the material at his disposal. The musical officials of the cathedral have determined to take advantage of the occasion, and endeavour to organise a permanent union of the Catholic choirs of the arch

diocese.

The Burns Club, connected with the Highland Society of New South Wales, celebrated the birth- day of Robert Burns by a concert, chiefly composed of songs associated with the homely national poet

of Scotland.

Music is satisfactorily progressing in suburban localities. At one of the outlying Anglican churches (St Thomas's, North Shore) selections from Handel's " Messiah " were performed last week by the choir of the church, under the direction of the organist, Mr. Joseph MasSON. The suburb of Summer Hill, also, has just organised and inaugurated a choral union, under the conductorship of Mr. Frank Brewer, well known in Sydney as the director of the choir at St Patrick's (It. 0.) Church. The first concert was given last week, and proved to be up to the standard aimed at.

The following instrumental works were performed Beethoven's Opus 59, No 3 the third of the " Ransoumowski " quartets); Mendelssohn's pianoforte concerto in G minor; Saint-Saens' transcription for violin, piano and organ of the March. Religious." from Wagner's "Lohengrin"; Emile Saurot's Nocturne in E major (op. 16) ; Reber's popular " Berceuse ; " and No. 4 of Brahm's " Hungarian Dances." Miss Florence Menk-Meyer has given two more pianoforte recitals, and there has been one of the fortnightly organ recitals at the University.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The year marks the bi-centenary of the death of Aroangelo Corelli, the famous Italian violin virtuoso, who laid the foundation of good violin
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The year marks the bi-centenary of the death of Aroangelo Corelli, the famous Italian violin virtuoso, who laid the foundation of good violin technique. Corelli was the most esteemed master of his instrument of his day. To him are attributed the systematisation of the science of bow ing, and the regulation of the shifts and the introduction of chord-playing. Also, it is sa'i3. he contributed mate

rially to the foundations of modern or chestral playing, and was instrumental in moulding the sonata form. He wrote upwards of 60 sonatas and con certos, and these and other of his com positions are still regarded as clas sics. His greatest effort was 'Con- cert Grossi,' whioh saw the light just Bix weeks before his death. Many of the works published under Corelli's name are probably spnriouSj but the authenticated sonatas remain in re quest among present-day artists, and they are held in much favour by cul tured Audiences. ' Defend Australia,' the words by George Benson, the music hv D. L. Palmer, published by W. H. Glen and Co., is a patriotic song. Its melody is bright and stirring with a swinging chorus, tiie words of which read : — ' The army and the navy. With a hundred thousand more, Could keep the flag still flying At the end of any war. For the future of Australia Depends upon us all, So bring the question forward, And be ready at the call.' There is sufficient stirring music to make it a popular song at any pat riotic gathering. ' Defend Australia ' will be played at the Lyric theatre, Prahran, this evening. heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: CHORAL SERVICES AT TOOWOKG CHURCH.— The full choral services at Toowong parish church, on Wednesday evening, were exceedingly attractive, and the new setting of the
articleText:
MUSICAL.

CHOKAL SKBVICKS AT TOOWOKG CHURCH.-t The full choral services at Toowong parish chnrch, on Wednesday evening) were exceed ingly attractive, and the new setting of the hymn, " Nearer my God to Thee," does great credit to the composer. The music is beauti fully adapted to the words, so much BO, that we think it will prove a popular hymn, and, should be published with a view to a more ex tensive circulation. The anthem on the occa. sion was that by Himmel, "Incline Thine ear," for solo quartette (unaccompanied) and chorus, and was well rendered by the choir of the church. The sermon was preached by the Rev. G. G. Bobinson, of All Saints, and the offertory was for the reduction of the debt on

the church.

CONCERT.-A ballad concert by Mr. Atkinson and family (with some amateur assistance) was given on Wednesday nightat the School of Arts. The attendance was not equal to the merits of the performance, but some allowance must be made for the fact that the title given to the concert was hardly realised in the programme. There was very little ballad properly so-called. The attraction might have been greater if more of the selections had come within the category known as popular, and if some of them had not been beyond the Fcope of the voices which essayed them. Most musicians would shudder at the notion of the overture to " Zauber Flote," being performed by a violin, concertinas, and piano; yet this celebrated piece, concerning which more, perhaps, has been written than of any other composition of equal size, was ren dered much more pleasantly than could have been expected. Hiss Atkinson carried off the honours of the evening. She sang well through out, and achieved a genuine success. The duet from " I Puritani," which this lady shared with her brother, was deservedly encored. Mrs. Atkinson sang " Children's Voices" very well; but 410 mio Fernando" did not give equal satisfaction. The gentlemen amateurs were painstaking, but their selections mijrht have been more attractive. The descriptive air calle4 " The Raft," might, as far as descrip tion is concerned, have been entitled " The Walking Funeral." In the absence of power ful instrumentation, the popular can only be safely studied at these concerts. We trust that on a future occasion the Atkinson family will meet with the support they deserve..*

YOUTHFUL PIANISTS.-Two youthful pro digies in the shape of two little girls named Douste-pianists of the age of 12 and 7 years respectively-are just now attracting

much attention In Pari*. Madame Pereire first took these new candidates for fame and fortune

by the hand; under her kindly auspices, they have become " the rage" of the moment, and " everybody" is trying to have thematthe private musical Boirees, which, during Lent, console the gay world for the absence of dancing. Tbey have been playing at the Elysee, in the splendid saloons of the Marquis de ialhoriet, Baron Gourgand, Puke de Montmorency, Prince de Hontholon, the Duchess of Newcastle, and other tip-tops " of the " great world fo this city. When lately in England, they had. the .honour of performing at Windsor Castle. The youngest had a beautiful red camellia in her belt. "You have a beautiful flower!" said the Queen to the little creature. "It Is my taliftmau, your Majesty!" replied the child,4< Mademoiselle Albani gave it me; she said it would bring me. luck." " Here is another flower that will bring you luck also " returned the Queen, as she smilingly broke off a splendid white camellia from a plant just "by, and placed it beside the red one in the little girl's sash, giving a motherly kiss to the mite of a musician as she did so. Since they came to Paris, both the children wear, a flower wherever they go; these flowers, renewed every day, are always the gift of, Madame Albani, the diva having taken a great liking to the two wonder ful little prodigies, and 'the children having the greatest possible confidence in the "luck" which.; they:fancy is. secured to them by the flowers thusgiven them by the great songstress, for whom they haver a sort, of worshipping

affection.

How TO SING A. SOKG.-Not the least im portant requisite of "how to sing a song" is (says Mr. Cumming*, the well-known [English shiver) nerve. If the singer allow nervousness to get the mastery, it is impossible that the K>ng can be well sung. Of course some degree of nervousness is natural and desirable, as.evi dence tbat the vo<jalist possesses both soul and sensibility; but nervousness must be controlled, and the best antidote against it is the conscions * ness that the singer has well studied the song,

and knows that he or she can render it compe tently and correctly; and I may add that the singer must not be discouraged if the first attempt at singing a.well-studied song Bhould not prove as successful as it ought to have done. The second trial will probably right mattern; the old mottoes," perseverance," and "try;try again/'"are as applicable to singing as to all undertakings. I cannot better con clude than by recording a tradition of John Btirtlemnn, the most celebrated singer of the last century. He was described as *' small of stature, but a leviathan in intellect," and, it is said, used to declare that he "never sang a song in his l:fe before the public until he had studied it, the words more, especially, for twelve months." We may allow for the gradual ex aggeration of the story by passing from one narration to another, and also something for . the slow pace of olden days; but even then the

anecdote gives us a hint which we ought not to be too dull to profit by.

CEAUPAOHE.-The RheimB Chamber of Com merce reports that 16,207,841 bottles of cham pagne were exported from France last year, and estimates the average selling price at 3f. (2s. 6d.) a bottle, or £2,025,980 for the total quantity exported. The number of bottles re tained for consumption in France was 3,629,421.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: On Saturday last (15th June) Miss Marie Hall gave her first concert in Sydney, and the reception accorded by music lovers of that city was on a par with that which she
articleText:
MUSICAL.

On Saturday last (loth June) Miss Marie Hall gave her first concert in Sydney, and the reception accorded by music lovers of that city was on a par with that which she won in Melbourne. A great audience

greeted her, and every succeeding number was received with increasing enthusiasm, until a perfect furore of applause was eli cited at the close of each item. The im pression she made was indeed profound. During the last few days she has been giv ing a series of concerts in Sydney, and next week she -leaves for New Zealand on the brief visit which was all that Messrs. J. and N. Tait could arrange for her. There is certainly some faculty, call it intuition, telepathy or. anything else that highly strung, nervous organisations pos sess, in contradistinction to the ordinary man in the street. Take for example a re cent incident in which Miss Marie Hall figured. She had been playing in Bendigo in the interval between two Melbourne con ceits, and on the morning after her recital she awoke feeling certain that something was wrong. When the papers arrived from Melbourne, where she was to play that evening, and before she had a chance to see them for herself, she declared that the an nouncement of the recital had not been ad vertised. It was really so, a clerical error in the office of Messrs. J. and N. Tait in Melbourne being responsible for the omis sion. Of all the concert party which Madame Clara Butt is bringing out for her Austral asian tour under Messrs. J. and N. Tait's management, Miss' -Marie Hall speaks in terms of the highest praise, with a special word of commendation for Mr. Frank Mer- riek, whom she classes as a very fine pianist, whose finished style is likely to ap peal to Australians. The scheme for the establishment of a festival choral society in Melbourne, put forward recently by Mr. Frederic Beard, is going apace. No fewer Than 230 applica tions were received last week, and the list will remain open for some months yet, be fore the final selection is made. It is in tended to give the first series of concerts announced during next year, and the first festival proper will most likely take place during the month of July, 1909. The Queensland tour of the Besses o' th' Barn Band, which began at Brisbane last week, is proving just as enormous at traction as has been the experience of the organisation all along their Australian sojourn. , Madame-Garreno will give in Sydney, on her return from Brisbane, three farewell recitals. Then „the .distinguished pianist

will go to Adelaide, to. New Zealand, and finally to Vancouver to tour the United States. The Sydney Philharmonic Society are ad vertising for a conductor, n&t only through the Australian press, but in the London newspapers. The concert on 22nd August is the last that the society's conductor, Signor Ilazon, will direct. The work chosen is Handel's Israel in Egypt. "A pronounced successs" was the un equivocal praise used by Mr. J. C. Wil liamson's London representative last week when he cabled the reception of Mr. Geo. Edwardes's new piece, The Merry Widow, which succeeded The Lady Dandies, at Daly's Theatre a few days ago. "Die Lus- tige Witwe," from which the new success has been translated, has for some time past been the rage throughout Europe, anda recently returned Australian who had done the grand tour declared that you could not. go into a town on the Continent where the piece was not being played or had been played (in which case you were flrivien- nearly mad by tlio constant whistling of the melodies), or in which the residents were not looking forward to its advent; Mr. Geo. Edwardes himself saw it in Vienna, and came back to London enrap tured with it." "I can recall nothing like it," he told an interviewer; 'The music is charming. All Europe is humming that gor geous waltz song in the second act." The story has a good deal of real comedy possi bilities in it, apropos of the love affair of

a ricn widow; -who. on the death of her banker husband, searches out her first love, and finds him unwilling to marry her, but willing to defend her from fortune hunters. It will be done here, of course, by the Royal Comic Opera Company. " The Spring Chicken has been playing to crowded houses ever since its opening night at Her Majesty's Theatre, Sydney, and, helped by the excellent interpretation

given it by the ltoyal Comic Opera Com pany, its gaiety, brightness and eatchiness have appealed strongly to the taste of playgoers there. Since leaving Australia some few years ago, Mr. 1'. B. Batliurst has met with varied experiences, including a consider able amount of concert nppearances in London and the English provinces, as well as a good deal of operatic work with the Carl .Rosa Company. But though tbc was everywhere well received, lie comes back, like most other returned Australians, more ardently patriotic than ever.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Madame Ada Crossley, with her husband, Dr. Francis Muccke, sails for Australia by the Orontes on Friday, 7th August, to take up her concert tour under the direction of
articleText:
MUSICAL

Madame -Ada Crossley, with her husband, Dr. Francis Muccke, sails for Australia by the Orontes on Friday, 7th August, to take up her concert tour under the direction of

Mr. J, p. Williamson. . Apropos of Mr. Percy Grainger's London farewell" recital, tlta London "Daily News" says: — "If Mr. Percy Grainger plays as finely during the tour be is about to take through Australia as he did yesterday afternoon its success will not be for a moment in doubt. He lias loug been re cognised as one of the best of British pian ists, but he has never displayed such ma turity of style and interpretative ability as were evinced in the course, of a long pro gramme, which .was as unhackneyed as it was exacting in the wide lunge of musical thought expressed." The forthcoming appearances of the three Cheraiavskis, who are announced to give a scries of concert recitals here shortly, will provide musical fare of the highest quality, ft is the first time that children of such conspicuous talents, and who have won fame before the most critical audiences on the Continent and in London, have visited- us. They will open in the Melbourne Town j Hall oa 19th September. The Royal Welsh Male Choir, which will arrive this month, commences its season in Sydney. The Melbourne season opens at! the Town Hall on 1st October. The Kingdom, Elgar's latest oratoria, will be given for the first time in Australia on Monday evening, in the Town Hall; by the Philharmonic Society.. - The soloists are Miss Lilian Reid, Miss Elva Rogers, Mr. Jas. Wade and Mr. Horace Stevens. The whole will be under the direction of Mr. Geo. Peuke. The final of the present scries of Mel bourne Chamber Concerts was given in Glen s Ifall on Wednesday evening. The Weston string quartet gave Beethoven's Quartet in.E minor, Mr. Herman Sckrader played Chopin's Ballade, op. 47, and, with Mr. George Weston, the Sonata in G major, for piano and violin, by Rubinstein The vocalist was Madame Chris tensen.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: At Kubelik's first concert in Sydney on Thursday evening he received a demonstrative reception. Crowds cheered him enroute, and a vast assemblage
articleText:
MUSICAL.

At Kubelik's first concert in Sydney on Thursday evening he received a demonstra tive reception. Crowds cheered him en route, and a vast assemblage await ed his arrival at the hall. He

was accompanied by Countess Kubelik, and was received by the Lord and Lady Mayoress. The enormous audience took him to its heart before he drew the bow across the strings. The violinist conquers as much by his demeanor as by his per fect playing. Ever unsatisfied, the audi ence recalled him time after time, and the concert concluded in a wild scene of clamor ous applause. The two Bendigo girls, Erna Mueller and Emily Dyason, had a most generous reception. There was simi lar enthusiasm at the subsequent concerts. The "Sydney Daily Telegraph" critic, in writing of Kubelik's first concert in Syd ney, says: — "The writer of this notice heard Kubelik at the beginning of his career, at a time when the young virtuoso showed more of the objective than subjective quali ties of a player. lie was conscientiously intent upon faithfully and musically fulfil ling the composers' intentions, and was not conspicuously intellectual, perhaps, but strangely musical and exhilarating. His playing had the buoyant, sparkling nature of which youth alone is capable. There was a singular beauty and clarity of tone, a wizard-like delivery of octaves, double stopping, harmonics and double harmonics. There was ever the purest intonation, and in the rapid runs an ability to turn off the notes with the utmost distinctness. True, it was not the most impassioned violin playing, but who would have Subjected the young Bohemian virtuoso to comparison with Ysaye, and the other mature violin giants. It is somewhat different now. Kubelik's playing shows he has gained greatly in artistic breadth. His style is still strongly marked by the same unconscious elegance, and, as heretofore, be plays in that wonderfully relaxed way of the Seveik pupils (Marie Hall, for ex ample), overcoming technical difficulties with such apparent ease as to make one forget they exist. His tone is greater now, though the violin he was using (a Festori) is not strong in resonant qualities. He has become a master of rhetorical expres sion in melody playing, and his range of tone, color is something totally individual. He is not likely to assimilate to the type of Ysaye and his school; he represents, rather, that rare type of virility combined with a genuinely poetic instinct. There is a charming fluency in his playing, like the bubbling and foaming water in a spring as it rushes up to the sunlight from its under-: ground retreats." The Ivubelik concerts in Melbourne will be given at the Town Hall on Friday, Satur day and Monday evening next. There is every indication of veiy crowded audi ences. Mark Hambourg in a few weeks will be gin bis tour of Australia under the direc tion of Messrs. J. and N Tait.. He has always been a patron of the drama, and the secret of his theatregoing appears in a re cent intervitw with the young Russian pianist. He advises all students of the piano to study tlie actor— not the matinee idol with bis immaculate trouser creases — but the older fashioned hero who plays upon the emotions. You may limit grind ing practice at the keyboard to three hours a day, in any case you must not give more than four hours to mechanical work, but you cannot he a great emotional pianist, such as Hambourg himself undoubtedly is, unless you study the art of declamation on the stage and watch how the actor suits his methods to the sentiments he wants to in spire. A great amount of interest is apparent among Melbourne music lovers regarding the debut of Messrs. J. and N. Tail's new discovery, Madame Revillo, the Spanish soprano, who is to make her first appear ance in the Melbourne Town Hall on Satur day (Gth June). The Royal Welsh Male Choir, the won derful organisation of voices which is to tour Australia under Messrs. J. and FT. 'Bait's direction, will be here in September. The cable published in the press on Mon day to the effect that Queen Alexandra had conferred her patronage upon the Mallin- son song recitals in Australia aroused con siderable interest, tlliis- being the first oc casion on which such a distinction has been accorded to any concert artiste. Fir. Ffal- linsoii, who is regarded as the leading Eng lish song composer, and his wife, Madame Anna Steinhauer, the famous Danhffi so prano, are personally known to her Ma jesty,. before whom they have appeared at Buckingham Palace on various occasions. J . heir first recital will be given under these distinguished auspices at the Town Hall, Melbourne, on 20th June, the Svdnev sea- son conunencing on 1st July. 'Die Neweastle-on-Tync Royal Artillery Band, under engagement to the Australian Concert Company, reached Adelaide bv the a ilc i-on le 20tl1 inst'> nn(1 Pe»ed its Australian tour the same evening under most auspicious conditions. The Melbourne season will commence on Tuesday evening, 2nd June. During the stay in .Melbourne of the band performances will be given daily at 3 pan, The Royal Artillery Band consists of 30 per formers, under the baton of Mr. Robert Smith, a conductor of bands well known in England. The organisation

is a complete military band, and has amongst its members several soloists of re nown. In addition to the usual brass in struments a complete set of wood instru ments of all kinds is making up the en semble, giving their performances tlmt mel low and subdued tone so seldom met with in purely brass bands.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Mme. Georgina Burns, who 20 years age was one of the most popular English prima donnas in London, has by a combination of untoward circumstances, been reduced to
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Mme. Oeorgina Burns, who 20 years ago was one of the most popular English prima donnas in London, has by a combination pi untoward cirennist,i.nM»s'. horn rprlnmxl fn

poverty, to alleviate which Mr. Ben Davies and others who knew the singer in her 'almy days have -opened a public fund. Mme. Burns has still a fine voice though not, of course, such as it was when she sang with Mr. Ben Davies in tne Carl Pvosa Opera Company, and she is very desirous of establishing herself in Liverpool as a. teacher of singing. Though, as a pupil of the once celebrated Signoi- Randeg'er. she is well nualifipcl for such work.' Mime. Burns's failing health makes this brave effort at ind./endence all the more admir able, and the general interest in the ap peal which is being made on her behalf is emphasized by. tiie fact that the Church Aito.v ha.ve consented to receiver any sub scriptions at their headquarters in Bryans ton street, AV. Readers of this paragraph who have heard Georgina Burns in the eighties will he sorry to hear that her con dition is described as 'forsaken, forgotten and destitute.' ' Mme. Clara Butt, who was reported convalescent after her recent severe illness and who had arranged to make her initial reappearance at a concert in Bournemouth to-morrow, has been unfortunate enoifh to contract a chill, which has obliged hn to- cancel the engagement., and may result In further serio:is illness. The famous contralto is now in London, and it whs on her .journey there from a stay in Bourne mouth that she caught the chill which has ™e r on-:e .more ^ invalid. Mr Charles San'Jey is a great public fa vourite, and a movement is nw on foot to give him a jubilee benefit, which is likely to result in a generous response irom the public, cr[:ecially as it has already secured the su-pport of such men as E-irl ' Kilmorey .tne Duke of Norfolk, and Sir JJoiiglas .Straight. Tne arrangements in ch,0 the holding of a eon*rt at the Royal -ilbert .Hall on the afternoon of May' 1 at which several distinguished artists have promised tiieir services, and the fund now lieing siibscnbed L;is been headed by the ? m -Sorfo'!c Trith a generous donation Hie death took place in London this week at the nge of 78. of Mr. Otto Gold schmult better known' as the husband of Jenny L'md than ir his own right as a ta lented pianist and a musical composer of ?Tleilt.rv ^'le P5111' first m^de acquaintance in ibi'J at a concert, at Her Majesty's Thea tre, and three years later were married at Boston, whither Mr. Goldschmidt had ac companied, Jenny Lind and her concert company as conductor. In 1850 Mr and Mrs Goldsehmidt settled in London. The husband, though possessed of ample private means— he was the son of a well-to-do

«amDurg merchant— went on with his mu sical career as a teacher at the Royal Aca demy of Music, and also composed various songs and oratorios. The Mendelssohn scholarshipowes its inception to the efforts °l 'Jenny Lind and her husband, and it Was -Mr. Gadsohmidt who, as an enthusiastic admirer of Bach's music, in 1S7G formed the iiach Choir, to cive a I^ondon performance x, V,ie,, composer's mass in B minor. .Mr. Goldsehmidt had at least one rival for the affections o; the Swedish Nightingale. A man from New Jersev fell desperately in love with her, or with her exquisite voice, at one of her concerts, and his friends hav ing hoaxed him into the belief that Jenny Lind wished to make his personal 'acquaint ance, the passionate lover presented himself at her house when a reception was in pro gress. Undismayed by the presence of a numerous company, he there and then pro tested how much he was attached to her; and Jliss Jenny Lind, not unnaturally con cluding that she had to deal with a mad man, turned the modern Malvolio out of ! the house. Even this severe treatment did not quench his passion, and he pressed his hopeless suit with- such pertinacity that legal proceedings were taken by the fair singer to protect herself against' the perse- 1 cution. Ihen the unfortunate lover gave in, went home to live a hermit existence, devoted to her memory, and when he died had her portrait buried with him.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: THE only concert that enlivened the dullness of musical circles last week was the at Balmain, given at the School-room by the members of the choir of St. Mary's Church in that suburb, assisted by the Misses Howson
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The only concert that enlivened the dullness of musical circles last week was one at Balmain, given at the School-room by the members of the choir of St. Mary's Church in that suburb, assisted by the Misses Howson and Mr. Sussmilch. The room was well filled, and the enter ainment very satisfactory, bat for tba extreme length of the programme. The concert waa ander'the direction of Mr. Linck, the organist of the church, a

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: THE programme, she informed me, was a charming one indeed, From the splendid Wagner overture (which nothing could exceed)
articleText:
MUSIOA L.

THE programme, she informed me, was a

charming one indeed,

From the splendid Wagner overture (which

nothing could exceed)

To the lovely little scheme and the minuet

for strings

And the latest bit of Dvorak, which made

her sigh for wings.

Throughout the Grieg concetto her emotion

was intense;

It seemed to me at Limes she held her breath

in deep suspense;

She raved of opus this and that, of Schubert,

Bach and Liszt;

Beethoven, Brahms, Tschfiillowski, and a

score whose names I missed.

But when at last 'twas over aud I led her

down the stair

1 noticed that beneath her breath she

hummed a little air,

It was nob upon the programme, being

commonplace and tuney,

And I wondered at the sudden drop from

Bach to "Annie Rooney."

heading: Musical.
snippet: The London DAILY CHRONICLE describes an interview which a representative of it had with Mr. Sims Reeves in reference to the great English tenor's work at the Guildhall
articleText:
Musical.

The London Dailt Chronicle describes an interview which a representative of it had with Mr. Sims Reeves in reference to the great English tenor's work at the Guildhall school of music. Mr. Beeves said : ' My object in giving lessons lies in my hope that I will get pupils with uood voices jand young, to train as operatic and oratorio singers. It is absolutely necessary

that they should be young. People ; sometimes come to me for what they call finishing lesBOM when they are considerably over 30; but then it is too late to do anything. The muscles upon which voice production depend are then set, and can' no longer be made flexible. I desire to train them for opera and oratorio. If they are proficient at that, they can tackle any ballad.' ' Of course I love the bal lad,' was the reply ; ' but the difference is this, the ballad depends upon the mind of the singer Most people sing a ballad with no idea of the poetry or sentiment. Yon have to make the pub. lie feel — to touch their hearts. The so-called teacher of ballad singing nowadays generally conveys to his pupil simply his own rendering, which usually — as might be expected from a man who knows no better than to do so — is a false one Hence the falseness of modern ballad-singing, and, hence, too, the neglect of the ballad form by the best modern composers. The ballad should be the expression of the individual singer. If the executant has intellect, he will say to his master, 'Excuse me, but that is not my idea; allow me to Eing it to you as it presents itself to my mind.' The modern voice has a wide range, but no middle. It has been written up tUl the middle register has grown weak and thin. If a tenor has a erood, strong:, middle voice, he is

now called a baritone. I think I may claim to be I a tenor ; yet I used to be called a baritone st I first, because I had preserved this part of my ? voice fresh and strong-. The modern voice, too.ie ? strained at the top. Modern songs for sensa-fl tional reasons are made to end on a high note. I Think how many voices Wagner alone has I ruined! Almost all G-erman conductors allow I their orchestras to be too loud. You see the I tenor comes forward in one of these over instru- 1 mented pieces, opens his mouth to its fullest ex- 1 tent, and then nothing comes out of it but a I shriek. The modern tenor must have a throat I like a bull's, because he has to bellow. Compare I Paccio, when he conducted * Otello ' at the opera I lately had an orchestra of 120 instruments,! yet above them all you could enjoy per- 1 fectly a sustained piano voice.' 'Of all! the roles you have sung, what is your favorite ?' I ' I think * Fra Diavolo.' It is so musical, so full I of point, so interesting; it always gives you! something to think- about. -I want to impress ? upon you my regret at 'the lack of dramatic ? strength in the middle range of modern voices,! and the absence of passages in modern cemposi'I tions to exhibit qualities of this kind where they] do exist. Handel's pitch, remember, was^nearly I a whole tone lower than our own, and yet A is I the highest note he wrote for a tenor — that is, I our O What I want to restore is the ienorel robusto; to me so many of our tenor voices have I an effeminate quality — they are disagreeable, a illegitimate. Of course, while the modern sys-l tern to composition lasts, they must sing the! music that is written for them; but I want to I see a better quantity and quality of tone. Sing- 1 ing in the head robs the middle voice of its sonor- 1 ous qualities. My own method must be a pretty I good one, for I am 70 next month, yet I can sing I as well as ever I. did.' ' What do vou con- 1

eider the best ballad that was ever written?' 1 1 asked. 'Oh, I think, 'Tom Bowling/ The! words and the music are alike unique, there is I very great variety in it, and the composer has B left it to the mind of the singer to portray Ms I meaning. If I were asked to sing at any time, I and to choose my own ballad, I should always ? sing 'Tom Bowling.'' 'And are there any! modern ballads as good as the old ones ?' ' Yes, I a few. Speaking without reflection, I should ? instance Blumenthal's ' Thinking of Thee ' and ' 1 1 Wish Thou Wert Not Going.' Henry Smart, I too, wrote some fine ones ; and there is Hatton's I Good-bye, Sweetheart.' Most modern ballads I are not nearly simple enough. A ballad I is but a sermon after all, and the singer ii 1 the preacher.' It was almost pathetic as the! grand old singer Eaid to me as I was going, '1 1 want somebody to impart my knowledge of sing- 1 ing to before I die.' I

So-culled society 1« now so largo, and fees aro so high, that tho next great drawing-room tenor is assured an income at over £20,000 a year, and 'Vanity JTalr' -wants ito know where the lucky man is to ?bo found.

.-uuny stones are toiu 01 uie uit-un.u ui opera singers to drawing-room concerts, soys 'Talent,' au American journal, and II is known that thore are some who posi tively deollnc to toko such an engagement, no matter w'hat tho conditions may be. All tho groat singers dislike to appear In pri vate houses. Mmo. Sonitorloh sang several times in Now York last year. Sho began by malting hor terms luOOdol., with the in ?tontlon that they should bo prohibitive, but far from having that effect, she was in duced onco to go as lar aa Chicago to sing in a privato concert there, after having placed her terms at 2500dol. Mmo. Melba sang hero ut .1 private musicalc, and de manded' considerably moro than she ro colvod at the opera. Mrao. Nordlca made a similar arrangement when sho sang once or :twico tho Winter beforo last here. Mme. , Melba was ln£t Spring In London tho most popular of the ptima donnas at Covent Garden for private appearances, for ?whlon t'ho received loOOdol. It lasted five hours, being produced without cuts.
