She claims to havo restored to health a poor little child who had been kept in a bomb-proof cellar in Mafcklng. Tho latest 'Illustrated Bits' is graced with an oxcellcnt picture of Miss Neva Carr-Glynn. 'The Botany Bunyip,' in tlio course of his notes, always brisk and en tertaining, pays tho young contralto a high compliment for her ability. Mls3 Louie Morrell spent Christmas at Grasraere, English Lakes, and returned to London early In January to fulfil several concert engagements. She sang for the Na tional Sunday League on .January' 20 at Islington in company with Madame Belle Cole. Death of W. a. Barker. . The death of Mr. William G. Barker, tho popular basso, who expired on Thursday morning, though expected for somo time past, will nevertheless be keenly felt in Melbourne musical circles. Three or four njouths ago Mr. Barker was troubled with an abscess on the brain, which was opera ted on no less than five times, but without success. He continued his duties as long as possible, but his condition grew worse, and on Sunday week he lapsed, into uncon sciousness, and remained so until his death. Mr. Barker, who was one of the best bass singers who has ever resided in Australia, was 29 years of age, and a native of Mel bourne. He leaves a widow and one son. Mr. Barker's services were frequently asked on behalf of charitable objects, and wero nevrr askptl in vnin rvn/1 'li*- won rlnsnrvivifw

one of the most popular of Melbourne vo calists. When tho news of his serious ill ness was announced, arrangement's were made by a number of his admirers to (hold n, benefit concert on his behalf, although personally he disclaimed any desire to re ceive any reward for any charitable acts ?which he had performed on various occa sions, i ? ? ? ? In Borrowed Plumes. The Italian papers are greatly occupied just now with the subject of the decadence of Italian musical and theatrical art abroad. Formerly Italian artists appeared every season In London, New York, Berlin, St. Petersburg, and other capitals, but for tlio present musical season the only engage ments announced are those of Signor Mar coni at Madrid, Signor Bonci and Signor Totrazzlnl at St. Petersburg, and Signor Scotti at New York. Ono of the reasons of this decadence is the . falsification of names which has crept into the musical profession. Singers of all nationalities now take unto themselves Italian names, pre sent themselves to the public as Italians, and trade on the renown which Italian. ar- tists long ago justly acquired. The gonulne Tfnllnn sin!?rM-R find thp.msplvps no longer

able to hold their own with these competi tors in borrowed plumes. * * . * ? Jenny LinU's Letters. A large number of letters from Jenny Lind have just' been discovered In Rome, written to a lady friend resident In Italy, and covering a period of thirty years, from lS45to 1874. It is said that they aro moro than a hundred In all, and arb in the most ?intlmato and unconventional terms, giving tho great prlma donna's candid opinion of much of the music and many of the musi cians of her time. The letters have been purchased by an Italian publisher, who pro poses to issue them to the world very short ly. It Is to be hoped, however, that thoy will be judiciously edited (remarks a writer in the 'Daily News'). It will add a new terror to life if private letters, never in tended for tho public, and probably written with a freedom only adopted in correspon dence with an intimate frlond, can be print ed without suitable revision. In this coun try it Is assumed the copyright would bo ?with tho deceased singer's executor, name ly her husband, Mr. Otto Goldschmldt ? * ? ? Will Verfll's Huslc Live? : Roferring to the death of Verdi, a writer in last issue of the 'Sunday Times' says:— ?'It was his own wish that ho should be judged by his latest works — 'Alda,' 'Otel- lo,' and '.'FalstaU.' . On these he staked his renutatlon. Thero Is no sign that theso

works will ever be cast into exterior dark ness whilo Europe retains its artistic taste, and the love of the' grand and beautiful In music remains. Just at present Verdi Is being 'kept out of the running' in Aus tralia by the Wagnorlan performances. But .tho fact that 'Maritana' and 'Tho Bohc raian Girl' are kcoplng paco Bide by sldo with 'Tannhauser' and 'Lohengrin' is a protty good evidence that Verdi would bs warmly welcomed back to eur opera houses. Whatever may be tho caprices of - public taste and managerial enterprise, we predict that it will bo many a long day beforo tho last it heard of 'Trovatoro,' 'Rigolotto,' 'Un Ballo,' and 'Ernanl.' Pure melody is immortal, and cannot die.' . ? _►.._?_-_ ?

In consequence, the new French opera,- .'Le Cid,' was not given' in Boston Tuesday night by th.g Grau Opera Company. The management 'simply announced the change of operas, and said the great tenor was In disposed. As near as can be learned. Do. Reszke has been stricken with the same form of bronchitis with which he was af flicted last year, and which kept him voiceless for many months His physicians believe he will be unable ever to appear upon the operatic stage again. 'Jean, do Reszke's voice is only memory hereafter,' is the mournful prophecy of music lovers who heard him in Boston.'

Paderewski's opera, 'Manru,' which Is said to recall the style of Bizet, and also a little that of Wagner, appears to bave been a- great success in Dresden, where the author was called eight times after tho first act; ten after the second, and as many as thirteen times after the third act. Mijs Placo is a Launccston girl, and studied under Slgnor Pauzani when she wont to England a year ago. There was a great audlcnco at Covcnt Garden last month, when Mdine. Melba made her re-nppcarancc. Tho opera and other singers wero of purely secondary In terest.' Melba was singing, and the rest mattered little. Tho Australian prlma donna selected Puccini's 'La Boheme' and tbe mad scene from 'Lucia dl Lammor moor' for hor re-ontreo, and sho undoubted ly selected well; 'No ono In his senses (says tho 'Dally Mall') wants' to hear Melba in Wagner or in anything elso strenuous. To listen to her voice sliding without effort through the melodies of a Puccini, and a Donizetti Is sufficient. Just as Blanche Marchcsi's vocalisation is a miracle' of in tellect and art, so Melba's Is a miracle of nature. Her singing i3 as unpremeditated as a nightingale's. Hor wonderful cdgoless voice is of itself a perfect thing of beauty.' Mrs. Robert Mitchell, better known under her professional name of Mi33 Bessto Doyle, tho Australian' violinist, welcomed -the ar rival of a baby son last month at her apart ments in Paris. Madamo Pattl, assisted by Mr. Santley, the Misses ..Eissler, and Mr. Pendoro Price, recently gave a morning concert, under the conductorshlp of Mr. Ganz, at tho Gwyn Hall, Ncath, for the benefit of tho poor of Neath, the Swansea Hospital, and the Homo for Convalescent Poor at Porthcawl, the town being decorated In honor of the occa sion. The Mayor and Corporation received tho Cnaig-y-nos party at the railway sta tion; and conducted them to their carriages, in which they drove to tho hall, passing under triumphal arches bearing appropriate mottoes, and throush streets lined by a cheering populace. Madame Pattl's singing mas clamorously encored, nnd she respond ed generously, singing In all nine times. Two of her encore songs were 'Comin' Thro tho Rye' and 'Home, Sweet Home.' An il luminated address, couched in flattering terms, was presented to Madame Patti by the Mayor of Neath. The concert, which was organised by Mr. Curtis, tho local town clerk and a nephew of Mr. Henry Weir, realised about £S00. M. Gerardy gave Ills fourth concert at the Town Hall last night, when, as on the pre vious occasions, the attendance was not ;by ?any means in keeping with the excellence o! tho entertainment. Why this should be so Is- 'difficult .'-to understand, for Jean Gerardy is. one.of the mo.3t superb artists ot to-day— and in saying' this we do riot speak lightly. His magnificent command of t'he 'cello-7-hls fine 'technique'— appeajs directly to the musician, and his marvel lous 'tone' is in itself a revelation to those who know what 'collo'. playing is. It is regrettable ttat such a fine musician has not 'been able to command larger atten dances. A mdtineo will bo given this afternoon. . ' The Dolores Company has been very suc cessful in the North. A letter from Mr. Harold Ash'ton, from Townsville . to the Brisbane 'Courier,' says: 'I havo arranged for Mdlle. Dolores to give three farewell concerts nt His Majesty's, Brisbane, on. July 22, 24, and 27. I have specially engaged Miss Nora M'Kay; your brilliant young. Queensland violinist. I heard her in Bun-, daberg, and think she is a marvel.'

articleText:
MUSICAL.

The Patey concert season closed on Saturday, the 25th ultimo, when the Centennial Hall was crowded by an audience which grew enthusiastic over the contributions of the great contralto. Madame Patey, it is arranged, will visit Sydney again In order to assist in the Christmas performances of the "Messiah," which the Sydney Philharmonic Society is promoting. A new musical society the Sydney Choral and Orchestral Society which has for its conductor Mons. Henri Kowalski, has made its appearance in a successful concert, The orchestral entertainments have been rather interfered with by the social derangement consequent upon the departure of Lord and Lady Carrington.

v«»i.io uuuci tut; £*iuiB.ijer smiljll QUOC tion. A curious incident occurred during the recent tour (country) of Madame Slaggio Stirling and her conceit party through tlie Goulburn Valley district. A tiny child of six iiad been put to lied by her parents, who lived a short distance from the liall, so that tliev might attend tho concert. When tb'e entertainment was nearlv half-way through both audience and' performers were startled at seeing a little white robed figuro walk through the hall to the front seats. She had evidently wakened by the sound of the music and applause, and, attended by lier faitli ful dog, walked across the field so that she, too, might enjoy the music. There is a common belief that Puri tanism was hostile to music, and a re cent book asserted that during the Puritan era song iras dead ,'„ Ji»claii(J. Mr. Percy A. Sclioles. Mus.lj., of Manchester University, has just been stating that nothing could be further from the truth: — 'Take tho great Puritan poet, Milton (lie said), The peahug organ ' was to him oue of tin features of irarship, and his concep tions of heaven in his great epic were suffused with music. Hunyan, a stricter Puritan, was, like many others against instrumental music in church, but he appreciated song, as frequent references in his 'Pilgrim's Progress' showed. At tlie Interpreter's Douse there were musical instruments for the recreation of the travellers. While in prison, Bunyan made a flute out of t)ie leg of a chair, a feat which showed not only his musical leanings, but no moan mechanical abilities.' As a matter of fact, more music was published during the Coranionn-ealtb than in the corre sponding period, either before or after. In a chat on drums, a writer in the 'British Bandsman' soys: 'In con tests for military bands the drums are generally used as if they were playing the piece in a programme, and the extra practice in preparing for such a contest is of much use- in im proving tbe drummers. The brass band drummers would very likely prove themselves quite as good as those in the military bands if they bad the same opportunities. Many years ago tlie brass bands, when they went to a march contest, used drums and cym bals, and drummers then could at least drum tho mawlios well. So in order to encourage the drummers 1 would suK eest that at tin. march contests of the future the marches should be played twice, and that the drums should' be used tlie first time through.

: Botal Acadeut o? Music.—An interesting, and in England, novel competition, took place on the 27th instant at the itoyal Academy of Music. A new.feature was introduced in the selection of the judges, who in this instance were not chosen from the ranks of the Academy professors. The committee were fortunate in obtaining the services of the following gentle men as judges:—^lr. W. A. Cum tilings, the Chevalier Lemmens, and Mr. t-ims Beeves. ; l-A GrbjltTbxorix HIS OLD Agb.-"We (FiU Mall Gazette) are informed on trustworthy authority that the statements recently published by the Paris Figaro as to the easy circumstances of Signor Mario were altogether incorrect. Sign r Mario is unfortunately quite without resources; and it is to be regretted that a move ment which bad been made for a subscription on his behalf has been greatly hindered by the publication of the Figaro s paragraph. A con cert is about to be giren in London for his benefit, at which Mdme. Christine Nilsson, who comes specially to London for this occasion, will be heard-probably for the only time this season. Several of our most emin?nt English artists, Mr. Sims Reeves and Mr. Santley among the number, haveofiered their services; and it is hoped that by the sale of concert tickets, and through contributions apart from the concert, a sufficient sum willbt collected to enable the committee of gentlemen who are interesting themselves in London on Signoc Mario's behalf, to buy him a comfortable annuity. The concert will take place at St. James's H&U on the 29th of May.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The scheme for the establishment of a festival choral society in Melbourne, put forward recently by Mr. Frederic Beard, is going apace. No fewer than 230
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The scheme for the establishment of a festival choral society in Melbourne, put forAvard recently by Mr. Frederic Beard, is going apace.' No feAver than 230 applica tions Avere received last Aveek, and the list will remain open for some months yet, be fore the final selection is made. It is in tended to give the first series of concerts announced during next year,- and the first festival proper will most likely take place during the month of July, 1909.

Those who can hark back into the seventies and eighties — Avhen W. S. Lvster was king — Avill doubtless recall pleasant memories of Rossini's Moses in Egypt, done as an opera on the public stage. Re produced 'by the Lyric orchestra under Mr. Charles Levy a performance was given on Thursday. 'Mr. Horace SteA'ens was a care ful and often forcible exponent of the music allotted to Moses; and Mr. C. H. Lednvard made an excellent SIioav Avith that of Phar- oah, though it is a pity that a voice so good as his in the middle register is not more effective at top and bottom. Miss Evelyn Ashley sang the music of Anais very creditably, though at starting her in tonation Avas not above reproof; and Miss Bella Bull was a satisfactory Zillah. The part of Amenophis is not an easy one, as it is elaborate and bears often rather high, so that Mr. Claude Haigh is to be compli mented on having done as Avell as he did. Miss Minnie Paton made a satisfactory Sinais, albeit her voice is not too sympa thetic in quality. The other principals need no special reference. Rossini Avas rarely severe upon his orchestra, and Mr. LeA'y's amateurs may legitimately pride themselves on having been fairly Avell equal to all requirements, Mr. J. B.. North being a most helpful leader. It is perhaps worth chronicling that the audience at Miss Marie Hall's first concert in Sydney avere roused by her brilliant playing to such a pitch of genuine enthu siasm that they actually left their seats and clustered round the platform, cheer ing and applauding until the young artist played for them a second time the Trau- merei. The same intense appreciation marked the ivhole of her recitals there, and so great Avas the public desire to hear her that Messrs. lJ. and N. Tait had/to prolong the series, just as they had to do in Mel bourne. Miss Marie Hall leaves Sydney to day (29th June), for Wellington, aa'liere she giA'es her first concert on Thursday next, 4th July. Australian music loA'ers in gene ral, and particularly those avIio have not had an opportunity of hearing Miss Hall, will regret to learn, hoAvever, that it has been found impossible to arrange for her return to the Commomvealtli, in spite of all Messr. J. and N. Tait could do, al though in the beginning they aa'ere hopeful that a'isits could be paid to Brisbane, Ade laide and Perth, and other centres. But Miss Hall has important engagements' in the old Avorld aa'liich cannot be brqken, and therefore Avlien the Ncav Zealand tour finishes she will go "straight to England a'ia America. Queensland lias fallen absolutely captiA'e to the Besses o' the Barn Band, aa'liich has been delighting audiences in all parts of that State for the past few Aveeke. Messrs. J. and N. Tait liaA'e noAV definitely fixed 27th July for their opening in Melbourne, and the Besses will therefore come south again, playing by the way,, and a return visit to Sydney as hinted at as within the bounds of -probability. Some eight or ten performances Avillbe given in Melbourne,

and then the band will visit the Victorian provincial centres. - < Messrs. J. and N; Tait received adA'ices by -the Inst -mail from London aa'hich go to indicate that Mr. Percy Grainger is making a name for himself as a composer as Avell as an executant. /Sir 'Edward Elgar . has interested himself very deeply in .the young Australian -pianist, and has stated ' that in his opinion he Avill be one of the most dis tinguished among modern composers. It is not so. many years ago that Madame Clara Butt was an unknown student at the Royal Academy of Music in London, in which institution she won -the Royal Scho larship of 400 guineas. At the age of 19, ho\ve\'0r, she leapt into a fame which has increased ever since, until it is now in its heyday. The Albert Hall Avas the place, The Golden Legend tlie piece, in aa-liich she made her debut, and her success Avas imme diate and immense. That sueh a \-oioe, un paralleled in its sAvcetness and its power alike, should come from one so young fairly .amazed the audience, and next day it aa-as Miss Butt ujioii aa-hom the critics lavished their most laudatory adjectives, so that the young girl, aaIio the day before Avas a stu dent, aAvoke to find herself famous.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Opera at the Princess's has been confined chiefly to a series of repetitions, with a representation of The Barber of Seville interpolated. Faust is to be given on
articleText:
4 MUSICAL.

Opera at the Princess's has been confined 'chiefly to a series of repetitions, with a re presentation of The Barber of Seville inter polated. Faust is to be given on Satur day and Die Walkj-rie will be produced best; week.

. 'At the Orpheus Society's . concert in the -Town Hall on Wednesday Mr. Frederic Beard, the new conductor, made a success ful inauguration. The most noteworthy item in the programme was the Coronation .Ode, written by Mr. A. C. Benson and set to music by Sir Edward Elgar. It opens with an imposing chorus Crown the King with Life, interspersed with brief -passages for the soloists. This number, though lengthy, is well .varied and highly attractive, the climax, God Shall Make Him Great, being finely worked out. Next we have a chorus, practically unaccompanied Daughter of Ancient Kings— a charming and simple bit of four part writing, with a imost original ending, the final chord in place of the expected tonic (E flat) being the siibmediant (0 -minor). This number. in stantly established itself in the favor of the audience, and a repetition was insisted on. Next comes a bass solo with male chorus Britain. Ask of Thyself; a fine' and effective number, in which Mr. C. H. Ledward, a singer of whom more is likely to be heard, created a very favorable impression', despite the fact that in places it bears rather high for him. There is some power ful work towards the close, which he did very well. The soprano and tenor divide the first part of No. 4, Hark Upon the Hallowed Air, after which there is a quar tet. This is all graceful music, and would be very beautiful if tlie voices blended; but. unluckily, Mr. Oswald Rippon, tbe tenor, lias a quality of tone that is too assertive "to _ blend with that of Miss Lilian Held: Tlie succeeding quartet and chorus, _ sung entirely ".without ac companiment, is very charming, and the 6de ..winds up with the telling contralto solo and chorus Land of Hope and Glory; This is founded on a theme which Elgar iiad previously used in his Fotnj) and Cir cumstance march, and which sp pleased Ithe King that he asked the composer .to introduce it into his Coronation Ode. Miss 9lrft Rogers sang the solo beautifully. She

has a nice velvety quality of voicis. Other novelties were Gounod's Hymne, _a Sain to 'Cecile, a. beautiful subject, treated with all . the composer's art, and well played by the orchestra; and Elgar's Pomp, ana. Circumstance March above re ferred to. The Tannhauser March pleased so well, that an encore had to be" granted, but Tschaikowsky's 1812 Overture' is a work that ought always to be heard in the open air; in a concert room the noise is too deafening: ' - . ' ' " Some artists have to wait. a long time for recognition, but Miss Marie Hall conquered tlie public almost from -the day that Savoik put his own violin into her hands and sent her forth to let it give to the world the message of . beauty that- it held. Before leaving Prague"she roused "so critical an audience as the members of the local con servatoire to. such a pitch of enthusiasm that she was recalled to the .platform twenty times after her first solo. The same scenes of enthusiasm were repeated when Miss Hall played in .Vienna, and when she made her debut in London. It was immediately apparent from the eulo gistic references made about lier by the press and public that a violinist of tbe front rank had suddenly appeared. Since then, only a few years ago, Miss Hall's career has been one of continued triumphs, not only in Europe, but also throughout America, where she has just brought a second tour to a conclusion. She loaves Vancouver on Friday, 26th April, in the Moana for her Australasian engagements under Messrs. J, and N. Tait, which begins with an orches tral . concert in the Melbourne Town Iiall on the 1st June. Madame Clara Butt and her husband, Mr. Kenneiiey Ituniford, sang at Liverpool a day or two after the Huddcrsfield incident, of which mention has already been made, and the public evinced such an exceptional eagerness to hear her that every seat in the hall was sold out two days beforehand. Ac cording to advices received by Messrs. J. and N. Tait, under whose management they will tour Australasia in September, the two stars will give a farewell concert in Lou don on 29 th June, and leave a few days afterwards for this side of the world. Auckland has supplied anothe?: piece of evidence as to tlie popularity of the Besses o' th' Barn Band in New Zealand. At an open air performance there recently the at tendance was so great that it could not be kept within bounds and broke down ail the barriers erected to contain" them. - last Saturday (20tli April) the Besses gave their services in aid of the Seddon Memorial Fund at Wellington, and for the . rest of -their stay in New -Zealand they will' be playing through the North Island. Tliey lc-ave for Australia on the Cth May and open their Australan tour, which' Messrs. J. and N. Tait have fixed to commence in Sydngy on the 11th May. . Sir. Percy Grainger, according to advices received by Messrs. J. and N. Tait, lias reached this year a very prominent posi tion in tlie world of music. Last month in London the brilliant - Australian pianist was recalled half a dozen times for his playingat a Philharmonic concert, and the papers r.ext day commended liim for liis refined brilliance, bis virility, his insight and bis charm. He has a tour of Denmark in pros pect, where he is very popular, and in June he plays at an orchestral concert at tbe Albert Hall. An Oxford recital and a big reception by the Marchoness of Bath are two more of his more important engage ments. Mr. J. C. Williamson has been fortunate enough to secure Miss Amy Murphy, one of the most prominent sopranos in New Zealand,' for his. new musical comedy com pany. Miss Murpliy, who lias a splendid voice and a brilliant reputation on the concert platform, lias figured frequently in amateur theatricals in the colony, and Mr. Williamson lias been trying for. three years now to induce her to accept an- en gagement .under his management. It was not until lie was over in New Zealand him self, however, that fie was able to per suade her to change her status from ama teur to professional, and lie considers it an exceptionally fortunate thing, both for the company and for the Australian public, that he" was able to do so. Another engage ment he has made is that of Mr. Reginald Kenneth, a baritone of address and experi ence, who has been trained .in the George Edwardes companies in England and South Africa. To-niglit, 27th April, the highly success ful season of the Royal Comic Opera Com pany in Adelaide comes to a conclusion, and next week they will play at Ballarat (29th, 30th, and 1st May), and at Geelong for one night. Tlien they leave for Brisbane, where their season commences on 6th May, Herr Benno Scherek has received a cable gram announcing that Madame Teresa Car- reno, the celebrated pianist, who com mences a professional tour of Australia next month, has sailed from London.by the Oruba. - Miss Violet Clarke, daughter of Sir G. Sydenham Clarke, whose musical tastes led lier some rime ago to engage in regular con cert singing in London, has now, writes our London correspondent, advanced a fur ther step in her profession by joining the D'Oyley Carte Company, which is very suc cessfully reproducing the -whole of the Gil bert and Sullivan operas at the Savoy Theatre. Mr. Frank Wilson, who , was principal baritone of Mr. J. C. Williamson's Gilbert and Sullivan Company,. has been engaged for the baritone roles .in the D'Oyley Carte revivals at the Savoy. " He; was announced to apnear as the Colohelin. "Patience, a role in which he gained success in this -part of the world.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The organ recitals at the Town Hall by Dr. Price are appreciated by those of musical taste, arid the growing attendances prove that they are exercising a
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The organ recitals at the Town Hall by Dr. Price are appreciated by those of musical taste, arid the growing attend ances : prove that they are exercising a wider influence... The programmes are well selected, and make appeal to those who are able to enjoy a high standard. On Sat ui-day evening the Toccata and Eugue in 0. major, .by -J,; S. Baph, was admirably x-endered, and a transcription of the Tanrihauser . overture was .. also cleverly: done. Other-numbers wererWolfram's Star of Eve, from, the same opera; a beautiful Ave Marie; by Arcadelt; a Scherzo from

one ot ' Schubert s works, Morandi s bril liant Offertoire in E flat, the Nocturne and Wedding March from Menclelssoh'n's Mid summer Night's Dream music, and a selec tion' from Faust. . -, . > Madame Teresa Carreno, the famous pianist, who has been desoribed by ' Yon Bulow as the most interesting pianoforte ' player of the present day, arrived by the mail steamer, and will make her opening appearance at the Marshall-Hall concert in the Town llali on Saturday afternoon. ' This will "also be the occasion of the first appearance in' Melbourne "of Miss Florence Ballara, who is now on a visit to this city after her. European success as a vocalist. Miss Marie Hall, the brilliant young violinist, to whose advent all Australian music lovers are looking forward, is due; to arrive in Brisbane on board the Moana on Sunday next -(19th May), anil will tra vel straight through to Melbourne, where her first concert will be given on the 1st June. For the occasion the Marshall-Hall orchestra .has been specially engaged by Messrs. J. and N. Tait, Professor Marshall- Hall himself occupying the. conductor's desk. In the week following recitals will be given on" the 4th and 6th June in the Town Ilall, and then Miss "Marie Hull goes on to Adelaide. The Sydney season- will commence about the 15th June. Messrs. J. and N. Tait are compelled to restrict the tour of twenty concerts, owing to bliss' Hall's many engagements on the other side of the world during the closing months of the year. The violinist . will be accom panied on her tour by Miss Lonie Bjsch, a young pianist who has already made an enviable reputation for herself at impor tant London concerts. Some indication of the waj , in- which Australians have been anticipating the visit 'of "the Besses- o'lh' Barn Band is afforded by the fashion in which tlie book ing office was rushed when it was opened in Sydney for the season there, xlie first day saw over 500 seats booked, and before the week closed very nearly, the whole of the huge Town Ilall had been reserved. For the opening night Messrs. J. and N . Tait has made ' elabora tc preparations, which included the decoration of the audi torium with hundreds of electric lights in the Besses colors. .The opening perform ance last Saturday (11 th May) even ex ceeded' the high expectations formed. The hall was filled before 7 o'clock, quite 5000 being turned away, anil the immense au dience was aroused to a tremendous pitch of enthusiasm One might almost describe Madame Clara Butt's party as "a complete com pany" so many people are accompanying the great prima donna to Australia. In addition to herself and her husband (Mr. Kennerley Humford) and their concert party, there will be -Mndame's three child ren, lior sister," who is coming to look after the hopes of the ltuni fords; a nurse to as sist her in that. important task, madame's maid, and a secretary. Messrs. J, and N. '.fait will therefore have to make arrange ments for the accommodation anil trans port of quite a dozen individuals. Brisbane is doing its. duty by the Royal Comic Opera Company in splendid fashion, and the season there is one record of well filled houses and unstinted enthusiasm. The company will remain there for about ten nights more, and 'then leave for the south again in time to make their long ex pected appearance at Iler -Majesty! Theatre, Sydney, on 1st June. After Tlie Spring Chicken has been "fairly started and Mr. Coventry has . seen The Blue Moon through its preparatory stage by the musi cal comedy company at tlie Melbourne Princess's, the company will at once begin rehearsals of The Dairymaids, which will be the next attraction to be, produced by them. The new musical comedy company, whose Australian debut is to be made at the Princess's Theatre, Melbourne, on 22nd June, is taking shape in the most attractive form. The company promises to be excep tionally strong vocally, and also in the mat ter of comedians. There are three of the latter— Messrs. Gouriot, Clifton and Parker —all capable of taking leading parts; while Miss Daisy Wallace in the soubrctte parts is likely to score heavily. Furthermore, to the company's groat advantage, Miss Celia Gh i Ion i is to join it, und she will be a tower of .strength, both from the musical anil the comedian point of view. The chorus, which has been engaged both in Sydney and Melbourne, also contains really excellent material. Mr. and Mrs. Albert Mallinson have ac cepted- an olTor to give fifty song recitals in Australasia during tlie year 1008. Their recitals in London last season (together with Madame Ada Ccosslcy) aroused unwonted interest, and the impression made at that Lime by Mr. Mai linson's many beautiful songs was a. deep one.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Even the week's extension of the Melbourne season of the Besses o' th' Barn Band was not sufficient by a long way to satisfy the public's desire to hear them,
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Even the week's extension of the Mel bourne season of the Besses o' th' Barn Band was not sufficient by a long way to satisfy the public's desire to hear them,

and Messrs. J. and N. Tait have therefore arranged for a return visit during the first week in September. The Town Hall having proved inadequate to accomodate the audiences, the Exhibition Building has been engaged in order to enable everybody to hear the famous organisation, and popular prices . vyill be charged. This week the Besses., are in'-Adelaide, and next week will he spent-rin Broken Hill. Adelaide will again be visited ,on the way back to Mel bourne, and at the present moment Messrs. J. .'and N.'Tait are engaged in an endeavor to arrange their Western Australian tour. To that end they have cabled to England asking whether trie band miglit return via the Suez Canal1 instead of across America, as was the original intention. If this can be managed it will mean a prolongation of their sojourn in. Australia — which recent events have shown will be amply justified. Mr. Frank Merrick and Mr. Carl Barre the two instrumentalists of the concert party who are accompanying Madame Butt to Australia, gave a recital in London a few days before they sailed, which was very favorably commented on. "Delicious," "fine intelligence," "high artistic aims" are some of the Times' references to the former, while the same paper calls the latter a highly finished violinist. The Melbourne Amateur Orchestral So ciety gave an excellent concert in the Town Hall on Thursday evening, under the direc tion of Mr. Dawson. The Beethoven sym phony was done remarkably well. There were passages, such as the pjprise of the subject in the andante, or in the minuet, where mere professionals might have done better, but, taken all round, it was a high ly creditable performance. Two pieces by Nicode, for strings, horns and an oboe, were presented. The former one a varia tion of the naked and familiar Old Hun dredth; the other of more musical consis tency. It was nicely played, a special word of praise being due to the horn soloist, while oboe and cor anglais were in safe and capable hands. Mendelssohn's Hebrides overture and the Weird Dance Macabre of Saint Saens were also included in the re cord. Miss Una Bourne played brilliantly Liszt's Hungarian Fantasia. In the An dante Spianato and Polonaise of Chopin she showed neat, crisp execution. She ad ded a characteristic Grieg piece as an on- core after the fantasia. This evening, at the Town Hall, an in teresting programme of songs and biograph pictures will be presented by the Coward Company. , , . . Madame Blanche Arral has been singing in Sydney at the town ball, and made her final appeurance lust week. It is recorded in an admiring manner that she dresses in costume to suit her different songs. In the Shadow Song, from Dinorali, Madame Arral wore an Empire dress of pale pink, with an overdress studded with opals, white, bird of paradise plumes being, ar ranged in her hair, aud diamond orna ments.

articleText: MUSICAL At the Parramatta Police Court last Wednesday Magistrate Sutherland had just convicted a motorist of dangerous driving. articleText:
Musical.

It is reported that Mr. Alec. Marsh is teaching the Sandow system of voice' cul ture at Hongkong. Mr. Philip Newbury commenced another series of concerts at the Melbourne Town

day night. Tho company In cludes Mdrae. Emily 'Spada, Miss -Una Bourne (pian ist). Miss Kitty Bourne (mezzo soprano), Miss Allco Appleby (contralto), Mr. Albert Broad (basso), Herr Benno Schefek (a ccompanfBt), end the Austral Singers (a new company of un a c c o mpanied part singers). It

Is probable that the popular tendr'wlll re turn hero before long.. He will bo heartily welcomed, not only by his many friends, but by the public generally. Miss Ethel E. Sinclair, the holder or the Sir William Clarke scholdrehip, is making excellent progress at the Royal College of Music, London. The director, Sir Hubert Parry, in his report for the Christmas term (says the 'Age'), speaks of Miss Sin clair as having made great Improvement in the study of the violin and piano and satisfactory development in harmony. Mr. Lachlan G. Sharpe, well-known in Australia as a pilot of various concert com panies, has opened a concert agency in London. Madame Albanl, It is reported, is con

siaerjDg anocner visit to Australia. Paderewski's future tours will be directed, it Is anno'uncod in a New York paper, by Madamo Paderewski, who will act as his secretary and business manager. Sir Arthur. Sullivan's Will. Additional details of Sir Arthur Sullivan's will are now disclosed In the London Press.; To Mr: Edward Dlcy, one of his execu tors, he leaves 'a comfortable armchair, and tho 'Encyclopaedia Britannica.' 'V Mr.! Charles Matthews, barrister, another executor, receives 'a collection of framed playbills, with the names of celebrated ac tors and actresses of the eighteenth and part of. the nineteenth century.'1 Mr. D'Oyly Carte is to have 'the auto graph full scoro of 'Iolantho,' an.d ^ an en graving, of Solomon's picture, 'The Judg ment of Paris.' ' ? The National Portrait Gallery is to have Sir Arthur's portrait painted by John Eve rett Millais; the Royal Academy of Music, his original autograph full score of J'The Martyr of Antloch'. and 'The Mikado,' and a signed. photograph of himself; the Royal College of Music, his original autograph full soores of 'The Golden Legend' and 'The Yeomen of tho Guard,' with a signed photograph. . . Mr. W..S. Gilbert 1b left tho scoro of .'Ruddlgore.' Tp the Prince of Wales is bequeathed a tortoise-shell and silver carclbox and the clip to match; tho Duke of York, a carved silver-mounted coooanut; and the late.Duko ot Saxe-Coburg, the original autograph full score of 'Tho Light' of the World,' in r'o mombrance of 'many happy hours' spent' with his Royal Highness when he was writing it;- al3o'the' muSlc-sland which be longed to Sir Arthur's' friend, Joseph .Barnby. ? ; ' ' ' '?' ; To his 'devoted servant and good friend Clothlldc Raquct,' who had nursed him 'through so many Illnesses,' £1000 and certain' furniture.

heading: Musical.
snippet: Madame Laura Carrington, an Australian soprano, made her debit in London last month at the Portman Rooms, at a concert given by Mr. Chas. Santley, under whom
articleText:
Musical.

Madame Laura Carrlngion, an Australian soprano, made her debut in London last month at i tho Portmari Rooms, at a concert given by Mr.. Chas. Santley, under whom she is stud vise.' '??-.?? . '. ?? ? ? ' ? ?Madame Melba's youngest brother, Mr. Ernest Mitchell, has just gone to the front In- South Africa. He was intended for an Australian ' scuatter. but his tenor volco

led him to Italy arid Germany, where h« also Btudied theory and composition,, and later ho travelled wlffi his sister. , Miss-Mabel Manson, the Dunedln (N.Z.) soprano studying under Mr. Charles Sant Iey, ivitb whom sho sang at a concort in London recently, lias gained a further step forward in her career by singing before Mr. Coleridge, at Rochester. The famous composer of 'Hiawatha,' it is reported, sent her a letter, expressing his satisfac tion, and giving her much encouragement.

heading: Musical.
snippet: Mr. Carte has engaged Mr. Edward German to finish the late Sir Arthur Sullivan's score of "The Emerald Isle." which it is , hoped will be produced at the London Savoy
articleText:
Musical.

Mr. Carte hus engaged Mr. Edward Ger man to finish the late Sir Arthur Sullivan's score of 'The iimerald Isle,' which It is hoped will be produced at the London Savoy about Easter. ?. ? ' ? * ? ' A preliminary meeting of the committee for tho Vera Eyton benefit concert was held

on Saturday at the Hotel Australia. It was resolved to nold th« concert at the Cen tenary Hall on March 20. Tho arrange ments for the programme are In the hand3 ot Mr. H. N. Southwell. Miss Eyton (who loaves by the Cuzco on the 27th) Is at pre sent a member of the Hawtrey Comedy Company. Sho i.1 to continue her vocal studies in England. Slgnor Hazon, her late teacher, considers her voice of great promise. Mr. Fink, Mr. Musgrove's representative

with tho Grand' Opera. Company, tells a good story about a man who wont to see 'Lohengrin.' The stranger saw 'Carmen' one night, and then, missing a night, went again when 'Carmen' was Aguin ? being played. Seeing Mr. Fink, he saild: 'Look here. I saw 'Carmine' the night before last and I come again to-night and I see 'Car mine' again. Now,. 'Carmine's' all right, but 1 wanned to see 'Lonnlgon.' ' Mr. Fink' ex- plained thmt they played tho operas on nl tornate mights to rest the artists. Ho said If the patron cume on the following evening he could see 'Lonnlgan,' as ho called It. The man canio, and Mr. Fink, being anxious to hear what ho thought of 'Lohengrin,' went over and Interrogated him. 'Well,' ho remarked, 'tho blokes can sing all right, but lot's go and have a drink; I can't stand 'Lohnigan'; givo me 'Carmine !' ' Mr. Fink then told him tho best was 'to come, explain ed the action of the opera, got the man into the theatre again, and he was so delighted tha!t ho heard the Wagncrion nmsterpleco three or four times afterwards. ? ? ? ? . An amusing incident occurred at the re hearsal of one of the Gilbert and Sullivan operas (says Mr. Grossmiith In the 'Pall Mall Magazine'). Sullivan made us all come in a crowd to the footlights and sing with outstretched arms over, the footlights towards 'the gallery, a la Italian method. Tho composer screwed his eyeglass into his eye, and, addressing us individually, said: 'Don't you understand; I want you to think you are at Covent Garden Opera, not at the Opera Comitiuo ? I yranlt you, Miss — — t to Imagine you are Adelina Patti; and you, my dear Grossmitih, are dreadful — there is not enough Mario about you.' I saw what ?he meant, and exaggerated the Italian mode, and neariy fell over the footlights into the orchestra.. Sullivan, with a smile, said: 'Ah ! 'that's better. Capitol ! Do oven more. You needn't consider your safety.' Verdi, the grand old man ot the musical world, who died a few weeks ago, suffered much at the hamls of organ-grinders, and it is' said that to hoar one of his pwn pieces ground out on thalt terriible instrument of torture, the barrel-organ, was more than 'he could bear. The first opera libretto that Wagner ever wrote, according to a London paper, was so morbid that it aroused his sister's antipa thy, and the piece was never finished, but it could not hold a candle to Ws first lite rary effort, which was a drama penned at the early age of fourteen. In tho first four acts forty-two speaking characters mot with violent dealths, and tho cast was so much depleted that the characters had t» be worked in again as ghosts: Wagner's later works were cheerful in comparison. ? * ? « Miss Beatrico'Grifnths, the Sydney pia nist, h'as several important London engage ments, including one at a forthcoming Patti concert. ? ? .«'»?«' Which is the largest organ in the world ? Most of our readers would unhesitatingly give. the palm to thalt in the 'local Centen nial Hall, which, if we Include the 'thunder atop' and the carillon, can boast of 128 speaking stops. But ait Lib.au, in Germany, they have an instrument, built in 1S85 by B. Grun'eberg, of Stettin, which has 131 stops; and that in the Cathedral at Riga is said to have either 120 or 130. So Cbait merely on the score of hugeness, the Sydney orgaxrr seems only to come third on the list of honor(?). But Oho Americans, with their roverence for bulk, have in contemplation (says the Melbourne 'Age') the erection of en organ larger than any of these. It is about time we heard tne end of this craze for tho gigantic in organs. And many or? gnnists and. persons competent to give on opinion say that some 65 or 70 stops, if judiciously -chosen, will give practically every combination nnd variety of tone that a performer can wish. Anyone can put up a 'bigger building 'than the Parthenon; but he does not thereupon shout for joy at hav ing surpassed Phidias and his contempora ries. ? ? ? ? Anronos of onrans, the following dpsnrin

tion of an organ in Winchester Caidhedral in the 10th century will not come am'iss. This instrument, had 400 pipes, and required tlie united exertions of 70 stTong men to keep it supplied with wind; and though it tad cmly ten keys, it needed two performers to manipulate it. The keys were about three inches wide, and the player used'hls gloved first or his elbow— save the mark ! — to bring out the tones. There has fortunately been many changes for the better since those old days. . * ? ? ? ? * . According to 'Lo Monestral,' a good doal of secrecy is being maintained about Herr Siegfried 'Wagner's new opera, 'Herzog Wildfang.' The score and libretto are printed, but Horr Max Brockhaus, of Leip sic, keeps both under lock and key. By the enterprise of a Dresden Journalist, however — the modern newspaper laughs at lock smiths — tho argument has been given to the world, and proves to be of the lightest and most gossamer-like texture. Siegfried is wiso in not attempting to don thelmantle of immortal Richard; the sons of Tom Hood, Charles Dickens and a host of other celebrities who could be named did not show the same critical discernment.

snippet: Mr. Phil. Nowbury was at Wellington, when the New Zealand mall left. Mrs. Travers Falconer, professionally known as Miss E. A. Lambert, died at her
articleText:
Musical.

Mr. Phil. Newbury was at Wellington rwheu the New Zealand mall left. Mrs. Travera Falconor, professionally known as Miss E. A. Lambert, died at her residence, North Sydney, a few days ago, after a brief but painful illness, and wa3

lUlbl 1 bU UL tJl,. i. UUUIUB IJCUIUUJI J . iVIISS Lambert was brought out of the chorus in the early days of W. Lyster's Opera Com-v pany, as the contralto solo of hl3 company. Sho mado a distinct success in grand opera, English opera, and especially In opera comic. Miss Lambert was an artist of re nown In those days, possessing a beautiful contralto. voice, and being an excellent artist sho mado many successes, and bo came very popular. Sho was loved by all who came in contact with her. Miss Lilian Devlin gave an afternoon concert on Juno 11, at St. Janies' Hall, London, when sho was assisted by Miss Ada Crossley, Mr. Innes Smith, and Mr. Ken ncrlcy Rumford, ,Mr. F. A. Sowoll (accom panist), and Mr. Percy Grainger, a young Australian pianist, who made his first ap pearance in England. Miss Florence Schmidt mado a hit at the Royal Amateur. Orchootral coacert, Lond*

Inst month, wlllh her singing at 'Bol'Rag- gio.' Tho cxtromo florlturo of the scena, according to an exchange, was brought out with romarkable iluency and precision, nntl her phrasing was no less admirable. Miss .Schmidt among her encores Introduced a taking little ballad that emphasised her gift of clear enunciation. As sho had been in bed all the preceding day with a bad cold, tor success was all tho more note worthy. Mr. Huch Novlll-Smith, a young Mel bourno violinist, made his first appearance In London at Miss Hope Squire's concert, at tho Sallo Erard last month. As a boy violinist in Melbourne Mr. NovIU-Smlth arrested attention with his powerful tone. Facility in the loft hand is another strong point, and a technical finish, rare In one so young, was noticeable (throughout His se lections wero a sarabande and 'Tambourln' (Leclalr), a 'Nocturne' (Field), and, with Miss Hope Squire, a BoeUhovon sonata — a varied performance. Mdme. Albanl iaa returned to London from America.

Ml3s Louie Morrell provided an excellent programme for her concert at tho Steln way Hall, London, lost month. Quito a group of Australian artistes took part, for, In addltiou to Miss Morrell, there were Miss Julia Franks, Mons. Andre Kaya, Miss Charlotte Hemming, and Mr. Charles Saunders. : Miss Ada Crosoley, after a short visit la Paris, has returned to London. The popu lar con;tralto met with an enthusiastic re ception at Blackpool recently, where she was recalled five times for her singing of 'Quo Faro.' Preceding that wero engage ments at tho Queen's Hall, M. Jacques Blu monthal's 'At Home' (whore Lord and Lady Brassey wore among the guests), and receptions at Hydo ? Park Terrace and Sydenhani, when Miss Crossley favored several noteworthy compositions' of Mr. Albert Mallinson, the New Zealand com poser, 'Eleanore,' ''Slow, Horses, Slow,' 'Odanke Night,' and 'New Year's Song.'

snippet: "Your husband does not seem to have any organic trouble," said the doctor. "Oh, no," said the wife, "not in this neighborhood. But the folks that live next door to
articleText:
HusicaL

"Your husband does not seem to have any organic trouble," said the doctor.

"Oh, no," said the wife, "not in this neigh borhood. But the folks that live next door to us have a phonograph that .worries him nearly to death."

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Concerts have been given during the past fortnight by all three of the chief choral societies of the city. The Sydney Liedertafel came first an[?] its concert was in certain respects of most value,
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Concerts have been given during the past fortnight by all three of the chief choral societies of the city, The Sydney Liedertafel came first and I its concert was in certain respects of most value, for at it was produced Felicien David's picturesque .' Symphonic Odo," entitled " The Desert" which has not been heard here since early in 1887. The performance was meritorious, and reflected credit on the conductor, Mr. J A. Delaney. The solo portions were (sung by Mr. Henry Stockwell, of Melbourne. The

concert also included a miscellaneous (election of vocal and instrumental pieces performed by com 1 potent artists, The Admiral and Lady Charles Scott, were present The Metropolitan Liedertafel Society followed a couple of days later with a gentlemen's " smoke " concert On this occasion the work of the society was confined to the performance of male voice part songs of comparatively small importance, and the rest of the programme was made up of songs and violin and violoncello solos. The Philharmonic Society gave its annual performance of "Messiah" on Christmas night under the direction of Signor Roberto Hazon. For many years it has been the custom in Sydney to produce the oratorio the night of the great Festal Day, but there is a growing conviction that the time is not well chosen. The attendance was smaller than usual, and the audience showed a strong desire to get to their homes at an early hour, with the result that a very large proportion left long before the end of the performance Much of the solo music was admirably suit?, the principal vocalists being Miss Frances Saville, Mrs. Yanderveer Greene, Mr. Harry Clinton, and Mr. F. J. Hallewell. The chorus had been well drilled, and most of the familiar numbers were sang correctly both as regards notice and tempo, but the performance as a whole looked spirit. The failings are not attributable to the conductor who, indeed, is one of the most talented who has been in Australia,

but rather to the fact that people are careless

about the rehearsal of a work so well known as this, while also it appears that at such a time as Christmas Night there is but small disposition to set seriously to the work of performing difficult and

elaborate music

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The chief musical event that has occurred during the past fortnight was in connection with the formal dedication of the sanctuary of St. Mary's Cathedral. A chorus of about
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The chief musical event that has occurred during the past fortnight was in connection with the formal dedication of the sanctuary of St Mary's Cathedral. A chorus of about 200 ' voices, comprising the combined Roman Catholic choirs of Sydney, an orchestra of over 60 performers, and a large number of solo singers, were engaged in a musical festival held in the cathedral on the afternoon of the days preceding the formal dedication. On that

occasion Rossini's " Stabat Mater " was performed in its entirety, and other compositions by Handel, Mozart, Beethoven, Cherubini, Rossini, Co,, were

also produced. The performance was very credit

I able to the amateur members of the cathedral and

church choirs, upon whom fell the greater portion of the work. At the high mass celebrated on the occasion of the ceremony of dedication, the music

performed was that known as Mozart's " Twelfth Mass." This was impressively and creditably won dered by the combined Catholic choirs of the city, supported by a small orchestra of string and|\vood."»Vmd, and the organ, the latter being under the charge of Mr. Neville Barnett, F. C.O., the cathedral organist The direction of the performances. both occasions devolved upon Mr. J. A. Delany, the choirmaster of the cathedral, who has gained 1 great credit for the successful results he obtained from the material at his disposal. The musical officials of the cathedral have determined to take advantage of the occasion, and endeavour to organise a permanent union of the Catholic choirs of the arch

diocese.

The Burns Club, connected with the Highland Society of New South Wales, celebrated the birth- day of Robert Burns by a concert, chiefly composed of songs associated with the homely national poet

of Scotland.

Music is satisfactorily progressing in suburban localities. At one of the outlying Anglican churches (St Thomas's, North Shore) selections from Handel's " Messiah " were performed last week by the choir of the church, under the direction of the organist, Mr. Joseph MasSON. The suburb of Summer Hill, also, has just organised and inaugurated a choral union, under the conductorship of Mr. Frank Brewer, well known in Sydney as the director of the choir at St Patrick's (It. 0.) Church. The first concert was given last week, and proved to be up to the standard aimed at.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Only one concert of prominent importance has taken place in Sydney since the issue of our previous summary, namely, the monthly con[?] of the Orpheus Society. The following instrumental
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Only one concert of prominent importance has taken place in Sydney since the ISSUE of our previous Summary, namely, the monthly concert of the Orpheus Society. The following instrumental works were performed Beethoven's Opus 59, No 3 the third of the " Ransoumowski " quartets); Mendelssohn's pianoforte concerto in G minor; Saint-Saens' transcription for violin, piano and organ of the March. Religious." from Wagner's "Lohengrin"; Emile Saurot's Nocturne in E major (op. 16) ; Reber's popular " Berceuse ; " and No. 4 of Brahm's " Hungarian Dances." Miss Florence Menk-Meyer has given two more pianoforte recitals, and there has been one of the fortnightly organ recitals at the University.

snippet: The tenth session of the Sydney Liedertafel Society opened auspiciously on Wednesday evening, March 11, in the Centennial Hall. The concert was the fifty-sixth given by the society, and it was
articleText:

Tho tenth Bossion of tho Sydney Liedertafel Society oponod auspiciously on Wednesday evening, March 11, in the Centennial Halt Tho concert was tho fifty-sixth giyon by tho socioty, and it was attondod by an audience larger than has been attraotod to any previous performance. His Excel- lency tho Governor, who has accepted the post of "patron," with Lady Jersey and Lord Kintore, was -prosont as also waa several members of tho Federal Convention. The society was assisted by Miss Colboumo-Babor and Mr. Wm.Walsho, as solo vocalists, with Mr. Charles Huenerboin as ac- companist, and Mr. Herbert Rico as principal violinist in tho orchestra. Tho part songs giyon woro :-" All Solo Alono" (Braun), " Pooceful Night" (Schubert), " Bird of tho Forest" (Ddrrnor) and a " OapBtan Chorus" (Smart). Inolndod in the programme was Schubert'» " Great is Jehovah," arranged for mala chorus and tenor solo, and two choruses from Mendelssohn's " CEdipus in Colenus." Miss Colbourno-Babor, who Bang unusually woll, contributed tho grand aria "Bon io finvenni" from Verdi's " Nabucco," Hope Tomplo'B " Whon wo Meet" and the romance " Boee softly bloom- ing," from Spohr'B "Azor and Zelmira." Tho chief Bolo rendered by Mr. Walsho was Beothovon's " Adolaide." A now society entitlod " The Sydney Musical Society " has boon added to tho list of tho vocal unions. Its first concort waB givon in the Y. M. C. A. Hall on Thursday ovoning, Maroh 12, wbon a woll-arrangod programmo was presented, and a largo and appreeiatiyo andience gathered to liston. The ohorns waa under the oon ductorship of Mr. A. W. Juncker. Mies Josephine Deakin, Madamo Pcohotsch, Mr. Alf, A. ¡_mith, Herr Pechetsch, and Mr. W. Walshe assisted. heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Two further pupils of Miss D. Whiteside, of Colac, Misses Nina Cattannch and Jean Bath, have been successful in passing the theory examination, junior
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Two further pupils of Miss D. White side, of Colac, MisBeB Nina Cattanach and Jean Bath, have been successful in passing the theory examination, junior division, of the London College of Music. Miss Bath, in the elementary division, passed with first-class dis tinction.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The year marks the bi-centenary of the death of Aroangelo Corelli, the famous Italian violin virtuoso, who laid the foundation of good violin
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The year marks the bi-centenary of the death of Aroangelo Corelli, the famous Italian violin virtuoso, who laid the foundation of good violin technique. Corelli was the most esteemed master of his instrument of his day. To him are attributed the systematisation of the science of bow ing, and the regulation of the shifts and the introduction of chord-playing. Also, it is sa'i3. he contributed mate

rially to the foundations of modern or chestral playing, and was instrumental in moulding the sonata form. He wrote upwards of 60 sonatas and con certos, and these and other of his com positions are still regarded as clas sics. His greatest effort was 'Con- cert Grossi,' whioh saw the light just Bix weeks before his death. Many of the works published under Corelli's name are probably spnriouSj but the authenticated sonatas remain in re quest among present-day artists, and they are held in much favour by cul tured Audiences. ' Defend Australia,' the words by George Benson, the music hv D. L. Palmer, published by W. H. Glen and Co., is a patriotic song. Its melody is bright and stirring with a swinging chorus, tiie words of which read : — ' The army and the navy. With a hundred thousand more, Could keep the flag still flying At the end of any war. For the future of Australia Depends upon us all, So bring the question forward, And be ready at the call.' There is sufficient stirring music to make it a popular song at any pat riotic gathering. ' Defend Australia ' will be played at the Lyric theatre, Prahran, this evening. heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: CHORAL SERVICES AT TOOWOKG CHURCH.— The full choral services at Toowong parish church, on Wednesday evening, were exceedingly attractive, and the new setting of the
articleText:
MUSICAL.

CHOKAL SKBVICKS AT TOOWOKG CHURCH.-t The full choral services at Toowong parish chnrch, on Wednesday evening) were exceed ingly attractive, and the new setting of the hymn, " Nearer my God to Thee," does great credit to the composer. The music is beauti fully adapted to the words, so much BO, that we think it will prove a popular hymn, and, should be published with a view to a more ex tensive circulation. The anthem on the occa. sion was that by Himmel, "Incline Thine ear," for solo quartette (unaccompanied) and chorus, and was well rendered by the choir of the church. The sermon was preached by the Rev. G. G. Bobinson, of All Saints, and the offertory was for the reduction of the debt on

the church.

CONCERT.-A ballad concert by Mr. Atkinson and family (with some amateur assistance) was given on Wednesday nightat the School of Arts. The attendance was not equal to the merits of the performance, but some allowance must be made for the fact that the title given to the concert was hardly realised in the programme. There was very little ballad properly so-called. The attraction might have been greater if more of the selections had come within the category known as popular, and if some of them had not been beyond the Fcope of the voices which essayed them. Most musicians would shudder at the notion of the overture to " Zauber Flote," being performed by a violin, concertinas, and piano; yet this celebrated piece, concerning which more, perhaps, has been written than of any other composition of equal size, was ren dered much more pleasantly than could have been expected. Hiss Atkinson carried off the honours of the evening. She sang well through out, and achieved a genuine success. The duet from " I Puritani," which this lady shared with her brother, was deservedly encored. Mrs. Atkinson sang " Children's Voices" very well; but 410 mio Fernando" did not give equal satisfaction. The gentlemen amateurs were painstaking, but their selections mijrht have been more attractive. The descriptive air calle4 " The Raft," might, as far as descrip tion is concerned, have been entitled " The Walking Funeral." In the absence of power ful instrumentation, the popular can only be safely studied at these concerts. We trust that on a future occasion the Atkinson family will meet with the support they deserve..*

YOUTHFUL PIANISTS.-Two youthful pro digies in the shape of two little girls named Douste-pianists of the age of 12 and 7 years respectively-are just now attracting

much attention In Pari*. Madame Pereire first took these new candidates for fame and fortune

by the hand; under her kindly auspices, they have become " the rage" of the moment, and " everybody" is trying to have thematthe private musical Boirees, which, during Lent, console the gay world for the absence of dancing. Tbey have been playing at the Elysee, in the splendid saloons of the Marquis de ialhoriet, Baron Gourgand, Puke de Montmorency, Prince de Hontholon, the Duchess of Newcastle, and other tip-tops " of the " great world fo this city. When lately in England, they had. the .honour of performing at Windsor Castle. The youngest had a beautiful red camellia in her belt. "You have a beautiful flower!" said the Queen to the little creature. "It Is my taliftmau, your Majesty!" replied the child,4< Mademoiselle Albani gave it me; she said it would bring me. luck." " Here is another flower that will bring you luck also " returned the Queen, as she smilingly broke off a splendid white camellia from a plant just "by, and placed it beside the red one in the little girl's sash, giving a motherly kiss to the mite of a musician as she did so. Since they came to Paris, both the children wear, a flower wherever they go; these flowers, renewed every day, are always the gift of, Madame Albani, the diva having taken a great liking to the two wonder ful little prodigies, and 'the children having the greatest possible confidence in the "luck" which.; they:fancy is. secured to them by the flowers thusgiven them by the great songstress, for whom they haver a sort, of worshipping

affection.

How TO SING A. SOKG.-Not the least im portant requisite of "how to sing a song" is (says Mr. Cumming*, the well-known [English shiver) nerve. If the singer allow nervousness to get the mastery, it is impossible that the K>ng can be well sung. Of course some degree of nervousness is natural and desirable, as.evi dence tbat the vo<jalist possesses both soul and sensibility; but nervousness must be controlled, and the best antidote against it is the conscions * ness that the singer has well studied the song,

and knows that he or she can render it compe tently and correctly; and I may add that the singer must not be discouraged if the first attempt at singing a.well-studied song Bhould not prove as successful as it ought to have done. The second trial will probably right mattern; the old mottoes," perseverance," and "try;try again/'"are as applicable to singing as to all undertakings. I cannot better con clude than by recording a tradition of John Btirtlemnn, the most celebrated singer of the last century. He was described as *' small of stature, but a leviathan in intellect," and, it is said, used to declare that he "never sang a song in his l:fe before the public until he had studied it, the words more, especially, for twelve months." We may allow for the gradual ex aggeration of the story by passing from one narration to another, and also something for . the slow pace of olden days; but even then the

anecdote gives us a hint which we ought not to be too dull to profit by.

CEAUPAOHE.-The RheimB Chamber of Com merce reports that 16,207,841 bottles of cham pagne were exported from France last year, and estimates the average selling price at 3f. (2s. 6d.) a bottle, or £2,025,980 for the total quantity exported. The number of bottles re tained for consumption in France was 3,629,421.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: On Saturday last (15th June) Miss Marie Hall gave her first concert in Sydney, and the reception accorded by music lovers of that city was on a par with that which she
articleText:
MUSICAL.

On Saturday last (loth June) Miss Marie Hall gave her first concert in Sydney, and the reception accorded by music lovers of that city was on a par with that which she won in Melbourne. A great audience

greeted her, and every succeeding number was received with increasing enthusiasm, until a perfect furore of applause was eli cited at the close of each item. The im pression she made was indeed profound. During the last few days she has been giv ing a series of concerts in Sydney, and next week she -leaves for New Zealand on the brief visit which was all that Messrs. J. and N. Tait could arrange for her. There is certainly some faculty, call it intuition, telepathy or. anything else that highly strung, nervous organisations pos sess, in contradistinction to the ordinary man in the street. Take for example a re cent incident in which Miss Marie Hall figured. She had been playing in Bendigo in the interval between two Melbourne con ceits, and on the morning after her recital she awoke feeling certain that something was wrong. When the papers arrived from Melbourne, where she was to play that evening, and before she had a chance to see them for herself, she declared that the an nouncement of the recital had not been ad vertised. It was really so, a clerical error in the office of Messrs. J. and N. Tait in Melbourne being responsible for the omis sion. Of all the concert party which Madame Clara Butt is bringing out for her Austral asian tour under Messrs. J. and N. Tait's management, Miss' -Marie Hall speaks in terms of the highest praise, with a special word of commendation for Mr. Frank Mer- riek, whom she classes as a very fine pianist, whose finished style is likely to ap peal to Australians. The scheme for the establishment of a festival choral society in Melbourne, put forward recently by Mr. Frederic Beard, is going apace. No fewer Than 230 applica tions were received last week, and the list will remain open for some months yet, be fore the final selection is made. It is in tended to give the first series of concerts announced during next year, and the first festival proper will most likely take place during the month of July, 1909. The Queensland tour of the Besses o' th' Barn Band, which began at Brisbane last week, is proving just as enormous at traction as has been the experience of the organisation all along their Australian sojourn. , Madame-Garreno will give in Sydney, on her return from Brisbane, three farewell recitals. Then „the .distinguished pianist

will go to Adelaide, to. New Zealand, and finally to Vancouver to tour the United States. The Sydney Philharmonic Society are ad vertising for a conductor, n&t only through the Australian press, but in the London newspapers. The concert on 22nd August is the last that the society's conductor, Signor Ilazon, will direct. The work chosen is Handel's Israel in Egypt. "A pronounced successs" was the un equivocal praise used by Mr. J. C. Wil liamson's London representative last week when he cabled the reception of Mr. Geo. Edwardes's new piece, The Merry Widow, which succeeded The Lady Dandies, at Daly's Theatre a few days ago. "Die Lus- tige Witwe," from which the new success has been translated, has for some time past been the rage throughout Europe, anda recently returned Australian who had done the grand tour declared that you could not. go into a town on the Continent where the piece was not being played or had been played (in which case you were flrivien- nearly mad by tlio constant whistling of the melodies), or in which the residents were not looking forward to its advent; Mr. Geo. Edwardes himself saw it in Vienna, and came back to London enrap tured with it." "I can recall nothing like it," he told an interviewer; 'The music is charming. All Europe is humming that gor geous waltz song in the second act." The story has a good deal of real comedy possi bilities in it, apropos of the love affair of

a ricn widow; -who. on the death of her banker husband, searches out her first love, and finds him unwilling to marry her, but willing to defend her from fortune hunters. It will be done here, of course, by the Royal Comic Opera Company. " The Spring Chicken has been playing to crowded houses ever since its opening night at Her Majesty's Theatre, Sydney, and, helped by the excellent interpretation

given it by the ltoyal Comic Opera Com pany, its gaiety, brightness and eatchiness have appealed strongly to the taste of playgoers there. Since leaving Australia some few years ago, Mr. 1'. B. Batliurst has met with varied experiences, including a consider able amount of concert nppearances in London and the English provinces, as well as a good deal of operatic work with the Carl .Rosa Company. But though tbc was everywhere well received, lie comes back, like most other returned Australians, more ardently patriotic than ever.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Madame Ada Crossley, with her husband, Dr. Francis Muccke, sails for Australia by the Orontes on Friday, 7th August, to take up her concert tour under the direction of
articleText:
MUSICAL

Madame -Ada Crossley, with her husband, Dr. Francis Muccke, sails for Australia by the Orontes on Friday, 7th August, to take up her concert tour under the direction of

Mr. J, p. Williamson. . Apropos of Mr. Percy Grainger's London farewell" recital, tlta London "Daily News" says: — "If Mr. Percy Grainger plays as finely during the tour be is about to take through Australia as he did yesterday afternoon its success will not be for a moment in doubt. He lias loug been re cognised as one of the best of British pian ists, but he has never displayed such ma turity of style and interpretative ability as were evinced in the course, of a long pro gramme, which .was as unhackneyed as it was exacting in the wide lunge of musical thought expressed." The forthcoming appearances of the three Cheraiavskis, who are announced to give a scries of concert recitals here shortly, will provide musical fare of the highest quality, ft is the first time that children of such conspicuous talents, and who have won fame before the most critical audiences on the Continent and in London, have visited- us. They will open in the Melbourne Town j Hall oa 19th September. The Royal Welsh Male Choir, which will arrive this month, commences its season in Sydney. The Melbourne season opens at! the Town Hall on 1st October. The Kingdom, Elgar's latest oratoria, will be given for the first time in Australia on Monday evening, in the Town Hall; by the Philharmonic Society.. - The soloists are Miss Lilian Reid, Miss Elva Rogers, Mr. Jas. Wade and Mr. Horace Stevens. The whole will be under the direction of Mr. Geo. Peuke. The final of the present scries of Mel bourne Chamber Concerts was given in Glen s Ifall on Wednesday evening. The Weston string quartet gave Beethoven's Quartet in.E minor, Mr. Herman Sckrader played Chopin's Ballade, op. 47, and, with Mr. George Weston, the Sonata in G major, for piano and violin, by Rubinstein The vocalist was Madame Chris tensen.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: At Kubelik's first concert in Sydney on Thursday evening he received a demonstrative reception. Crowds cheered him enroute, and a vast assemblage
articleText:
MUSICAL.

At Kubelik's first concert in Sydney on Thursday evening he received a demonstra tive reception. Crowds cheered him en route, and a vast assemblage await ed his arrival at the hall. He

was accompanied by Countess Kubelik, and was received by the Lord and Lady Mayoress. The enormous audience took him to its heart before he drew the bow across the strings. The violinist conquers as much by his demeanor as by his per fect playing. Ever unsatisfied, the audi ence recalled him time after time, and the concert concluded in a wild scene of clamor ous applause. The two Bendigo girls, Erna Mueller and Emily Dyason, had a most generous reception. There was simi lar enthusiasm at the subsequent concerts. The "Sydney Daily Telegraph" critic, in writing of Kubelik's first concert in Syd ney, says: — "The writer of this notice heard Kubelik at the beginning of his career, at a time when the young virtuoso showed more of the objective than subjective quali ties of a player. lie was conscientiously intent upon faithfully and musically fulfil ling the composers' intentions, and was not conspicuously intellectual, perhaps, but strangely musical and exhilarating. His playing had the buoyant, sparkling nature of which youth alone is capable. There was a singular beauty and clarity of tone, a wizard-like delivery of octaves, double stopping, harmonics and double harmonics. There was ever the purest intonation, and in the rapid runs an ability to turn off the notes with the utmost distinctness. True, it was not the most impassioned violin playing, but who would have Subjected the young Bohemian virtuoso to comparison with Ysaye, and the other mature violin giants. It is somewhat different now. Kubelik's playing shows he has gained greatly in artistic breadth. His style is still strongly marked by the same unconscious elegance, and, as heretofore, be plays in that wonderfully relaxed way of the Seveik pupils (Marie Hall, for ex ample), overcoming technical difficulties with such apparent ease as to make one forget they exist. His tone is greater now, though the violin he was using (a Festori) is not strong in resonant qualities. He has become a master of rhetorical expres sion in melody playing, and his range of tone, color is something totally individual. He is not likely to assimilate to the type of Ysaye and his school; he represents, rather, that rare type of virility combined with a genuinely poetic instinct. There is a charming fluency in his playing, like the bubbling and foaming water in a spring as it rushes up to the sunlight from its under-: ground retreats." The Ivubelik concerts in Melbourne will be given at the Town Hall on Friday, Satur day and Monday evening next. There is every indication of veiy crowded audi ences. Mark Hambourg in a few weeks will be gin bis tour of Australia under the direc tion of Messrs. J. and N Tait.. He has always been a patron of the drama, and the secret of his theatregoing appears in a re cent intervitw with the young Russian pianist. He advises all students of the piano to study tlie actor— not the matinee idol with bis immaculate trouser creases — but the older fashioned hero who plays upon the emotions. You may limit grind ing practice at the keyboard to three hours a day, in any case you must not give more than four hours to mechanical work, but you cannot he a great emotional pianist, such as Hambourg himself undoubtedly is, unless you study the art of declamation on the stage and watch how the actor suits his methods to the sentiments he wants to in spire. A great amount of interest is apparent among Melbourne music lovers regarding the debut of Messrs. J. and N. Tail's new discovery, Madame Revillo, the Spanish soprano, who is to make her first appear ance in the Melbourne Town Hall on Satur day (Gth June). The Royal Welsh Male Choir, the won derful organisation of voices which is to tour Australia under Messrs. J. and FT. 'Bait's direction, will be here in September. The cable published in the press on Mon day to the effect that Queen Alexandra had conferred her patronage upon the Mallin- son song recitals in Australia aroused con siderable interest, tlliis- being the first oc casion on which such a distinction has been accorded to any concert artiste. Fir. Ffal- linsoii, who is regarded as the leading Eng lish song composer, and his wife, Madame Anna Steinhauer, the famous Danhffi so prano, are personally known to her Ma jesty,. before whom they have appeared at Buckingham Palace on various occasions. J . heir first recital will be given under these distinguished auspices at the Town Hall, Melbourne, on 20th June, the Svdnev sea- son conunencing on 1st July. 'Die Neweastle-on-Tync Royal Artillery Band, under engagement to the Australian Concert Company, reached Adelaide bv the a ilc i-on le 20tl1 inst'> nn(1 Pe»ed its Australian tour the same evening under most auspicious conditions. The Melbourne season will commence on Tuesday evening, 2nd June. During the stay in .Melbourne of the band performances will be given daily at 3 pan, The Royal Artillery Band consists of 30 per formers, under the baton of Mr. Robert Smith, a conductor of bands well known in England. The organisation

is a complete military band, and has amongst its members several soloists of re nown. In addition to the usual brass in struments a complete set of wood instru ments of all kinds is making up the en semble, giving their performances tlmt mel low and subdued tone so seldom met with in purely brass bands.
