heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Mme. Georgina Burns, who 20 years age was one of the most popular English prima donnas in London, has by a combination of untoward circumstances, been reduced to
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Mme. Oeorgina Burns, who 20 years ago was one of the most popular English prima donnas in London, has by a combination pi untoward cirennist,i.nM»s'. horn rprlnmxl fn

poverty, to alleviate which Mr. Ben Davies and others who knew the singer in her 'almy days have -opened a public fund. Mme. Burns has still a fine voice though not, of course, such as it was when she sang with Mr. Ben Davies in tne Carl Pvosa Opera Company, and she is very desirous of establishing herself in Liverpool as a. teacher of singing. Though, as a pupil of the once celebrated Signoi- Randeg'er. she is well nualifipcl for such work.' Mime. Burns's failing health makes this brave effort at ind./endence all the more admir able, and the general interest in the ap peal which is being made on her behalf is emphasized by. tiie fact that the Church Aito.v ha.ve consented to receiver any sub scriptions at their headquarters in Bryans ton street, AV. Readers of this paragraph who have heard Georgina Burns in the eighties will he sorry to hear that her con dition is described as 'forsaken, forgotten and destitute.' ' Mme. Clara Butt, who was reported convalescent after her recent severe illness and who had arranged to make her initial reappearance at a concert in Bournemouth to-morrow, has been unfortunate enoifh to contract a chill, which has obliged hn to- cancel the engagement., and may result In further serio:is illness. The famous contralto is now in London, and it whs on her .journey there from a stay in Bourne mouth that she caught the chill which has ™e r on-:e .more ^ invalid. Mr Charles San'Jey is a great public fa vourite, and a movement is nw on foot to give him a jubilee benefit, which is likely to result in a generous response irom the public, cr[:ecially as it has already secured the su-pport of such men as E-irl ' Kilmorey .tne Duke of Norfolk, and Sir JJoiiglas .Straight. Tne arrangements in ch,0 the holding of a eon*rt at the Royal -ilbert .Hall on the afternoon of May' 1 at which several distinguished artists have promised tiieir services, and the fund now lieing siibscnbed L;is been headed by the ? m -Sorfo'!c Trith a generous donation Hie death took place in London this week at the nge of 78. of Mr. Otto Gold schmult better known' as the husband of Jenny L'md than ir his own right as a ta lented pianist and a musical composer of ?Tleilt.rv ^'le P5111' first m^de acquaintance in ibi'J at a concert, at Her Majesty's Thea tre, and three years later were married at Boston, whither Mr. Goldschmidt had ac companied, Jenny Lind and her concert company as conductor. In 1850 Mr and Mrs Goldsehmidt settled in London. The husband, though possessed of ample private means— he was the son of a well-to-do

«amDurg merchant— went on with his mu sical career as a teacher at the Royal Aca demy of Music, and also composed various songs and oratorios. The Mendelssohn scholarshipowes its inception to the efforts °l 'Jenny Lind and her husband, and it Was -Mr. Gadsohmidt who, as an enthusiastic admirer of Bach's music, in 1S7G formed the iiach Choir, to cive a I^ondon performance x, V,ie,, composer's mass in B minor. .Mr. Goldsehmidt had at least one rival for the affections o; the Swedish Nightingale. A man from New Jersev fell desperately in love with her, or with her exquisite voice, at one of her concerts, and his friends hav ing hoaxed him into the belief that Jenny Lind wished to make his personal 'acquaint ance, the passionate lover presented himself at her house when a reception was in pro gress. Undismayed by the presence of a numerous company, he there and then pro tested how much he was attached to her; and Jliss Jenny Lind, not unnaturally con cluding that she had to deal with a mad man, turned the modern Malvolio out of ! the house. Even this severe treatment did not quench his passion, and he pressed his hopeless suit with- such pertinacity that legal proceedings were taken by the fair singer to protect herself against' the perse- 1 cution. Ihen the unfortunate lover gave in, went home to live a hermit existence, devoted to her memory, and when he died had her portrait buried with him.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: THE only concert that enlivened the dullness of musical circles last week was the at Balmain, given at the School-room by the members of the choir of St. Mary's Church in that suburb, assisted by the Misses Howson
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The only concert that enlivened the dullness of musical circles last week was one at Balmain, given at the School-room by the members of the choir of St. Mary's Church in that suburb, assisted by the Misses Howson and Mr. Sussmilch. The room was well filled, and the enter ainment very satisfactory, bat for tba extreme length of the programme. The concert waa ander'the direction of Mr. Linck, the organist of the church, a

very pail,a taking German fna-ieien, who ia aBing hil 1 endeavours for tba advancement of maaio in Balmain, j The first part waa of sacred music executed by the choir, and a duet "O Salutaris," by Neukomm, sang by the Misses Howson. Tba second part consisted of secular voe il mu'io (including tba "Gentle Troubadour," by Miaa Clelia, and " The Convent Cell," by Misa Howson, ?both ootruotly and melodiously given), and a violin 1 and piaaoforta duet played by Clelia Howson and Hr. I Linok.

[ The Vocal Harmonic Society will give its first concert i for the presant season, tba third of ita foundation,

on Thursday evening. Spohr's " Last Judgment " will : be produced on this occasion only, as the system of

repeating each concert will ba dise ntlnned for the fature ; but a general rehearsal will take place to nigh», for wbioh each member of tba choras will reoeive two : extra tio'eta of admission. The soloa will ba aung by Mrs. Bridaon, Mrs. Cordner, Mr. Ellard, and amateurs

of the sosiety,

I Tue members of tba Philharmonic Soolety ara prac.

fleing some fina vocal and ina'rumental selections for I their next concert.. By a judicious blending of ola-sical I. mnsio with that of a lighter, bul also valuable oharacter, [ tb» happy middle path is oboien, wbioh will enable the

I more proforma" style, for wbiob it is impossible to ezpeat J a taste io a general audience in ibis country.

I There ia every probability of oar abortly having

the advantage of operatic performances here, if a theatre is disposable for tba parpóse. The English I and Italian opera troupe, nader the management of M-. ' Lyster, were to leave California in the Aobilles, wbioh

vesad bas arrived at Melbourne. The company consists of Miss Lucy Escott, Miss Rosalie Durand, Misa Georgia Hodson, Mr. Henry Squires, Mr. F. Lester, Mr. Frank Trevor and the Impresario or direotor, Mr. W. Leati>r. We believe also that tba principal members of choras and orchestra accompany t em. Tba company has been very suooesafu 1 in Califcr.iis.

It la understood that preparations axe in progress for opening the Masonic Hall with a musical festival.

A new amateur private mescal society ia, we believe, about being formed, having for its ohj«ot the meeting of amateurs, ladies and gentlemen, in botb vocal and in* simmental muBie,"jfor the purpose of displaying tba telen' far music possessed by members of mary, families in Sydney. The sooiety will be strictly piivate, and that tba oommlttee may be perfectly ftes from any bias in the selection or rejection of members, the black ball ballot- ing system will ba resorted to, and only saab members be admitted, aa are proposed by tbe committee. Booms wi 1 be arranged for t'Ja club, and the musical direotion will be nader tba management of a malician of eminence

in this oily.

Some activity is apparent in tbe publication of new music, the engravers sad printers being engaged in aome artistic productions. In the meantime a new number of the "Musical Bouqaet," has been issued, and   it appears under new auspices. This is, we believe, the edition formerly issued by Mr. Peck ; it is now published by Mr. Fussell, and edited by Mr. Cobley, These cheap musical publica- tions are of great utility in the oountry, and will be tba means of extending tnusio to the aottsges o' every vil- lage. The present number contains "the Volunteers' Polka Mazurka," by the Editor, a song, "the Lost Marguerite," composed by Mr. G. Addison, and the "Nativity Christmas Hymn," It is well engraved on

good mnato pr-per. ?

Lt a ri cent general nc tice respecting Maofarren'a opera of .' Bobin Hood," we expressed oar intention of alluding more pirtioularly. to the principal parts of tho music This, though perhaps scarcely . quai in melody to Wallan*-** "Lurline,'' ia manifestly mast rich In harmony, and o ntains msny peculiarities. A dreamy softness pervade* the entire work, troept where barata of joyous oborel eff-ots lift the veil. The construction un doubted'y follóos Ge'ttran models, rather tbsa the usual English ballad style, the sparkling French, or meloiious Italian. With orchestral effects, ead a careful instru- mentation (Mr. Maofarren is known as ta profound theoretical musiolsn), many portions that in the pianoforte copy app ar tame, will no doubt Bhow a vastly ... diff rant colouring. Aa in many modern operas, one favourite melody oconrs at intervals throughout the >ntire w rk. Thia is partly the case In "Bobin Hood," with Marian's air "Tine Love." In th - flrBt set, after the overture (introducing the melody of "Trui> Love"), a characteristic chorus of amilhs (»H in the " Trova'ore" i oroduoas a i-oj rffeot

for tbe opening soeno. The oom a leona ive between Allan-a-Dale end Aline, wi h accompanying chorus, pre. paree tbe way for the first eris of tbe latter, "The Hunters wake," an agreeable ballad in F for a mezzo, soprano voloe, within tba cimpa»» of any rolan, extend, ing from D to G. A. mdodiuui duet, '. Wu en lovers are parted," b. tween Locksley and Mirlan, follows. Thr harmony is veiy pleasing, snd the piece is suited'for private precie. - After a trio tba ballad "True love" succeeds. This will undoubtedly he tba popular piece. It is rsther melancholy hat very touching, and quite un. pretentious. Tbe next song is s grand basasoena, sung bj the Sompnour, or eolleotor, " The Monk within his cell," something in tho msnner of Fra TJiavolo's last seen«, when be rooitea bis adventures. This will be a favourite with bass singers, sa 'be pie-e is very spirited. " Englishmen by birth are free," is a short bat flVry tenor song, and if sung with spirit must provo very efl" alive. Tbe finale of tbe flint aot ia in oharaoter with tbe reat of the music, and again introduces "Truelove." Tb« second sot is of a far heavier obaraoter, and is principally fitted for stage effe it in the " Outlaws' scone." It never- theless contains the grand soena of the opera, for Marian -descriptive and .constantly ohaogiag time and key. Tbe music aocompaoiing tbe rustió aporta at the fiir ia very well arranged; but some of the obarsoters appear trifling. .Here, however, is the loveliest air of the entire opera, a luxury for a bigh tenor voioe, " My own, my guiding Btsr":-evidently oomposed for Sims Beeves; it is in Ove flat«, and up to B, bnt tbe melody is exquisite. In the third sot is also a charming soprano song for Marian, "Sons of the Greenwood." "True, love" is sgain inlroduoed in tbe finales to the second and third

aots.

On a fufare occasion we shall take an opportunity of noticing B¡Item new opera of " Bianoa."

OBPHETJS.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: THE programme, she informed me, was a charming one indeed, From the splendid Wagner overture (which nothing could exceed)
articleText:
MUSIOA L.

THE programme, she informed me, was a

charming one indeed,

From the splendid Wagner overture (which

nothing could exceed)

To the lovely little scheme and the minuet

for strings

And the latest bit of Dvorak, which made

her sigh for wings.

Throughout the Grieg concetto her emotion

was intense;

It seemed to me at Limes she held her breath

in deep suspense;

She raved of opus this and that, of Schubert,

Bach and Liszt;

Beethoven, Brahms, Tschfiillowski, and a

score whose names I missed.

But when at last 'twas over aud I led her

down the stair

1 noticed that beneath her breath she

hummed a little air,

It was nob upon the programme, being

commonplace and tuney,

And I wondered at the sudden drop from

Bach to "Annie Rooney."

The British-India steamer Nurl dea, which arrived at Melbourne last week from the United Kingdom, encountered very heavy weather around the Cape. The decks were awash for days, pipe easing was torn off by. heavy seas, and a stan chion was broken off the bridge and one of the lifeboats was smashed. A huge wave swept everything movable- from the decks W. Hagnn, a young man] ivae driving a dray over a crppk about four miles from Ruby Vale ^Q.), when the vehicle overturned, tie was pinned beneath the dray, wher- he lay for sonne Time with a frae hired; leg and out anns. Blood froir liis wounds attracted ants, which iiwanned over him, causing him in tense pain. liis cries were heard by a man, who securerl assistance, and rescued Hagan from his ter rible position. He was admitted tc the hospital at Rockbampton in a critical condition.

heading: Musical.
snippet: The London DAILY CHRONICLE describes an interview which a representative of it had with Mr. Sims Reeves in reference to the great English tenor's work at the Guildhall
articleText:
Musical.

The London Dailt Chronicle describes an interview which a representative of it had with Mr. Sims Reeves in reference to the great English tenor's work at the Guildhall school of music. Mr. Beeves said : ' My object in giving lessons lies in my hope that I will get pupils with uood voices jand young, to train as operatic and oratorio singers. It is absolutely necessary

that they should be young. People ; sometimes come to me for what they call finishing lesBOM when they are considerably over 30; but then it is too late to do anything. The muscles upon which voice production depend are then set, and can' no longer be made flexible. I desire to train them for opera and oratorio. If they are proficient at that, they can tackle any ballad.' ' Of course I love the bal lad,' was the reply ; ' but the difference is this, the ballad depends upon the mind of the singer Most people sing a ballad with no idea of the poetry or sentiment. Yon have to make the pub. lie feel — to touch their hearts. The so-called teacher of ballad singing nowadays generally conveys to his pupil simply his own rendering, which usually — as might be expected from a man who knows no better than to do so — is a false one Hence the falseness of modern ballad-singing, and, hence, too, the neglect of the ballad form by the best modern composers. The ballad should be the expression of the individual singer. If the executant has intellect, he will say to his master, 'Excuse me, but that is not my idea; allow me to Eing it to you as it presents itself to my mind.' The modern voice has a wide range, but no middle. It has been written up tUl the middle register has grown weak and thin. If a tenor has a erood, strong:, middle voice, he is

now called a baritone. I think I may claim to be I a tenor ; yet I used to be called a baritone st I first, because I had preserved this part of my ? voice fresh and strong-. The modern voice, too.ie ? strained at the top. Modern songs for sensa-fl tional reasons are made to end on a high note. I Think how many voices Wagner alone has I ruined! Almost all G-erman conductors allow I their orchestras to be too loud. You see the I tenor comes forward in one of these over instru- 1 mented pieces, opens his mouth to its fullest ex- 1 tent, and then nothing comes out of it but a I shriek. The modern tenor must have a throat I like a bull's, because he has to bellow. Compare I Paccio, when he conducted * Otello ' at the opera I lately had an orchestra of 120 instruments,! yet above them all you could enjoy per- 1 fectly a sustained piano voice.' 'Of all! the roles you have sung, what is your favorite ?' I ' I think * Fra Diavolo.' It is so musical, so full I of point, so interesting; it always gives you! something to think- about. -I want to impress ? upon you my regret at 'the lack of dramatic ? strength in the middle range of modern voices,! and the absence of passages in modern cemposi'I tions to exhibit qualities of this kind where they] do exist. Handel's pitch, remember, was^nearly I a whole tone lower than our own, and yet A is I the highest note he wrote for a tenor — that is, I our O What I want to restore is the ienorel robusto; to me so many of our tenor voices have I an effeminate quality — they are disagreeable, a illegitimate. Of course, while the modern sys-l tern to composition lasts, they must sing the! music that is written for them; but I want to I see a better quantity and quality of tone. Sing- 1 ing in the head robs the middle voice of its sonor- 1 ous qualities. My own method must be a pretty I good one, for I am 70 next month, yet I can sing I as well as ever I. did.' ' What do vou con- 1

eider the best ballad that was ever written?' 1 1 asked. 'Oh, I think, 'Tom Bowling/ The! words and the music are alike unique, there is I very great variety in it, and the composer has B left it to the mind of the singer to portray Ms I meaning. If I were asked to sing at any time, I and to choose my own ballad, I should always ? sing 'Tom Bowling.'' 'And are there any! modern ballads as good as the old ones ?' ' Yes, I a few. Speaking without reflection, I should ? instance Blumenthal's ' Thinking of Thee ' and ' 1 1 Wish Thou Wert Not Going.' Henry Smart, I too, wrote some fine ones ; and there is Hatton's I Good-bye, Sweetheart.' Most modern ballads I are not nearly simple enough. A ballad I is but a sermon after all, and the singer ii 1 the preacher.' It was almost pathetic as the! grand old singer Eaid to me as I was going, '1 1 want somebody to impart my knowledge of sing- 1 ing to before I die.' I

heading: Musical.
snippet: Mr. Edward Lloyd's Tetiring makes the dearth of really good toners' still more marked. So-called society in now so large, and fees are so high, that the next great
articleText:
Musical.

Mr. Edward Lloyd's TOtirlng makes tho dearth of really good tonors' still moro marked. So-culled society 1« now so largo, and fees aro so high, that tho next great drawing-room tenor is assured an income at over £20,000 a year, and 'Vanity JTalr' -wants ito know where the lucky man is to ?bo found.

.-uuny stones are toiu 01 uie uit-un.u ui opera singers to drawing-room concerts, soys 'Talent,' au American journal, and II is known that thore are some who posi tively deollnc to toko such an engagement, no matter w'hat tho conditions may be. All tho groat singers dislike to appear In pri vate houses. Mmo. Sonitorloh sang several times in Now York last year. Sho began by malting hor terms luOOdol., with the in ?tontlon that they should bo prohibitive, but far from having that effect, she was in duced onco to go as lar aa Chicago to sing in a privato concert there, after having placed her terms at 2500dol. Mmo. Melba sang hero ut .1 private musicalc, and de manded' considerably moro than she ro colvod at the opera. Mrao. Nordlca made a similar arrangement when sho sang once or :twico tho Winter beforo last here. Mme. , Melba was ln£t Spring In London tho most popular of the ptima donnas at Covent Garden for private appearances, for ?whlon t'ho received loOOdol. It Is 50 years sinco 'Lohengrin' was pro duced at Weimar for tho first time, under tho conductorship of Liszt, and tho opora has just been performed at tho Weimar Opera House in commemoration. It lasted five hours, being produced without cuts. Miss Julia Franks, who has had several attractive engagements lately, was (says a London paper) the vocalist at Signor Ran-, degger's concert In tho Imperial Institute the other day. ?Madame Belle .Colo, tho vocalist,, who has just returned to London from South Africa,'

1*1, lino 1MOUU111U JLIllUlUUbLU fSWIllIlg, U LUll vert to Christian science, anil thinks that she has even developed a certain amount of faith healing power herself. She claims to havo restored to health a poor little child who had been kept in a bomb-proof cellar in Mafcklng. Tho latest 'Illustrated Bits' is graced with an oxcellcnt picture of Miss Neva Carr-Glynn. 'The Botany Bunyip,' in tlio course of his notes, always brisk and en tertaining, pays tho young contralto a high compliment for her ability. Mls3 Louie Morrell spent Christmas at Grasraere, English Lakes, and returned to London early In January to fulfil several concert engagements. She sang for the Na tional Sunday League on .January' 20 at Islington in company with Madame Belle Cole. Death of W. a. Barker. . The death of Mr. William G. Barker, tho popular basso, who expired on Thursday morning, though expected for somo time past, will nevertheless be keenly felt in Melbourne musical circles. Three or four njouths ago Mr. Barker was troubled with an abscess on the brain, which was opera ted on no less than five times, but without success. He continued his duties as long as possible, but his condition grew worse, and on Sunday week he lapsed, into uncon sciousness, and remained so until his death. Mr. Barker, who was one of the best bass singers who has ever resided in Australia, was 29 years of age, and a native of Mel bourne. He leaves a widow and one son. Mr. Barker's services were frequently asked on behalf of charitable objects, and wero nevrr askptl in vnin rvn/1 'li*- won rlnsnrvivifw

one of the most popular of Melbourne vo calists. When tho news of his serious ill ness was announced, arrangement's were made by a number of his admirers to (hold n, benefit concert on his behalf, although personally he disclaimed any desire to re ceive any reward for any charitable acts ?which he had performed on various occa sions, i ? ? ? ? In Borrowed Plumes. The Italian papers are greatly occupied just now with the subject of the decadence of Italian musical and theatrical art abroad. Formerly Italian artists appeared every season In London, New York, Berlin, St. Petersburg, and other capitals, but for tlio present musical season the only engage ments announced are those of Signor Mar coni at Madrid, Signor Bonci and Signor Totrazzlnl at St. Petersburg, and Signor Scotti at New York. Ono of the reasons of this decadence is the . falsification of names which has crept into the musical profession. Singers of all nationalities now take unto themselves Italian names, pre sent themselves to the public as Italians, and trade on the renown which Italian. ar- tists long ago justly acquired. The gonulne Tfnllnn sin!?rM-R find thp.msplvps no longer

able to hold their own with these competi tors in borrowed plumes. * * . * ? Jenny LinU's Letters. A large number of letters from Jenny Lind have just' been discovered In Rome, written to a lady friend resident In Italy, and covering a period of thirty years, from lS45to 1874. It is said that they aro moro than a hundred In all, and arb in the most ?intlmato and unconventional terms, giving tho great prlma donna's candid opinion of much of the music and many of the musi cians of her time. The letters have been purchased by an Italian publisher, who pro poses to issue them to the world very short ly. It Is to be hoped, however, that thoy will be judiciously edited (remarks a writer in the 'Daily News'). It will add a new terror to life if private letters, never in tended for tho public, and probably written with a freedom only adopted in correspon dence with an intimate frlond, can be print ed without suitable revision. In this coun try it Is assumed the copyright would bo ?with tho deceased singer's executor, name ly her husband, Mr. Otto Goldschmldt ? * ? ? Will Verfll's Huslc Live? : Roferring to the death of Verdi, a writer in last issue of the 'Sunday Times' says:— ?'It was his own wish that ho should be judged by his latest works — 'Alda,' 'Otel- lo,' and '.'FalstaU.' . On these he staked his renutatlon. Thero Is no sign that theso

works will ever be cast into exterior dark ness whilo Europe retains its artistic taste, and the love of the' grand and beautiful In music remains. Just at present Verdi Is being 'kept out of the running' in Aus tralia by the Wagnorlan performances. But .tho fact that 'Maritana' and 'Tho Bohc raian Girl' are kcoplng paco Bide by sldo with 'Tannhauser' and 'Lohengrin' is a protty good evidence that Verdi would bs warmly welcomed back to eur opera houses. Whatever may be tho caprices of - public taste and managerial enterprise, we predict that it will bo many a long day beforo tho last it heard of 'Trovatoro,' 'Rigolotto,' 'Un Ballo,' and 'Ernanl.' Pure melody is immortal, and cannot die.' . ? _►.._?_-_ ?

Miss Ada Crossley was one of the princi pal vocalists on Good Friday at the London Crystal Palace. ' ? Miss Evangeline Florence, out here with a concert company a few years ago. was singing at the London Crystal Palace when the mail left Says a late 'Frisco paper :— 'Jean de Reszkc's voice has failed him again. In consequence, the new French opera,- .'Le Cid,' was not given' in Boston Tuesday night by th.g Grau Opera Company. The management 'simply announced the change of operas, and said the great tenor was In disposed. As near as can be learned. Do. Reszke has been stricken with the same form of bronchitis with which he was af flicted last year, and which kept him voiceless for many months His physicians believe he will be unable ever to appear upon the operatic stage again. 'Jean, do Reszke's voice is only memory hereafter,' is the mournful prophecy of music lovers who heard him in Boston.'

articleText:
Musical.

Mr. Lempriere Prlngle, after his Austra lian engagement with Mr. Mtisgrove Is con cluded, will appear in a new opera In Lon don. -.???? . ? ? Miss Lilian Devlin, who gave a concert at St. James' Hall, London, just prior to the departure of the mail, recently sang at Mrs. Clayton's, before the Duke and Duchess of Connaught. Their Highnesses, it is re ported, warmly congratulated * the young Australian on her singing.

Miss Florence Young appeared with much success at Madame Marchesl's concert in Parl3'aweek or two ego, according to a London paper. She was twice recalled for hor singing of an air from 'Titus,' with clarionet obbllgato, and received great praise 'from sovoral connoisseurs present. Miss Young's term with Madamo Marchesl was to have ended last month, when she .was to have returned to London. Paderewski's opera, 'Manru,' which Is said to recall the style of Bizet, and also a little that of Wagner, appears to bave been a- great success in Dresden, where the author was called eight times after tho first act; ten after the second, and as many as thirteen times after the third act. Tho Misses Beatrice, Muriel, and Bessie Griffiths arranged an evening concert at the Salle Erard for July 3. Among those who were to havo assisted were Madame Bertha Rossow, Madame Eleanor Cleaver, Mr. Ro bert Radford, Mr. Conway Dlxon, and Mr. Reginald Clarke. The Misses Griffiths play ed at Lady Brassoy's recent 'At Home,' at 24 Park-lane, when their skill on their various Instruments created much admii'a- i tlon. ' ' ? t

Miss Addio Place, formerly of Mr. J. C. Williamson's company, hos been touring in Encland with tho Morcll-Mouillot Opera Company. Sho Is tho leading lady's under study, and at Bath recently played the prin cipal part In 'A Runaway Girl' with much success. Mijs Placo is a Launccston girl, and studied under Slgnor Pauzani when she wont to England a year ago. There was a great audlcnco at Covcnt Garden last month, when Mdine. Melba made her re-nppcarancc. Tho opera and other singers wero of purely secondary In terest.' Melba was singing, and the rest mattered little. Tho Australian prlma donna selected Puccini's 'La Boheme' and tbe mad scene from 'Lucia dl Lammor moor' for hor re-ontreo, and sho undoubted ly selected well; 'No ono In his senses (says tho 'Dally Mall') wants' to hear Melba in Wagner or in anything elso strenuous. To listen to her voice sliding without effort through the melodies of a Puccini, and a Donizetti Is sufficient. Just as Blanche Marchcsi's vocalisation is a miracle' of in tellect and art, so Melba's Is a miracle of nature. Her singing i3 as unpremeditated as a nightingale's. Hor wonderful cdgoless voice is of itself a perfect thing of beauty.' Mrs. Robert Mitchell, better known under her professional name of Mi33 Bessto Doyle, tho Australian' violinist, welcomed -the ar rival of a baby son last month at her apart ments in Paris. Madamo Pattl, assisted by Mr. Santley, the Misses ..Eissler, and Mr. Pendoro Price, recently gave a morning concert, under the conductorshlp of Mr. Ganz, at tho Gwyn Hall, Ncath, for the benefit of tho poor of Neath, the Swansea Hospital, and the Homo for Convalescent Poor at Porthcawl, the town being decorated In honor of the occa sion. The Mayor and Corporation received tho Cnaig-y-nos party at the railway sta tion; and conducted them to their carriages, in which they drove to tho hall, passing under triumphal arches bearing appropriate mottoes, and throush streets lined by a cheering populace. Madame Pattl's singing mas clamorously encored, nnd she respond ed generously, singing In all nine times. Two of her encore songs were 'Comin' Thro tho Rye' and 'Home, Sweet Home.' An il luminated address, couched in flattering terms, was presented to Madame Patti by the Mayor of Neath. The concert, which was organised by Mr. Curtis, tho local town clerk and a nephew of Mr. Henry Weir, realised about £S00. M. Gerardy gave Ills fourth concert at the Town Hall last night, when, as on the pre vious occasions, the attendance was not ;by ?any means in keeping with the excellence o! tho entertainment. Why this should be so Is- 'difficult .'-to understand, for Jean Gerardy is. one.of the mo.3t superb artists ot to-day— and in saying' this we do riot speak lightly. His magnificent command of t'he 'cello-7-hls fine 'technique'— appeajs directly to the musician, and his marvel lous 'tone' is in itself a revelation to those who know what 'collo'. playing is. It is regrettable ttat such a fine musician has not 'been able to command larger atten dances. A mdtineo will bo given this afternoon. . ' The Dolores Company has been very suc cessful in the North. A letter from Mr. Harold Ash'ton, from Townsville . to the Brisbane 'Courier,' says: 'I havo arranged for Mdlle. Dolores to give three farewell concerts nt His Majesty's, Brisbane, on. July 22, 24, and 27. I have specially engaged Miss Nora M'Kay; your brilliant young. Queensland violinist. I heard her in Bun-, daberg, and think she is a marvel.'

articleText:

The Patey concert season closed on Saturday, the 25th ultimo, when the Centennial Hall was crowded by an audience which grew enthusiastic over the contributions of the great contralto. Madame Patey, it is arranged, will visit Sydney again In order to assist in the Christmas performances of the "Messiah," which the Sydney Philharmonic Society is promoting. A new musical society the Sydney Choral and Orchestral Society which has for its conductor Mons. Henri Kowalski, has made its appearance in a successful concert, The orchestral entertainments have been rather interfered with by the social derangement consequent upon the departure of Lord and Lady Carrington.

snippet: Madame Mary Conly has been specially engaged to appear with the Wellington Philharmonic Society in " Ehjah," and " The Creation," both of
articleText:

Madame Mary Conly has been speci ally engaged to appear with the \\~el lington Philharmonic Society iu ' Jili jab,' and ' The Creation,' both ol winch she sang last month in Sydney uith remarkable success. Prior to her appearance in New Zealand in August she will toui some of the principal dis

v«»i.io uuuci tut; £*iuiB.ijer smiljll QUOC tion. A curious incident occurred during the recent tour (country) of Madame Slaggio Stirling and her conceit party through tlie Goulburn Valley district. A tiny child of six iiad been put to lied by her parents, who lived a short distance from the liall, so that tliev might attend tho concert. When tb'e entertainment was nearlv half-way through both audience and' performers were startled at seeing a little white robed figuro walk through the hall to the front seats. She had evidently wakened by the sound of the music and applause, and, attended by lier faitli ful dog, walked across the field so that she, too, might enjoy the music. There is a common belief that Puri tanism was hostile to music, and a re cent book asserted that during the Puritan era song iras dead ,'„ Ji»claii(J. Mr. Percy A. Sclioles. Mus.lj., of Manchester University, has just been stating that nothing could be further from the truth: — 'Take tho great Puritan poet, Milton (lie said), The peahug organ ' was to him oue of tin features of irarship, and his concep tions of heaven in his great epic were suffused with music. Hunyan, a stricter Puritan, was, like many others against instrumental music in church, but he appreciated song, as frequent references in his 'Pilgrim's Progress' showed. At tlie Interpreter's Douse there were musical instruments for the recreation of the travellers. While in prison, Bunyan made a flute out of t)ie leg of a chair, a feat which showed not only his musical leanings, but no moan mechanical abilities.' As a matter of fact, more music was published during the Coranionn-ealtb than in the corre sponding period, either before or after. In a chat on drums, a writer in the 'British Bandsman' soys: 'In con tests for military bands the drums are generally used as if they were playing the piece in a programme, and the extra practice in preparing for such a contest is of much use- in im proving tbe drummers. The brass band drummers would very likely prove themselves quite as good as those in the military bands if they bad the same opportunities. Many years ago tlie brass bands, when they went to a march contest, used drums and cym bals, and drummers then could at least drum tho mawlios well. So in order to encourage the drummers 1 would suK eest that at tin. march contests of the future the marches should be played twice, and that the drums should' be used tlie first time through.

: Botal Acadeut o? Music.—An interesting, and in England, novel competition, took place on the 27th instant at the itoyal Academy of Music. The' prizo competed for was a gold medal, presented by Dr. Llewelyn Thomas, physician to the Academy, for decla matory and expressional singing, the contest being confined to sopranos and con traltos. A new.feature was introduced in the selection of the judges, who in this instance were not chosen from the ranks of the Academy professors. The committee were fortunate in obtaining the services of the following gentle men as judges:—^lr. W. A. Cum tilings, the Chevalier Lemmens, and Mr. t-ims Beeves. There were sixteen competitors, and the medal was awarded to Mtm Ellen Orridge;

Mary Davis and Jliss Martian Williams beine

commended.

The ceiling is beautifully decorated, and when the artists

and workmen have completed their work the i house will have a remarkably handsome |

appearance.

; l-A GrbjltTbxorix HIS OLD Agb.-"We (FiU Mall Gazette) are informed on trustworthy authority that the statements recently published by the Paris Figaro as to the easy circumstances of Signor Mario were altogether incorrect. Sign r Mario is unfortunately quite without resources; and it is to be regretted that a move ment which bad been made for a subscription on his behalf has been greatly hindered by the publication of the Figaro s paragraph. A con cert is about to be giren in London for his benefit, at which Mdme. Christine Nilsson, who comes specially to London for this occasion, will be heard-probably for the only time this season. Several of our most emin?nt English artists, Mr. Sims Reeves and Mr. Santley among the number, haveofiered their services; and it is hoped that by the sale of concert tickets, and through contributions apart from the concert, a sufficient sum willbt collected to enable the committee of gentlemen who are interesting themselves in London on Signoc Mario's behalf, to buy him a comfortable annuity. The concert will take place at St. James's H&U on the 29th of May.

THE Gskat Ciscixkati OBGAX.-Up to the ' present, the Boston Music Hall orgau has

ranked t»a the largest instrument of the kind, in ; America. It was built by E.: F. Walcker and

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The scheme for the establishment of a festival choral society in Melbourne, put forward recently by Mr. Frederic Beard, is going apace. No fewer than 230
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The scheme for the establishment of a festival choral society in Melbourne, put forAvard recently by Mr. Frederic Beard, is going apace.' No feAver than 230 applica tions Avere received last Aveek, and the list will remain open for some months yet, be fore the final selection is made. It is in tended to give the first series of concerts announced during next year,- and the first festival proper will most likely take place during the month of July, 1909.

Those who can hark back into the seventies and eighties — Avhen W. S. Lvster was king — Avill doubtless recall pleasant memories of Rossini's Moses in Egypt, done as an opera on the public stage. Re produced 'by the Lyric orchestra under Mr. Charles Levy a performance was given on Thursday. 'Mr. Horace SteA'ens was a care ful and often forcible exponent of the music allotted to Moses; and Mr. C. H. Lednvard made an excellent SIioav Avith that of Phar- oah, though it is a pity that a voice so good as his in the middle register is not more effective at top and bottom. Miss Evelyn Ashley sang the music of Anais very creditably, though at starting her in tonation Avas not above reproof; and Miss Bella Bull was a satisfactory Zillah. The part of Amenophis is not an easy one, as it is elaborate and bears often rather high, so that Mr. Claude Haigh is to be compli mented on having done as Avell as he did. Miss Minnie Paton made a satisfactory Sinais, albeit her voice is not too sympa thetic in quality. The other principals need no special reference. Rossini Avas rarely severe upon his orchestra, and Mr. LeA'y's amateurs may legitimately pride themselves on having been fairly Avell equal to all requirements, Mr. J. B.. North being a most helpful leader. It is perhaps worth chronicling that the audience at Miss Marie Hall's first concert in Sydney avere roused by her brilliant playing to such a pitch of genuine enthu siasm that they actually left their seats and clustered round the platform, cheer ing and applauding until the young artist played for them a second time the Trau- merei. The same intense appreciation marked the ivhole of her recitals there, and so great Avas the public desire to hear her that Messrs. lJ. and N. Tait had/to prolong the series, just as they had to do in Mel bourne. Miss Marie Hall leaves Sydney to day (29th June), for Wellington, aa'liere she giA'es her first concert on Thursday next, 4th July. Australian music loA'ers in gene ral, and particularly those avIio have not had an opportunity of hearing Miss Hall, will regret to learn, hoAvever, that it has been found impossible to arrange for her return to the Commomvealtli, in spite of all Messr. J. and N. Tait could do, al though in the beginning they aa'ere hopeful that a'isits could be paid to Brisbane, Ade laide and Perth, and other centres. But Miss Hall has important engagements' in the old Avorld aa'liich cannot be brqken, and therefore Avlien the Ncav Zealand tour finishes she will go "straight to England a'ia America. Queensland lias fallen absolutely captiA'e to the Besses o' the Barn Band, aa'liich has been delighting audiences in all parts of that State for the past few Aveeke. Messrs. J. and N. Tait liaA'e noAV definitely fixed 27th July for their opening in Melbourne, and the Besses will therefore come south again, playing by the way,, and a return visit to Sydney as hinted at as within the bounds of -probability. Some eight or ten performances Avillbe given in Melbourne,

and then the band will visit the Victorian provincial centres. - < Messrs. J. and N; Tait received adA'ices by -the Inst -mail from London aa'hich go to indicate that Mr. Percy Grainger is making a name for himself as a composer as Avell as an executant. /Sir 'Edward Elgar . has interested himself very deeply in .the young Australian -pianist, and has stated ' that in his opinion he Avill be one of the most dis tinguished among modern composers. It is not so. many years ago that Madame Clara Butt was an unknown student at the Royal Academy of Music in London, in which institution she won -the Royal Scho larship of 400 guineas. At the age of 19, ho\ve\'0r, she leapt into a fame which has increased ever since, until it is now in its heyday. The Albert Hall Avas the place, The Golden Legend tlie piece, in aa-liich she made her debut, and her success Avas imme diate and immense. That sueh a \-oioe, un paralleled in its sAvcetness and its power alike, should come from one so young fairly .amazed the audience, and next day it aa-as Miss Butt ujioii aa-hom the critics lavished their most laudatory adjectives, so that the young girl, aaIio the day before Avas a stu dent, aAvoke to find herself famous.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Opera at the Princess's has been confined chiefly to a series of repetitions, with a representation of The Barber of Seville interpolated. Faust is to be given on
articleText:
4 MUSICAL.

Opera at the Princess's has been confined 'chiefly to a series of repetitions, with a re presentation of The Barber of Seville inter polated. Faust is to be given on Satur day and Die Walkj-rie will be produced best; week.

. 'At the Orpheus Society's . concert in the -Town Hall on Wednesday Mr. Frederic Beard, the new conductor, made a success ful inauguration. The most noteworthy item in the programme was the Coronation .Ode, written by Mr. A. C. Benson and set to music by Sir Edward Elgar. It opens with an imposing chorus Crown the King with Life, interspersed with brief -passages for the soloists. This number, though lengthy, is well .varied and highly attractive, the climax, God Shall Make Him Great, being finely worked out. Next we have a chorus, practically unaccompanied Daughter of Ancient Kings— a charming and simple bit of four part writing, with a imost original ending, the final chord in place of the expected tonic (E flat) being the siibmediant (0 -minor). This number. in stantly established itself in the favor of the audience, and a repetition was insisted on. Next comes a bass solo with male chorus Britain. Ask of Thyself; a fine' and effective number, in which Mr. C. H. Ledward, a singer of whom more is likely to be heard, created a very favorable impression', despite the fact that in places it bears rather high for him. There is some power ful work towards the close, which he did very well. The soprano and tenor divide the first part of No. 4, Hark Upon the Hallowed Air, after which there is a quar tet. This is all graceful music, and would be very beautiful if tlie voices blended; but. unluckily, Mr. Oswald Rippon, tbe tenor, lias a quality of tone that is too assertive "to _ blend with that of Miss Lilian Held: Tlie succeeding quartet and chorus, _ sung entirely ".without ac companiment, is very charming, and the 6de ..winds up with the telling contralto solo and chorus Land of Hope and Glory; This is founded on a theme which Elgar iiad previously used in his Fotnj) and Cir cumstance march, and which sp pleased Ithe King that he asked the composer .to introduce it into his Coronation Ode. Miss 9lrft Rogers sang the solo beautifully. She

has a nice velvety quality of voicis. Other novelties were Gounod's Hymne, _a Sain to 'Cecile, a. beautiful subject, treated with all . the composer's art, and well played by the orchestra; and Elgar's Pomp, ana. Circumstance March above re ferred to. The Tannhauser March pleased so well, that an encore had to be" granted, but Tschaikowsky's 1812 Overture' is a work that ought always to be heard in the open air; in a concert room the noise is too deafening: ' - . ' ' " Some artists have to wait. a long time for recognition, but Miss Marie Hall conquered tlie public almost from -the day that Savoik put his own violin into her hands and sent her forth to let it give to the world the message of . beauty that- it held. Before leaving Prague"she roused "so critical an audience as the members of the local con servatoire to. such a pitch of enthusiasm that she was recalled to the .platform twenty times after her first solo. The same scenes of enthusiasm were repeated when Miss Hall played in .Vienna, and when she made her debut in London. It was immediately apparent from the eulo gistic references made about lier by the press and public that a violinist of tbe front rank had suddenly appeared. Since then, only a few years ago, Miss Hall's career has been one of continued triumphs, not only in Europe, but also throughout America, where she has just brought a second tour to a conclusion. She loaves Vancouver on Friday, 26th April, in the Moana for her Australasian engagements under Messrs. J, and N. Tait, which begins with an orches tral . concert in the Melbourne Town Iiall on the 1st June. Madame Clara Butt and her husband, Mr. Kenneiiey Ituniford, sang at Liverpool a day or two after the Huddcrsfield incident, of which mention has already been made, and the public evinced such an exceptional eagerness to hear her that every seat in the hall was sold out two days beforehand. Ac cording to advices received by Messrs. J. and N. Tait, under whose management they will tour Australasia in September, the two stars will give a farewell concert in Lou don on 29 th June, and leave a few days afterwards for this side of the world. Auckland has supplied anothe?: piece of evidence as to tlie popularity of the Besses o' th' Barn Band in New Zealand. At an open air performance there recently the at tendance was so great that it could not be kept within bounds and broke down ail the barriers erected to contain" them. - last Saturday (20tli April) the Besses gave their services in aid of the Seddon Memorial Fund at Wellington, and for the . rest of -their stay in New -Zealand they will' be playing through the North Island. Tliey lc-ave for Australia on the Cth May and open their Australan tour, which' Messrs. J. and N. Tait have fixed to commence in Sydngy on the 11th May. . Sir. Percy Grainger, according to advices received by Messrs. J. and N. Tait, lias reached this year a very prominent posi tion in tlie world of music. Last month in London the brilliant - Australian pianist was recalled half a dozen times for his playingat a Philharmonic concert, and the papers r.ext day commended liim for liis refined brilliance, bis virility, his insight and bis charm. He has a tour of Denmark in pros pect, where he is very popular, and in June he plays at an orchestral concert at tbe Albert Hall. An Oxford recital and a big reception by the Marchoness of Bath are two more of his more important engage ments. Mr. J. C. Williamson has been fortunate enough to secure Miss Amy Murphy, one of the most prominent sopranos in New Zealand,' for his. new musical comedy com pany. Miss Murpliy, who lias a splendid voice and a brilliant reputation on the concert platform, lias figured frequently in amateur theatricals in the colony, and Mr. Williamson lias been trying for. three years now to induce her to accept an- en gagement .under his management. It was not until lie was over in New Zealand him self, however, that fie was able to per suade her to change her status from ama teur to professional, and lie considers it an exceptionally fortunate thing, both for the company and for the Australian public, that he" was able to do so. Another engage ment he has made is that of Mr. Reginald Kenneth, a baritone of address and experi ence, who has been trained .in the George Edwardes companies in England and South Africa. To-niglit, 27th April, the highly success ful season of the Royal Comic Opera Com pany in Adelaide comes to a conclusion, and next week they will play at Ballarat (29th, 30th, and 1st May), and at Geelong for one night. Tlien they leave for Brisbane, where their season commences on 6th May, Herr Benno Scherek has received a cable gram announcing that Madame Teresa Car- reno, the celebrated pianist, who com mences a professional tour of Australia next month, has sailed from London.by the Oruba. - Miss Violet Clarke, daughter of Sir G. Sydenham Clarke, whose musical tastes led lier some rime ago to engage in regular con cert singing in London, has now, writes our London correspondent, advanced a fur ther step in her profession by joining the D'Oyley Carte Company, which is very suc cessfully reproducing the -whole of the Gil bert and Sullivan operas at the Savoy Theatre. Mr. Frank Wilson, who , was principal baritone of Mr. J. C. Williamson's Gilbert and Sullivan Company,. has been engaged for the baritone roles .in the D'Oyley Carte revivals at the Savoy. " He; was announced to apnear as the Colohelin. "Patience, a role in which he gained success in this -part of the world.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The organ recitals at the Town Hall by Dr. Price are appreciated by those of musical taste, arid the growing attendances prove that they are exercising a
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The organ recitals at the Town Hall by Dr. Price are appreciated by those of musical taste, arid the growing attend ances : prove that they are exercising a wider influence... The programmes are well selected, and make appeal to those who are able to enjoy a high standard. On Sat ui-day evening the Toccata and Eugue in 0. major, .by -J,; S. Baph, was admirably x-endered, and a transcription of the Tanrihauser . overture was .. also cleverly: done. Other-numbers wererWolfram's Star of Eve, from, the same opera; a beautiful Ave Marie; by Arcadelt; a Scherzo from

one ot ' Schubert s works, Morandi s bril liant Offertoire in E flat, the Nocturne and Wedding March from Menclelssoh'n's Mid summer Night's Dream music, and a selec tion' from Faust. . -, . > Madame Teresa Carreno, the famous pianist, who has been desoribed by ' Yon Bulow as the most interesting pianoforte ' player of the present day, arrived by the mail steamer, and will make her opening appearance at the Marshall-Hall concert in the Town llali on Saturday afternoon. ' This will "also be the occasion of the first appearance in' Melbourne "of Miss Florence Ballara, who is now on a visit to this city after her. European success as a vocalist. Miss Marie Hall, the brilliant young violinist, to whose advent all Australian music lovers are looking forward, is due; to arrive in Brisbane on board the Moana on Sunday next -(19th May), anil will tra vel straight through to Melbourne, where her first concert will be given on the 1st June. For the occasion the Marshall-Hall orchestra .has been specially engaged by Messrs. J. and N. Tait, Professor Marshall- Hall himself occupying the. conductor's desk. In the week following recitals will be given on" the 4th and 6th June in the Town Ilall, and then Miss "Marie Hull goes on to Adelaide. The Sydney season- will commence about the 15th June. Messrs. J. and N. Tait are compelled to restrict the tour of twenty concerts, owing to bliss' Hall's many engagements on the other side of the world during the closing months of the year. The violinist . will be accom panied on her tour by Miss Lonie Bjsch, a young pianist who has already made an enviable reputation for herself at impor tant London concerts. Some indication of the waj , in- which Australians have been anticipating the visit 'of "the Besses- o'lh' Barn Band is afforded by the fashion in which tlie book ing office was rushed when it was opened in Sydney for the season there, xlie first day saw over 500 seats booked, and before the week closed very nearly, the whole of the huge Town Ilall had been reserved. For the opening night Messrs. J. and N . Tait has made ' elabora tc preparations, which included the decoration of the audi torium with hundreds of electric lights in the Besses colors. .The opening perform ance last Saturday (11 th May) even ex ceeded' the high expectations formed. The hall was filled before 7 o'clock, quite 5000 being turned away, anil the immense au dience was aroused to a tremendous pitch of enthusiasm One might almost describe Madame Clara Butt's party as "a complete com pany" so many people are accompanying the great prima donna to Australia. In addition to herself and her husband (Mr. Kennerley Humford) and their concert party, there will be -Mndame's three child ren, lior sister," who is coming to look after the hopes of the ltuni fords; a nurse to as sist her in that. important task, madame's maid, and a secretary. Messrs. J, and N. '.fait will therefore have to make arrange ments for the accommodation anil trans port of quite a dozen individuals. Brisbane is doing its. duty by the Royal Comic Opera Company in splendid fashion, and the season there is one record of well filled houses and unstinted enthusiasm. The company will remain there for about ten nights more, and 'then leave for the south again in time to make their long ex pected appearance at Iler -Majesty! Theatre, Sydney, on 1st June. After Tlie Spring Chicken has been "fairly started and Mr. Coventry has . seen The Blue Moon through its preparatory stage by the musi cal comedy company at tlie Melbourne Princess's, the company will at once begin rehearsals of The Dairymaids, which will be the next attraction to be, produced by them. The new musical comedy company, whose Australian debut is to be made at the Princess's Theatre, Melbourne, on 22nd June, is taking shape in the most attractive form. The company promises to be excep tionally strong vocally, and also in the mat ter of comedians. There are three of the latter— Messrs. Gouriot, Clifton and Parker —all capable of taking leading parts; while Miss Daisy Wallace in the soubrctte parts is likely to score heavily. Furthermore, to the company's groat advantage, Miss Celia Gh i Ion i is to join it, und she will be a tower of .strength, both from the musical anil the comedian point of view. The chorus, which has been engaged both in Sydney and Melbourne, also contains really excellent material. Mr. and Mrs. Albert Mallinson have ac cepted- an olTor to give fifty song recitals in Australasia during tlie year 1008. Their recitals in London last season (together with Madame Ada Ccosslcy) aroused unwonted interest, and the impression made at that Lime by Mr. Mai linson's many beautiful songs was a. deep one.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Even the week's extension of the Melbourne season of the Besses o' th' Barn Band was not sufficient by a long way to satisfy the public's desire to hear them,
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Even the week's extension of the Mel bourne season of the Besses o' th' Barn Band was not sufficient by a long way to satisfy the public's desire to hear them,

and Messrs. J. and N. Tait have therefore arranged for a return visit during the first week in September. The Town Hall having proved inadequate to accomodate the audiences, the Exhibition Building has been engaged in order to enable everybody to hear the famous organisation, and popular prices . vyill be charged. This week the Besses., are in'-Adelaide, and next week will he spent-rin Broken Hill. Adelaide will again be visited ,on the way back to Mel bourne, and at the present moment Messrs. J. .'and N.'Tait are engaged in an endeavor to arrange their Western Australian tour. To that end they have cabled to England asking whether trie band miglit return via the Suez Canal1 instead of across America, as was the original intention. If this can be managed it will mean a prolongation of their sojourn in. Australia — which recent events have shown will be amply justified. Mr. Frank Merrick and Mr. Carl Barre the two instrumentalists of the concert party who are accompanying Madame Butt to Australia, gave a recital in London a few days before they sailed, which was very favorably commented on. "Delicious," "fine intelligence," "high artistic aims" are some of the Times' references to the former, while the same paper calls the latter a highly finished violinist. The Melbourne Amateur Orchestral So ciety gave an excellent concert in the Town Hall on Thursday evening, under the direc tion of Mr. Dawson. The Beethoven sym phony was done remarkably well. There were passages, such as the pjprise of the subject in the andante, or in the minuet, where mere professionals might have done better, but, taken all round, it was a high ly creditable performance. Two pieces by Nicode, for strings, horns and an oboe, were presented. The former one a varia tion of the naked and familiar Old Hun dredth; the other of more musical consis tency. It was nicely played, a special word of praise being due to the horn soloist, while oboe and cor anglais were in safe and capable hands. Mendelssohn's Hebrides overture and the Weird Dance Macabre of Saint Saens were also included in the re cord. Miss Una Bourne played brilliantly Liszt's Hungarian Fantasia. In the An dante Spianato and Polonaise of Chopin she showed neat, crisp execution. She ad ded a characteristic Grieg piece as an on- core after the fantasia. This evening, at the Town Hall, an in teresting programme of songs and biograph pictures will be presented by the Coward Company. , , . . Madame Blanche Arral has been singing in Sydney at the town ball, and made her final appeurance lust week. It is recorded in an admiring manner that she dresses in costume to suit her different songs. In the Shadow Song, from Dinorali, Madame Arral wore an Empire dress of pale pink, with an overdress studded with opals, white, bird of paradise plumes being, ar ranged in her hair, aud diamond orna ments.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: In the realms of music, as well as of song, it is pleasant to note the progress both in numbers and attainments made by our girls' generally of late. Our attention has just
articleText:
MUSICAL.

snippet: English Opera House, Sydney.—The performances of Madame Anna Bishop have consisted of Norma, Donizetti's opera of L'Elisir D'Amore, part of Tancredi and Lucrezia Borgia, the celebrated Mexican
articleText:
MUSICAL.

English Opera, Home, Sydney-the performances of Madame Anna Bishop have consisted of, Norma, Donizetti's opera of L'Elisir d'Amore, part of Tan- cred! and Lucrezia Borgia, the challenge' scene from Lucia di Lammermoor, and the celebrated Mexican

piece! entitled La Pasadita.; Of the Norma of Madame; Bishop we have frequently recorded an opinion; nor have,we.reason,,to.suppose.the lyric stage presents so perfect an embodiment as that of the high priestess of this distinguished, and accomplished artiste. So essential to a finished delineation is the fusion or combination of musicale with drama

tique qualifications, that we are prepared to find many aspirants for public favour fall in their attempted impersonation of this great character, However exquisite the talents of a vocalist maybe, nevertheless, without the aid of certain physical, attributes and the genius to feel and depict the many phases of passion which so strongly distinguish the role of Norma, we find that success, if attained, is not so decided as that which attends the union of those qualifications which, in the aggregate, we so, rarely witness. Of the merits of Madame Anna' Bishop, whether her Norma is considered, by the elaborate and artistic rendering of her Lucrezia Borgia, as performed on the evening of Thursday last, we may venture the assertion that, her vocal powers do not' alone. call forth the admira- tion of her audience! In,the,picturesque positions? the commanding and dignified gait the repose and ease which characterises her style of. acting the graceful deportment, and in the note! expression of Joy, sorrow, anguish,, revenge, and despair, we may trace much of the success, achieved by this, accomplished lady.''' OperatM' time" is not so simple' a matter as. is that popularity which is gained in the concert-room..-,;. To portray faithfullytyorma or Lucresta, a considerable amount of stage knowledge and a high order of dramatic or' histrionic genius are requisite and essential. The houses during the week! have been fully attended, and the engagement of the present company is hailed with satisfaction by all lovers of? the divine art, The corps musicale including as it clubs' Messrs. Coulon' and Laglaise, and other well-known artistes, is of a nature to afford

the people of our city an opportunity of witnessing operatic productions in an ensemble 'br entirety not hitherto attempted among, us.,:; The orchestral department, led by Mr.' Gibbs, and conducted by Mr. Charles Packer,: is some guarantee. that those popular musicians will make the most of the material at their, disposal. heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Mr. Watkin Mills—than whom no modern vocalist ranks higher as an exponent of Handel, and who may therefore be considered as an authority on the work of
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Mr. Watkin Mills — than whom no modern vocalist ranks higher as an expo nent of Handel, and who may therefore be considered as an authority on the work of the 'AiiKhtv Saxon1'— savs that he has

noticed with regret a steady decline in the interest taken by amateurs in oratorios by this and other masters, formerly more than popular with the great music-loving public of Britain. Li the opinion- of 'Mr. Mills, the chahee is chiefly due to the toopreva lent fondness for things light and_ scrappy in art and literature, not .to mention mat ters of a more practical kind. At the recent Crystal ? Palace festival he was especially struck by the want of support accorded by the Londoners., though there was a gratify ing lai'ge attendance of foreigners. This change in public taste, says Sir. 'Mills, is unfortunate, as mere selections afford little opportunity for the cultivation of good voealisui, such as is given 'by. the works of Handel, whose study is, he thiuks. the best that can be recommended to youuiy sinner.*. Tn view of .Mine. Clara Butt and Mr. Keuuerley Ruinford's visit to Australasia in 10(-7-S.'ifc-inay prove of interest to readers to learn that the christening of their infant son took place to-day, when Mr. and Mrs. Kttanerley Rumford had the signal honour of ths Princess Christian of SchleswigHol stein consenting to be godmother to the child,r,who received the names of Victor (in memory of the late Prince Christian Vic tor) Ian Melton Kennerley Rumford. The other sponsors were Mrs. Edward Murray, the Ear! of Darnley; and Mr. Tan -Malcolm. M.P. The ceremony. took place at the ! Church of St. Paul, 'and was performed by the Rev. Herbert Bury, vicar of the parish. ! After the ceremony Mr. and Mrs. Rumford j held a reception at Compton Lodge. I Madame Melba is ahraysather best in the i Mart of Marcueritc in Gounod's 'Faust,'

and she was in especially' good vofce at the Covent Garden Theatre on Saturday, with the result that the big audience showed its pleasure in an unmistakable fashion. She was well supported by Faust and Mephis topheles (MM. Lafittc and Marconx). and the director was warmly congratulated on the success of the evening. Senor Manuel Garcia, who died in his 102nd year on Sunday, was perhaps ir.ore entitled to the gratitude of the public at large as being practically the inventor of the laryngoscope than even for his excellent and original work as a teacher of singing. The medical faculty and throat sufferers generally, as well as vocal instruc tors, have permanent reason to bless Gar cia's happy idea of employing a lnirnjr to reflect the action and state of the ?ocal chords. Before this, young Garcia's talent had enabled him to save a peculiarly valu able voice to delight thousands in; years to come, Jenny Lind having wisely been guid ed by his advice when her voice was threat ened with serious damage as a result of strain and incorrect production. In 1S4S Senor Garcia was appointed to a professor ship at the Royal Academy, and he held the position for nearly half a century. Among his pupils were such weiyknown 'irisjers as Antoinette Sterling. Jladame Marchesi, Charles Santley, Hcrr Julius Stockhausen. and. as before mentioned, the famous Jenny Lind. When £cnor Garcia celebrated his centenary last year he was received in person by His Majesty at Buck ingham Palace, when the King made the aged sinser-teacher an honorary Commander of the Eoyal Victorian Order. The Kaiser gave to him the much-prized Great Gold Medal for Science, and the younj; KAjg of Spain bestowed upon Iris distinguished sub ject the Royal Order of Alphonso XII.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: THE programme of the Philharmonic Society for their concert to-morrow evening, the fourth of the season, presents many features of interest; and the selection of vocal and instrumental music shows skill
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The programme of the Philharmonic Society for their concert to-morrow evening, the fourth of the season,pre sentB many features of interest; end the selaotion of vooal and instrumenta* musió shows skill in the arrongemen-, nnd an . evident desire for advancement by advocating a taste foe the ex- cellent in crt. The orchestral department (under the baton of Mr. Callen), offers us Rossini's overture to " Otello," Beethoven's No. 1 Symphony, and Mendels- sohn's " Wedding March," for finale ; end as the pro- gramme is not too long, and-the eonoeit oonspquontly likely to terminate betimes, we do ainooroly hope that Mendelssohn's inspiring harmonious wedding feast may have no discordant accompaniment of the abuflliug fett of departing visitor?. In addition to this instrumental repast, a gentleman amateur will play a pianoforte solo

-" Weber's Last Waltz," arranged by Hertz.

Tbe vocal music is to be under the guidance of Charles Packer, and will include a trio of this composer, "O'er   the far Mountain," a glee ; and the Ernani scoria, " Infellae," all to be exeouted by amateur vocalists of the socioty. But that portion that rrill most attraot atten- tion, is the first appoarrmae in Sydney of a young lady amateur, îately from England, a pupil of Signor Arditi, conductor at her Majesty's Theatre. Report, with       trumpet tongue, proclaims this lady to be a cantatrice far above the genoral race of srliB's, whilst amateurs are said to be oast by her completely in the shade. We are to expect a rich soprano voice, with muoh expres- sion, end great powers of execution. Tho pieoes she baB chosen for ber dobut are a cavatina, by Signor Arditi, "Beminisrences ' in homage of Angfolina Bosio". (the renowned soprano,-lately deceased); and Meyerbeer's aria-a trial for all vocalists- "Robert to que j'aime." Thus, this conceit, whilst popularly at- tractive, is sufficiently classical to please the most fasti-

dious.

" BOBIN HOOD."-The step taken of late years by Oreat Britain in { be advance of the art of musie is BO remarkable, that eveything tending to exemplify this', deserves'espaoial notioe, even in this far colony of Aus- tralis. Without adverting to tho number' of English musicians, that havo .become known in the annals of mfisio, we may mention operatic composers who may vie (with one or two exceptions), with the musio writers of any European country in the present day,-Balfe, Loder, Wallace, Macfarren. Tbe enthusiasm aroused by Wal- lace's " Lurline," has been almost excelled by tbe latest npciralia production, Mncfarren's " Bobin Hood." The Gerraui subject of Wallaco's opera, in-itself inoited to composition, by its weird legendary form; but it waa badly handled by the poet, and hrrein the composer bad to suffer. " Bobin Hood," on tbe contrary, has a broader and more common-place snbjeot, though familiar and in- teresting, and this is placed by Mr. Oxenford, in lan- guage so beautiful and rhythmical, that wa enly wonder that Mr. Macfarren has been led occasionally to forget this rhythm in a false accentuation of the muBio. In point? af melody we think the preference mast be given to "Lurline;'* but "Bobin Hood" con- tains greater evidence of -originality in ' the forme of the compositions, and io peculiarities of musical idiom. Mr. Maofsrren is, perhaps the ; profounder musician and theorist, his, instrumentation is said to be very fine ; of tl.i-s we oann'ot judge as only the pianoforte copy has been received by the agent hero, Mr. L. Moss. No one will need sn outline of Bobin Hood's story. Tho characters introdncod ate Locksley, (tenor) (Robin Hood,) Little John, Moah (Millet's Son,) Allan-a-dale betrothed to ' Alice, the attendant of Maid Marian, (soprano,) who is here introduced aa the daughter of the high sheriff-Sir Beginal de Braoy (baritone}; we have also Hugo, the Sompnour or Collector, (bass.) who, like all basses, iathe bad ofaaraoter of the piece. The plot turns on the arrest of Bobin Hood for way- laying thia Sompnour, and his pardon by tba King at tho moment of exeontion, and of course, as all know bis marriage with MIBS Marian de Braoy

'Atvs shall aoón hear Borne of this music at f atare concerts, we shall return to this branch of the opera

[ far which we bare now co ipaee.- ;

articleText:

The Newbury-Spada Company left for Melbourne yesterday, to give a-, series of 'pops' at Iho Exhibition Building during Xmas week. Prior to his departure, the popular tenor entertained a number of h!:s most intimate friends at a dinner, when among those present wore Mr., Mrs., and the Misses- Wilkinson, Mdme. Emily Sol

done; Mr. and Mrs. W. A. Crawley, Mr.' Archibald Newbury, and Mr. Rodda Perry. Tho company will return here for another iories of 'pops,' commencing January 14. Madamo Melba, previous to her depar ture rcce'ntly for A~erica If vesumo her operatic- career, r.-'.e n -' .-'.rt at tho Royal Albert Hal Lone1- - In referring to. the event,, tho .'-Daily '. -egraph' says:

traliancantatrico appears all too seldom on the concert platform in London, to tho genuine regret of those who es teem at their full, value her excep tionally brilliant qualities, ' arid therefore it was only to be expec ted that amateurs would assemble in full force, and mako the occa sion one for pay ing high compli ments to a sing er of such un questionable re

source, who occupies, indeed, at the pre sent time, a position of supreme eminence. That Madamo Melba. was accorded a wol como of the warmest description when she ?advanced to the front of the platform last evening wlll.be readily assured, and that she. scored. a triumph will also bo readily conceded... .Australia was .ilso represen ted at , last evening's concert by Miss Ada Crossley,. who. sang 'Cho faro'' with deep expression and : commanding vocal ability, and' by. Mr. Kruse, a member of the Joac him Quartet, who played the introduction sjiC, -. Adagio Religoso from Vieuxteraps' Violin Concerto in D minor in a highly effective manner. ? * » * * Mr. Durward Lely is on tour through the States of .Canada. He returns to London in January. ? * ? ? At the London, Crystal Palace concert last month, a. novelty in the programme was an 'Idyl,' for orchestra, by Mr. George. W. Xi. Marshall Hall, who resigned recently

tho 'Ormondo' Chair of Music at Mel bourne University,: which ho had filled sinco 1SD0. If, as suggested in tho pro gramino anaiysin,; says a critic, thlB tono poem was 'Inspired by scenes and scenery which tho composer. witnessed in Austra lia,' wo can only infer, after listening to tho music, that tho Impressions, rcccivcl .wero-not altogether ot a pleasing nature Of agreeable melody in this elaborate and ambitious piece there- Is, a plentiful lack* continued restlessness being tho prevail ing-feature. Mr. Marshall Hall handles his orchestra capably enough, and in that direction lie any merits that his 'Idyl' may possess. That tho Crystal Palaco aud ience, found littlo to udmiro in tho work was:shown by, tho faint applauso accorded at thoclosc. ? * ?* ? Hero is a churmlnc story about Verdi (told by London 'Figaro'),\and;ju3f fresh .from Italy. A farmer, living lni the depths of Iho country,' was very desirous to hear one of; tho illustrious composer's operas. So, '..better Into than never/ lie, took his ticket, travelled up to Milan, and, secur ing a good seat, heard 'Aida.' Tho farmer wasvery much disappointed, and wrote to Verdi to say so, adding that ho did not like music at all, and that under these circum stances he hoped that Verdi would see llic reasonableness of at once returnlns him his money. Thero was his railway .tare, his ticket of admission, and his supper at Milan; for which ho enclosed tho bill. Tlib grand old maestro entered fully into the humor of the situation. Ho wroto back a pblilo letter, 'regretting that his music had failed' to please, and enclosing the railway fare and; tho prico of admission. But ho added that, as the farmer would havo to provide himself with suppor at home, he could not admit tho justice of that part ot hia claim, nnd he absolutely declined to pay tor Mils supper at Milan. c-', ' * ' ' ? ' According to a London paper Jean dc Renzko is probably tho most popular man in rhls profession, and.ainliko most of his fello^v-artista, bis popularity is as great among men as among women. Besides be ing one of the greatest operalje singers of tub 'day, ho is ah athlete of some renown. Monsieur do Reszlco, curiously, cnougii; makes a, point of ignoring the irksome rules usually laid down by great singers for the preservation'' of .'their voices.- That ' h'.s voice' Is none the worse for it all the world knows.

heading: Musical.
snippet: Madame De'Lara, the wife of that popular actor Mr Thomas Kingston, will make her Australian debut at the Centenary Hall on October 2. The lady has a budget
articleText:
Musical.

Madame Do'Lara, tho wife of that popu lar actor, Mr Thomas Kingston, will make her Austr.ill.in debut at tho. Centenary' Hall on October 2 Tho lady has a budget of cicollcnt pi ess notices us a pianlstc

This from n London contemporary — 'Paderevvbkl'is a gieat beliovei in leading in bed N Ho sayi ho finds it very benefi cial.' Wo shall: bo told next that the emi nent pianist usually washes in warm water, or tied his tlo In a sailor's knot, or does something elso equally remarkable. There Is literally' 116 holding theso geniuses. . They aro* always doing such original things. Madame Amy Sherwin Writes. No doubt the Australian musical public havo wondered why they havo heard so little ot, Madame Amy Sherwin sinco her return to the old country. A letter which

'Musicus,' :'.--' ot the South Aus tralian Regis ter,' has jubi received from tho gifted can tatrlco explains matters. Writ ing from Kent on August 2 she says: 'Since my return irons Australla-I have been through dark days - of trouble on ac count of my little girl's very dangerous state of health. Mr. T r e v e s, the eminent special ist, performed

an operation, and advised me that the only hope of saving her was to let her live for sonio years at Margate. To do this I was obliged to bury myself for a long timo, for I could not send the llttlo one, in her ' very precarious state, away from me. Mar gate is so inconveniently situated that in living there one Is cut off from almost every-' thing. However, I havo ray reward. My little' girl is recovering wonderfully, and tho doctors have allowed me to move her to this place (Bromley), which is close to town. I am now able to tako up vyork again, and have booked a large number of engagements for the Autumn and Winter in London and tho provinces. Tho pro menado concerts at Queen's Hall begin on tho 25th of this month, and I am engaged to sing at the opening ' performance and many more during. the season. On October 15 I am- to start on n four weeks' tour of tho provinces, and after that am engaged to sing at concerts in Leeds, Birmingham, Liverpool, Newcastle, and other towns. In addition to this, I' am booked for forty con certs in London. . . . Pleaso tell tho dear peoplo of Adelaide, who remember mo, to kcop on doing so, for I treasure tho memory 6! their kindness very dearly, and hopo to see them and to sing to them, bofore so very long.' Death of an Old Favorite. ? Mrs. Marmaduko Constable (nee Miss 'Joey' Gougeuhoim), one of tho mo3t gift ed and popular actresses that ever trod tho Australian stage, died at her residence at Darllnghurst early last Thursday morning. Tho deceased, whose father, Augustus Gou geuhelm, a Frenchman, and a solicitor by profession, was born in Dublin, and, at an early age, in conjunction with her sister,

Adelaide Gougenhelm, adapted Iho stage as a profession. After causing a groat sonsa tlon as a high-class comedy actress in tho United States, Miss 'Jooy' Gougonholm made her first appearance in -London at tho Lyceum Theatre In 1861, as Norah Mcr rion, in tho 'Irish Heiress.' After playing with success for some weeks in London, Miss 'Joey,' accompanied by her sister, re visited the United States, whore she gained fresh laurels, and, after a sojourn thero of about a year, came to Australia, where she at once established! herself a. warm fa vorite with theatregoers; in such plays as 'Tho Woman in White,' 'Ticket-of-lcavo Man,' 'Lady of Lyons,' and 'Court and Stage.' She played short seasons in the principal cities ot Australia, which she re visited a year or two later. In the early seventies she retired from the stage, at tho

height ot her popularity, and married Mr. Marmaduko. Constable, a. wealthy merchant, who carried, on business in Sydney. Mr. Constable died about two years ago. Miss Gougenhelm mado a brief return to the stage some few years after her marriage, playing with success in this. colony, Queens land, and Victoria. She had. been in in different health for some time past, and leaves surviving her two sons and two daughters, all grown up. Her remains wore interred in tho Waverley Comctery, tho funeral being very largely attended. .;.. Miss Kale Rooney. . '.'-., Miss Kate Rooney has returned after her Queensland season, aud made her reap pearance here at the Congress 'concert at .

Iho Town Hall on Saturday night. Needless to say ???: the popular artiste was , heartily recalled for each of her con trlbutions, which were given in her usual artistic and pleasing style. ?? Miss . Rooney intends starting on a tour ot tho Western lino shortly, and upon 'its con clusion will do the ? Southern towns, prior to a visit to Mel bourne. The ta

lented lady intends leaving for London In December, and will tako with, her the sinccrest good wishes ot a great army o£ admirers.

Tho 'Era' says that the absence of Mr. W. S. Gilbert's name from the list of those wlro attended the. funeral of the late Sir Arthur Sullivan 'Is accoainte-il for by tho fact that 'Mr. Gilbert is a)i present in Egypt seeking health. He was reprcsentea by his .brother. ; ?? '?? . ^ Mdlle. Trebclli, or, as tlho talented voea 11st now styles herself, Mdlle.
