Keers, leader of the Ti voli orchestra, particularly distinguished himself in Vieuxtemps' Violin Concerto, and called forth encomiums from the guest of tho evening. Professor Marshall Hall. - * . « ? ? ? Ono ot tho many stories told of the Iat6 Sir Arthur Sullivan's humor concerned an incident which happened at a rehearsal of one of the early Savoy operas. Sir Arthur ?was not feeling well, and his temper was just the least bit less genial than it usually s\2s. One of tho'actors had a bad cold, and persisted in singing out ot tune. Sir Ar thur bore It as long as he couia, but his gooa nature graaually cvaporutoa until none of it was. left. 'Mr. Sorana-So,' he oxclaimod, keepins 83 calm ana cool as possible unacr the exasperating circum stances, 'there is something radically wrong with that song. Either you don't understand it or I do not.' 'I think I understand it, Sir Arthur,' replied the vo calist, on his dignity. 'Ah, no doubt,' said Sir Arthur, acidly, 'that's tho worst ot being n composer. One always begins at the wrong end of the stick. For the future 1 shall start at the other end. I'll got you to sing my songs first, and then I will com unoo ttiisni^afterwards.'

Why Amy Castles Left Madame Marchcsi. With reference to the recent retirement of Miss Amy Castles from the 'ultlon of Madame Marchcsi, the Bbndlgo 'Adver- tiser' writes as follows: 'On the recent ar rival of Mrs. Castles in Paris her daughter gave up Marches!. Madame's statement ?was that the young Bendigo singer had been given up by her, as she declined to give any further lessons to one who wished to be a. dramatic soprano against hor wishes. Marchesl denied ever having said that tho voice was a magnificent one; ohe asserted ? that Amy's voice was perfectly tired when heard first by hor; it was only a sweet little voice; she was too small to sing in opera (this much insisted on), and she had no high notes In her voice, It being only a mezzo soprano — in fact, madame as serted that the young lady could, not sing up to B flat ! It has been freely asserted by many professional musicians, and by critics quite as capable of Judging voices as Marchcsi, that tho voice of Miss Castles was a pure aramatlc soprano, which woulu bo displayed at best in opera, so that this judgment of hers was qulto wrong. It is also well known in Australia that it is untrue tho volco is a small ono — it filled tho great hall of the Exhibition so that every one of the 14,000 people in the audienco heard quite perfcotly. As for tho otato ment that she was unablo to sing up to B fiat, she sang up to D flat at her own con cert in Melbourne, and no ono found fault with tho quality of the note ? Though Madamo Marches! aecllncd (whijn she knew it was all over) to givo further lessons to Mis3 Caqtlos, she said nothing about returning to her the balance ot tho money paid in advance for lessons which are not to be given. Moreover, tho lessons already given lastea often only 10 minutes lnsteaa of tho stipulated half-hour. ? 'Miss Castles has now been placed with a 'M. Bouhy, who has ?iho greatest reputation ot any teacher in Palis, not excepting Mar chesl herself, and ho aeclaros tho \-oi6c lo bo a magnificent aramatic soprano. He placed her at once in the opera class. Miss Castles was movea to go to him by somo Australian singers, who wero forceu tu leave Marchesl, ana -who aro doing woll with him.'' . n ?

snippet: The first concert of the year, hold on New Year's Night, had a special interest, inasmuch as Madame Patey, the last of the four great musical artist who visited Sydney during the past twelve months, mad[?]
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The first concert of the year, held on New Year's Night, had a special interest, inasmuch as Madame Patey, the last of the four great musical artists who visited Sydney during the past twelve months, made her " farewell " appearance. Madame Patey, in all, contributed six songs, she was warmly encored on each appearance, and, indeed, roused the audience to a high pitch of enthusiasm. Miss Bertha HOBSON', Sir. Austin Craven, Mr J. G. Patey, Mr. J. Lemmone (flautist), and Mr. Rivers Allpress (violinist), assisted Madame Patey. The entertainment took place in the Centennial Hall, and the great building was crowded. Before returning to England Madame Patey intends to travel through China and Japan.

snippet: Madame Alice Charbonnet-Kellermann has added to her previous compositions a set of studies for the pianoforte or exercises in rhythm, the first for acquiring facility in chromatic scales, the second for
articleText:
Musical.

Madame Alice Charbonnet-Kellermann has added to her previous compositions a set of studies for the pianoforte or exercises in rhythm, the first for acquiring facility in chromatic scales, the second for the shake (a very effective ornament; which is very cleverly handled in this exercise), the third for pre cision in attack, the fourth without any special designation except as regards the tempo, the fifth for expression, and the sixth for the practice of double notes. These am all

carefully fingered where necessary, and though ex cellent as exercises, have yet the charm of melody, and so far from wearying a pupil from being too dry will act rather as an incentive to study. The printing is very clear, and the 20 pages form quite a volume. Each exercise is dedicated to a pupil by name. The Sydney publishers are Messrs. Elvy and Go. From the Stuttgart News of 20th January last the following paragraph is taken ' On Tuesday of last week a magnificent concert was given in Stuttgart by the famous Australian composer and pianist, Miss Florence Menkmeyer, who, of all the artiststhathave ever visited Stuttgart, appears to have succeeded in evoking the greatest enthusiasm of her brilliant tech nique, and the great power of her interpretation, especially noticeable in her rendering of the works of Chopin, and her own soulful compositions. The evening was a memorable one, all the more inas much as Stuttgart had of late been visited by few artists of first rank, such as Bubenstein, d'Albert, &c. The fair young artist met with a well-merited and enthusiastic reception, and was frequently en cored. ' Miss Florence Menkmeyer's success will be read with interest by her Australian friends. The Norwegian musician Edvard Greig has arranged a second suite from his music to Ibsen's - play, ' Peer Gynt.' This has been performed with great success at Christiania, and it is said to be quite equal to the first suite in attractiveness. The first suite our readers will remember was introduced here by Signor Hazon in the orchestral concerts of 1890, with great success. Baron Bodolphe Prochaza, a Bohemian musician, is writing a pamphlet on the experiences of Mozart in Prague. He promises documents hitherto un known or at least unpublished. After the detailed and comprehensive work of Otto Jahn, the publication of new matter relative to the great musician will be awaited with interest. The Sydney Liedertafel, at their annual iwapKb^ received the resignation of Sir Patrick Jennings, who has filled the office of president from the formation of the society. Mr. Sydney Burdekin, vice-president, has been elected to succeed Sir Patrick, and Sir William Windeyer has been unanimously elected vice-president. A well-deserved compliment has been paid to Mr. H. B. Brewer, who, for his valu able services, has been elected a life mtgnhpr of the society. At a meeting of the Chicago Exhibition Com mission last week, the committee on liberal arts submitted a list of names of distinguished mpp, busts of whom it was 'proposed to send to the New South Wales court of the Chicago Exhi bition, After discussion the list was rejected in toto. By cable from head office the general manager of the New York Life Insurance Company, Mr. Josiah Howell, is informed that the total assets of the company on the lst January, 1892, were £25,915,080, a gain during the year of over £2,000,000, with a clear surplus over liahiliHon 0f £3,105,432. The total income for the year was £6,554,300, and the new business written amounted to £31,000,000, while the expenses had decreased by over £100,000.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: CONCERT.—Madame Mallalien gave a most enjoyable concert at the Institute, Toowong, on Wednesday night. There was a good attendance, especially in the front seats. The
articleText:
MUSICAL.

CONCEIT.-Madame Mallalieu gave amoat en joyable ooncert at tho Institute, Toowon^, on Wednesday night. There was a good atten. dance, especially in the front seats. Tho instru mental portion of the concert was the best. The accomplished concert-giver afforded a great treat by her piano performances. She played three short but oharming compositions by Mendelssohn, with great taste, and with a lady amateur, performed some striking picces for two pianos-" Hommage nu Handel" and a selection from " Don Giovanni." Admirably played was the duet for piano and violin by Madame Mallalieu and Mr. A. Quin; this was a selection from Flotow's tnneful opera J" Martha." Mr. A. Quin played on the violin, in ?; find stylo, a beautiful composition " La Melancholic," Several well known amatears gavetheir services in tho vocal department.

! IMWIOH" MUSICAX. SOCIETT.

THB third subscription concert of tho third season of tho Ipswich Musical Society came off on Friday evening week, and, on the whole, was as well received as any of its predecessors, not withstandingthattherewasnothingparticularly elaborate in the musio performed. The chornses, although for the most part comparatively easy, were: evidently appreciated, and the voice parts were rendered in such a style as to cause several encorea. Mr. Weise (the secretary of the society) especially, wasso determinedly called back thatitdelayedproceedingafor some minutes. He, however, showed his wisdom in notyielding to an excited audience, for the hour was late. Signor Banvonuti the violinist was exceedingly happy in iis.choice and in his execution, and the fact of his being each time called back by tho audienco showed that the townspeople can appreciate talent and brilliant execution. Tho selection from " Maritana," as arranged by the indefatigable conductor, was one of the greatest successes of the evening: it was indeed a chann ing'prodnction. -

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: MADAME MALLILIEU'S CONCERT.—The benefit concert given by Madame Mallalieu, at the old School of Arts on Monday night, proved a complete success in all respects. The
articleText:
MUSICAL.

MADAXB MALLILIZD'B CONCERT.-The bene fit conceit given by Madame Mallalieu, at tbe old School of Arte on Monday night, proved a ' complete . success in all respects. The admirable pianists herself has never been heard to greater advantage. Her four performances were a great treat. Her first piece, ".Rigoletto," by Liszt, was beautifully executed, and its conclusion was the signal for an enthusiastic demonstration on tbe part of the audience. A not-to-be denied encore was responded to by one of Men

delssohn's " Lieder Ohne "Worte." "Bim*

boola," the lively production by Gots chalk, vraa equally well played, but tbe gem in connection with Madame Mai lalieu's playing was undoubtedly tbe two move ments from Hummel's Concerto " Lea Adieux " for piano and stringed instruments. Tbis charming ' composition was rendered with exquisite taste and feeling by tbe pianiste, the orchestra doing their part very creditably. The audience appeared delighted with this perform ance, which, it xs to be hoped, will be repeated on some future occasion. The orchestra also . played the overture to the " Domino Noir," and Gonncd's "Harche Bomaine, ' with much spirit. The vocal department was exceptionally strong. The members of the Orpheus Glee Club lent their aid, and eang several part songs very agree ably. A lady amateur sang in very finished style a song by Blumenthal-" The message." She received a well-deserved encore, to which ehe responded with the ballad, " Let me dream again," which was equally well Bung. " When the quiet moon is beaming'' waa another fea ture of the concert, being beautifully sung by an established favouiite. Mr. Deigan, who has a fine and well cultivated voice, was heard twice to great advantage. Another gem was Mr. A. Quin's violin solo, which was executed in a manner never excelled by this talented musician. The piano accompaniment was very well performed by an amateur pianiste, who is always heard to advantage..

THE coldest-mannered people are frequently those who look 7or most warmth from others; and, when their expectations are not gratified, they forget that the coolness they meet with

ia bnt a dim reflection of their own.

IT is easy to work with a blight prospect of great reward immediately before one's eyes. But the world is not so constituted as to admit of this, as a general thing. Large diamonds do not lie scattered around promiscuously on tbe face of the earth, where anyone may stretch foith his hand and pick them np. They have to be delved for-not only in the dark, but, in the majority of cases, in "uncertainty.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Miss Marie Narelle, who will open her Melbourne season at the Town Hall on Monday next, has met with pronounced success since her return to Australia last
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Miss Marie Narelle, who will open her Melbourne season at the Town Hall on Monday next, has met with pronounced success since her return to Australia last June. In Sydney she gave eleven concerts, after which she f-oiirerl finnHi WnToo

and Queensland, and lias just completed a three months' visit to New Zealand. While here she will be assisted by Mr. Chester Fentress, an American tenor, who has met With much favor during the tour; and Con stance Brandon Usher, solo pianiste. Miss Una Bourne promises a very inter-' esting programme for her concert on the 14th March. Besides playing well known compositions by Brahms, Chopin' and Schutt, she will introduce W. F. Bach's Organ Concerto, transcribed by A. Stradal for the piano. This work has not been heard in Melbourne before. Another work which will be heard here for the first time is the GVIinuetto by Zanella. Another item of great interest will be the Faust Valse, Gounod-Liszt. The last named composi tion is Godowsky's tour de force, and at all his recitals the audience insist on the famous valse being played. It was while Miss Una Bourne was in Berlin that she heard the famous pianist play the Faust Yalse. and she was so struck with it that she immediately included it in her reper toire. Herr Louis Hattenbach will assist Miss Una Bourne at her recital. Miss Alice Hollander, who accepted a starring engagement for Christmas in New lYork, met with an accident on the voyage across, and severely sprained her ankle. The White Star liner Oceanic was suddcnly uwept from stem to stern by a monstrous eea, resembling a tidal wave. Miss Hol lander, when all the passengers were or dered below at thebeginning of the storm, contrived to stay on deck, being a good sailor, and preferring fresh air. Everyone on board considered her escape with a eprained ankle fortunate, but it cost her several hundred pounds, and spoilt an in troduction in New York which had been carefully prepared for her by elaborate ad vertisement. Madame Slapoffski, who alternated prima donna roles with Madame Ella Rmsoll and Miss Lilian Coomber during Mr. George Musgrove's grand opera season five years logo, making special successes both as Elsa nnd'as Mignon, returned to Australia by (the Ventura last week. In addition to con cert appearances in the States, Madame Slapoffski accepted a starring engagement - at the vaudeville theatres of Messrs. Keith . and Proctor. On arrival, says the "Sydney Morning Herald," Madame Slapoffski went .straight on to Melbourne to rejoin her hus band, who is just now forming the chorus for the Musgrove Royal Grand Opera Com pany. At Easter the soprano will embark upon a concert tour of Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and Brisbane. ' : The Besses o' th' Barn Band are continu-

ing their triumphal -tour in New Zealand. Recent advices announce that, they played for a week in Wellington at the town, hall, to an audience of nearly 3009 nightly,, and from there they went to- such towns as- Blenheim arid Nelson, and are at present touring in the West Coast District, where they are. being appreciated most enthusias tically, for it. is. of very rare occurrence that such a large combination " finds it possible: to visit 'such 'inaccessible country. As an! instance of the ' enormous ' success of the band, it may be stated that in Blenheim,; which has a population of not more than 3500, the audience that gather ed ' to hear the' BesSes was prac tically double that, number. It is evident that for miles around people came from the outlying 'districts." At the end of this week, the Besses o' th' Bam play at the- Christchurch Exhibition . for another fort night. Tbey will' then continue then tour in tha. North. Island, which is expected to ; terminate about the '3rd May. Messrs. J, and N. Tail; announce that their tour will probably commence in jffydhey about the middle of May. Mrs. Henry Bracy is appearing in New York at the Lincoln-square Theatre in a new farcical opera called Matilda. She . ap pears on the programme as "Miss. Clara Thompson,"' the name under ' which she made her first appearance in Australia over 20 years ago. Mr. Robert Cunningham, the Melbourne tenor, was regarded as one oF the most suc cessful singers - in the German season of opera at Co vent Garden. Mr. Cunningham sutamed such important roles as that of Melot fit Tristan and Isolde, and the Steers man, with his fine song, in The Flying Dutchman. Referring; to the concert in which. Madame Clara Butt and Mr. Kennerley Rumford recently "took part, in Plymouth, the "Western News-" says that the visit of these distinguished artists and great pub lic favorites is the most important, and cer tainly the most enjoyable, of all the engage ments which make up the' annual local musical season. The last concert at the' Guild Hall was crowded to overflowing by a most enthusiastic audience, greater in size-and enthusiasm than has ever before greeted the famous contralto and her hus band in this place. The only regret was that it would be two years at least before they would again be heard owing to the ap proaching tour they were about to take in the colonies. Mr. and Mrs. Kennerlej Rumford will start for the Australian -tour some time in July next. Of the singing of Madame Clara Butt, the report says that in the' magnificent aria "Divinites du Styx," there was an intensity of dramatic feeling which thrilled her audience, and there was a storm, of applause when it was finished, many handsome bouquets were handed up to the distinguished contralto. Liddle's well known song. Abide With Me, was also magnificently rendered. . The Gondoliers is to be revived at the Savoy. In connection with this event it may not be amiss to mention that Mrs! D'Oyly Carte has, by a comparison, of re ceipts, made the interesting discovery that her present season shows a very perceptible increase in the returns from the cheaper parts of the house. In the early days of the Gilbert-Sullivan operas these were not very largely patronised. As the Opera Comique, for example, stalls and dress circle were chiefly in demand, while a little later, at the Savoy, the gallery attendance was never a strong feature. In the new condition of affairs Mrs. Carte is disposed to trace a growing appreciation on the part of the great body of the public of good music and ; a straightforward libretto. Oddly enough, too, it is not the isolated song3, but the har monised numbers, which appear to have most attraction for the audiences of to day. In connection with Madame Albnni's tour of Australia, New Zealand and India, it is stated that only 30 concerts are to be given during the stay at the Antipodes, and a six weeks' tour of India is to follow. Mr. William Green, the tenor, occupies a very prominent position in England, and Mr. Haydn Wood is described as "a splendid violinist." The Albani party will, leave Eng. .land on 16th April. Miss Lalla Miranda, the Melbourne soprano, who during the past few years has achieved much popularity on the Con tinent, has been appearing as prima donria in the operas Rigolctto, Hamlet and La Traviata, at Lisbon and Nice, and has met with great success.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Miss Florence Ballara (Miss Florence Towl), an Australian singer, late of the Moody-Manners Grand Opera Company, and at present attached to the Court Opera
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Miss Florence Ballara (Miss Florence Towl), an Australian singer, late of the Moody-Manners Grand Opera Company, and at present attached to the Court Opera in Newstrelitz, now on a brief visit to her

native land, gave a recital in the Masonic Hall on Tuesday. She was assisted by Miss Una Bourne. The programme included songs by Beethoven, Brahms, d'Albert, Richard Strauss, Hugo Wolf, Elgar, Grieg, &c., and piano soli by Liszt, Saint-Saens and Schutt. On the 3rd inst. a concert was given at the Town Hall as a kind of farewell com pliment to Miss Carline Rudd, a young pianiste of more than ordinary promise, who is leaving for a course of European tuition. She played Chopin's valse in E minor with delicacy of touch, and exliibi; ted very creditable proficiency in the well known black note study; but jier "reading" of the B major Nocturne was open to question. She showed distinct talent in the first movement of Schumann's piano concerto in A minor. Miss Maud Har rington, Miss Elva Rogers, Mr. Albert Zel- man, Mr. Amadio and Mr. W. E. Lewis contributed to the programme. Madame Clara Butt is now engaged in the final preparations for her Australasian tour under Messrs. J. and N. Tait, which has been fixed to begin at the Melbourne Town Hall on the 10th September next. She will be accompanied by her husband (Mr. Kemierlcy Rumford), and also by her three children, her sister, a nurse, a maid and three instrumentalists. The whole party leave by the Mongolia on the 19th inst., so that Madame Butt will have some

days' rest in Melbourne before the open ing, concert. Since Madame Clara Butt's visit to Aus tralia was announced, many inquiries have been made for gramophone records from those who desired a foretaste of her glorious voice. Their desire was a vain one, however, for Madame Butt is among the few who have resolutely refused to allow their voices to be transferred to the waxen cylinder, believing that it cheapened an art to reproduce it by mechanical means. Indeed so strong was that belief that recently she declined an extremely, tempting offer of 10,000 guineas from a Lon don firm for the privilege of taking a few records. Messrs. J. and N. Tait received a cable from their 'New Zealand representatives last week stating- that Miss Marie Hall's opening concert at Wellington was an em phatic success, and that all indications pointed to a very gratifying tour for the brilliant young violinist. The Queensland tour of the Besses o' th' Barn Band, which has been followed by unbroken popularity, will finish to-day (13th July), and after visiting a few towns in New South Wales on the way south ward the band will open in Melbourne on the 27th July, going thereafter to one or two provincial centres en route to Ade laide, where Messrs. J. and N. Tait have arranged that they shall open on the 13th August. The conversazione arranged as a farewell to Madame Charbonnet-Kellermann, the well-known . pianist, will take place at Glen's Conceit Hall on the 17th inst. Amongst the artists assisting will be Madame Albertine Gay, Signorina Coy, Miss'Felice Crozier, and Mr. and Mrs. W. L. Paine. It is difficult to believe that Lady Halle, who played the solo in the Mendelssohn Concerto at the Philharmonic concert re cently, took part in one of 'that soeiey's entertainments fifty-eight yeai-s ago. Yet such .is the case. The Neruda family, consisting of the pianist, Amalie, aged twelve; Wilhelmine (Lady Halle), aged nine; and Victor, cellist, aged eleven, made their first appearance in England on 30th April, 1849, at the old Princess's

Theatre. Wilhelmine played Ernst's "Car- naval de Venise" with such success that she was engaged for the Philharmonic con cert in the following June, when she undertook the solo pari, in a concerto by De Beriot. Miss Amy Castles, who has quite recover ed from her recent illness, is now booking engagements. In a private letter to a friend, Miss Castles states that she has ac cepted the following engagements: — Co logne, Sehweriu, Douglas, for July; Baden, and Magdeburg, for iScpfemoer; Munich, Dortmund, Mannheim. Metz, for October; Berlin, St. Petersburg, Vienna, Frankfurt and the Harrison tour, for November; and Birmingham,- Manchester, Liverpool, Brad ford, Neweastle-on-Tyne, Edinburgh, Aber deen, Glasgow, Sunderland, Sheffield and Leeds, for December. Miss Castles re gretted very much that her recent attack of measles prevented her appearance in opera at Cologne, for . which she was en gaged. _

heading: Musical.
snippet: Last month’s issue of The Musical Standard contains an “impression” by Joseph Holbrooke of “Mr. Albeit Mallinson” and “his huge song output.”
articleText:
?

Last month's issue of The Musical Standard contains an "impression" by Joseph Holbrooke of "Mr. Albeit Mallinison" and "his huge song; output." The writer, whose high position in the musical world entitles him to be taken seriously, describes many of Mr. Malliuson's songs as "gems." After reviewing in detail six volumes of the songs, he concludes: "Mr. Mallirson is quite the same, I should say, without having met him. These songs, with some "Songs of Sappho," bid fair to raise English art a heap, and this is urgent with me. The "Sa»^>ho" ditties are the most modern, by a great deal, of all the songs; always vocal and pregnant with big thought. Englishmen can be proud of Mr. Mallinson's giftshe is worthy of them. I, an unworthy wight, say it with unction." It is not often that a composer goes out of his way to speak in such warm terms of a contemporary. Mr. and Mrs. Mallinson commence a recital tour of Australia in May next.

snippet: INGLEBURN camp was open to visitors on Sunday and Sarah, who was on a holiday in the city from Gundyroo, decided to call on some
articleText:
MUSICAL

1NGLEBURN camp was open to visitors on Sunday and Sarah, who was on a holiday in the city from Gundyroo, decided to call on some

of the boys front her own town who were in camp. She saw quite a num ber of the boys whom she knew and finally came to young Joe, who had

a sneaking regard tor aaran. g "Why didn't you tell me that you were in the band, ! Joe?" Sarah asked him. "I'm not in any band," Joe replied, "I'm still in the g infantry." < "You can't kid me, Joe," Sarah told him. "All the boys have been telling me that you blow your own S

trumpet from daylight until dark." — "Wongarbon," i Woollahra, N.S.W. ' |

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Master Len Hallett who passed in his primary examination in music in December last, has just succeeded in passing in his elementary in the
articleText: MUSICAL. Master Len Hallett who passed in his primary examination in music 'n December last, has just.sueeeeded in passing in his elementary in the re cent June examinations of the London College of Music. He came through with considerable success, scoring 92 points ouft of a possible 100. Master Don Brown, after 14 months tuition has also just passed his elementary with 90 marks. heading: Musical.
snippet: FROM an advertisement which appears in our business columns this issue it will be seen that Miss F. Edwards is prepared to receive pupils locally for the pianoforte and
articleText:
Htfusicsl*

From an advertisement which appears in our business columns this issue it will be seen that Miss P. Edwards is prepared to receive pupils locally for the pianoforte and to fit them for all examinations, practical and theoretical. Miss Edwards until re

cently resided at Mittagong. For nine years she acted as organist to the Wesfeyan Church, and was also accompanist to the Bowral Philharmonic Society. . In June, 1896, she passed the Intermediate examina tion with pass and honors, and in the follow ing year won «? senior pass and honors. Both these examinations were in -connection with Trinity College, London. .In the next year, 1897, for senior honours, she was awarded a medal for highest marks (Sydney College). Later still she passed in the highest exami nation iu -theory (Trinity. College, London), and her last examinations got through were counterpoint (1698) and special harmony (1900), with honors. Miss Edwards received tuition' from' Mr. Sector R. M&cLean, A.T.C.L., and Mr. G, DeCairos Rego, both of Sydney. She has passed no less than six examinations within five years. As showing the high price of stock in 'and- around Wangnnui. N.Z., two bullocks, weighing 17 cwt. mioh, wero recently pur chased for export to Sydney at a oast of £20 per hiiiul.

The perseverance of Mr. Harry Gordon vSooch tbe 5*oung Australian basso, in the prosecution of bis studies, and the cultivation of bis voice at the Hoyal Academy of Muslcr London, has won for him one of tbe only two silver medals awarded by die Society at the examination in July last. who paid a well-deserved compliment to our talented native, who now ranks as a chief among tbe 300 BtudeutB with whom he is associated. This medal is no small honor to gain among the Bojal Academicians and proves the possession of great ability in Mr. Harry Gooch and entitles him to the congrntulatious of those musical friends in this city, amongst whom he Ural give proiclse of the success be has now attained.

heading: Musical.
snippet: Mdlle. Antonia Dolores has appeared in three, concorts at the Town Hall (Wednes­day, Saturday, and yesterday); and on each occasion has delighted largo audiences. The
articleText:
Musical.

Mdlle. Antonla Dolores has appeared In threo concerts at. the Town Hall (Wednes day, Saturday, and yesterday)', and on each occasion has delighted large audiences. The great soprano will give a fourth recital (a matineo) to-day. Mr. F. R. Woodhouse, the well-known tenor, who has been unfortunate In tho matter of health, is at least fortunate in possessing the sympathy of troops of friends, and there is little doubt that the Vi-*Y\fifif ftT\tnrinlnTm(*nt wlifloh In hpSni» Y\rft

moted on his behalf will result In a well deserved success. Tho affair will take place at the Town Hall on Saturday even ing, the 27th lnst The gathering is aptly described as 'A Night in Bohemia,' and bohemians in all branches of art will cou ti'ibuto to a prograrome of a unique and novel character. Heady responses to assist therein havo been received from all the best vocajlsts, Instrumentalists, elocutionists, sketch artists, &c, at present In Sydney, so that an entertainment comprising tho best vocal and Instrumental music, pleasantly varied with other interesting items, may bo expected. The card of admission de signed by Mr. H. Soutar Is clever and characteristic of the movement, and will doubtless be kept by patrons as a valuable oouvenir. Mr. Geo. F. Pack, the popular young con ductor, who has supplied the music for tho several Christmas productions at Her Majesty's Theatre for some years past, Is about leaving for England, but prior to his departure he is to be given a farewell bene fit. This will- take place at tho Palace Theatre on tho afternoon of Thursday, tho 25th lnst. Mr. Pack, who has himself as sisted at numerous benofits, has been as sured of the ready co-operation of his fel low artists, and a great programme, drawn from the various placps' of amusement at present open in Sydney, is in course of pre paration. Tho bcnoflciare propoics to lcavo by the A trie. Tho managing committee met yesterday afternoon and arranged a programme for the occasion, which is certainly one of the strongest that has ever been submitted for tlho attraction of the public. Many of the principal artists attached to the various theatres will appear by permission of their respective managers. The list Includes the names of Miss Nellie Stewart, Miss Grace Palotta, Miss Carrlo Moore, Mr. George Lauri, Mr. Wallace Brownlow, Mr. Charles Kenningham, Sir. Leon Caron, Mr. Harry Rlckards, Miss Ncta Clarke-Leeto, Miss Eugenie Duggan, and members of Mr. W. Anderson's Lyceum Company, Mr. C. M. Rodney, Mr. G. Rivers Allpress, Mr. Harry Leston, and Mr. Charles Arnold and his English Comedy Company. Mr. Joe Brown is acting as honorary secretary of the movement. Our Bourko correspondent, writing on the Uth inst., says: 'Bourke is 'to be honored by a visit from that line Australian soprano singer, Miss Marie Narelle, who opens in Tobin's Hall with a very strong company on May 2. Tho combination includes Mr. John* Lcmmone, the Australian flautist. Miss Narello Bhould meet with crowded houses.

heading: Musical.
snippet: Mr. Carte has engaged Mr. Edward Gor-man to finish Ibo late Sir Arthur Sullivan's score of "The Emeraid Isle," which it is hoped will be [?] at the London Savoy .
articleText:
Musical.

Mr. Carte .bis engaged Mr. Edward Ger man to finish tho late Sir Arthur Sullivan's score of 'Tho Emerald Isle,' which it is hoped will be produced at the London Savoy about Easter. ? * ? ? A preliminary meeting of the committee for tbe Vcra Ey ton benefit concert was held on Saturday at the Hotel Australia. It was resolved to hold tha concert at tho Cen

tenary Hall on March 20. Tho arrange ments for tho programme arc in tho hands of Mr. H. N. Southwell. Miss Eyton (who leaves by the Cuzco o/i tho 27th) Is nt pre sent a momber of tho Hawtrey Comedy Company. She Is to continue her vocal studies in England. Slgnor Hazon, her lato teacher, considers her voice of great promise. ? ? ? ? Mr, Fink, ilr. Muogrovo'o representative

with tho Grand' Opera Company, ?fells a good Blory about a man who wont -o see 'Lohengrin.' The stranger taw 'Carmen' ono nig'ht, and ?then, missing a night, went again when 'Oarnicn' was igaln being played. Seeing Mr. Flrik, ho Bald: 'Look hero. I saw 'Carmine' tho night beforo last and I come again to-night and I seo 'Car mine' again. Now, 'Carmine's' all right, but I wnrttal to see 'Lonnlgan.' ' Mr. Fink ex plained that they played tho operas on al ternate nights to root, tho artists. Ho Bald If tho patron camo on tho following evening he could see 'Lonnlgan,' as ho called It. The miiB camo, and Mr. Fink, being anxious to hear what ho thought of 'Lohengrin,' wont over and Interrogated him. 'Well.' he remarked, 'tho blokes can Bins all right, but let's go and havo a drink; I can't stand 'Lonulgan'; give mo 'Carmine !' ' Mr, Fink then told him tho best was to come, explain ed the action of the opera, got the man into tho theatro again, and ho was so delighted that ho heard the Woftncrlan nutstorpleco three or four times afterwards. ? « ' * ? An amusing Incident occurred at the re hearsal of ono of the Gilbert and Sullivan operas (says Mr. Grossmlth In the 'Pall Mall Magazine'). Sullivan mode iis all camo in a crowd to the footlights and sing with outstretched arms over the footlights towards 'the gallery, a la Italian method. Tho composer screwed his eyeglass Into his eye. und, addressing us individually, said: 'Don't you understand; I want you to think you are at Coveut Garden Opera, not at tho Opera Comirruo ? I warft you, Miss ? , to imagine you are Adolina Pat tl ; and you, my dear Grossmitih, are dreadful— there Is not enough Mario about you.' I caw what he meant, and exaggerated the Italian mode, and nearly fell over the footlights into the orchestra.. Sullivan, with a smile, said: 'Ah ! 'that's better. Capital ! Do even more. You needn't consider your safety.' Verdi, the grand old man of tho musical world, who died a few weeks ago, suffered much at tho hands of organ-grinders, and. it is said. that to hoar one of his own pieces ground out on thalt terrlole Instrument of torture, the barrel-organ, was more than, 'ho could bear. Tho first opera libretto that Wagner ever wrote, according to a London paper, was so morbid that It aroused his sister's antipa thy, and tho piece was never finished, but it could not hold a candle to his first lite rary effort, which, was a drama penned at the' early age of fourteen. In the first four acts forty-two speaking characters met with violent deaths, and the cast was so much depleted 'that the characters had t» be worked in again as ghosts. Wagner's later works were cheerful in comparison. Miss Beatrice Griffiths, the Sydney pia nist, h'as several important London engage ments, including one -at a forthcoming Paitti concert. ? ? ? ._??-.? Which is the largest organ in the world ? Most of our readers would unhesitatingly give tho palm to thalt In the 'local Centen nial Hall, which, If we include the 'thunder stop' and the carillon, can boost of 128 speaking stops. But ait Llbau, in Germany, they have an instrument, built in 1885 by

B. Gruneberg, of Stettin, which has 131 Stops; and that in the Cathedral at Riga is said to have either 129 or 130. So that merely on the score of hugeness, the Sydney orga-nr seems only to como third on the list of honor(?). But the Americans, with their reverence for bulk, have in contemplation (says the Melbourne 'Age') the erection of ?an organ larger titan any of these. It is about time wo heard tao end of this craze for tho gigantic in organs. And many or ganists and persons competent to give on opinion say that some 65 or 70 stops, if judiciously chosen, will give practically every combination and variety of tone that a performer can wish. Anyone can put up . a 'bigger building than the Parthenon; but ho does not thereupon shout for joy at hav ing surpassed Phidias and Ms contempora ries. Apropos of organs, the following descrip tion of an organ in Winchester Cathedral in the 10th century will not come amiss. This instrument had 400 pipes, and required the united exertions of 70 strong men to keep it supplied with wind; and though it had only ten keys, It needed two performers to manipulate it. The keys were about three inches wide, and the player used his gloved first or his elbow — save the mark ! — to bring out the tones. There has fortunately been many changes for the better since those old days. ? ? ? ? According to 'Lo Menestral,' a good deal of secrecy is being maintained about Herr Siegfried Wagner's new opera, 'Herzog Wildfang.' The score and libretto are printed, but Herr Max Brockhaus, of Lelp sic, keeps both under lock and key. By the enterprise of a Dresden Journalist, however —the modern newspaper- laughs at lock smiths — the argument has been given to the world, and proves to be of the lightest and most gossamer-like texture. Siegfried is wise in not attempting to don tho mantle of immortal Richard; the sons of . Tom Hood, Charles Dickens and a host of other celebrities who could be named did not show the same critical discernment.

tun of vocal development. IIo has sold quite n number of his songs to Boospj, Chappcll, and other gieat publishing houses, aud ha- also doue some slghtsee inc In this lespect, however, Mi Junc ker'i -visit to England has been clouded o\er bj the death of his .iged mother, who expired oftci reading a letter to posted at P«rt Said informing her that they would meet again in a few days after a sepai.1 tfou of 17 jears This sad event, which occurred at Liverpool, has entirely altered Mi Tunckers plans, as his share of tho family property relieves him of anxiety, ns to the future, so that he now proposes mere!/ to spend d lew months' holiday In Europe, and then to roturu to his homo -in Australia Mr Juneker, who hai been 'put up' at the Savage Club, has met quite a crowd of old fuenda there Only half tho operatic season is as jet passed, nnd (sajs a vvilttr in Satuidnys 'Age ') alrcjdj four of tho seven opens piomlsed have been prosented Last week's achievement is specially notenorthj To produce within fourdajs, and on the scale ot completeness attained at the. Princess' Theatre, two biich exacting works as 'Car- men' and 'Lohengrin,' savs nuch for Mr Musgrovo's resources, and for the zeal with which the mombers of his company (includ ing chorus and orchestia as well aa puu cipals) have co-operated -with tho manager. It is i elated that on moro ihin one occa sion tho members of tho chorus petitioned for an extra rehearsal of ccrlain passages in 'Lohengrin' — .vhich is not an cveiy-diy event In theatrical annals In no cltj i.i the world probablj hns 'Lohengrin' been moro sumptuously mounter!,, and ;'ns tho .'opening

performance turned out to Do a romnrkablj evPii one fiom start to finish, nnd loused tho 'uidiencc to a high pitch of enthusiasm, no further 'novelties' are llkelj to l,o au nonnced for tho present 'Lohengrin' Is magnificent, even regarded merely as a spoctaclc, and thoso who fear lest tho music should he 'over their heads' ma/ bo counselled to 'go nnd see ' The sb-elds carried by the Brabantlne nobles More mado by Mr Musgrave's ordei in England, according to an approved pat tern, and each shield was to bear its own heraldic Jevlco When tho shields wore unpacked It was. found that tho makor had' carried cut the «rdei with taste aud, cave in one individual case, Mith judgment Re membering that 'the goods wero to lie sent to Aiistralia, he thought that n touch of 'local color' would be appreciated; and lie -grave- ly proceeded to decorate one ot the shields with — a kangaroo' A kangaroo by tho -banks ; of the Scheldt in : Wng ner's twilight day« of mjth and mys ticism would have been indeed a ujlraolo, besldo which all Ijohengrln's accomplished 'marvels would pale. It Is lucky tho manu facturer did not think of tho omu.'.or 'that singular Irird with' a manner absurd' would assuredly have figured as one ot the horaldlc doviees of old Brabant.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: WAGNER AND HIS OPERAS.—At a recent meeting of the Society for the Encouragement of the Fine Arts, Mr. Ferdinand Praeger delivered a very interesting lecture upon
articleText:
MUSICAL

Wagxebaxd his Operas.—At a recent meet*

ing of the Society for the Encouragement of the Fine. Arts, Mr. Ferdinand Praeger deli vered a very interesting lecture upon "Richard Wagner's Tetralogy*." The lec turer commenced by giving an epitome of the plot of " Der Ring des Nibelengen," daring the description of which the philosophical ideas therein embodied were explained. The necessity of an opera-house for the purpose of giving this representation was absolutely necessary, as at no other house was it possible to devote the time nor adequately illustrate the art theories of the composer. Referring to the instrumentation, which is usnally characterised as boisterous, the lecturer pointed out that the additional wind instruments and the arrange ment of the resonance-boards mellowed the

combined effect, and preserved unbroken the waves of sound Lhat issued from *' the abyss." In describing the arrangements 'of the audi torium, Buskin was quoted to confirm Wag ner* s idea that the interior of a theatre should be modelled on the simplest pattern and* with out any attempts at decoration. In order to give an example of the melody which Wagner is said to ignore, two excerpts from the u Bheingold'' wrxe performed by Mies Blanche Wyatt on the piano, and Mr. Dwver sang Sig mund's Iiebesiied with marked success. Mr. Praeger, after refuting all the objections to Wagner as & poet, composer, and dramatist, concluded by expressing a confident belief that the innate poetic feeling of the English would eventually lead to the regeneration of the

opera and the triumph of' Wagner in this ; country. * .

Photography and Music.—One of the latest

novelties in applied science, it seems, is to photograph musical tones, and'.in this way to record by light sounds that are usually apparent only to the ear. The art of photography has already worked so many wonders that few pro bably will bo astonished nt hny further feats it may be able to accomplish. At Greenwich for a long time past the magnetic pulsations of the earth have been automatically written down hy that most faithful and trustworthy, of clerks, and at the Kew Observatory we hear of daily records being secured of the sun, whenever that of late rather bashful luminary can be prevailed upon to show us its face. The movements of the barometer and thermometer are also noted nowadays by the retina of a sensitive plate, and doctors may employ the same infallible and sharp-eyed tell-tale to register the pulse beats of their patients. It -is, perhaps, only in the natural course of events, therefore, that notes and sounds should be found capable of being writtendown hythe same wonderful agency. Dr. Tvndall showed us some years ago how flames were influenced .by sounds uttered in their im mediate neighbourhood, and how they were capable of appreciating various intonations in a very marked degree; indeed, if we remember rightly, one flame that he exhibited was so sen sitive that, like a delicate minded person, it invariably went out when some particular word or yowel was mentioned. M. Koenig, of Paris,

. has already essayed to record by photography

the change. that overcomes flames from this cause, bat a German physicist, Dr. Stein, has successfully accomplished the ".photography of tones*' by a much more direct method.

plan, it appears, is simply to fix upon a violin string an upright disc or screen of mica, with a hole in it. A brilliant ray of light is made to pass through th™ little hole on to a sensitive photographic plate, which moves along at a rapid pace. Of course, if the disk and the tiny orifice in it remain perfectly stationary while the photographic plate is moving, all that will he produced in the end upon the plate is along and even line, where the ray of light has acted. But as soon as the string vibrates—as soon, that is, as the violin bow is drawn across it— the- little-' disk also trembles and vibrates, moving hp and down with, great celerity, and the,ray of light reflected upon the photographic . plate behaving in a similar manner, a curved

Hue is the result; and the number of these curves denotes the number of vibrations, which are. thus made visible and so easily counted. All, ordinary musical tones, it is said can be photographed, in this way, and Dr. Stein has been able to register several tones together, by fixing the discs attached to a series of strings like those of a violin, one above another, so that four curved Hnes are written down at

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The members of the Scottish-Canadian concert band, known as "The Kilties," who are on their moth tour of the world, arrived in Melbourne on Monday, and
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The members of the Scottish-Canadian concert band, known as "The Kilties," who are on their. ninth -tour of the world; arrived in Melbourne on /Monday, and were escorted by a squad of local bands men along Collins-street, which . was lined with interested spectators on -.both sides.

At the Town Hall the visitors ,were received by the Premier, who exhibited 'his. -peculiar? quality of humor in- their welcome. The' "opening concert of the series was held in

the-Exh'ibition Building on Monday. There was ai large 'find interesting audience. The concerted rendition of well known; Scottish airs/ as - well as' of more ambitious selec tions, were well- appreciated, and encores were also demanded of the coniet and bag pipe soloists. "- The hand is supported to a great 'extent by the Clan Johnstone troupe of dancers, who provide about a third of the programme. " The " Kilties' Choir was recalled for its singing of Annie Laurie. A. special raatinec was given on Tuesday af ternoon. Aliss Katherine Goodson, the brilliant English pianist, will make her Jirst appear ance in Australia on 12th September at the Town Hall. ' At her first recital Miss Good- son will be assisted by an orchestra under the conductorship of Professor Marshall Hull. ,. .. / Aliss Beatrice Higginson will shortly give a vocal recital in Glen's Hall,' under the direction of Mr. H. F. "Smith; . - Tlie ' Harmonists' male quartet, compris ing Messrs,' W. A. Annois, Spenser R. Kim- ber, Edwin Grainger and Jas. R. Riddell, will give an invitation concert in the Masonic Hall on "Wednesday, 16th Septem ber. They will have the assistance of Aliss Elsy Trcweek, ' Aliss Ruby Drew, Air. Jas. H. Davey, and as violinist, Aliss Louisa Groucher. AIiv Edward Reeves, an elocutionist of ability, will arrive in Alelbourne towards the latter end of Septembor, and will give a series of recitals.. Amongst his. perform ances will be Dickens's Cricket on the' Hearth," Ralph1 Connor's Sky Pilot , and Conan Doyle's Exploits of Brigadier Gerard, all of which will.be given without note. or. book. The season will be under the direc tion of Air. H. F. Smith. V ,

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The opening concert of the Clara Butt Company will be held at the Town Hall on Tuesday next. The demand for tickets is already abnormally large, and the
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The. opening concert of the Clara Butt Company will be held at the Town Hall on Tuesday next. The demand for tickets is . already abnormally large, and the suc cess of the season may be regarded as as sured. The programme has not been de-

finitely decided upon, but the great singer will probably choose the grand aria, Divinites du Styx, from Gluck's opera Al- ceste, for her opening number. Another item that is almost certain to be included in the first programme is Liddle's Abide With Me, which is considered Madame Butt's favorite song. This was first intro duced by her at a morning concert given by Madame Melba at Queen's Hall, London in June, 1897, the occasion being announced as that of the operatic diva's final appear- ance for the season. The new music was touchingly delivered by the contralto, and the success was instantaneous. The com position proved at once one of the most popular sacred pieces of the day, and bar ing already lasted a decade is not likely to fall easily out of the contralto repertoire. Mr. Ivennerley Rumford will sing three times, and Mr. Carl Barre and Mr. Frank Merrick will contribute two soW each The Besses o' th' Bam Band have' return ed to Melbourne, and on the afternoon and evening of Wednesday and the remain ing days of the week gave a series of eon- certs in the Exhibition Building, at 3 and 8 p.m. on each day. The band gave a similar concert in Adelaide last Saturday evening and over 10,000 people paid for admis- sion. The seventh and final concert of x the series of Marshall-Hall orchestral concerts will be given on Saturday afternoon at the Town Hall. The death has occurred, suddenly, of M. Edward Hagerup Grieg, the distinguished Norwegian composer and pianist, .who was in his 65th year. 1 he story which has been going the rounds about Liszt may be old, but at any rate it has the merit, seemingly, of not being — as are so many musical anecdotes — apocryphal, Felix FV'eingartner, who was one of Liszt's pupils, is responsible for circulating the story in question. "A pretty young lady," it runs, "'once played in class a ballade by Chopin in a very amateurish way. Liszt waiked up and down the room excitedly murmuring 'Heiliger Bimbam ! lleiiiger Bimbam !' fthe equivalent, apparently, of 'Great Scot !') We were all eagerly ex pecting the final verdict. But when she had finished he went up to her in a most friendly manner, laid his hand upon her head, as if in benediction, and said" gently: 'My dear child, marry soon. Good-bye.' " Strange rumors are afloat in Paris, which, if they come to anything, must alarm the stars of the operatic stage. A combination is rather vaguely talked of among managers all over the world to beat down swollen salaries. If an "opera trust" be formed, obviously, the half dozen stars who can now command pretty much wliaC prices they choose would be brought to terms, instead of dictating them. The new combination, presumably American to a large extent, is said to propose building an opera house in Paris, which would be a serious competitor for the national Opera. The latter can rarely afford the best sing ers, and could not hope to outbid the "trust," which thus would have the stars in its power. Some singers, however, could snap their fingers at it, like Caruso, whose American contract is said to assure him £40,000 a year for some years, a salary on which it seems possible to put by. Mr. Paderewski is fulfilling a few engage ments in Paris before coming to London. Ill the autumn Fir. Paderewski proceeds to America, where a tour has been ar ranged for him, in the course of which lie will appear at some seventy concerts and recitals. His new Symphony has; been com pleted, save for a few details in the orches tration, and may possibly be produced in Londoti next spring.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Last week must have been a record even for the Besses o' th' Barn Band, for during it they played to ten audiences, which in the aggregate must have numbered nearly
articleText:
MUSICAL.

...-Last 'week must have been a record even! for the Besses o' th' Barn Band, for during it ' they played to ten : audiences, which in- the aggregate must have numbered nearly

150,000 people, first in Adelaide and then at the Exhibition Building, Melbourne, when their eight popular priced concerts proved an immense success. Just at pre sent the Besses are touring Victoria, and next week, from the 18th to the 21st inst., they, will be in Sydney. Afterwards Tas mania and Western Australia will be visit ed for the final weeks of the Australian visit. , Slumber Tide is a new song, by W. F. G. Steele, a Melbourne, writer, which has had an extremely favorable "wntion from musical people. It is ofie of the finest con tralto songs issued for some time. It is rather, a : curious coincidence that Mr., Howard Carr and Mr. Andrew M'Cunn have once before been in the same position as they occupy , to-day— that is to say, the former relieved the latter of his duties in the chair with one of Mr. George Edwardes' companies in England. Mr. M'Cunn, who leaves in the Mongolia next Tuesday (17th September), has by this time "handed over" to Mr. Carr, who will take on The Dairymaids as "a going con cern." #

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Sullivan's cantata, The Golden Legend, was performed by the Philharmonic Society on Tuesday evening in the Town Hall. The principals included Miss Lilian
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Sullivan's cantata, The Golden Legend, was performed by tlie Philharmonic So ciety on Tuesday evening in the Town Hall. The principals included Miss Lilian Reid, Miss Elva Rogers, All". A. C. Bot toms and Mr. Jas. Hay, a new tenor, re-

cently arrived from Western Australia. Amongst the artists announced for Aus tralia next year is Miss Dorothy Maggs, a pianist who will anticipate the winter sea son by arriving here in March. Miss Maggs has been touring the Gape, and is at pre sent at Johannesburg. The Besses 0' th' Barn Band brought its tour, as far as Melbourne is concerned; to a very successful conclusion by the fiual concert on the Melbourne Cricket ground on Monday evening. There was an audi ence of between 20,000 and 30,000. The band has now started on a country tour, and will give concerts at Bendigo, Mary borough, Ballarat and Hamilton before leav ing for London. . The Clara Butt concerts in Sydney have

been an enormous success, lliere was an immense gathering at the town ball on Sat urday evening at the seventh concert. A Sydney contemporary states, as the result of an interview- with Mr. J. Nevin Tait, that the 15 concerts which have been given in Melbourne and Sydney by Ma dame Clara Butt and Mr. Kenncrlcy Rum- ford have been attended by a total of 45,000 persons. "It is understood," it is added, "that Madame Butt will take nearly £10,000 away with lier as the result of her Australian tour." ilr. Percy Coward's series of popular en tertainments at the Town llall on Saturday evenings are much appreciated. Sir. Percy Jones, the talented young band master of St. Augustine's Orphanage, left an orphan at eight years of age, was admitted to the institution in 1893, and at thirteen years of age lie had made sueh progress that he was not only solo cornet player in the band, but was also dux of the sebool and champion athlete of the orphan age. For a young man who has just reached his majority, Mr. Jones has a splen did record, lie leav es for Europe on 3rd December to continue his musical career. Miss Lalla Miranda has appeared in grand opera at Covent Garden Theatre, and achieved a striking success as Gilda, in Eigoletto. It is only a week since the fact was cabled that Miss Beatrice Miranda, the younger sister of Miss Lalla Miranda, had made a successful appearance at a bal lad concert in the Queen's Hall, London,

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The third of the Marshall Hall orchestral concerts was given on Saturday afternoon. The programme was one of special interest. No absolute novelty was included, though
articleText:
MU8ICAL

The third of the Marshall Hall orchestral concerts was given on Saturday afternoon. The programme was one of special interest. No absolute novelty was. included, though Schumann's Genoveva overture has not been heard in Melbourne since the days

of F. H. Cowen and the Centennial Ex hibition; while the other three items have figured rarely on previous programmes. The lovely theme which opens the an dante in the Brahms symphony, and its subsequent intricate, yet always perspicu ously clear, treatment make this move ment a favorite everywhere, and the suc ceeding poeo allegretto — wherein the horn solo was finely played by Mr. Kuhr— is a noble strain of glorious music. Other num bers were Handel's Concerto Grosso in G, and an excerpt from Die Meistersinger. The next concert will be on Saturday, 15th May. Kubelik, the famous violinist, who is to give his first Melbourne concert at the end of May, is an artist who has met with a plethora of success. Nearly everywhere he has been in Europe he has been com manded to appear at court, and his decora tions are numerous and costly. One of the most interesting of them all is the cross of the Order of St. Gregory, bestowed upon him by the Tate Pope after the Holy Father had talked long and affectionately with him. The decoration carries the right to wear a gorgeous robe of scarlet velvet heav ily embroidered with gold. Mr. Richard Aldrich, musical critic of the "New York Times" of 10th November last, attempts a description of the .magic bow of Jan Kubelik, the world-famed violinist, who is to appear in Sydney next month. He writes:— "Mr. Kubelik's artistry is of the most remarkable kind. There is something aloof in him as he plays; yet few have the power of so ravishing the senses with the sheer beauty of his tone, the charm of his cantilena, the elegance and ease with which he masters nil the technical difficulties of what he is playing, that they no longer suggest themselves as difficulties. Octaves, thirds and . sixths drop from his instrument in a tone of honeyed sweetness and oily smoothness; not a large tone, hut once of indescribable roundness and purity, bis runs and passages of all sorts are as pearls from bis hands. There is something of feminine grace and charm in Mr. Kubelik's playing, but in its way it is wholly delightful." Mr. Charles Saunders, a tenor of repu tation, is renewing his acquaintance with Australians, and will appear at the Town Hall next Tuesday. The performance will take the shape of stories of celebrated sing- era, interspersed with gems from tlielr repertoires. The tenor songs will be given by Mr. Saunders,/ the contralto ones by Miss Clara Robson.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The concerts arranged by Messrs. J. and N. Tait for Mr. Max Schluter, the famous Danish violinist, will take place at the Town Hall on
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The concerts arranged by Messrs. J. and X. Tait for Mr. Max Schluter, the famous Danish violinist, will take place at the Town Hall on Satur day next; Wednesday, 15tli, and Satur day, 21st. Miss Gladys Kingsley (soprano) and Mr. Harold S. Elvins (pianist) are associated with him. Mr. John Lennnone, Madame Melba s

Australian manager, states that Madame Melba will return to Australia in March of next year to make the comprehensive tour of the Commonwealth, she could not on her present visit entertain doing. On her way to England she will, ill pursuance of her Australian grand opera project, make a call at Maples to lay the foundation of this enterprise, which, it may be re membered, includes the servicea of the ex perienced conductor of the San Carlo Opera Company. Signor Caruso is contem plated as the principal tenor, but this will depend largely upon the time and place the famous singer decides upon for. this prolonged holiday. The Marshall-Hall orchestral concerts have taken a new departure, as arrange ments have, now been completed for giving them in the evening. The difficulty hither to- has been in securing the services of the professional musician, who is likely to be. otherwise engaged. The experiment on Monday evening augurs well, though when contrasted with the - performances of the last three or four seasons there was a coarseness, or lack of refine ment, 'that left something to be desired. Schubert's symphony, great in every sense of the word, gained rather than lost by the, omission of the repeats marked in the score. Of the other purely, orchestral works Mr.v Marsliall-Hall succeeded, in giving highly ' creditable performances. Both tlie 'bveftures-TBeethoven's Coriolan and Weber's Der FreiselmtzH-were capably and intelligently played. Miss Mona M'Burney's ' Fantasia for Piano and Orchestra, " entitled A' Northern Ballad, is a remarkably fine piece of musicianly writing. It is well conceived, and the workmanship is clever and effective. Played by Miss Una Bourne, and conducted by the gifted composer, this Northern Ballad proved a distinct "hit,' and well merited tlie applause, which followed its conclusion. The second concert is announced foi Mon day c veiling, the 30th inst. A meeting, composed almost entirely of ladies, was held on Monday at the \ ienna Cufe for the purpose of eliciting, support for Mr. .Frederick Beard in the carrying oat of a series of four orchestral concerts in tha Melbourne Town Hall, the first to be held on lltli April. Mr. Beard said that terrific opposition had been brought to bear against him in the present undertaking by the man agement of another musical organisa tion in Melbourne. He did not wish to bo personal. He was broad-minded enough to be able to appreciate the g od work accomplished by Mr. Marshall-Hall. But people grew tired of hearing the same .readings time after time of the great musi cal masterpieces under the sime conductor- ship. One organisation should spur on the other, and improved results would ensue. The concerts were proposed solely in the interests of and for the advancement of musical art locally. It was improbable that they would prove a success financially, as the" total expense for the series would be .6800, which would demand large audiences to obviate a deficit. The Marsliall-llall orehest'ia had been reconstituted, with the result that theatre musicians had been ex cluded from it, and it was partly with a view of retaining the services . of tlics: musician.-. — comprising some of the best artists in .Melbourne— in the rendition of high class works that the orchestral con certs were to he held. Those present formed themselves into a committee to pro mote the success of the concerts. ...

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The last concert of the Clara Butt series on 10th April aroused great enthusiasm, as it was in the nature of a farewell. Mr.
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The last concert of the Clara Butt < series on. 10th April aroused great enthusiasm, as it was in the nature of a farewell. Mr. -Kenner- ley Rumford was absolutely at his best in his opening "bracket" — one song by Schu mann and two bv Brahms: Die Mai Nacht

he sang with delicious self restraint, and So Willst du cles Armen without any re straint at all. In charming contrast to the "abandon" of this latter we had by way of encore Massenet's Ouvre tes Yeux Bleus sung with exquisite delicacy and re: finement. Three songs by Maude Valerie White were all nicely and expressively given. Mr. Rumford added -as -an encore Alfred Hill's Maori Poi Dance, but this spirited and characteristic ditty served merely to add fuel to flames high; and he was not let off till he had added yet an other, which took shape as a Little Red Fox— Arthur Somervell's transcription of an old Irish melody. Madame Clara Butt commenced with Gounod's 0, Divine Re deemer, which' she sang in the original French. In such music Madame Butt fairly revels, and her glori ous voice has rarely been heard to more convincing effect than in this item. The ensuing encore, Donizetti's II Segreto, bright and brilliant though it be, sounded almost tawdry by comparison. In the second part of her programme she brought forward four novelties. Sir Ed ward Elgar's Come, Gentle Night, is a pleasing setting of pleasantly conceived words, though they hardly seem to re quire the aid of an organ to make their purport clear. Teresa del Ricgo's Three Little People is hardly more than a drawingroom ballad of the better sort. My Dear Zoul— carefully translated in parallel columns into My Dear Soul (and so throughout, with "Zingen" replaced by "singing," &c.)— seems to owe its origin to "Zummerzetshire"; but it is a decidedly taking little effusion, and the author of its being, Wilfrid Sanderson, is to be compli mented 011 making many good bricks with a rather poor supply of straw. Mrs. Peter son's Good Night is a charming and quite unpretentious piece of work. Elgar's Land of Hope and Glory was grandly delivered by Madame Butt. Another encore, Trevalsa's My Treasure, delightfully sung, resulted. Mr. and Mrs. Rumford finally sang Liza Lehmann's duet, Snow drops, following up tlieiv success, as usual, with the lveys of Heaven. Mr. Barre was in excellent form in a Berceuse by Arensky and a Bohemian Dance by Randegger. Mr. Merrick may be cordially complimented on his perform ance of Chopin's C minor Etude. The two performers joined forces with admirable ef fect in Scbybert's duet — the allegro from duo in A. Madame Clara Butt was accorded a public welcome at Albury by the mayor, on behalf of the townspeople, on her arrival on Sun day night. On Monday she gave a concert at the Mechanics' Theatre, to an excellent house. On Wednesday evening Madame Clara Butt and Mr. lvennerley Rumford appeared in Elijah with the Mel bourne Philharmonic Society, the other principals being Miss Eileen O'Brien, sop-, rnno, and Mr. , James Wade, tenor. On Good Friday evening The Messiah will be given, the soprano being Miss Lilian Read ,'iud the tenor Mr. Gregor Wood Before

leaving for England Madame Butt and Mr. Rumford will give a charity .matinee. The first of the orchestral concerts or ganised by. Mr. Frederic Beard was given in the Town Hall on Saturday afternoon. There was an attendance above expectation, and at least it can be claimed that aii en couraging start was made. Mr. Beard has shown that he can secure the cooperation of a capable orchestra close on one hundred strong, and that he can utilise this powerful phalanx with ' great advantage. His beat is nervous, but incisive; his indica tions are clearly and crisply given. Proceedings opened with ' Dvorak's Carne- val overture, a work for the most part bril liant in its Sclavonic rhythms and the lavish use of a color scheme almost bar baric in its intensity. Two short episodes, widely contrasted in char acter, bring us to the second subject proper, which is "a beautiful " and extended melody allotted to the violins. The development section strikes one on a first hearing as rather disappointing; it seems disjointed, and sounds dull, as though the composer had lost the thread of his discourse. The overture concludes as brilliantly as it began, and, if possible, in even a bigger volume of sound. The performance' may be spoken of in high terms. It "caught on" with the audi ence, who compelled Mr. Beard to bow his acknowledgments twice or thrice at its con clusion. Tschaikowsky's fifth symphony has been. heard here at least once previously. Though hot rival ling in popularity his later work,' known as The Pathetic, the symphony in E minor combines the rugged force of his Russian character with the broad, sweep ing melody of which he. was such a master. The Tannhauser overture merited the very warmest of praise, the "grand climacteric" being admirably worked"" up. Next in order came iferr Hattenbach's performanice. of Wagner's Traeume— a sketch for love music to be used in Tristan. This is a delight ful little inspiration, into whose spirit the solo cellist fully entered. Liszt's Rhapsody No. 2, brilliantly scored for orchestra by Matthey, brought the concert to a close. Mr. Charles Saunders, the well known tenor, who visited Australia some years ago, will commence his new tour at the Town Hall on 5th May. The United Ancient Order of Druids are not "holding their annual gala on Easter Monday, but are concentrating their efforts to make their annual sacred concert at the Exhibition Building on: Good Friday night a success. They have specialy imported, through Messrs. Gunn and Sons, a film 3000 feet long, showing the most striking inci dents in the life and death of Christ. This will be shown, accompanied by appropriate music on the . Exhibition organ. In addi tion there will be sacred songs, a recitation by Miss Jennie Lee and an organ recital by Mr. Chas. Sykes. The proceeds will go to the grand lodge benevolent fund. The Merrymakers Company now en route from London is not a concert party in the ordinary sense of the word. The enter tainment is on distinctly novel lines, in which music is a feature, but the comnanv dress in quite original costume, and give sketches of a humorous character. The programmes have been prepared under the personal supervision of Mr. G. P. Huntley, the famous comedian. A good start was made with the City Concerts, to be held weekly in the Town Hall during the winter months. An ex cellent programme was given at a charge exceptionally moderate. In the sacred concert to be given on Good Friday night at the Theatre Royal, Madame Blanche Arral will appear as the principal performer. An interesting letter has been received by an Australian friend from Madame Ada Crossley, who visited Paris last January and saw Sarah Bernhardt in La Belle, au Bois Dormant— a poetic version of The Sleeping Beauty. It was a wonderful per formance, and the great tragedienne, says Madame Crossley, looked Prince Charming to perfection, while her voice was "golden- er" than ever. The love scenes were beau tifully played, and the whole production most artistic." The play will most likelv be included in the repertoire which Madame Bernhardt will bring to Australia with her when she fulfils her engagement to J. C. Williamson next vear. . Mr. J. C. Williamson is completing ar rangements for a tour of Australia by a concert party headed by Miss Ada Cross- ley, the famous Victorian contralto. The party will include Mr. Percy Grainger, the Victorian pianist; Mr. John Harrison (tenor), Mr. Hamilton Earie (baritone) and other well-known artists. The company will sail for Australia on 7th August.

title.value: The People's Advocate and New South Wales Vindicator (Sydney, NSW : 1848-1856)

snippet: The lovers of music in Sydney need not fear a lack of musical entertainments for some time to come. The furor which is daily being increased by the wonderful performance of Miska Hauser, will hardly have time to subside when we will be favoured with
articleText:
MUSICAL.

W The lovers of musio in Sydney need not fear a lack of musical entertainments for some time to come. The furor wh oh is daily being increased by the wonderfui performance of Miska Hauser, will hardly have time to subside when we will be favoured with

the presence of a Turkish gentleman, calling himself 44 Ali-Ben-Sou- Alle," whose performances in his national costume in the neighbor ing colonies, has oreated a great senaation. We subjoin the following letter we have reoeived from this gentleman. To the Editor of the People's Advocate. Sir,-— Having ju>3t returned from a short tour in Tasmania, I purpose next visiting your flourishing town prior to my departure ior Europe. My intention is to leave Melbourne by the next steamer, so that I shall probably be in Sydney in about 10 or 12 days. Might I .ask the favour bf your announcing the same in " your columns. " I expect , to give three, concerts, either with or without full orchestra, aonording to ibe facilities offered. In the former oase I should endeavour to produce in my three ooncerts the majority of my compositions for grand orchestra, which met with such signal eucoess in Melbourne. I send you a programme and a few reports, and have the honor to remain; Sir, Yours respectfully,

Geelong, 17th Nov., 1854.

ALl-BEN-SOU-ALLE.

. The following notice of bis performances which we extract from the Hob AR.ro wn Mercury of the 4th November, will give o\ir readers some idea of the praises lavished on this gentleman by our " contemporaries in the neighbouring colonies. ALI-BEN-SO U-ALLE . Seldom have so many opportunities presented themselves within the 6ame limited period, to the music loving portion of our community for an indul gence in their favourite relaxation as occurs at the present time, when not only musical entertainments are unusually frequent, but also especially pre eminent in character. We recently had occasion to speak in terms of com mendation respecting the concert at Government House, and again it devolves upon us to eulogise in no very measured terms the performance that has, en two evenings during the present week, been greeted with the acclamations of audiences such as have rarely been equalled iu the Hall of the Mechanics' Institute. The introduction of any new instrument is usually accompanied with so many' laudatory recommendations both as regards its own powers and those too of the performer, that disappointment frequently succeeds an exalted expectation. Ali-Ben-Sou-Alle refrained from such preliminary laudations, and truly he did not need them, either on behalf of himself or either of his instruments. The Fantasia on Somnambula on the first evening sufficed to convince the audiahce that a treat of no ordinary description was in store, nor could the most sanguine expectations have been other than fully gratified. In the brief notice to which we must necessarily confine ourselves, it were impossible sufficiently to describe the varied powers, both in tone and Compass, exhibited on the Turkophorie; an instrument combining the fulness of the Ophicleide, and much of the tone and power of the Cornopean, with the flowing softness of the Flute. Ali-Ben-Sou-AUe is a perfect master of the instrument in all its capabilities ; but this is saying little : he is evidently a performer of high musical ability, and possessed of a degree of talent such as is seldom exhibited betore a Colonial or even as European auditory. His execution of " The lost Rose of Summer" (with variations) amply justifies this expression of our opinion, as too, the imitation of the Scotch Bagpipe. This is a favorite piece of exhibition among many instrumental performers, and we have heard it admirably performed both on the violin and some wind instruments in England, but seldom, we think we may say never, with so much perfection as by our Turkish visitor on Tuesday evening last- In a series. of pieces, each of which was given with all the care and taste for effective display, which characterises the perfect musician, it were not expedient to attempt a selection of any with a view to place its merits pre eminently forward; generally this universal perfection is not found to obtain, but in the case of Ali-Ben-Sou-Alle, an exception, and that of a most marked kind, must certainly be acknowledged; his skill In execution upon each of the four instruments he introduced is of the most accomplished grade ; his power of perception and the spirit infused into every piece were equally signal; in short, Ali-Ben-Sou-AUe may with justice claim a place among the ablest musicians of the present day, not only as a performer, but also as possessing a deep theoretical knowledge of the art together with a facility for the just appreciation of an author. As we premised, the Second Concert on Thursday evening proved equally as attractive as its predecessor. Ali-Ben-Sou-AIle perfectly electrifying his auditory by the immensity of his execution upon the several instruments he has so perfect a command of. Mr. Buddee's solo from Norma was brilliantly executed, and called forth an unanimons encore. Mrs. Dawson sang several pieces in her usual style. We trust that Ali-Ben-Sou-AUe will not depart without affording the. inhabitants another oppoitunity of listening to his delightful and extraordinary performance. . —
