articleText:
NIwkju

NEW YORK: Broadway director Harold Prince is working on a musical based on the lynching of a southern Jew in the early part of the century. Parade, based on the case of Leo Frank, a pencil factory manager in Atlanta, Georgia^ who was killed while he was a suspect in the murder of a Christian girl, is to open next month in Toronto.

heading: Musical.
snippet: PAGANINI.—In a biographical account of Paganini, lately published, the following amusing anecdote is related of him. This great artist was once travelling in
articleText:
j*iu0(cal, -o PAGANINI.-In a biographical account of Paganini, lately published, the follow ing amusing anecdote is related of him. This great artist was once travelling in Germany; and had just arrived without the gates of Frankfort, where he alighted, and went privately into a retired inn out side the city. After having taken his usual modest repast, absorbed in reverie, hie mounted to the little garret pointed out to him by his host. The night was far advanced and remarkably fine; Pa. ganini placed himself at the window, con teomplating the brilliant heavens through the mist of his own dreamy imaginations. It struck one; and instantly the recolloc tion occurred to his mind of an occur rence of which he had lately boon an ear. witness. He seized his violin, and en deavoured to pourtray sounds that still rang in his ears. The moans and cries of a mother, and her now born infant, were represented to the life by his wonderful and over varying bow. But the host was awakened, and precipitately arose, won during by what means such visitors could have entered the house, without his knowledge. Awakening his son, they hastened together into the room from whence the plaintive sounds proceeded. What was their astonishment to behold a man apparently lost in thought, not even observing their entrance, making his violin utter, as it were, human sounds in the brightest-starlight. On some occa sions, during an access of fever, or any other extraordinary excitement, Paga nini has produced on his instrument the different cries of animals in the most per foot manner. VALENTINO FIORAVANT'I.-This dis tinguished musician of the old Italian School, but who may be considered to have contributed in some degree to the formation of the modern style, was born at Rome, in the year 1764. His father, an intelligent merchant, having noticed in his son traces of future genius, sought to encourage their development by giving him the advantages of a good edu cation, and as Valentino displayed a pe culiar talent for music, he procured him the instructions of Jannacconi, who was then looked upon as the greatest master of counterpoint in Italy. ''The rapid pro. gross of the boy now determined his father to send him to the Conservatorio at Naples, at that time regarded as the chosen seat of music of the highest class, as dranatic music was then considered, and the residence of the greatest masters

of the art-Paesiollo, Cimarosa, Gugit olmi, &e. Fioravanti speedily showed himself to be a worthy rival of these great men, and beinggifted with a lively wit, ano intelligent spirit, and true fooling, he doe dicated his talents more particularly to the production of comic operas, and con tributed in no small degree to correct the taste for this species of composition. He commenced his career as a dramatic com poser at Turin, where his Opera-" II furlio contra il furbo" was first performed at the Theatre Royal,.in the year 1797. It was immediately followed by " It fabro Parigino." Both works were dis. tinguished by a natural genius, brilli ancy, vivacity, and agreeable style, and obtained for their writer not only a far spread reputation, but invitations to com. pose now operas from almost every theatre in Italy. But though he had the power of composing with great readiness, he did not avail himself of it, preferring to do. vote so much time to each work as would ensure its adding to the reputation he had already acquired. In 1802 he produced his " Capricciosa sentita," which re mained for so long a period the favorite of the Milanese. Fioravanti being appointed dit.tur ofr tl1e Itallttl Opera at Lisbon, loft, but not without considerable regret, his new adopted country, Naples, where his sovereign, Ferdinand the Fifth, had honored him with many marks of his favor. In Portugal, he wrote " La Ca milla," which, although now forgotten, was much admired on its first appearance. On his return, however, in 1807, he was received with the greatest attention both in Spain and France. In Paris they produced his " Virtuosi ambulaynti," which afforded no less delight than his " Biaggiatori ridicoli," or the " Ca. pricciosa," which had been performed there two years previously, and like his " Cantatrici villane," established the writer's reputation throughout Europe. On his return to Naples, he produced upon the stage his Opera-" I raggiri ciarlataneschi," the beauties of which even his enemies were forced to admit in the face of the cabal which they had raised against it. After a long pause, occasioned by a serious illness under which he had been labouring, he pro duced his " Raoul de Crequi," and " Gli amori di Comingio e d'Adelaide ;" and when requested by Napoleon to visit Paris and superintend the Chapel of the Imperial Palace, true to the principles he had adopted, he declined theinvitation. In the year 1816, the Pope appointed him Maestro di Capella at St. Peters, upon which Fioravanti desisted for a long time from the composition of secular music; but at length, wearied out with the importunities which were incessantly addressed to him, he wrote for the Teatro Nuovo at Naples his last dramatic work " It ciabattino." From this time he de voted himself entirely to the production of music for the Church, and the nunt bhors of masses, offertories, &o., which he produced is very great -all of them giving evidence of great genius, and affording when performed the greatest delight to all who hear them. A ' miserero' for three voices, composed by him for three Ro man princesses, has long been celebrated. Full of years, and weakened by attacks of apoplexy, he long lay weak and decay ing before he could make up his mind to yield to his own wishes and those of his children, that he.should return to Naples and there end his days. At length, in spired by the hope that the salutary air of that city might give him new life and strength, he set forth on his journey full of spirits and expectation of seeing once more his adopted country. But this was not to be. He sunk under the exertions of his journey, and died on the 10th of June last, at Capua, where his mortal remains were buried in the cathedral, with all the honors due to so great an artist.

articleText: Musical.l Mr. J. A, Steele, Mus. Bac., will be out of town, conducting examinations in music on behalf of the University, from lzth to the 24Lh inst. Ms. Steele has been appointed examinet Ior the Bendigo and Castlemaine districts, and also for Gippsland and portion of the North-Eastern d strict. heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Miss Alice Sydney Bur vett, the celebrated Australian pianiste, will give a musical recital to night in the Oddfellows' Hall, and will perform
articleText:
MUSICAL.--Miss Alice Sydno~ vett,the celebrated Australian pianiste, will give a musical recital to night in the Oddfellows' Hall, and will perform ao programme of twenty five items culled from the greatest composers' works, ancient and modern. Miss Bur vett has travelled through England, France, Belgium, &c. A most enjoyable evening is assured to all those who at. tend. It may be added that Miss Bur. vett is sister to the well known (detec tive of that name.

DEPARTURE OF VOLUNTEERS - On Friday morning another contingent of our local naval forces entrained for Melbourne for active service. The first contingent comprised youths from the Naval. Cadets, who were compulsorily called. The second batch was drawn from the Naval Reserve, all fine,herdy young men who were volunteering for service abroad. Their departure was the occasion of a patriotic demonstra tion on the part of the large crowd that gathered at the railway station. The newly formed band played national airs, and a number of persons carried the national colors. The RIev. Tait, M.A., gave a stirring address. Speak ing to the volunteers he said they had responded to the call for the defence of the Empire in this her hour of trial, and all were proud of, them, and felt sure they would uphold the best traditions of the British race.- It was not everyone who was able to go, and so those who remained looked upon those who did go as their riepresentas tives, and would accordingly follow their campaign with the deepest inter et... He would like them to remember they were kin to the heroes of Trafal gar, the Nile and Waterloo, and. tlhht they not only represented Australia, but Portland as well. Finally, in the words of the old book, lie asked them to "Fear God and lionoer the King." The National Anthem was sun', and cheers were given ;for the Empire amid Our Allies, with a' parting one for Our Iloys. Following are ths nanmes ,f the volunteers:-W. Allen, J. Bailey, L. Glare, T. Bush, S. Bush, C. Keiller; O. Teague, E Frost, C. E. Patterson, C. Patterson, V Pithousc, N. Beglcn, G Jarrett, R.Monckton. It is stated   that several of the first contirngent have since volunteered for service abroad. IVAut NE:ws.- -When war broke onut we followed thie old custom of issuing "extraordinaries" gratis, and would probably have continued to do so within reasonablel limits, but the public do niand for news was so gr'eat that it was soon realised by the more thoughtful that the cost of meeting that demand without some remuneration was more tlhan the press shouhl be expected to bear. JIn most other towns the news. piaper's make ia clhaure for their war bulletins, but we had somue dillidence in adopting that tourse, andl when thie Mayor (Cr. Williamson) suggested that: to ensure a colltiillunce of free tele gramns he would see that we were reilnm bursed to some extent we readily ugreed. The result was that the Mayor, whose efforts were supplemented by Mr. Burnett, collected-and it may said that refusals were few-the sum of £8 3/6/, of .which we have received . a cheque for £l4/1/9. .We greatly ap preciate the Mayor's thoughtfulness, not only on our account but also that of the general public, and hope that this somewhat unique arrangement will worlk satisfactorily. IMIIFIIAN.CE.-A conference of re presentutives of the local churches and tenperance societies was held in the TIempriance Hall on Friday evening. The meeting included representativ\es of the PFeshyterian, Anglican, Metho dist and Baritit churclhes, the Sons of Temperance, Rechabites and Womnen's Christian Temperance Union. IMr. B. )uavis wis voted to the chair, and Mr. Alan Long was nppointed- secretary. nMr. Alan Long, on behalf of the So s of Temperance, who lhad convened the meeting, said it was thought desirable, in view of the prospect of complete local option coining into operation inl 1917 to take early steps in the diree tion of educating public opini. n on the temperance question. It was also neces saryi to exercise vigilance to see tlhat the promise made by the Government that the people should have complete' local option ins . ll7 '. was carried out. Hints had been throwni out.thiitthis promised measure of adtlvanced temnper amce reform would. be 'witldr'awvi, and in place tltremo'f thle present Licences Reduction Board continued. IHis so ciety had no definite proposals to sub mnit to the meeting, hoping .that by discussion something practical might be volved that would, comnnend itself to all the bodies represented. The Rev. H. Boulter suggested thatl the first step slohultl be the formation of a No Licence League, but before that could be definitely decided upon it would be necessary for the delegates to get the apprbval 'dEf their respective societies. Rev. WV.. Tait and Messrs. W. Jlarrett, I. HRa; Taylor and Westlake spoke, and ultimately the suggestion was adopted. The (lute of the next meeting will be announced by the secretary, who in tlhe meantime will obtain infor mation foromu the Victorian Alliance concerniug the formation and functions of such a league.

FATAL ACCIDENT -- sad fatality occurred at the Loreto Convent, Port land, on Thursday evening. Tihe Con vent is lighted with air gas, in the manufaicture of which a tall tower suse pending a heavy weight forms part of the plant. This weight has to be wound up at regular periods. The winding gear is enclosed in a small room, and the space at the base of the tower be low the dependent weight is shut off with barbed wire. One of the Sisters was turning the winding gear, when the wire broke and the weight fell. The Sister, on running out to see what had happened, was horrified to find tirat the weight had fallen on a little boy, named Kelven Pitt, aged two years and three months. Des. Sleeman and Campbell, who were immediately sent for, found that the child was badly in jurred, one leg being broken and his head badly bruised. The little sufferer died of shock a few hours later. The Sisters naturally are greatly shocked by the sad occtrrence. It would appear that the child, unknown to her, fol. lowed the Sister to the gas tower and while she was in tlhe room where the winding gear is placed the child eras led under thie barbed wire barrier, and un fortunately happened to be underneath the weight when it fell. The child was niever known to go there before, and it is the first time that the weight has fallen. The childl was living at the .Convrent, his parents having gone to ELrop The mnatter was reported to tihe police and the Deputy Coroner, Mr. A. Donald, who held a rnrgisterial inquiry. Evidence was given by one of the Sisters showing how theaccidernt occurred, ras stated above. Dr. Sleernrrr described the nature of the child's in .uries. Constable O'Donnell deposed to having made an examination of the place where the accident occurred, and said the child haid evidently crawled undertlthe wire, which was about a foot from the ground. The Deputy Coroner returned ai verdict of accidental death, and that no blame attached to any !ierson. articleText:
Musical.

Everybody knows how keen was tho de votion to -music of tho Rev H. R. Hawola, who recently dlod. 'Yoars ago,' writes a lady In a London paper, 'I was sitting lis tening to an oratorio, when I felt a hand suddenly clutch my arm in a grip that ab solutely hurt inc. It startled me for tho moment. I looked at my neighbor, and saw

a tiny man with a vast head of hair, lost in an absoluto delirium of pleasure. His eyes sparkled, nnd the u'liolo attenuated ''body quivered with excltemont. Two or threo times again1 during tho performance ho clutched my arm, absolutely uncon scious ot 'what ho was doing. I realised what was tho slate of the case, and boro it as best I could. It was long afterwards that I recognised the musical fanatic, whon I saw him In a pulpit. It was Jlr. Hawois.' Madamo Albanl has discovered a new

MADAME ALDAXI.

young Canadian singer in tho porson of Jliss Eileen Mlllctt. Her voice Is said to bo a pure soprano of s y m p a t hotlc quality, with a from A bolow tho stave to D flat above, and her repertory is already very ex tensive. Miss Mlllett is going to England to complete her training, and will afterwards be introduced to a London audi

ence, under tho patronage of her country woman/Madamc Alboni. - - ? ? - * - Madamo Adellna Pattl's life earnings are estimated at considerably over a million pounds sterling; and tho Jewels now in her possession are said to bo worth over £160,000. The voteran baritone, Mr. Charles Sant ley, is now the leading conductor of the or chestra at 'tho Pro-Cathedral, Kensington. Ho has composed several new works for the services. ? - ? ? ? ? Jlrs. Howie (Te-rangi-pal), tho Anglo Maori contralto introduced to Australian audiences last year by Mr. R. S. Smythe, sailed from Melbourne with her husband lor London by tbo Runic on Friday. Mr. Smytbc believes that Mrs. Howie's JIaori descent and rich voice will excite special interest in London musical circles, and that she may divide Vie honors of tho con cert platform with the popular .Eurasian mezzo-soprano, JIlss Alice Gomez, a native of Calcutta. Mrs.. Howie has three bro thers at the frtont in South Africa, and her father, Colonel Porter, goes in command of tho seventh New Zealand contingent.

Sho wjis offered an eoEagement in Ostend for the Summer, which, unfortunately, M1S3 M'Kay cannot accept, as she returns this month to Australia for 'lihe purpose of giving a series of concerts in the principal towns. Another young Australian, Miss May Beat tie, from North Queensland, has received a freo scholarship at tho Comservatorlum, enabling her 'to study for another year free. Miss Josephine Stan ton, who shortly vlBl'ts Australia, is 'thus referred to In a 'Frisco paper to hand by tho latest mail ?: — 'Tho latest operatic venturo is one out of the ordinary. Josephine Stanton, the young Canadian prima-donna, late of the Boston Lyric Opora Company, is being sur rounded by a carefully selected company of singers, and will make a tour that Is away ahead of any that has been conceived ? In years. The trip will include Honolulu, Yokohama, Kobe, Nagasaki, Tokio, Vladl vostock (Siberia), Shanghai, Hongkong, Manila, Australia; India, South Africa, and London. Miss Stanton's career has been a not&blo one for one so young. In the United States and Canada sho is held in high regard, and loved by all who have heard her in different operatic roles. Sho sings in a clear, firm voice, and has a per sonality that stamps all her work as ar tistic.' ??? ? ? ? ? Mr. J. G. Kelly, ot Forest Lodge, writing to tho 'Sunday Times,' in reference to a recent paragraph, In which it was asked by a . correspondent if Jldme. Anna Bishop ever sang at tho Mol ? bourne Opera Houso, says: 'Jldme. Bishop sang at the Melbourne Opera Houso during a concert tour which sho was making through tho colonicsiin the year 1875. Tho lato Jlr. W. Saurlh Lyster engaged her for a short season of two weeks, in which sho produced 'La Somnambula,' 'Lucia,' and, if I romembcr rightly, 'Norma.' Mr. Charlos Lasccllcs Was a member ot her company, and played the part of Alcssio In 'La Som nambula.' He remained in Melbourne when the company doparted, and was afterwards chorus master for Mr. Lyster for some con siderable time. I speak with some know ledge ot the subject, as I was tor some years, both before and aftor, a member of Mr. Lystcr's companies.' ? ? t ? .

articleText:

Mr. Louis Luscombe is touring in 13jo provinces with a musical comedy company. Giuseppe Vordi, the veteran Italian com poser, Is reported 'by cable to bo dying. Great regret will 'be felt in musical circto -it thl?? nnws. Verdi, who wna bnrn In

1SU, in the Duchy of Parma, produced his flrst great, work in 1830. 'II Rlgoletto,' 'II Trovatore,' and 'La Traviata,' com posed between 1851 and 1853, wore all ex ceedingly popular. Subsequently Ijo ctxm pl-ately changed his style, taking tho world 'by storm with his opera ,'A1da,' produced at Suez in 1871 to commemorate the open ing of tho Suez Canal. 'Otello' and 'Fal- staff,' produced In 1889 and 1893 respec tively, were h.if}hly appreciated.

Sir Mlchaol Costa has tho following re marks on singing:— 'The qualities with which a merely correct slngor ought to bo endowed arc: A just intonation, a voice of good quality, a scrupulous precision In the time prescribed by the music, an exact knowlcdgo of all word sounds, and a sym motric and agreeable form of movement. An accomplished .vocalist, besides possess ing tho foregoing qualities in 'a prepondera ting degree, ought to bo ablo to lay claim to an original and elevated stylo of sing ing, joined to a natural vivacity of expres sion. Then comes tho lost and greatest requisite — genius !' Miss Maggie Stirling sang with marked success at a Matinee Muslcale given on De cember 15 at Madame Marchcsl's Ecolo (Paris) in honor of M. Massenet, who was present, an air from that composer's 'Lo Cld.' M. Massenet was so pleased with the singing that he subsequently presented to tho Australian vocalist his photograph, with his signature attached and the word 'admiration' inscribed on It. In November last Miss Stirling sang at 'Normanhurst' at a concert given by Lady Brassoy, who expressed her satisfaction at the marked vocal Improvement with kindly emphasis. ? ? ? ? Madamo Anna Steinhauer gave her second vocal recital last month at the Steinway Hall, London, the programme being entire ly composed of compositions by her hus band, Mr. Albert MalHnson, late of Mel bourne, who has been hailed by tho entire London Press as a song-writer of quite re markable talents. ' Madame Steinhauer was assisted by Miss Regina Nagel, of Mel- bourne, who was much applauded for her second set of songs. Mr. Percy Grainger, the young Melbourne pianist and composer, who has been study ing on the Continent for some years past, gave a recital at Frankfurt recently, when he was most successful. Tho four leading journals were unanimous In their praise of his ringing touch, perfect technique, and splendid musical gifts. Mr. Grainger; ac cording to tho latest 'British-Australa- sian,' will shortly appear in London. At the Queen's Hall (London) Ballad Concert on December 15 there were intro duced several new songs, among them one of interest, 'A. Garden Song,' from the pen of Mr. Charles Willeby, who a few years aso was wall known in Australia, and whose wife is a sister of Mr. Fergus Hume. ? It is a composition, says an ex change, showing originality of conception and breadth of treatment, arid on the occa sion in, question was fortunate in having Miss Ada Crosslcy as the Interpreter of its finely-colored and most interesting melody.' ? ? m m nclba In America. The Now York opera season, -which la always regarded as one of tho principal social events of the year, opened at the Metropolitan Opera Houso on December 18, amid scenes of unusual splendor..,. Says an exchange, referring to the event:— 'So- ciety was present in full force, and every seat in the great auditorium was taken. The tiers of boxes wore filled with repre sentatives of wealth and fashion. The women, resplendent in superb costume3 and dazzling jewels, presented a magnificent sight. Present indications are that the season will be one of the most successful on record. Mr. Maurice Grau has brought over an. unusually strong company, intro ducing established favorites of former, sea sons and several new candidates for local honors. The opera presented last night was Gounod's 'Romeo et Juliette,' in which Mme. Melba and Messrs. Saleza, Edouard do Reszke, and. Plancon filled the leading role3. It was splendidly rendered and en thusiastically received.'

articleText:
i Musical.

Mdmc. Belle Cole gave her final concert In Melbourne on Saturday night. '..' Jean Gerardy gave his first recllo.1 in Ade laide on Saturday, night at the Town- Hall. 'According to a London paper, Mis3 Sylvia Yarra was very ' successful In her singing ol well-known Messiah solos, In a perfor mance given last month at the Town Hall, Clacton-on-Sea. ' ? ?

' Miss Ada Crossioy's flno ringing of Fran ces Allitsen's 'Sing Me to. Rest' .was one of the fentures of tno Ballad Concert at the Queen's Hall, London, last month. Mrs. Graco Millar Wara, the American soprano, made a big hit at tbo Town Hall 'Pop'- on Saturday night. ? ' ? / « ? 1 Mdme. Melfca has returned to London, after her successful tour In America. Since her arrival in tho great metropolis she has consented to sing In a fow performances at Coveat Garden Theatre, during tho opera_ season. ? » * ? ? ~-A choir master was wanted for a church thToe miles from Bristol, and an advertise ment duly appeared asking for applications. The salary offeroa as a beginning was vaguely announced as'small,' but the suc cessful candidate had the promise held out that for attending on 'Sundays, two week nights and festivals,' he might look to re ceive '£10 per annum after twelve- years' service.' One wonders if the churchwardens were not rushed with applications for a- post so lucrative ! ? « * « - A performance of 'Carmen' was given recently in tho arena at Nimes, In' the preV senee of 12,000 spectators. In tho last act of .the opera a real bull fight took place, in view of tho audience, a bull being killed. During tho absence In Melbourne of Mons. L. C'aron, musical director of Hor Majesty's Theatre, Sydney, who conducted .several items at the State concert there, his local position was occupied by Mr. R. Cane, the accomplished loader of tho orchestra, ana in acknowledgment of his valued services tho latter lias received a very handsome sllvor cigar case from Mons. Caron, with an' ac companying letter of appreciation for his work as acting conductor.

articleText:

?According to Saturday's Melbourne 'Age' Mr. George Musgrove's present season of grand opera at Mie Princess's closes on Saturday, May 11, and his ..company leave :tlhait evening by special train, at 11.59— the sanctity of the Sabbath Day being Ithereby, we must presume, safeguarded-^ ?for Svduev. whoro t'hnv nru-n fhp fnllowdnrr

An in terval of tlireo weeks will thus separate uao conclusion of the English opera season ait the Princess's and Die opening of the Italian season at Her Majesty's — not too long a breathing space for those who by ?duty or inclination (or a mixture of boUh motives) are impelled to be frequently In evidence when grand opera is on the bills. Oddly enough, It is in Edinburgh that the prima donna has met the most enthusiastic of her audiences. Ex tremes of latitude are, sho maintains, in habited by peoplo very similar in the matter of excitability, it being the dwellers

in temperate parts who are slowest to 'let themselves go.' American, English, and Australian audiences she has so far found much alike, all being equally re sponsive when touched, and all equally un willing to take anythlni: for Rianted. I

Madame Russell, Who Is accompanied by tier husband, the Count dl Rlgh'Inl, lives near HampsbKi'd Heath, In England, a comfortable and quiet. life. Sho has a dis tinct feeling after purely domestic plea sures, and i3 Inclined to think that' when a singer attempts to lead a society as well .13 an artistic life her talonts aro very apt to suffer. At the same time, she Is an essentially convivial person, being blessed with a charm ot manner that natu rally brings her frionrla. pianist' of her concert party. Findlng'Uiat the name of line pianoforte mak ers was not ?given on tlic programme, ' he demanded an extra 10 gui neas before going on . to play. Madame Shenwin sent to ithe box-office for the amount in the smallest coki3 possible, and emptied them' on to a table in front, of the excited pia nist, WhO3e in ability to count

10 guineas in coppers and smoJl' silver .'coins made him glad to get on with his work, a-nd leave the payment for a moro aus picious moment. M.IS3 Connie Usher, the young Sydney pianist, who bas been studying 5n Leipzig for tho past three years, expects to shortly make her debut in London. It is Miss Usher's intention to settle 'in Sydney later on. : . ' ? A London paper announces that Miss Louie Morrell, of Melbourne, who has been in- England tor some months past pursuing hor musicaJ studies, has .decided to return to Australia In July. Before leaving Lon don siae purposes giving another concert, and 'has. secured the -Stc'inwuy Hall for May 0, w'ieu she will have the assistance of Mi*. Charle3 Saunders and other artists.

The company .also bring wluh lliiem liwelvc orchestral instaunients, the costumes for all -the operas to be performed — these costumes being an exact fac-simile of thoao supplied to La Scola, Mi'lan— -and the sce nery and properities for 'all tho operas ex cept 'AMa.' heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: It is definitely stated that Melba will give two concerts before returning to Europe, the dates having been fixed for Saturday, 23rd, and Saturday, 30th
articleText:
MUSICAL.

\ It is definitely stated that Melba will $j.ye two concerts; .before returning to Europe, the dates having - been :fixed for Saturday; 23rd, and Saturday, 30th No vember. This -no doubt will be a most ac ceptable announcement to the public, and it may be remarked that- Melba- also views

tlie arrangement witli great satisfaction. She is only sorry that her holiday " visit to Australia precludes anything like a com prehensive tour. The concerts will be .con-' lined to two in Melbourne, two in Sydney, with- perhaps one in Brisbane. The plans will be opened at- Allan's on Saturday, 16tb inst. Seats may be . reserved at 21/ and 10/6. The names of the artists to support the great singer will be announced in a day or two. Messrs. John Lemmoqe and H. N. Southwell .will manage the Melba concerts. Miss Amy Castles, the Victorian singer, will not appear in grand opera at Cologne (Germany) during the autumn, as she had formerly arranged. A cable message from London explains that she has been engaged to smg at Monte Carlo in February. She will appear in the operas La Boheiiie, La Rigoletto, Traviata and Barbiero. Miss Castles sings this month at St. Petersburg, Dresden and Vienna, and then-returns to London to take up the Har rison tour concerts. Miss Lalla Miranda is doing . uncommonly well in her appearance in grand opera at Cw.nl Garden. She has made notable suc cesses in Micaela in Carmen and Zcrlina in Don Giovanni. Miss Dolly Castles has made a pronounc ed success at the Gaiety Theatre, London, in The Girls of Gottenburg.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The Besses o' th' Barn Band did not fail to justify expectations on their opening appearance at the Town Hall on Saturday evening, a judgment amply maintained by
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The Besses o' th' Barn Band did not fail to justify expectations on their opening ap pearance at the Town Hall on Saturday evening, a judgment amply maintained by their subsequent performances. Their pre vious reputation, obtained under conditions

winch precluded any idea of partiality, in duced the belief that their quality as in strumentalists would be of an exceptional nature. They have been prominent among the list of winners in band contests in Great Britain for many years. In 1892 they actually held every challenge cup in

the United Kingdom. Four years ago, at the Crystal Palace, they won the £2500 challenge trophy in competition with over 100 of the best bands in the country; and last year, in addition to the honor of .ap pearing by command before the King and Queen, they carried out a triumphal tour through France, in aid of French charities. Their Australasian tour has been one of continuous success. The welcome accorded to them on their arrival in Melbourne showed that public anticipation was pitched high, but the evening performance left behind no sense of disappointment. It was quickly realised that in the quality of the tone, the evenness of production and the musicianly interpretation of the pieces Ave Avere being afforded a revelation in the Avay of band orchestral effect. Under the direction of Alexander OAven, the conduc tor, the band plays like one man ; the finest professional orchestra could not, in the matter of absolute precision or certainty of attack, sIioav a more unblemished record, aa'hilc contrasts of light and shade are eleverl' managed. Such transcriptions as the Poet and Peasant oa'erture, or the selection from Tannhauser, sIioav rare skill on the adapter's part; and even in a full ensemble the band does not sound too loud for the ToAvn Hall. The audience Avas so demonstraiiA'e in its delight that it Avas almost impossible to furnish compliance aa'ith the extent of its desire. During the aa'eek t-avo performances have been given daily, arid there is still remaining an Oliver Twist demand for more. The concluding Aveeks of Madame Clara Butt.'s- fareAvell tour of Great Britain must liaA'e been exceptionally busy ones, for not only had she to appear at concert after concert, culminating in the huge success in the Albert Hall, but she and her husband had to attend to the manifold social duties of "fareAvelling." They gave a great garden party at their oaati home on, iSt-h June, the guests including rep- resentatiA'es of eA'ery circle in London. The approaching termination of the Royal Comic Opera Company's season in; Sydney limited the run of, '.Dorothy,-, cor dially. ' though it aa'as. receiATed, -to. a fort night and to-night. (Saturday, 3rd August); La Mascotte, of Avliich the company made" such an emphatic success in -Melbourne in the early part of the > year, - Aviil be staged for a similar period. The final fortnight' of . the -visit, will be deA'oted to The Belle of NeAA' York, another of . the most recent and most notable additions to. the revival repertoire. . of the company. - Another important' engagement has just been concluded by Mr. J; C. Williamson, Avlio cables that, he has secured Miss Fanny Dango, specially" to create for Australia, the. part of Peggy Sabine, in The Dairymaids, the next big production of the Royal Comic Opera Company Miss Dango, who has already left for Australia, on board the Mongolia, is a younger sister of Miss Let ty Lind, Avell remembered out here as -one of the shining lights of the first London Gaiety Company, and she lias already a long list of successes to her credit, notably that of the name part in San Toy, during the latter part of, its tAA'o years' run in London. She was, indeed, the tenth girl to Avhoin" Mr. Reginald Kenneth, the bari tone of the Blue Moon Company, sang the same songs lie had rendered for a thousand nights and to half a score of heroines. Some interesting figures of the Continen tal triumph of the Merry Widoiv, particu lars of the London success of which as'erc. published last aa-eek, are noAV available. "Die Lustige Witwe," AA'hich lias already produced in royalties over a million marks for its authors, Avas staged first in Vienna Avliere it ran for 450 nights— hitherto an unheard .of thing in the Austrian capital.. St. Petersburg and Copenhagen suav it for oa'er 300 nights, and eA'en in toAvns like Hamburg. and Cologne it registered over 200 performances apiece. Finally the great Avnltz song of the second act has attained sueli . marvellous popularity that over 1,000,000 copies of it liaA'e already been sold. The story of the neAV German comic opera, The Merry "WidoAV, is thus de scribed. Sonia, Avlien a farmer's daughter, had Avon Prince Danilo by her beauty, but his uncle, the King of Marsovia, had inter vened, and it Avas a case of "he lo\'ed and lie rode aAvny." When the curtain rises Sonia has become an enormously aa'ealth.v AvidoAV, and as the GoA'crnmcnt a\-ishcs to keep her millions in the country, the Prince is scut to Paris to find her and pro pose marriage. But she taunts him Avith his desertion, hints that uoav she is rich he is likely to sue for pardon, and so stings him that he sAvears that throughout his stay he Avill never sneak one Avord of love. Sonia, Avoinan-like, thereupon determines to make him break his oath. The piece pre sents beautiful fabloana shoAving the Mnr- sovinn Embassy in Paris, the garden of the Avidow's house. Avith roses and chestnut trees in blossom, and all the characters in quaint Mrirsovian costumes, and Maxim's gay restaurant.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: In matters musical the month has brought one or two striking features. Musical Director Thomas is now firmly established and will
articleText: MUSICAL. In matters musical the month has brought one or two strik ing features. Musical Director Thomas is now firmly established and will Idoubt not,hold on untill the curtain is run down in October. Toward the close of last month a programme which drew a very large attendance in the Choral Hall was the appearance of the Apollo Club, supported by the Exposition orchestra, in the oratorio " Elijah." The musical club named has a vocal strength of 400 voices and had as soloiatsMadame Nordica Neilson-dreir, Whitney, Mockridge and Mr Plumbet-Greene. The last named was the undoubted star and he gave a unexcep tional rendering of those gems "Lord God of Abraham " and " it is enough. " The attendance numbered 1500. The Columbian choir, a local organisation which dates its inception from the form ing of a choir to sing the numbers on Dedication Day,has also produced Haydns masterpiece " Creation " Haifa 71st hirth day received observation in the form of a concert devotsd exclusively to his com positions. The selections were-Overture, " A safe stronghold our God is still;" concerto for piano in C minor; symphony "i 'm Wolde." MrH. Sherwood, a good performer,was the soloist on this occasion. The members of the Thomas Orchestra have given very good proof thus far of their superiority. Among other instru mental soloists nit mentioned, oppor tunity has been afforded to acquaint one self with the capabilities of Loeffer and Brodsky, violinists, and Schroede,'cellist. The Lineff Russian Choir held the Music Hall for some four days; then followed a Schumann concert on the 9th. Schu mann was born on June 8, 1810. June 10 introduced Edward Lloyd, over whose performance the local press has literally run wild in the matter of praise of the great tenor. Not a little has been evoked by the single rate ad mission to the concerts and musical enter tainments that are not free-a dollar. Perhaps before half their season has ex pired the directors will recognise that they are practically debarring many from participating. The popular concerts, which are free, are certainly very appro priately named, and now that the acoustic properties of the hall have been corrected and made satisfactory it is very pleasant to be present at these. The open air concerts likewise are well attended.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Mrs. Grainier and her now famous son Percy have been staying at Iris Court, Pangbourne, the beautiful country home of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Menpes, and
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Mrs. Grainger and her now famous son Percy have been staying at liis Court, Panabourne, the beautiful country home of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Menpes. and

aave just terminated a pleasant time witu their host and hestes?, enjoying the plea sures of motoring and driving. Mr. Grain ger will not forget in a lifetime tlie tri umph at the Queen's Hall pionienadc con cert la^t Thursday. The manager is strong ly averse to encores for concertos, but sif ter Mr. Grainger rf rendering of Liszt's Hungarian fantasia he was obliged lo iwk the pianist to play again. After eight ex cited recalls the manager tried to start another piece, but the people stormed and shouted 'Clrainger'' until the Adelaide per former reappeared. Even the newspaper critics were enthusiastic. The Daily Tele graph says the number was the sensation of the evening, and that the public suc cess u-as emphatic, adding that Mr Grainger certainly played with splendid spirit and energy and masterly ease, as if he, too, were enjoying tlie music and not battling with it. The Standard says Mr. Grainger was the hero of the evening, labels him 'the brilliant, young Australian pianist.' and remarks that his precision, his strength of touch, and his freshness of spirit were all displayed to the full.. Effect after effect was brought oft with perfection, and the whole work was given with a verve and spontaneity that well deserved the en core demanded. The Evening Standard says:— ''Percy Graip-ger scored a veritable triumph. This izifted artist played the effective and exhilarating work with abso lute simplicity and sureness, and it had at his strong and at tlie .same delicate fingers an ideal interpretation. He well deserved his enthusiastic encore.'' The Daily Express calls his pliiying the distinguishing feature

of the concert, and also marks his nation ality. ''Absolute fidelity to the notes and the spirit of the piece and an unaffected manner aroused the great audience to an. un- usual degree of enthusiasm.' Mr. Grainger' has several excellent engagements for the autumn and winter season, among them some nt the Richter and Philharmonio Halls, at Edinburgh, Belfast, and Copen hagen. He will also ba one of. the per formers at the London Sunday symphony concerts. He was unfortunate in catching n. chill in coming home from Denmark, but is now better. i Sir Edward (better, perhaps, known still is Dr.) Elgiir. in his new oratorio 'The Kinpdom,' which was produced for the first 'time at tlie Birmingham Musical Fes tival (his week, has distinctly diverged from his characteristic plan of composi tion. This oratorio displays a much more simple and, direct style oi expression, which :dds perhaps to its forco, -while in a mea sure sacrificinK melodious, richness to the purity of style which wus presumably con sidered by the composer as l)est. expressing the motive. 'The Kingdom,'7 of course, is the second in order ot the trio of ora torios of which 'The Apostles.' conies first, and it bears traces of having been written in rather more haste. Put. it has been, received with great appreciation by the cog'noscenti, who fully recognise that we have now in England a - empower of classi cal music worthy of high lilace.

snippet: Mr Cecil Sharp has the satisfaction of knowing that his efforts to revive interest in English folk songs and national dances are bearing fruit. The Esperance
articleText:

Mr Cecil Sharp has the satisf iction. o^' knnvrina that his efforts to revive 'intetWt in English folk songs and national da noes are bearing iruit. The Esperance Work

ing Girls' Club has taken tip the subject witih enthusiasm, and the most a?-t pupils in dancing have been teaching morris dances in Somerset, Devon. Derby, Mon mouth, and Suffolk. Lessons will also bs (riven shortly in Surrey. A j/;reat perform ance is to take place on November 15 in the Queen's Hall, when Mr. Sharp will lecture. Many clergymen are favourable to the movment. ?Signor Kaisiner came over from Italy, where he is a very popular tenor, to earn his laurels at Covent Garden, as a reputa tion won there will establish an artist's fame throughout Europe. But after a single performance on Friday night the tenor re signed his: post, for which he had an eight weeks' engagement. He suffered ii'om stage fright. Madame Melha is delighting music lovers at Covent Garden. Her 'Mimi' in 'La lioheme'' and her exquisite singing m -Rigoletto'' are the .subject of enthusiasts comment.

snippet: Mr. C. H. Allen, who has been recently appointed organist and choirmaster to St. Mark's Church, and conductor of the Warwick Orchestral Society, is a musician of 25
articleText:
Musical.

Mr. C. H. Allen, who has been recently appointed organist and choirmaster to St. Mark'* Church, and conductor of the War wick Orchestral Society, is a musician of 25 years' standing. Educated in London under distinguished masters, amongst whom were Sir John Slainer, Warwick Jordon, Henry Gadsby, Christian Ersteld and Ernst Pnucr, lie followed Ills profession with success in .the metropolis for 18 years. Leaving Lon don for the Southern Hemisphere he held appointments in Hobart and Sydney, finally settling in Brisbane where, as organist to Wickbam Terrace Presbyterian Church and as a teacher of front rank, ho bas bold ail oxcellent position for tbo past live years. His servicoB have boon sought after by younger music tcachers of whom be bas at the present time no less than cit'lit under bis tuition. He has bcun frequently requi sitioned to act as musical adjudicator in Queensland, and bus judged tbo ( barters Towers Eisteddfod, the A.N. A. competitions iu Brisbane, and musical contests at Ips wich, South Brisbane awl elseu-bcie. Ifo is a conductor of experience, and was ap pointed by tbo Council of Churcbcs to con duct the milled smico bold in ^Brisbane on the occasion of the King's Coronation. He has mado arrangomculs to give lessons at the Warwick High School.

heading: Musical.
snippet: At length Sydney appears to be awakening from its long apathy in musical matters, and we are glad to announce the projection of on "Amateur Choral Union," which has already elected its officers and put
articleText:
Musical.

At length Sydney appears to be awakening from its long apatby in musical matters, and we are glad to announce the piojection of an 'Amateur Choral Union,' which has already elected its officers aud put forth a prospectus of intentions. Tbe Hon. John Campball, M.L.O., is president ; James 'Wateou, Esqi, MX. A., vice-president; with a committee consisting of

Messrs. B. Day, J.J?., 1', A. N. Davis, J. G. Holmes, and B. J. Hughes. The honorary conductor is Mr. Hector K. N. M'Lean, and hou. accompaniest Mr. J. Massey. The object of the choral union ib tue cultivation and practice of vocal and instrumental music by lady and gentlemen amateurs, who aloiie are eligible for ad mission as members. There is no subscription payable by lady 'member*, and gentlemen are admitted upon half a guinea entrance fee, and & similar sum is the an nual subscription. It isjioped the society will meet fcbs support so pleasant and popular an amusement ought readily to obtain.

heading: Musical.
snippet: That Richard Wagner had but a low idea of the utility of musical critics will be evident to any intelligent person who may chace to peruse the following extract from one of his works. The
articleText:
Musical.

That Bichard Wagner had but a low idea of the utility of musical critics will be evident to any intelligent person who may chance to peruse tte following extract from one of his works. The translation from German into English is by Ethel Smith : ' It is a pity that so many people give themselves the unnecessary trouble of blending

the musical and poetical languages with each other, supplying or completing with the one whatever, from their limited point of view, is wanting in the other. Once for all and for ever, it is an indisputable fact that where human speech ends musical utterance begins. Nothing is more in tolerable than the absurd pictures and histories that some people establish as the foundation of instrumental music. What poverty of soul and feeling does it betray when one of the audience, at the performance of a Beethoven symphony, is unable to keep up his interest but' by picturing to himself the incidents of some narrative as car ried on throughout the musical effusion! Such people often find occasion to complain of the great master when some unexpected turn in the music destroys the orderly sequence of their history. They accuse the composer of obscurity and want of finish, complaining that he fails in coherence of narrative. Oh, the block heads !' - ' Well, well,' said I ;' ' do allow every one, according to the suggestions of his more or less vivid imagination, to create these pictures and histories, by which means alone, perhaps, he is able to appreciate those great musical revela tions, and without which so many would be in capable, even after their own fasHion, of enjoying them. Anyhow, you must confess that in this way the number of Beethoven's admirers has been considerably increased; ay — that we may hope the works of the great master will thus achieve a popularity which would have been impossible for them were they comprehensible in an ideal sense only. 'Good gracious I' exclaimed B., 'do you claim even for these .noblest efforts of art the vulgar popularity that is the bane of everything great and lovely? Do you claim for these such an honor as that common people shall dance to the inspired rhythm in a village tavern ?' ' Toujare exaggerating,' I answered quietly ; 'I do not desire the popularity of streets and taverns for Beethoven's symphonies. But should you not consider it something gained did they cause the heart blood of the narrow-minded, grovelling man of the world to flow in a happier stream ?' 'These symphonies should have nothing to ? gain,' ' said my friend angrily ; ' they are there of their own accord and on their .own account— not that they may set a Philistine's blood going. Let him who is able benefif' therefrom to his own salvation ; but they are not called upon to force themselves into cold hearts.' 'You are a tiresome fellow, and won't under stand me, though we are driving at one and the same idea. Meanwhile, let us put the popularity question aside, and do you be kind enough, to toll me what your sensations were while listening to these two symphonies.' The passing cloud which temporary vexation had cuased across my friend's forehead cleaved away, and gazing at the steam emanating from the hot punch, he smiled. ' My sensations ! I felt the gentle warmth of a glorious spring evening. I fancied I was sitting under a great oak tree, gazing up between the branches at the starry heaven. I felt a . thousand other things I cannot describe. You have it now!' ' Not so bad,' said I, ' seeing that parhaps one of our neighbors was conscious of nothing more elevated than smoking a cigar, cf.riaking coffee, and making eyes at a young lady in a blue dress.' ' Very likely,' replied E. sarcastically; 'iand perhaps the big drum felt as if he was flogging his goodrfoy-npthing little wxetches, who had not yet brought him his evening- crust out of the town. Capital I At the entrance of the gardens I noticed a peasant who was listening full of joy and wonder to the A Major Symphony. I'd lay my bead this fellow was more on the right track than all of us put together; for not long ago you might have read in one of our musical papers that Beethoven's sole object in composing this symphony was to depict a rural wedding. So of course the worthy laborer, instantly re minded of his own wedding, was going over all the events of that day in imagination ; for instance, the arrival of the guests and the banquet; then going to church and the blessing; then the dance, and last, but not least, what the bride and bridegroom reserved for themselves.'' V The idea is_ excellent,' . cried I, laughing. 'But tell me now, for heaven's sake, why you wish to prevent, the good, man deriving- an hour'# happiness after his own. -heart from this sym phony, P ,Did.not he enjoy it eyery bit as much as you who were sitting uudepthe oak, gazing at the stars?' '' ..?.'? ' I give lin/ ',. said my friend good-naturedly. ' I will allow the good peasant to recall bis wed ding day and all its happy incidents upon hear ing the A Major Symphopy. JSut as fop those educated citizens who write for newspapers, I could tear the hair off their empty heads when I find $hem putting Ruch stuff before worthy people, -robbing them, before tne thing begins, of . all the unprejudiced im partial sentiments with which they would other vise have listened to a Beethoven symphony. Instead of giving full play to their natural feel ings, the p«or creatures Sod themselves endeavor ing, with full hearts but bewildered heads, to follow the. details of a rural wedding — a Bight they fiave perhaps never -witnessed — when other wise they would probably have been picturing to themselves with much delight something that lay mote within -the* sphere »£ their own imagina tion.' v Camilla Creo relates in the New fork Tooths' Compa2*ioh that -ra one occasion eh« found her self at the honse of a friend in New York in com pany with that* illustrious performer on. the Violin, Ole Bull; and a very talented pianist, a young : lady. Mr. Bull and this young l^dy -dis- cussed the relative, merits of their instruments, »nd: also the position and capacity of women in the field of music. The pianist asserted that she could bring -out as mucb .tone from her pianoasahy man, and that she 'could make the strings break as readily as the strongest man -could,' Ole Builj turning towards, me, exclaimed, very «x :*iteclly, 'See, Camilla! see what little regard Ahese pUmistB have for their instruments. They pound them, they bang them, they glory in break ing them. 'Bpw different from onr love f«? our violins! We pet them, cherish them, speak to Sbemj aw3# *htt» eHtgcA to jaffe hum thabt a

while; we lay them down, carefully wrapped up in the softest of silks,- in a bed lined with the choicest velvet. We are so jealous of them that we permit no other mortal hands to touch them.' To all of this I laughingly acquiesced, and turned the conversation towards something pleasanter.' Camilla Urso strangely recommends the violin to the attention of ladies aB a means of obtaining a livelihood; -! She eays : ft I will not touch upon the matter of the utility to many students who might turn an honest penny by their acquired talent. Since few women can become virtuosi, many really good players cap. earn nothing by their skill, who, if they were given an opportunity, might help their families and themselves. Why should not this moderate degree of talent be utilised in the orchestra ? Women, as a - rule, play in better tune than men. They play with greater expression, certainly, than the average orchestral musician. In Dublin and in Melbourne I have employed women violinists to reinforce my orchestra. They performed their part very well, and with close attention to details. They were quick to understand, prompt at re hearsals, dbedient and attentive to the conductor's remarks, and not inclined to sneak away, under one pretext or another, if the rehearsal were a trifle long. They gave good work for the money paid them. If such an incentive as paid employ ment in this way were given to the -many female performers on the violin,, it would be a great benefit to them,' as well as an advantage to the musical world.'

articleText:

'How long dees the train stop here?' the old ladv asked of the guard. 'Stop here?' answered the function ary. 'Oh, four minutes. From two to two to two-two.' 'I wonder,' mused the old lady, 'if that man thinks he is the whistle?'

heading: Musical.
snippet: Mr. Edward Lloyd's retiring makes the dearth of really good tenors' still more marked. So-called society is now so large, and fees are so high, that the next great
articleText:
Musical.

Mr. Edward Lloyd's Totiring wakes tho denrth of really good tenors' still moro marked. So-callMl society la now so largo, and fees aro so high, that thu next great drawing-room tenor is assured an incomo at over £20,000 n year, and 'Vanity F^lr' wants Ho knuw where the lucky man la to bo found.

Many stories arc told of tho dislike of opera singers lo drawing-room concerts, snya 'Talent,' an American Journal, and H la known that thoro are some who posi tively decline to tako such an engagement, no matter What tho conditions may bo. ' All tho great singers dlsllko lo appear in prl vato houses, lime. SonVbrlch sang several times in New York last year. Sho begau by making her terms ISOOdol., with tho In tention that they should bo prohibitive, but far from having that effect, sh0 was In duced onco to go n3 far aa Chicago to sln& lu a private concert there, after having placed her terms at 2500dol. Mme. Mclba sang here nt a privato muslcale, and de manded considerably more than sio re ceived at the opera. Mme. Nordlca mode n similar arrangement when Bho sang once or twice the Winter before last here. Mmo. Molba was last Spring In London tho most 7-opulnr of tho prima donnas nt Covent Garden for privato appearances, for -whiaa sho received loOOdoI. . It Is 50 years slnco 'Lohengrin' was pro duced at Weimar for tho first timo, under tho conductorship of Liszt, and tho opera has just been performed at the Weimar Opera House In commemoration. It -lasted flvo hours, being produced without cuts. Miss Julia Franks, who has had several attractive engagements lately, was (says a London paper) the vocalist at Signor Ran deggor's concert in the Imperial Institute the other day. Madame Belle Colo, tho vocalist, who has Just returned to London from South Africa, is, like Madame Antoinette Sterling, a con vert to Christian science, and thinks that aho has even developed a certain amount of faith healing power herself. She claims to havo restored to. health a poor llttlo child who had been kept in a bomb-proof cellar in Mafeklng. Tho latest 'Illustrated Bits' Is graced with an excellent picture of Miss Neva Carr-Glynn. 'The Botany Bunyln,' in tlio course of his notes, always brisk nnd en tertaining, pays tho young contralto a high compliment for htr ability. Miss Louie Morrell spent Christmas at Grasmcre, English Lakes, and returned to London early In January to fulfil several concert engagements. She song for the Na tional Sunday League on January 20 at Islington in company with Madame Bello Cole. Death of W. Q. Barker. The death of Mr. William G. Barker, the popular basso, who expired on Thursday morning, though expected for some tlmo past, will nevertheless bo keenly felt In Melbourne musical circles. Throe or four months ago Mr. Barker was troubled with an abscess on the brain, which was opera ted on no less than five times, but without success. He continued his duties as long as possible, but his condition grew wo'rse, and on Sunday week ho lapsed into uncon sciousness, aad remained so until bis death. Mr. Barker, who was one of the best bass singers who has ever resided in Australia, was 29 years of age, and a native ot Mel bourne. Ho leaves a widow and one son. Mr. Barker's services were frequently asked

on behalf of charitable objects, and were never asked In vain, and he was deservedly one of the most popular of Melbourne vo calists. When the news of his serious ill ness was announced, arrangements were made by a number of his admirers to bold a benefit concert on his behalf, although personally he disclaimed any desire to re ceive any reward for any charitable acts ?which he had performed on various occa sions. ? ? ? * ? In Borrowed Plumes. Tho Italian papers are greatly occupied just now with the subject of the decadence of Italian musical and theatrical art abroad. Formerly Italian artists appeared every season In London, New York, Berlin, St. Petersburg, and other capitals, but for the present musical season the only engage ments announced are those of Signor Mar coni at Madrid, Signor Bond and Slgnor Tetrazzlni at St. Petersburg, and Signor Scotti at New York. One of tho reasons of this decadence is the falsification ot names wiich ,has crept into the musical profession. Singers of all nationalities now take unto themselves Italian names, pre sent themselves to tbe public as Italians, and trade on the renown which Italian ar tists long ago justly acquired. Tho gonulne

able to hold their own with these competi tors in borrowed plumes. Jenny Lind's Letters. A large number of letters from Jenny Lind have just been discovered in Rome, written to a lady friend resident In Italy, and covering a period of thirty years, from 1845 to 1874. It Is said that they aro more than a hundred In all, and aro in the most intimate and unconventional terms, giving the great prlma donna's candid opinion ot ?much of the music and many of the musi cians of nor time. The letters have been purchased by an Italian publisher, who pro poses to issue them to the world very, short ly. It is to bo hoped, however, that they will be Judiciously edited (remarks a-.wrlter in tho 'Daily News'). It will add a now terror to life if privato letters, never in tended for the public, and probably written ?with a freedom only adopted in correspon dence with an intimate frlond, can be print ed without suitable revision. In this coun try it is assumed the copyright would bo with tho deceased singer's executor, name ly, her husband, Mr. Otto Goldsenmidt. Will Verdi's nuslc Live? Referring to the death of Verdi, a writer in last issue of the 'Sunday Times' says: — 'It was his own wish that he should bo judged by hla latest works— 'Alda,' 'Otel- lo,' and 'Falstaff.' On these he staked liis reputation. There 1b no sign that these works will ever bo cast into exterior dark ness while Europe retains its artistic taste, and tho lovo of tho grand and beautiful In music remainB. Just at present Verdt Is being 'kept out of the running' In Aus tralia by the Wagnerlan performances. But tho fact that 'Marltana' and 'The Bohe. mlan Girl' are keeping paco sldo by sldo with 'Tannhauser' and 'Lohengrin' is a pretty good evidence that Verdi would bs warmly welcomed back to our opera houses. Whatever may bo tho caprices of public tasto and managerial enterprise, we predict that it will bo many a long day before tho last 13 heard of 'Trovatore,' 'Rigoletto,' 'Un Ballo,' and 'Ernanl.' Pure melody is immortal, and cannot die.'

heading: Musical.
snippet: Miss Bertha Bird, the young Victorian soprano, who leaves for London shortly, gave a farewell concert in Melbourne a few nights ago. Commenting upon it, the "Age"
articleText:
Musical.

Miss Bertha Bird, the young Victorian soprano, who leaves for London shortly, gave a farewell concert in Melbourne a few nights ago. Commenting upon it, the 'Age' critic remarks:— 'It is not very easy to 'place' Miss Bird, or to prognosticate her future careeer in Europe. Operas like Mo- zart's Magic Flute, which contains parts

specially written for phenomenal voices. like hers, have been practically 'shelved' for seer lack of such voices. If her ap- pearance on the scene will serve to induce managers to revive them, well and good for Miss Bird; and not only in this work, but also in 'II Seraglio' and 'Dinorah' (neither of which is frequently given), our Victorian singer's singular gifts will find scope for display. Parts written, as those were, for exceptional singers are not, how- ever, sufficient in number to provide a livelihood for any vocalist, however 'highly' gifted. We are inclined. to think that Miss Bird will do well to take counsel of the best recognised teachers of voice produc- tion, since her voice in the mere 'ordinary' compass is not yet as satisfactory as could be wished; and after all, it is upon this 'ordinary' compass that she will have in large measure to rely. It is merely tau- tology to state that oportunlties for the display of her 'extraordinary' compass will seldom occur.' * * * *

The Barker memorial concert will take place at the Melbourne Town Hall to-night, and, judging by the exceptional booking at the box-offices, the admirers of the late popular vocalist are determined to make tho concert. an unqualified success. Up to Saturday nearly 1500 fiv6-shilllhg seats had been reserved, and there were in addition a large number sold that. had not been mark ed off. The programme will include many artists of note, who have been selected by the musical, committee from tho 100 pro fessionals and others who offered their ser* vices. Mr. Philip Newbury will sing 'The Message' (Blumenthal), and Mr. G. H. Snazelle will tell the story of 'Bill Adams.' Miss Nora Dane was to have sung for

in' London on February 4,. when her selec tions were to be 'Elsa's Dream' arid 'Elizabeth's Song of Greeting.', The Vic torian singer would thus make her first ap pearance before an English audience In Wagnerlan roles. Miss Dane has also been engaged by Mr. TOm Jones for several concerts at Harrogate and Buxton. ? . ? . ? m Miss Maggie Sterling sang at Madame MarchesVs. audition des elves last month, and was very successful in songs by Mas senet, who accompanied the Victorian so prano. Of tho five singers mentioned in the Parisian newspapers as most worthy of praise, Miss Sterling was placed second. Among tho miscellaneous papers of Sir Arthur Sullivan there have been found MSS. in some Instances uncompleted, songs and part-songs which date from his very enrly days. It is. of Interest to learn, on the authority of the 'St. James' Budget,' that in the collection of autographs now being exhibited at the Paris Conservatoire there is one signed a very 'few weeks be fore his death by Sullivan, and contain

ing, it is said, an extract from his now 'Victory' To Deum, which, on the final conclusion of peace, will bo performed In St, Paul's Cathedral. Miss Lulu Gillespie, the South Austra lian soprano, according to the 'British Aus tralasian,' has settled down in Sydenham. Her husband, Mr. Falrbairn, was well known In the London musical world before he left for Australia five or six years ago. Tho latest number of the 'Minim' (Lon don) contains the photographs and interest Ing sketches of two Australian favorites, Madame Adey Brunei and Mr. Mandcno Jackson, the New Zealand tenor. ;

Mlas Alice Hollander, the young Sydney contralto, Is giving concerts ia New Zea land. .Madame Pattl has explained (says the 'Sporting and Dramatic News') why Craig-y-nos Castlo is for sale. Baron Ce dorstrom wishes the prlma-donna to spend her Suiniher holiday in Sweden, and as the Welsh castle was chiefly used as a Summer residence, owing to the- delightful sl/.ua tion and tho lovely scenery surrounding it, Madame Pattl has decided to part with It. The prlma-donna might, it is true, have let it, but Cralg-y-nos would require the Income of a prince or an. American mllllon ulro to keep it in Its present condtton. Tho disposition shown by some musi cians of Anglo-Saxon parentage to mas querade under foreign names, in order to disguise their nationality. Is a matter that has often Elven rlso to comment. Mr. Foley became Signor Foil; Slgnor Camp'o bollo, the husband of Madame Sinlco, In reality belonged to the clan which owns the Duke of Argyll as Its head. William Green was. once well-known to Melbourne theatregoers— but under, the style and title of Guglielmo Verdi, a literal Italian trans lation of his proper patronymic; and of course our own Madame Mclba is another Instance in point. But surely the name of John Dunn, one of the very best of modern English' violinists, ought to bo sufficiently familiar in America (remarks Melbourne 'Age') to render such a process superfluous In his case. Mr. Dunn, however, evidently thinks otherwise. He says that the average American prefers artists with foreign names. This contention may be true or false; there is room, perhaps, for doubt on that score. But none can conveniently arise as to tho completeness of the method Mr. Dunn selected during his recent tour in the Slates, in order to fall in with this supposed, preference. Plain John Dunn blossoms forth before an amazed transAt lantic public as Ivan Donoiewski ! , There is nothing like doing a thing thoroughly while you are about it. * ? ? ' * The Musician and the Critic. There is an admirable little article on the late Sir Arthur Sullivan in the January num'ber of the 'Fortnightly Review' by Mt. Vernon Blackburn, the musical critic

ot -me rail man u-azecte. iiic iouuv-- ing amusing account of a nocturnal adven ture in Rome occurs dn it: — 'It so hap pened ? (writes Mr.-.Blackburn) that I jour neyed to Rome almost Immediately after my hearing for the first time The Yeo men of the Guard.' I was full of Its me lodies, full of its charm; and one night, ?walking through the Piazzl di Spagna, I ?wag whistling; the beautiful concerted piece, 'Strange Adventure,' whistling it. with absolutely no concern and just for the love of tho music. A window -was sud denly opened, and a. little face looked out in the moonlight, wftile a thin voice ex claimed in apparent seriousness: 'Who's -that whistling my, music ?' I looked up with astonishment and with some awe, and told the gentleman that, if he were . Sir Arthur Sullivan, it was his music that I was .whistling; and, said I, 1 thought that ?the copyright did not extend to Italy.- 1

remember how he convulsed with laughter somewhat to my dl-^omilture tnd closed the window to shut out tho chill of the night. I never dared at that period of life to make any call upon one whom 1 considered to be so far above the possl Willies of intercourse.' X

heading: Musical.
snippet: Private advices received in Melbourne from Miss Amy Castles state that she is now studying under M. Bouhy, to whom she was recommended when she become
articleText:
Musical.

Private advices received In Melbourne from Miss Amy Castles state that she. is now studying under M. Bouhy, to whom she was recommended when she became dis satisfied with Madame Marchesi's classifica tion of her voice as a mezzo-soprano. M. Bouhy, on the contrary, as soon as he had heard her, pronounced her voice to be 'a pure soprano of brilliant quality.' Tha change of instructors was not made without taking expert advice; and Miss Castles

ii-Tjio ki-ic^i/ out; 10 uun \Ji.i i*ms iij^ilL I Ua.u LU success.' Previous to her 'breach' with Madame. Marchesl — if that be the right term — the famous teacher had told her she was a 'dramatic soprano, that the voice was magnificent and perfect,' and that the Aus tralian public might rest assured that, de spite the fatigue from over-exertion, 'there was not a flaw in it.' . . -.' Slgnor Hazon and Mr. George Allan are, wo learn from a Melbourne journal, pro gressing well in their task of choosing the members of Mr. J. C. Williamson's new grand opera company. Mr. Allan evidently thinks there Is ubundance ot good material, the difficulty in his way being rather ono of 'omibarraa de richesses.' That Is good hearing, arid should ' sot our minds at rest as regards the personnel of, tho new organisation. As regards tho operas to be given, 'the chief no velties are Puccini's 'La Boheme,' a work which has roused almost a furore wherever it has been produced in Italy; Verdi's 'Otello' and Gounod's 'Romeo et Juliette.' Among quasi-noveltles may be classed Verdi's 'Alda' and Meyerbeer's 'L'Afri- oalno'; while 'Faust,' 'Un Bollo,' 'Rigo- lotto,' 'II Bar-biere,' 'The Huguenots,' 'Ernani,' and works of that ilk will supply tho more familiar clement. The , season opens early in Juno ? with 'Aida,' though whether in Melbourne or Sydney is at pre sent in doubt. ? ♦ ? » Once more comes the announcement that Madame Mclba will visit her native land next year. ? This time there eeems somo thlng fairly definite to go by, as the dis

tinguished slngor (according to a London paper) has declined to ^Ign any contracts for either England or America, and has let It bo known that Mr. Mnurlco Grau will lend her tho' necessary artistes from hla company, for a brilliant operatic combina tion. . l)y the way, a reference In a late Issue ot 'M.A.P.' to Australian singers who have sung before the late Queen in private ro mlndr. n correspondent that Madame Molba was tho first Australian to sing to Her Majesty on any occasion, formal or other wise. The circumstances of the diva's second appearance wero qullo exceptional, taking place at a time when her husband, Mr. Charles Armstrong, had already enter ed on divorco proceedings against his wife; proceedings, be it said, which failed utterly. The occasion was tho only ono during her late Majesty's lengthy reign, when any person against whom such a suit — even an unsuccessful one — was ponding, had ever bcon commanded to appear at tho Royal' Court. Mdroe. Antonio Dolores (Trebolli) has arrived by tho Sierra from America. Mios Florence Schmidt, at the symphony

concert at the Queen's- Hall last month, opened the pro gramme by pinging 'G o d Save tho King,' tho nudlenco joining in. Tho young Austra lian (according to tho 'Brltlsh- A u stroloslan') sang exquisite ly, and the number was most lmpres s 1 v o. Miss S c h m I dt also sang 'Vol oho Sanete' and the

gavotte from 'Manon' In splendid style. ?Miss Kate Rooney will leavo for London by tho Omrah on April 10, and intends to study for oratorio for a couple of years under Mr. Santley. The popular vocalist will give a farewell concert at the Cen tenary Hall on Easter Monday night ? ? . ? ? The N.Z. 'Snorting and ' Dramatic Ro vlow contains a brief, but interesting, chat with Miss Alice Hollander, who is at pre sent touring the Land of the Moa. Ques tioned as to !her futuro movements, , the young lady replied: 'After I get back to Sydney I sh'all remain there a mputh in order to study up some new pieces for tho Melbourne people, who, I understand, are very critical. I so much want to bo a suc cess there, for the sake of dear old Sydney, where I was born. The Melbourne people have sent to the old country so many musi cians who have turned out 'stars,' that I wont to be a credit to our colony, and show the Melbourne people that they have not all the talent In Victoria. ,[;.shall be in Melbourne at the time of the visit of the Duke and Duchess, and Mr, Bethune, my manager (who Is a connection of Lord Hopetoun's), has hopes of my singing be fore the royal visitors. We then do an Aus tralian tour, appearing in all the largo towns of Australia, and then back again for a second trip through New Zealand, where we shall open a'bout November^ — then America, and by that time I hope to have made enough money to go 'to Paris and study under one of the first masters.' Signer Brlgnoli, tho famous Italian singer, once agreed (according to a London scribe) to sing a solo at St. Agncs's Church, in New York. ? He arrived late, and tho sermon had commenced, but Brignpli, un abashed, leaned over the choir railing, and tried to attract the attention of the preacher by shaking his head and gesticulating wildly. At last ho yelled out in a voice that reached every corner of the church, 'Me ready for ze sing. Stoppe ze preach !' And the priest actually cut the sermon short in order to accommodate the im patient tenor, whose voice now rang out with such fervor as to thrill the worship pers and justify tho sacrifice. ? ? » ? Miss Lilian Devlin, tho Melbourno soprano, contributed to tho programme at the Victoria' Hall, London, recently. Miss Violet Ludlow (Newcastle) is en gaged for a tour of the English provinces with the band .of the Grenadier Guards. Miss Nora Dane has left London for Paris, where sh* intends working up a repertoire, prior to her appearing in opera in Brussels.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: A BOWRA correspondent writes :—Your realers will no doubt remember some mention being made in the columns of THE SUN regarding the successful candidates presented
articleText:
MUSICAL.

A Bowiia correspondent writes : — Your rca lers will no-doubt remember some mention being made in the columns of Tim SUN regarding the successful candidates presented by Miss Sweeney, of Bowra, at the London College of iluslc examinations recently held

at Ivcmpsey. At that time no ono thought Miss Sweeney had any intention of further pursuing her studies at so early a date, but recent events prove otherwise. At a London College of Music examination hold before the board of examiners at Paling's buildings, George-street, Sydney, on December 11, Miss Sweeney sat for examination to pass as an. Associate. This she succeedod in doing, obtaining 80 marks, thus entitling her to use tho letters A.L.C.M. after her name, also winning the cap and gown. Miss Sweeney is to be sincerely congratulated on the result, for while faithfully attending to her pupils for examination (who, by the way, were all successful), she porsevorcd in her own Btudies

ana was not content till she had climbed to the top of the tree. Considering that Miss Sweeney lias had to work her wny to the front stop by step, it is very creditable, and she has every right to feel proud of tho result. The results will not be published in the Sydney Press till after the New Year, but, owing to Miss Sweeney being anxious to return to Bowra, arrangements were made by which alio was enabled to order her cap and gown and bring them with her. Miss Molly Cox, of Bowra, also distinguished her self, passing the senior examination at the same time. By the way, she iB one of Miss Sweeney's pupils.
