heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Miss Una Bourne will make her reappearance in the Town Hall to-night (Thursday), and the public will hear her in an interesting programme, including a
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Miss Una Bourne will make her , re appearance in the Town Hall to-night (Thursday); and the public will bear her in an interesting programme, including a composition by Brahms, Bach, Chopin, Schutt, Zanella and -Liszt. The young pianiste Avill be assisted by Herr Louis Hattenbach, and Mr. Harold Eh-ins will act as accompanist. Miss Amy Sherwin (Madame Gorlitz), the

first Australian songstress ot the present day, Avho achieA'ed fame in Europe and America, and thus won for herself the title of the Australian nightingale, Avill return to Melbourne after an absence of ; eight years and appear at the Town Ha 11 on Thursday next, 21st March, supported- by a a-ery talented trio of artists, Mr... Arnold- Fraser Gauge, a yoimg Scottish /basso; Mr. Clement Harvey, pianist, Whcr traA-els AYith an open letter" from the Duke -.of Norfolk; and Gerard Kean, better, known/as John T. Kinahin, of Ballarat. Since her arrival in tlie -States on 16th October last Amy Sher.Avin has given -over eighty concerts,. 51 of which took place in. Tasmania, with a re cord attendance of 30 per cent, of theien- tire. adult population. During the eight years of her absence in Europe Amy Sher win has continued her brilliant career, she has appeared at the big festivals, at nearly, every musical function of note .in Great Bri tain,; making, .several tours of the Islands, one "of which was with Kubeiik,; the, great, violinist; She sang again, ;at the Philhar monic concerts, London, and now holds the record, of all living- sopranos for the num ber, of appearances with this old society, not excepting Albani. When the- Wagner monument Avas unveiled in Berlin Amy Sherwin had the great. honor bestowed up on her of being invited, as the representa tive British -singer. " Messrs. J. and N. Tait announce that they- have made arrangements Avith Miss Marie Hall, for an Australian toihr of- tAventy concerts, Avhich Avill be inaugurated' in, Melbourne'on thc.3Qth May. Music lovers Avill remember that Miss Ilall leapt into fame some, few years -back in a most remarkable manner.- ;" She was discovered playing in the streets, and' an interested friend Avas so struck with, her talents that a Complimentary concert wa3 tendered to her, Avhich enabled licr to study" with Sevcik at Prague. Tlie young artist was" so successful that when she made her debut in London musical critics -and the public received her ivith open a'rms, and she lias continued- her success ever since. It- is; ex pected that her Australian tour will be brilliantly 'successful. ' 'v- / According to latest adA-ices from Eng land, Madame Clara Butt lias been singing - in wonderful form. . In referring to her con certs the "Wales Daily Leader" 'thus re fers to the great contralto's voice: — "It, lias been/the fashion to compare the wonderful voice of Madame Clara Butt' Avith tlie rich notes of a pipe organ, but it has qualities wbicb/make the comparison a poor one at best, not alone because the aroice can ring Avith passion wliich can never touch tlie| strains of the pipes, but in that- it has- a color and resonance that never yet sounded from an organ. The Avriter at the Albert Hall, on Saturday evening, sat almost di rectly in the wave of the a'oice, and at times when a certain pitch was reached the vibration AA-as so intense as to set the drums of the ear singing. The hall seem ed floating with music. Madame Clara Butt and Mr. Kennerley Rumford are pro1 paring for their Australasian tour, and will make their final appearance in Lon don at the Albert Hall, at a great concert during July. It is expected that they will come by Avay of Suez to Australia, instead of by America, as was originally stated." By thi3 time the /Royal ; Comic Opera Company have, - become . accustomed ; to rapidity of transfer from place to place; but they Avill need all their experience , to cope with the rush that is just ahead of them. Mr. J. C. Williamson came to the conclusion that Easter Saturday, and not Easter Monday, must be the date of the. company's opening in Adelaide, and Messrs. Huddart, Parker agreed to expe dite the steaming of the Riverina across from New Zealand accordingly. The com pany Avill therefore leave the Bluff on Mon day, the 25th inst., and traAel across to ITobart, reaching there on Thursday. Training thence to Launceston they Avill embark on the Loongana for Melbourne, arriving there on Friday, and catching the Adelaide express on the same day. It Avill be a close thing, and it could only be accomplished by having at disposal the modern steamers that will carry the com pany on their sea trip.

heading: MUSICAL
snippet: The arrival of Mark Hambourg Australia was made a notable event by musical circles in Sydney, and for this week different functions had been arranged to greet
articleText:
MUSICAL

The arrival of Mark Hambourg jj.us- tralia was made a notable event by musical circles in Sydney, and for this week dif ferent functions had been arranged to greet the famous young pianist and his wife and infant daughter. To-night (10th July) he begins his tour at the Sydney town hall with a programme so carefully selected that it should show .every phase of his art and

the improvement therein since he was here before to the very best advantage. From the classics he has chosen Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata, Liszt's arrangement of Mendelssohn's Afidsummer Night's Dream and the Toccata and Fugue in D minor of Bach's. The romantic school is represent ed by a number -of Chopin's most charac-: teristic pieces, the Noctiu-hc in -E' major,' tiro Bolonaise in A flat, the Preludes' in 1) . flat 'anitoB flat; and tlie Etudes in C flat, and A fiat being. all bracketed together. A Barcarolle by Rubinstein, an air from' Gluck and a study by Holbrooks, one of the . new composers lie. is introducing to Australia, complete a programme exceed-' ingly wide in its range and exceptionally; attractive in its component parts. Among tlie impedimenta belonging to Mark. Hambourg which - the . Afanuku brought to, Sydney . this week were, two; magnificent grand pianos, which have been' specially constructed for him by a Lcipsig manufacturer. It will be remembered . that: Hambourg told an interviewer the other- day that the life of a concert grand aver- . aged aboiit twelve' recitals, : and when one takes = into , consideration . the immense power he exhibits at the .keyboard such a . limit is easy to understand. Moreover, lie - had to make -provision for the extended .tour of Australasia mapped out for him by Messrs. J. and N. Tait— a .tour ;in. which his instruments will have to undergo a great, deal of handling in tlie transporta tion from place to place. Hie superintended the .construction of them himself, 'and as he knoivs jiustralia, ; and what - will ,-be ex pected' from him out here) he will prob ably be able to depend- upon them. In an appreciation of Katharine Good- son, the brilliant pianist, who is now on her way to Australia, a contributor to the "Windsor Magazine" observes, a glance at the details of Aliss Goodson's career -will show, that she deserves well at our hands. Her early /training urns received at .the Roj-al Academy of;. Music, whore she spent four years under. Air; Oscar Beringer, to .ivhorii she -owes not a .httle of that splen did , technique which has proved so. invalu able to her. When .-she - left 'the Academy, there ..-was some talk of her- going to Paris to study with Paderewski, but as the move ments of that . famous pianist were natur ally somewhat uncertain/ it was deemed more advisable for . her to take her way to Vienna, tlierc to work under his master, Leschetizky, whose favorite " pupil she he- came. After she had been studying w.ith him for four years, Ysaye heard her play in Brussels, and immediately wrote to the late Arthur Chappell, saying that her talent had made a strong impression upon him, and entreating Air. Chappell to engage her for the "Pops," This lie did, and during her first season in -London she appeared four times , at these famous concerts. Tours through the. principal English provincial towns, and those of Holland and Belgium, followed, and in 1900 she fqiind herself in Berlin, where she gained the keen' interest of Dr; Joachim, Alax Brucli,! Scharwenka and many other of the leading musicians, and where 6he also had the honor of ap pearing before the Emperor. and Empress. : By the Pericles, which left London lost week, the Royal Welsh Male' Choir em barked for Australia. Alessrs. J. and N. Tait have arranged to open the tour in Sydney on 1st September, and divide that month equally between that city and Alel- bourne. Adelaide and Perth are the next. Air. AV. AI. Thomas, the conductor of the Royal Welsh Male Choir, is as much sought- after as judge in vocal competitions as Mr. Owen, of the -Besses o' th' Barn Band was in instrumental, and that is saying a good deal. Air. Thomas is, in fact, recognised as one of the best judges in Great Brit ain. - One. of the most important musical at tractions this - year for- Australia will be tlie concerts to be given by three Russian prodigies, Loo, Jan arid Alischel Cliernaav- ski. These three marvellously clever boya play the piano, violin and cello like fin ished artists,, yet their combined ages only total 38 years. The- were born in Odessa, and arc sons of the famous Russian con ductor, M. Oherniavski. Advices just re ceived from Cape Colony 6tate that the takings at the concerts for six weeks to talled nearly £10,000: The company will arrive in A'lelbourne in September, when a series of concert recitals will be n-iven. The second of the scries of popular cham ber concerts will be given in Glen's Con cert Hall on Wednesday next, 22nd July, when Schumann's Quintet in flat will be iierformed by the Weston nartet and Miss Una . Bourne. Haydn's " jn Jr. major will also be perforined. ATadame Christesen will introduce tr novelty in Folk Songs -by Beethoven, arranged, for voice, violin, cello and pianoforte and will also sing son!r= by Sibeluis, Siuding and Heise. The box plan is now'open at Glen's. Air. Percy Jones, the young Geelong mu sician, who was so successful as conductor of f?t. Augustine's. Orphanage Band at the inter-State hand contests held at Ballnrut and Launceston, 'and was sent to Europe liy his friends in Alelboume, Ballarat, Gee- long and the Western district to continue his musical studies, is now settled in Vienna. He is studying counterpoint under llcubexger, and taking lessons on tli.e pianoforte from Frau Dr. Alalwine Brce, an assistant of Leschetizky, and the .authoress of an excellent book on "The X'puudwork of tlicLesghetizliy iMethad,,; — -- - yvi.- ' 7

snippet: An orchestra has been formed in connection with the Innisfail Choral Society. Twenty-five players comprise the strength, and the
articleText:
MUSICAL

An orchestra has been formed in connection with the Innisfail Choral Society. Twenty-live players com prise the strength, and the orches tra will be heard in public for the first time at the Society's next eon- cert, on Thursday, lltli December. Mr. R. MiUett is the conductor, nnd a practice will he held in the C.W.A. 5 Rooms on Wednesday (to-morrow) night.

FOOTBALL Considerable interest has been aroused in fc otbnll circles in the Far North by a proposal ivom Townsville in connection with the Crowley Cup matches. The .idea is that Cairns and Innisfail play two matches (three if necessary), win ners to meet, the premiers of Towns ville and Maekay, such final to bo decided at Townsville. Opinion in the northern sector is strongly against the proposal ., A meeting of the Innisfail District lViffby League will be held next week to deal with the matter.

snippet: THE programme, she informed me, was a charming one indeed, From the splendid Wagner overture (which nothing could exceed)
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The programme, she informed me, was a charming one indeed, From the splendid Wagner overture (which nothing could exceed) To the lovely little scheme and the minuet

for strings And the latest bit of Dvorak, which made

tier sigh tor wings. Throughout the Grieg concerto her emotion was intense ; . It seemed to me at times she held her breath in deep suspense ; She raved of opus this and that, of Schubert, Bitch and Liszt ; Beethoven, Brahms, Tschaillowski, and a score whose names I missed. But when at last 'twas over and I led her down the stair I noticed that beneath her breath she hummed a little air, It was not upon the programme, being commonplace and tujiey, AivdT wondered at the sudden drop, from Bach to " Annie Rooney."

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The concert at the Princess's Theatre, says the Herald of Tuesday last, last evening drew a capital audience to every part of the,house; and the old favourites, as they successively appeared, were
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The concert at the Princess's Theatre, says ths Herald of Tuesday last, last evening drew a capital audience to every part of the,house; and the old favourites, na they successively appeared, were en thuswstically received, The programme originally was unusually long, and it was extended so much hy the numerous and not always discriminate evett, that it was not got through till nearly midnight. We consider such long entertainments, especially in this hot weather, as a mistake. Last night, for instance, a good portion of the dress cirelo company did not remain to the close, and they, consequently, lost the best executed thing in the programme, >tb» finale to the 4th act of ' Ernani,' admirably «Ongby Madame Carandini, and Messrs. Conlon, Laglaia, Maggiorotti, and chorus. The most novel feature in the programme (which was redolent of Verdi) was a selection from the 'Trovatore,' including the celebrated aria'D'amor full aura rosor,' and the duetto,'Quel snon,'with the'Miserere* choros. Madama Caran dinl sustained her part in the dust in a most satis- factory manner ; and the singing of M. Laglaise be- hind tim scenes, as Maurieo, was roost effective. We cannot say the same of his rendering of the ' Cujas animam,' from Rossini's ' Stabat Mater', which we never heard him sing so tamely. The principal triumphs of Madame Carandini, however, were ' Annie Laurie,' sung as the encore to a scene from ' La Traviata,' and'the Irish ballad of Molly Aathore.' M. Coulon sang with bis usual spirit,, and was called'upon to repeat every piece sllotttd to him. Tho aria, < Vieul la mia vendetta (Luere aiaBorgia),' wa bava never heard better rendered in Melbourne^ Signor Maggiorotti rose wonderfully in the estimation of the audienoe, and tma the humour which he threw into an aria from the ' Cene rentola' we are inclined to regard him as the best Italian buffo vocalist that we have had out here. We hope that his performance to night in 'Don Pasquale ' will confirm this opinion. The only in- strumental performer ( with the exception of Mr. Lavonu, who, when he did not officiate as conductor, presided at the pianoforte), was M. Kohler, who, as < three instrumentalists rolled into one, tor bs pelt ' formed solos on the concertina, flageolet, asd comet a-pistou, received perhaps a greater share of applaas» than any body. As a whole, the concert tmnuMi was highly successful, and every body appsuw

delighted.

heading: MUSICAL?
snippet: The following is an exact copy of a letter received by a young lady who wished to spend a holiday in a small country town, and advertised for a
articleText:
MUSICAL?

The following is an exact copy of a letter received bv a yonng lady who wished to spend a holiday in a small country town, • and advertised for a room:— " Dear Miss,—We think we kin sute you with room and bord, if you prefer to be where there is musick. I play the fiddeL 1 , my wife the orgin, my dotter Jule the akordion, my dotter Maty the bango,'. my son Hen the gittar, my son Jim. toe Boot and kornet, and my son Clem the base drum, while all of us sings hims, in which we would be glad to aave yon take part, both vocal or instrumental, if yoi p'ry on anything. We play by ear, ail' when we all git started there is real mos?.ck in the air. Let us know if you wan* to co:ne here : to bor«*_" It is hardly necessary to say she did not go. This from the Western States, U.S.A., not A.C.A. I—" Are yon the defendant in this ease ?" asked a magistrate sharply, as lie turned to a colored gentleman who was anxiously peering through the spikes of a deck. '' No, sab." was the prompt reply. " I has a lawyer hired to do de defendin*. I're de puesen dat stole de chickens!" That bit of pleasantly can now be equalled by tbe tale of a vritness at the recent Forbes Quarter Sessions, who wae asked by the presiding judge, *" Whom was the man whom you saw plucking the wool off the dead sheep ?" And in the most serious manner possible came the quaint reply, "It was the * excused 1 your Honor!" Strangely enoiigh, no one laughed at die blunder, although the witness continued to refer to the accused all through the case as "the excused," and a fitting dose was given to the trial by the jurors, who really did *' excuse" tbe man in the dock by their verdict of not guilty. Kridently the schoolmaster is very much abroad out West just at present, but it is -rarely that his pupils make such a suggestive «tep as the one quoted.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Marie Narelle will be home in a few weeks, after conquering the world. A Pittsburg man, who arrived in Sydney last week, gives an instance of her power over
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Marie Nardie will be homo in a few .weeks, after conquering tho" world. A Pittsburg man, who arrived in Sydney Inst week, gives an instance of her power over stran- gers. "Mr. Sullivan, tho millionaire, heard her in a distant city, and felt there was no one in the world like this Irish-Atistrnl ian girl. So when ho came home lie said to the directors of the Opera. House, 'You must engage Molly Ryan !' As 'Molly'

Hyatt they love to know her in the. States. What Sullivan wants is always done, and she was engaged for a week. Then, to our amazement, every street-car bore Molly Ryan's name in .huge letters. This was tho first time our street-cars carried an ndver-' tisument. The cars are controlled by Sul- livan. And when she came, what happen- ed ? Thousands were turned away every night from the great Opera House. Stars liad been appearing there for twenty years, and Mario Nardie broke all records. Tho management implored her to remain an- other "week, and allowed her to make her own terms. They gladly gave her what she asked, and nguiu the Opera House could not contain all who (locked to hear her. I don't know-what they think of her in England, but 1 do know that with our people in the States the world holds no moro popular artist than Marie Nnrelle."

Miss Nardie should get a great welcome home. She will arrive in Melbourne on

14th Jtino, and will open on the .1.0th in the Sydney Town Hull.

Tho friends of Miss Amy Castles will bo glad to hear of her continued successes In the old world. Lady Sydenham Clarke says that Miss Castles has noVv undoubt- edly entered upon n "career of fame," mid Hint lier prospects are the brightest. Miss

Castles has oilers of engagement from ninny of tho principal musical festivals and con- certs, and the young Australian will lutvo it very busy season. She received 100 guineas to sing at tho Dublin Theatre

Hoyal._

articleText:
MUSICAL. Madame

Patey, a gifted contralto singer, has signified her intention of taking her departure shortly for Aus- thine on a short professional tour.

Madame Patey has, been the leading contralto for many years in England, and has won much renown as principal contralto at the Handel (Crystal Palace) festivals, and throughout England in all great concerts.

' Madame Melba, the distinguished Australian vocalist and actress, has commenced another successful opera season in London. She achieved a

great triumph in the character of Juliet in the opera Romeo and Juliet, and the enthusiasm of the audience was great. The Prince and Princess of Wales were

present on the opening night.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Miss Lilian Gibson, who has been studying for some years under the able tuition of the Sisters of Mercy, is to give her first concert on the 12th November, in the Mechanics' Hall.
articleText: MUSICAL. Miss Lilian Gibson, who has been studying for some years under the able tuition of the Sisters of Mercy, is to give her first concert on the 12th November, in the Mechanics' Hall. Th6 gifted young singer will be assisted by leading artists, and the programme promises to be excellent. The concert is under the patronage of the Goulburn Liedertafel and Operatic Societies. Those who have not heard Miss Gibson should take an early opportunity of booking seats, as her many ardent support ors have recognised her as endowed with talent and a beautifully sympathetic voice, to which it is a pleasure to listen. Mr. Marsh Little, who returned from Europe last year after a most successful-tour with the Chapman-Alexander Mission party, will arrive ixn Goulburn about 0th November, and will give his farewell Goulburn concert in the Mechanics' Hall on the 11th November. Mr. Little has. just concluded a triumphant tour of the Iivorina. Following are extracts from a few of the press reports:-The Riverina Grazier, Hay: "Mr. Marsh Little.is probably the best male singer that lias ever visited alny." Narandera Argus: "The audience were treated to a veritable feast of song. Mr. Little com pletely carried his audience with him." Harden paper: "There is no doubt Mr. Little has a magnificent voice. He sang ninetcen songs, and captivated his audience from the start." Mr. Little will be assisted by Goulburn artists- ,Miss Doris Furner (violin), Miss Williams (contralto), Miss Amy Marsh (soprano), and Mr. W. Caspers (accompanist).

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: MR. PHILIP NEWBURY writes to the Sydney concert soprano, Miss Annie Perry, that, after his 10 years' absence in Australia, he found himself practically a new man in England,
articleText: MUSICAL. Mn. PnIsIr NEIwUrnY wriles to tile Sydney concert soprano, Miss Annie Perry, that, after his 10 years' absence in Australia, he found himself practically a new man in England, but thut he is now" rcgaining a position, hn, ssing repeatedly at the Queen's Hall Ilailed Concerts, and'is principal tenor wilth Mr. William Green on Mesors. Ibbs and Tillstt's list. Of Mr. Green, who is coming hero wilth Mime. Albani, he writes that he is "a most excellent tenor." Recently Mr. Neebury sang in thle Messiah at elfast with Miss Mary Couly, the Victorian soprano, of whom he says, "a very fine voice and good style." heading: Musical
snippet: THE musical 'Pippin' will open at Her Majesty's Theatre, Sydney, on August 10.
articleText:
Musical

THE musical 'Pippin' will

open at Her Majesty's

Theatre, Sydney, on August

10.

Starring Johnny Farnham and Colleen Hewett, the show began in Melbourne on February 23 this year. In addition to Farnham and Hewett, other well-known artists in the cast are Nancy Hayes, Jenny Howard, Ronne Arnold and David Ravenswood.

heading: Musical.
snippet: The lady who used to be known as Miss Clara Butt, and who is now Mrs. Kennerly Rumford, has just has a daughter in London. Will the little one be a great
articleText:
Musical.

Tho lady who used to be known as Miss Clara Butt, and who is now Mrs.. Konnerly Rumford, has just had a daughter in Lon don. Wdll tho little one be a great con tralto like' its mother ?

Tho death wa3 announced by cable a few days ago of M. Edmond Audran, aged 50, tho French composer. Miss Maude M'Carthy has had a special Invitation from Joachim to visit Berlin and play before tho Hocbschule. Herr and Madamo Max Vogrich, who ar rived in London last month, havo gone on to Vienna, after a brief stay In the great metropolis. Madame Vogrich will be best remembered by Australians as Miss Alico Rccs, tho Victorian soprano, who, though not very far advanced in her tcens,\ made captive tho Australian public about fifteen years ago, when the beauty of her voice and tho fire of her acting made a great sensation in tho local operatic world. Alice Rocs was the first native-born soprano to arouse en thusiasm in this country, and her re tirement from tho stage after a brief, but brilliant, career was much regretted by her music-loving compatriots. The couple, who have been living in New York for some time past, have now decided to moko London their home. ? ? '« ? According to a London contemporary, Madamo Melba gave a concert at her houso recently. 'Everyone admired the pretty house with its white pillars,' says tho chronicler of tho event. Surely thero were matters other than white pillars to admire ? The great vocalist was laid up with laryn gitis when the. mall left. « . * ? ? Mr. Charles Santley -will shortly cele brate his jubilee 'as a public singer. The veteran baritone, however, has no Intention of retiring at present. Jlr. Sdntley married in 1859 a granddaughter ot tho great actor, Charles Kcmblo. His son, Mr. Michael Santley, it is said, is becoming well known as an actor In musical comedy In England. Reports speak highly of tho young Austra lian singer, Mdllc. Lalla Miranda, who has been appearing with great success at Vichy; in (.'Lakme.' Classical concerts nnd grand opera ballets are Included in the entertain ments arranged for the Casino visitors at this fashionable resort. A tragic occurrence took place at tho Hermitage Opera House, Moscow, recently, during tho performance of 'Rlgolotto.' A woll-known French baritone, Jules De royodo, was singing a duet with Gilda, w-hen In the midst of tho applause he stag gered and fell. Tho curtain was lowered, aud he was found to be dead. It subsequently transpired that ho was in very poor circumstances, and was singing lite rally for' bread. Ho know that ho was dangerously ill, but determined on keeping ?to his work. Ho left a widow and six children totally unprovided for.

heading: Musical.

articleText:
Musical.

Tho 'British Australasian' just to hand Is responsible for the following: — 'Miss Violet Ludlow, of Newcastle (N.S.W.), sang at Birmingham and Wolverhamptou last week, and returned to town for tho Na tional Sunday's League concort at the Ag ricultural Hall on Sunday. Sho has- now returned to tho .provinces for a series of nine concerts.'

Siegfried Wagner Is finishing an opera, of which be has also written tbcllbretto.thatho purposes producing in Germany next 'April. Tho opera (according to an exchange) will then be translated In French for the sea con that the composer hopes to put lc in Paris. Miss Regina Nagel, who warbled 'Ben Bolt' during the season of the American 'Trilby' Company, sang with success at the Steinway Hall, London, last month. ?Mr. Arthur Deane is in the cast ot 'A Basso Porto,' a new romantic opera, at tho Coronet Theatre, London. 'Tho Stago' says that ho rendered with significance the lines entrusted to him. Tho Moltourno admirers ' of Mr. F. H. Cowen (says the London correspondent of a Southern exchange) will bo interested to learn that tho University of Cambridge havo conferred tho degree ot Doctor of Music (honoris causa) upon that gentleman. Tho public orator (Dr. Sandys), when pre senting Mr. Cowon for his degree, referred to him as having visited Australia on an auspicious occasion, when, In tbo words of ono of his many songs, 'the Btars wero with the voyagers.' . ? ? ? ? According to a London paper. Miss Louie Morroll, of Melbourne, who met with con slderablo success at a concert In Steinway Hall some tlmo ago, is engaged to be mar ried to Mr. Sydney Cronoen, surgeon in tho Royal Navy.

heading: Musical.
snippet: Says the latest London "Evening News": "Mr. Henry Russell, the veteran songwriter, who has recently kept his eighty-sixth birthday, tells some amusing stories
articleText:
Musical.

Says the latest. London 'Evening News': 'Mr. Henry Russell,- the veteran song writer, who has recently kept his eighty sixth birthday, tells some amusing stories of his experiences. Ono night, when h« was singing 'Woodman, Spare That Tree,' a gentleman rose up, and, in a very ex

cited voice, culled out, 'Was tho tree spared, sir '!' 'It was,' replied Mr. Russell. 'Thank God for that,' answered the agitated auditor, as he resumed his seat. On another occasion, whon Mr. Russell was singing h!n song, 'Carlo, tho Newfoundland Dog,' which w;as founded on a real incident, a man call ed from the gallery: 'Excuso me, sir, but was that, dog yourn V 'No, it was not,' re plied Mr. Russell. 'Did ho save tho child ?' ?Ho did.' 'Well,' exclaimed the man in the gallery, 'I Guess 1 should liko a pup. Could you get us one ?' ' Mr. Russell is an uncle of Madame. Adelina do Lara, tho accomplished planiste. . ? « ? ? Music' for All. ' '. Two recent American Inventions niako it possible for one to have his piano play auto matically, just as Paderewski would per form, upon it. The first ia an electrical recording ma chine, In which a roll of stiff paper unwind! while a number of knives stamp holes In the paper In accordance with the note or chord struck on the keyboard. This perforated paper is placed In the second invontlon — the, pianola — which haa a number of padded hammers projecting from it, and when those are placed ovor tho koy boord ot a piano and the pianola is set in motion it reproduces the selection which was played at first. The pianola plays each noto with tho name- volume, but the sound can bo regu lated by tho pedals, which are rogulated by small levors attached to tho inventlon To a London 'Evening Nowb' represen tative tho proprietor said: 'Wo sell rolls cut directly from tho muolc. Thoy aro more accurato than any pianist could make. 'Any man can now sit down and play tho most complicated music without any knowledge of music.' . ? ? ? : ? . v ?'??'.':? . ? ' *» ? ' '

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Messrs. W. H. Paling and Co., of George-street, have provided for the season a stock-in-trade replete in every department with the very latest novelties. They have displayed in their spacious showrooms a splendid
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Messrs. W H Paling and Co , of George-street, have provided for the season a stock-in-trade replete in every department with the very latest novelties They have displayed in their spacious showrooms a splendid assortment of musical instruments by all the most noted makers Amincan bteinway's,"famed Erard's, and other popular pianos, in a varied cases, are to be seen A show-case, containing a collection of Bnnsov's band instruments, stands near the entrance, and close by five other cars s containing dainty music folios in plush and artistic music stools. The latest songs can also be obtained either made up in handsomely-bound volumes or in single copies Paling's " Christmas Annual " comprises an excellent selection of composi- tions, vocal and instrumental, in a cover of striking design, bearing a characteristic view of Australian landscape

In the warehouse of Messrs Bruce and Massey, Pitt street, may be found a large number of the celebrated Wobago pianos, of which the firm are the sole agents in New South Wales. Approved types of the Smith cigars are kept in stock as well as canterbury music stools, and many other requisites and all the new

music

A better collection of tun Ronisch and Mignon pianos than that at Messrs Nicholson and Co.'s place, Ring and George streets will not be found anywhere in the colony Messrs Nicholson have received new shipments of those makes, for which they are the sole agents, as well as of the Clough and Warren's organs, so that they may be said to have a chance and ample display of the most prized instruments in the very 1 latest designs. They have for Christmastide also, a splendid collection of new songs and dance music Their popular Christmas Annual, which sells for Is , contains some 3D pieces Metal music stands and stools-the latter upholstered in many different colours of plush form acceptable presents the new Mignon piano stool is made either for solo or duet playing. "Messrs Nicholson have for sale solo path bound volumes suitable for gifts, as well as all the little accessories which belong to their particular

trade

Messrs. Elvy and Co have just opened out for the holiday season a magnificent stock of pianofortes in various models, ranging from the Iron-framed piano to to the more imposing cottage and grand, and all in the most beautiful woods of the different makers the celebrated firm of Collard and Collard are represented by w oil-selected types. Bluthner, Lipp, and other German makers have specimens exhibited in American organs, Mason and Hamlin and the Dominion Company make an excellent show Messrs. Elvy have in music all the newest and most popular compositions. Familiar songs, dances, and pianoforte pieces are heaped galore, affording scope

of choice to the most dilettanti.

The well-stocked showrooms of Mr. Charles Huener been, in George-street, and which have been entirely rebuilt on a convenient scale, contain a comprehensive assortment of pianofortes organs, and harmoniums by the best known English, American, and continental makers. Mr Huenerbein makes a speciality of the instruments manufactured by the celebrated London firm, John Brinsmead and Sons, for whom he is the accredited agent in New South Wales. The Brinsmead horizontal and upright " from grand" possess many improvements of great value to the executant The Worcester organ, which is considered one of the best furnished instruments in the world finds a place in Mr.

Huenerbein's show rooms

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The series of instrumental concerts given by Signor Hazon's orchestra has been concluded. The concerts have been successful both artstically and financially. The last concert was arranged as a
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The series of instrumental concerts given by Signor Hazon's orchestra has been concluded. The concerts have been successful both artistically and financially. The last concert was arranged as a " benefit," and the programme was made especially popular in consequence. The following are its details, and as most of the compositions are of considerable intrinsic merit, the programme may be taken as evidencing a fair standard of popular taste: - Wagner's "Tannhauser" overture; the "Andante and Finale' from Mendelssohn's " Italian Symphony ;" Prelude to the fourth act of Verdi's " La Traviata ; " " Scherzo," from Litolffs fourth " Concerto Symphonique for piano and orchestra ; Ponohielli's billet, " dance delle Ore." from the opera " Gio- conda : " a " Festival March, by Signor Hazon ; Saint-Saens " Danse Macabre;" Rubinstein's " Harmony of the Spheres "-tho " Motto Lent," from the string quartet in D ; Handel's celebrated " Largo," from Nerves Pnganani's' " Moto Perpetuo ; " and Liszt's " Hungarian Rhapsodie " in F.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: With the approach of Christmas the concert season is in full swing. During the fortnight M. Deslouis, the French baritone, has given two extremely successful entertainments. On the first
articleText:
MUSICAL. '

With the approach of Christmas the concert season is in full swing. During the fortnight M. Deslouis, the French baritone, has given two extremely successful entertainments. On the first occasion he had the assistance of Madamoiselle

kestel, who made her first appearance, of Mr. Van Speren, a Dutch violinist, and of Madame Char bonnet Keller mann; and on the second occasion, in addition to the artists named, Mons. Kowalski took a part. A grand concert was recently given, organised by a large committee of ladies, on behalf of the guarantee fund of the late series of orchestral concerts. It was a signal success. Several important numbers were rendered by the orchestra, under the cahduetorshij», of Signor Hazon, and, in addition. assistance was rendered by Mrs. Vanderreer Green, M. Deilema, Mr. Riven _ Allpress, Mr. Alexander Rea, and Mr. Charles Huenerbein.

snippet: It may be some satisfaction to many people to know (says "Musical Progress") that Sir A. Mackenzie has, at the Royal Academy of Music instituted
articleText:
MUSICAL. .Wiiorgg

It may be some satisfaction to many people to know (says ' Musical Pro gross') that Sir A. Mackenzie has. at t/ie Ifo.val Academy of Music, instituted a class for conductors, whore many aspirants havo proved themselves can able of directing the production of the most difficult works.

Tlie celebrated English oratorio soprano, Madame Maru Conly, will open the Victorian season at the Mel bnunio Town Hal] on Monday next, under the Faulkner Smith direction. Tlie popular singer will be supported by a full company, including Madame Maggie Stilling, Miss Natalie Dawson, Miss Olive Koger, Jlr. Hector Gold spink. Horr Louis Hattcnljach, Mr. Horace Jno Bouk, and the Harmonist Quai-tot. Madame Conly will after wards tour the principal country towns and go to Xow Zealand in August. In the 'Statesman,' of India, there has been some correspondence relating to the pay and status of bandmasters serving with British regiments In India llie drift appears to bo a desire for an increase of 50 rupees per month in the salnry u, the bandmaster. A contem porary remarks that some of them are clever, excellent fellows, wlio deserve much more than that, and there are others who are simply plain, earnest bandmasters who niaKe the best of the situation. In any case, it is an isolated job that should receive consideration, ami as reorganisation is in the air it might be as well to wait and see what is to turn up later on. It was two hundred years ago that a maker of spiiiets ill Paris, called Manus, addressed a preliminary note to the Royal Academy of Science, con cerning 'a project for an instrument, with hammers striking the cords directly instead of moving them by friction.' Tlie preliminary note of 1712 was followed by a more detailed rnniiiiuiiiration in 1715 containing a description and an engraving of four instruments in which the wooden tongues called sautoreaux (which pro duced the sound in the spinet by fric tion on the strings) were replaced by percussion hammers sot in motion by pressure on the keys. Thus tho prin ciple on which all modern developments of the niano are based was discovered. Of Marius practically nothing is known. Ho is supposed to have died in poverty about 1730; and his inven tion met with no genuine success. MoriHjyer its originality was disputed ; for it is maintained that it was several months before Marius's first communi cation to the Academy that a Floren tine. Rartolemco Christofori, submitted a plan for a similar instrument to the Grand Duke of Tuscany. The instru ment he called Clavicembalo a mark letti col piano e forte, whence tho name pianoforte is obviously derived. How ever, sinc« Christofori's discovery was not published till some years subse nuently, the honour of simultaneous discovery at least remains with the ob scure Marius.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: MUSIC IN BRISNBANE.— Musical matters in Brisbane are quiet, and no musical event has taken place since Madame Mallalieu's concert. The Musical Union, is now practising "Eli"
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Music ts Brisbane. — Musical matters in Brisbane are quiet, and no musical event has taken place since Madame Mallalieu's concert; Hie Musical Union, is now practising "Eli" for the next quarterly concert, which should come off some time in September. •" Eli " has already been given by the Society. It .will

he better understood at a second, hear ing. It is not, however, a work which is so well suited to the Musical Union as some

others in its repertoire. In the first place, its orchestral effects are numerous, and depend much on instruments which are lacking in the Union. 'Then, again, it is well known that the tenor part was written expressly for Sims Beeves, and we have hardly a Sims Reeves in Brisbane. The Musical Union, however, is well able to give such a rendering of Costa's great work as should satisfy a Brisbane au dience. The Musical .Union will soon, we believe, be in possession of a quantity of music new to Brisbane audiences, and which, judging from the list, willdelight both Union practising members and the musical public.

articleText:
MUSICAL.

Dr. Price gave one of the fine, .-musical- treats provided by, his weekly organi rccitals on Saturday. - 'The programme ' .included Bach's famous prelude and fugue , in " A

.minor; Dvorak s charming .largo -from -the- New World :Symphony, Guilmant's March Fitnebre, with its-.coneluding serapliic chant; .a selection from the .Plying -Dutchman, the overture .to R'uy Bias, Batiste's Offer toire in' D, Dudley- Buck's popular- variations on. Tlie Last Rose' of 'Summer, and - concluded with the Hallelujah Chorus. There .was a large attendance, and several of the pieces were .enthusiastically encored. . : The new. comic. opera Tom .Jones, which ;is founded on -Fielding's famous novel, was produced at Manchester -on .'Saturday might.; Miss Carrie Moore, the Australian actress,- who took the , part -of Honor, the maid, scored a . great success. - : . , , . Amongst , VHalf-a-minute .Interviews", .published in n London .contemporary is' one with Madame Alary Conly, formerly of. Melbourne, who is spoken of .in '.very com-, .nliincntary. fashion as ranlcirig amongst the; best .oftlie Australian singers "who Iiave. won their laurels "in tlie difficult and 'exact ing vocal field of, oratorio" in England. "I :don't think, ". said Madame Conly, in clos ing the interview, "Lhese ever was an -Australian so utterly lioinesiek: as -T dniT The cl'imate:is.my -bete ?noire. . .I tget bron- ichitis".- every year! Like all' Southerners, I tam fond of exercise, but how can you em joy a long walk when :it. is always raining? .So my chief recreation is revolver -prac tice, and I am becoming quite a. good, shot. iBut— let me -whisper : it ..to you— my chief .delight is milking! Not at -all the sort of -thing -to harmonise with .grand oratorio, is 'it? All thc:same, I'wiil /back myself to! milk a' cow. with anyone, and many a time I .hatch myself wishing I were back in Australia doing that instead of singing!" Considerable : success . as an oratorio singer is being obtained, says the "British Australasian," by Air. Tliorold Waters, the Alelbourne tenor, who snng to evident appreciation recently in a performance of the Alessiah with the Kensington Per manent Choir of the London Sunday School Choir, when he was associated as soloist with Miss Kate Cherry nnd Air. Dan Price. Mr. Waters also had fine re ceptions at concerts in the King's Hall and elsewhere during the week. He has just been engaged to sing the tenor roles in Gounod's Alesse Solennelle and Stern- dale Bennett's AIny Queen with the Bridge- water Choral Society on 18th April.

Another call of candidates for the police force will be made about the middle of this month. Those who pass the various tests will bo placed upon a list, and em ployed as vacancies occur. The last ex amination was disappointing, owing to the large number who failed through physical (lei eels, such as varicose veins and short ness of stature. Applicants must be be tween the ages of 20 and 25 years, and must be at least 5 feet 9 inches in height.?

heading: MUSICAL
snippet: The following is of interest to the musical members of repertory clubs “Handell’s Forgotten Operas.” Handel’s tremendous fame as a
articleText:
MUSICAL

The following is of interest to the

musical members of repertory clubs:— "Handell's Forgotten Operas." Handel's tremendous fame as a com poser of oratorio, in which field he is practically unrivalled and certainly surpassed, has somewhat dimmed his undoubted gifts as a composer of operas. As is well known, the composer of the "Messiah," "Ssufl," "Israel in Egypt" and other celebrated oratories, wrote great many operas in the Italian style of the period and was in, fact one of the earliest operatic conmposens. His rivalry with Buononcini, and his failures in this line, are noiwi matters of history. It was this failure which proved the turning point in Handel's career and

led him into the field of oratorio. Had he been more successful in his operatic ventures, the world might hav€ been denied the beauties of his long list of sacred compositions. Nevertheless these early operas though not dramatic enough for the modern stage, contain many lovely melodies of which the "Largo" from Xerses" is but one. A few of these airs have become popular, but the vast mine has scarcely been, tapped as yet. Among the numbers which have attained at least a small measure of success are "Where'er you walk" and "O! Sleep why 'dost thou leave me?" from "Semele," the "Care Selve" from "Atalanta." and the "Lascia ch'io Piangia ; rom " Rina,do -" Best > the celebrated EuS llsl1 organist, has made an arrangement for organ of the exquisite minuet from "Berenice,' which was published in the "Etude" some years ago. There are also arrangements, most of them quite old, of various airs from these old works. What a pity that more interest is not taken in them.! A few years ago Walter Damrosch brought out the long forgotten "Aeis and Galatea, with pronounced success. Why do not sonie other enterprising conduct-ore and singers revive at least portions of the Handelian opereus? They would certainly be a novelty and probably a very delightful one to most concertgoers.

snippet: “Naughty Marietta”, a musical drama written by Victor Herbert and first performed at the New York
articleText:
Musical

“Naughty Marietta”, a musical drama written by Victor Herbert and first performed at the New York Theatre on November 7, 1910, will be presented by the Sandringham Light Opera Co at Phoenix Theatre, 101 Glenhuntly Rd, for a limited season — April 15-23.

The play is set in New Orleans in 1790, which in the absence of its French Governor is being indifferently ad ministered by his deputy, Grandet, and his son Etienne, who is actually the pirate ‘Bras Pique’.

Through a series of adven tures, Captain Warrington manages to find Marietta and apprehend Etienne, who receives just punishment.

Performed throughout the world and filmed in the 30s with Jeanette McDonald and Nelson Eddy, its music has re tained its magic, with songs “Falling in Love with Some one” and “The Italian Street Song” becoming all-time classics.

Bookings and Inf: 836 8408. Adults $6/$7 Fri-Sat evening. Stud/Pens $4.50. Children U/12 $2.50 Matinee Only.

articleText: MUSICAL. Many of the great prima donna, were singers from infancy, and some have said that they could not re member any time in their lives when they : did not sing. There is no reason why, in a district such as this, where beautiful voices abound, we should not have juvenile singers as well as juvenile violinists and pianists. The example is set by Mlis Irene Benndt, of Stawell, 12 years of age, who, after six months' voi~ training from Mr. G. P. Frayling, passed, with distinction, the primary examination of the Associatul Board of the .Royal Academy of Music ald Royal College of Music, London. Complete results of the examination successes of Mr. Fra?ling's students in 190S are only just to hand, includ ing advanced grade pianoforte, Miss A. :R. Moody; harmony, Mr. II. vW. Zsohech: intermediate grade violin, llss Weld; harmony, Miss L. Moly neaux ; higher division hlarmony, Miss Weld; elementary pianoforte, Miss Wyatt; primary singing (distinction), Miss Irene Berndt. It is given to very few to be able to teach such round of musical subjects and with such conspicuous success as Mr. Fray ling does, whilst the advantage of fered to students wishing to qualify in more than one subject is plain and needs no comment. Mr. Fray ling resumes tuition at Iloraham or Friday, January 2Jth, and at Nati muk February 5th.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: SIR,—I have much pleasure in congratulating your correspondent "Progress" on taking up auch an important matter as the cultivation of music. It is only by the
articleText:
MUSICAL. ..

Sir,-I have much pleasure in congratulating your correspondent ',' Progress " on taking up such an important matter in the cultivation of music. It is only by the formation of societies' that great progress can be made. Anyone acquainted with, music knows how much more improvements can be made by the members of a union than by amateurs giving occasional concerts. It seems a very great pity indeed that there is not more interest taken in music in Hobart than at the present time. Surely out of the great number of amateurs here another first society could be formed, and. I think, as your correspondent states, that it only wants the initiatory steps to be taken, and the thing would be accomplished.

I feel confident that under a good conductor another society would achieve great

success. '

Hoping that this subject will receive your

invaluable assistance.

-Yours, etc.,

BASE CLEF. Elizabeth street, May 20.

heading: Musical.
snippet: Musical criticism by machinery would seem to be in a fair way of being an accomplished fact. A correspondent of a Chicago paper writes:—"A friend of mine
articleText:
. . ..Musical. ? : .

Musical criticism by machinery would seem to bo in a fair way of being an ac complished fact. A correspondent of a Chi cago paper writes: — 'A friend, ot mine bbught a fine phonograph, and asked me to play (something on the piano for it to record. I played my Valse Canarlote. I

was astonished to discover two bad defects In my playing. Ono passage of 20 notes was over-accelerated and quite jumbled, and another place that I had intended to give a certain rhythm, the way I had 'written it, was entirely wrong and unpleasant to the ear. As a result of this phonograph lesson I havo corrected both these defects. After this experience, it seems to mo it would be an excellent idea for teachers of singing, doclamations, and instrumental music to employ the phonograph so that pupils could hear their own faults. I can- ' not find words that will sufficiently recom mend a trial of this device.' Mark Hambourg, tho young Russian pianist, met Mark Twain in Vienna, and it is said tho two straightaway became fast friends. When Hambourg came to this country he brought with him some letters of introduction from the humorist,' ono of which contained this remark:— 'Ho plays the piano better than any of the Clemens family, but his complexion is not as good as mine.' Miss Hedwlg Materna, niece ot tho celo brated Wagncrian vocalist, and herEOlf the prlina donna of the Mayence Theatre, Ber lin, recently threw herself In the Rhine be cause her lover, a'musiclan without special talent, broko off their engagement. Sho was saved by somo boatmen. Infant prodigies in tbo musical world are constantly coming to light, but it is not often wo hear of a child of three as a com poser of music. The little Popito, as young Jose Rodriguez Arrldu, who was bonj at Betanzo3, in Spain, Is professionally called, commenced composing music, it appears, when only two and a half years old, aud, as a pianist, he is said to do wonders with bin instrument. According to tho 'Stage,' be performed the other day at a 'Figaro' ontertainment In Paris, and created a pro found sensation. Ono of tho child's pecu liarities is that he so much prefers his own piano, which happens to bo of very ordinary quality, that it is only on rare occasions, and vvhou he is in a particularly good tem per, that ho can be induced to plijy on any other. Peplto's compositions, which ure said to bo brimful of harmony, are written In a sad rather than a lively strain.

Mdlle. Agnes Janson, who has bo far scored the hit of the . Gcorgo Musgrovo grand opora season at the Melbourno Prin cess's, has, by request, suppHed a brief outline of her career to the 'Referoe.' Born at Stockholm, Mdllo. Janson under went her musical training at tho Royal

Academy of Mu ulc in tbo Swe dish capital, and on its com pletion was for tunato enough lo receive an engagement at the Royal Opora House there, whero sho re mained for two years. Believ ing in tho maxim that ge nius consists in an Infinlto capa city for taking pains, Mdlle. J a n s o n has, during tho years which

have elapsed slnco Eho left tho academy, been a diligent student under Herr Hugo Beyer, an able maestro, who is now resident Iu London, and while possessing exceptional natural gifts of song, she has neglected no opportunity of perfecting these by close assiduous study, both of tho musical aud dramatic side of her art. One result of this is that artistic and sympathetic method ot singing which captivates and delights her audiences. Mdlie. Agnes Janson wont to England, in 1885, and made her first ap pearanco at Albert Hall, London, whero Madauo Christine Nilsson also sang. Miss Agnes Janson was ono of the popular con cert party which went on tour in the south, west, and north of England, and Ireland, among others ot the party being Slgnor Foil, Mme. Antoinette Sterling, Signor. Bot tcsini, &c. .; Miss Janson has ? since appear ed at all the principal concerts- in Crystal Palace, Royal Albert Hall, and St. James' Hail, and gave a concert in- conjunction with Miss Ksther Palliser in Queen's I-Jall. She also sang before H.M. the Queen at Windsor Castle, 1890. Last Winter ? tho talented lady gave a Scandinavian song re cital in the U.S.A., which vvas highly suc cessful, and secured for her a prolonged engagement with the Boston Symph Or chestra, tho finest in the world. Mdllo. Jauson is looking forward with pleasure to her visit to Sydney.' With such excellent ?credentials as' sho possesses, the lady can depend upon a royal reception.. A London correspondent of a Melbourno paper writes: — 'There was a curious unani mity about, the costumes of tho lady per formers at-a promenade concert recently, and it is not often that professionals are quite so much of ono mind. ' As they ap peared. upon the platform one after another to take their .different' 'turns,' sit dawned on the . spectators that every lady had

cnosen greeu. '-? ine' uarpist -wore a leai green gown, -which, looked .well , amongst the palms and flowers,' tho contralto came on in palo green', tho lady- vloliniste in a well-cut gown of eau-do-nll. ,But the palm was universally awarded to Madamo Amy ^herwin, Whose toilette put all the others in tho shade. The 'Australian-Nightingale' appearedin an exquisite confection of sea green crepe do chine, with tho back of the skirt set in soft flounces which looked like foam, and the front arranged in a long tunic bordered with a wide band of somo wonderful passementerie made of silver sequins, which shimmered like the scaics of a fish. This dress was wonderfully bo coming to the charming singer, with her smiling face and wealth of Titianesque hair. Many music-lovers will regret to learn (says London 'Referee') that Lady Halle has announced her' intention ot retiring from the concert platform and dovotints herself to teaching the violin at Berlin; but when it is remembered that Wilma Maria Francesca Noruda first asked an audlenco to listen to her at Vienna in 1S46 at the ago of seven, it must bo; admitted that her desire to withdraw from the con cert-room is not unnatural. It is indeed somewhat disturbing to -think that she should have to teach after fifty-four years of fiddlius and tho survival of. two hus bands. 1 trust, her intention to teach springs from an artistic . desire to' impart the purity of her style to others rather than from pecuniary considerations; but artists are unfortunate- folk in guarding the gold they so hardly earn.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The Metropolitan Liedertafel gave its 37th concert on Tuesday evening, December 16, in the Centennial Hall. A considerable number of visitors was attracted, and the affair was a complete success.
articleText:
MUSICAL.

The Metropolitan Liedertafel gave its 87th concert on Tuesday evening, December 16, in the Centennial Hall. A considerable number of visitors was attracted, and the affair was l complete success, Several artists of repute, headed by Signora Link, assisted the society in entertaining the audience. On the Thursday evening following, the concert season of the Sydney Liedertafel was concluded. The final affair took place in the Centennial Hall, and was listened to by a very large audience. The society was assisted by Signora Link as solo vocalist and by Miss Lottie Hyam and Mr Rivers Al I press as Solo in- strumentalists. Christmastide brought with it the customary performance of " Messiah " by the Phil- harmonic Society. The first production took place on Tuesday evening, the 23rd instant and the principals were Madame Patey, Signora Link, Mr. W. Walsh's, and Signor Riccardi. The (great hall was packed in every part, and as for the performance it

was one of the finest which has yet been heard in Sydney. On the night of Christmas Day the oratorio was repeated. This performance was thrown open to the public, and the Centennial Hall was, if possible, even more crowded than before. The solo artists were the same as were heard on

previous Tuesday. a

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: A very large audience, which filled the Town Hall in all parts, assembled on Thursday evening to hear the first performance of Sir Edward Elgar's now famous
articleText:
MUSICAL.

A very large audience, which filled the Town Hall in all parts, assembled on Thurs day evening to hear "the first performance of Sir Edward Elgar's now famous com position. Melody is there in plenty; but it is mostly of the kind that

only discloses its true inwardness on close acquaintance. Harmonically the treatment is exceedingly chromatic; but the chords and progressions, though always ingenious, and, indeed, daringly original, are handled with consummate art; and the composer has embellished thein with finely chosen orchestral colors. His instrumentation, in truth, is masterly. He really "uses" a large orchestra; that is to say, he not only crowds his score with unusual instruments, but he gets good service from them. Of the soloists Madame Gregor Wood lias rarely been heard here to better ad vantage. Mr. Gregor Wood, who took the trying part of Gerontius, is to be compli mented. Mr. Horace Stevens is well equipp ed for such a part as that of the priest; it lies well within his compass, and he sang it satisfactorily and intelligently. Of the Liederlafel chorus, assisted by the associa ted ladies' choirs, we have little to say which is not highly Commendatory. And even the orchestra fulfilled its very import ant share in highly creditable fashion. Mr. Ernest Wood, who conducted, may feel justifiable pridethafc. .a£a first attempt so arduouaJiJMjf-a work was so satisfawdJJtftVseh'tTO'v., On SMayw'ejimR Mr.'Ghotge Mus- grove's ttSoyal CompAny will commentfe-lhort return season /of three weeks antfi-oimeslfrincess's Theatre. ThKe'ning 'praijm$ion will be Lohengrin, to be ToIkSSvecTin order during the first week by Romeo and Juliet, Faust, The Valkyrie, Carmen and Tannhauser. The new productions for the coming season are Rigoletto, The Marriage of Figaro and The Flying Dutchman. Fraulein Carlotta Bouehe, an artist with a high Continental reputation, will be added to the principals who appeared here last season. The Scottish Gaelic Society of Victoria will hold its annual concert in the Masonic TJall, Collins-street, on Wednesday evening, Cth November. Madame Clara Butt and Mr. Kenncrley Ruraford will give their final concert in Melbourne on Thursday evening, 7th No vember. They arc coming from Brisbane to Melbourne in order to be present at the Melbourne Cup. Miss Ethel Jackson, a new contralto singer, with a fine voice of light, agreeable quality, has arrived in Sydney. She won the Sims Reeves exhibition at Trinity Col lege, London, in 1002, and had the annual tenure renewed by examination until last year, when she resigned it in order to leave for Australia. Miss Jackson, who has a fine presence brings with her highly favorable notices of her appearance as the Fairy Queen in Iolanthe at a matinee under Richard Temple's direction at the Lyric Theatre in April, 1905. and it is probable, says the Sydney "Morning Herald," that she may be seen upon the Australian stage after her concert room debut. Mme. Albani, O.M., is making her final appearances at Perth. In New Zealand she made acquaintance with a Maoriland musician, Mr. Alfred Hill, and has a high opinion of his work. "So much so, in deed, that I have been singing The Maori Canoe and other songs, which suit me to perfection. I intend to sing them in Eng land, and make them known there if I can." She was to appear two or three times at Perth, and then at Colombo twice, after which at Bombay and Calcutta until 20th December, when she sails for home.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: Mr John R. Mitchell, teacher of music, Kadina, is now making arrangements to include Moonta, as one of his teaching centres. As a
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Mr John R. Mitchell, teacher of music, Kadina, is new making -arrangements to include Moonta, as one of hia teaching centres. As a musician Mr Mitchell possesses talent t>f a very high calibre. He has bad also, the advantage of a classical education extending over In any years at the Ad el ail e Con- Bervatorium of Music. Mr Mitchell's Bolo work lias a special attractiveness by reason of the rare qualities of vigor and individuality that characterise his interpretations. He is a son of Mr J. S. Mitchell, of Cowell, formerly of Kadina. For further particulars Se9 advt. Mr T. Trenwith, of Kadina, re ceived an official communication on Friday last that his son, Private Arthur A. Trenwith, of the 10th Battalion, had been killed in action on February 17. H:s younger brother, Private Roy, is in hospital suffering from a wound in the neck. Both young mun are wellknown and highly respected.

snippet: A musical firm advertises its mor[?]aux for sale in the following charmingly original and colloquial manner:--"Through every chance and change; Thee only I love; Alice where art thou; Thy voice is near; Blind Alice, I'm alone; Take this cup of sparkling wine; Ask
articleText:
Musical.

A musical firm advertises its morcsaux for sale in the following charmingly original and colloquial manner : — " Through every chance and change ; Thee only I love ; Alice whex-e ai-t thou ; Thy voice is near ; Blind Alice, I'm alone ; Take this cup of spai-kling wine ; Ask me not why ; Go not from me ; Pui-e as snow ; Sweeter than the

breath of morning.'' Mr. Punch has been so struck with this ingeni ous arrangement, that he has appended a similar one as thus : — Molly Brown, If I had a donkey, We may be happy yet, By the sad sea waves, Riding in a Railway Car, Deep in a mossy glen, with Gentle Annie, The Ratcatcher's Daughter, and Poll of Horsloy Down. I dreamt I dwelt in Marble Hall with Sukey by my side ; We have lived and loved together, In that ai-m chair, Where the bee sucks, My Sister Jane, Wha wadna fecht for Charlie, The Dandy Broadway Swell, Going up Holboi-n Hill with the Cavalier, Mary Blain and A Perfect Cure arrayed for the Bridal With a high ho tantivy.

snippet: Following on good fortune which has attended Miss Lucic Atkins, one of Tasmania's songtresses who has been taken in hand by Madame Melba, the glad
articleText:
MUSICAL. Following on good fortune which has attended Miss Luclo Atkins, one of Tas mania's songtresses who has been taken in hand by Madame Melba, the glad tid ings have come to hand that the diva has sent for another Tasmanian in the person of Miss Hempseed, a daughter of Mr. William Hempseed, of Hobart. The examiner in connection with the Royal Academy of Music, Mr. F. Moore, A.R.A.-L, was highly impressed with Miss ITempseed's abilities, and gave the young lady a letter to Melba couched in the highest terms of praise. Miss Hemp.

seed leaves for Melbourne by the Moe. raki on Thursday next, and with her will go the best wishes of Tasmania. October 30.

heading: MUSICAL.
snippet: The Victorian Orchestra, although not giving their two weekly concerts with as much regularity as usual lately, have been doing useful work, notably in
articleText: MUSICAL. The Victorian Orchestra, although not giving their two weekly concerts with as much regularity as usual lately, have been doing useful work, notably in con nection with the eminent English baritone singer, MIr Santley, enabling that gentle man to appear in the two famous oratorios " Elijah" (M1endelssohn) and "The Mes siah (IIandel). In most cases favonrable terms have been made for the regular subscribers by the committee, enabling them to witness these combination per. formances to advantage, and at a reduced tariff. Still it was with feelings of plea sure that the regular attend nts at the Orchestral Concerts once more assembled in the Town Hall, on Thursday evening, to hear a programme of purely instru mental music. An attraction also was the first appearance of -Mr W. T. Barker, as a solo harpist, choosing " Autumn" (Thomas) as his number. A great deal was expected from this gentleman, as the playing of his younger brother at the Exhibition Concerts led people to anti cipate an unusual performance, and it is gratifying to state that no one was disap. pointed; he received an unmistakeablo encore, responding with a finished per formance of IIandel's "Harmonious Black smith." The rest of the programme con sisted of well known selections, all well rendered and received, and were as follow -Overture " Mignon," Thomas; Entr' acto " La Colombre," Gounod, capitally played and repeated by universal desire. This was followed by the two movements of Schubert' unfinished symphony in B minor, written in 1822, an eventful period in the composer's short, hard life of 31 years. It was in this year that hie made the acquaintance of his two great contemporariee, Beethoven and Weber; the latter came to Vienna to supertintend the first performance of " Euryanthe," and was annoyed by hearing that Scubert had criticised it unfavorably, he retaliated by remarking, relative to "Alfonzo and Estrella," that the first puppies and the first operas should be drowned; notwith standing these little differences they seem t> have been on friendly terms, as Weber offered to give a performance of Scubert's workat Dresden. According to achindler Schubert's meeting with Beethoven was most unfortunate. Iie had written a set variations for four hands, which lie dedi cated to the great niester, and wished to present in person. In coming into the presence of him who for years had beent the object of his admiration all Schubert's presence of mind forsook him, he felt as if his hands were tied and his tongue fettered, Beethoven ran through the copy and found some inaccuracy of harmony ; in a kind manner Ihe pointed it out, in forming the young man that it was no deadly sin. The effect was so great on the nervous visitor that he did not recover his equanimity till outside the house, when he rebuked himself severely anti had never the courage to face Beethoven again. The unfinished symphony was not per formed until 1865 being 37 years after the composer's death, which occurred in 1828, and formed portion of a quantity of " old music" found in poor Schubert's room, and valued at ton florins. The performance on this occasion was a praiseworthy one, and we hope soots to hearit repeated. The remaining numbers were: Overture " Flying Dutchman," Suite " L'Arlessienno" (Bizet), and over turo " Mirella" (Gounod), which termi nated the 47th Concert successfully. Open Air Concerts took place on the Melbourne Cricket Ground on Saturday and Tuesday evenings, and were largely patronized. The prices are popular, and this kind of entertainment is thoroughly suited for our summer climate. It is sincerely hoped by those who have the welfare of the art at heart that this excellent organisation will not be allowed to suffer or collapse for want of funds. The practical way to prevent this is to support their public ventures.

articleText: Musical.! Ir. j. A. Steele, Mus. Bac., will be out of town, conducting examinations in music on behalf of the University, from 12th to the 24th inst. Mr. Steele has been appointed examinel for the Bendigo and Castlemaine districts, and also for Gippsland and portion of the North-Eastern d strict. In spite of the present unsettled state of affairs. the entries for country candtdates show a decided increase over last year.

articleText:
' ' MUSICAL.

SIR,-Asoné who has in his day worked pretty hard in the interests of music in this colony, I should like to make a few remarks on some points suggested by the letter of " Zil 'l in this day's Mercury. '

Allow me to repeat and emphasise his statement that " there are many young singers of both sexes with very good voices, but the want of really good training in pain- fully evident. So many make the great mistake of thinking that screaming out and making a great noise with their upper, dr favourite notes, is all that is wanted po constitute a good singer, and that the senti- ment of to music in the last thing to be thought of" '

As to the sentiment, you cannot make a silk purse out of a sow's ear. If the ants ment is not in the soul of the Singer, you cannot put it there. If it is there, it may certainly be cultivated and developed.

But what I would specially' call attention to are defects of utterance. These are two

-1. Inarticulateness. 2. Faults Of, pro-

nunciation. '

Very few amateurs take the trouble to acquire distinctness of enunciation. As a general rule one can scarcely distinguish a word of what they are singing. The, lan" guage might be Russian or Chinese for anything that the audience can tall. If people perform in public, they ought to take the trouble to matter the first principles of their art. To do' anything less. is! to treat their audience with disrespect. Every word ought to be heard distinctly over the whole room!; It is just in this point that the great difference between the ordinary amateur and the thoroughly educated professional He. 'It should never be lost sight of that in which, the words are the first thing, the musician only secondary. Unless ' proper attention is paid to the words there might as well be no words at all, and the. music might ' as well, and sometimes better, be played on a lifeless internment. ' "? 'Before, therefore, anyone, can sing correctly he must learn to speak correctly. He must not dip or for his words but after their firmly, distinctly, fully and without attention to their meaning and expression.' When we hear our young people sing or speak we often wonder- whether the teachers in our schools take any trouble , its all to correct their poplU't faults in speaking. Surely, if the schools were what they ought to be, the rising generation would speak a better, than they do. -,, i '. in

1 Musical.

Thu London 'Daily Mail' in its issue just

to haiKl, says : 'Siiss Florence Re h in id t, a

from the land of Melba and Ada Crossley, made a success ful first appear ance in .London at the Queen's Hall last night. Sliss Schmidt's light flexible voice was heard to advantage in the florid 'Caro Corapagnc' from 'La Sonnambu !a,' and her per formance was rendered the

more enjoyable by the excellence of her enunciation.' Gulseppe Verdi, the composer of 'IlTro- vatore;''to be presented at the Royal on Saturday night, entered on the SStfo year of hisJbusy 1 if u last month. He was born at Roncolc, a villago ? near Busseto, Pnrma, where hlb fu'-nor w.is the proprietor and Keeper of an inn. It is worthy of note that at first he was not considered by the dl lecter of thcConservatorlo to posses any special talent, and was refused' admission. After, writing, several smalls songs,' his llrst

opera was 'produced at ija.Scala, rsoy. 'IT, .?1839T-'Obonto,':'. 'Conte dl San -Bonifacio.' His ne\t piece, was a failure, but his ne\t, again, done in 1SI2, 'Nabucco,' was a huge success, and ;mndo,:bis name. Thenceforth, the master -wrote a new opora every 'year, but it was in 1851 that Verdi's brilliant career began with 'Rigoletto.' Then camo ??]r,Trovatore,' 1852; 'Traviaka,'.' 1853— tho composer's most'. popular works. Opora upon 'opera and success upon success fol lowed, .until wo reach 'Falstaff,' a wonder ful piece, in 1853. on a hearty reception. No one could more fully deserve it. Sir:. Fred Laithom, the English represen tative of Sir. Maurice Grau, has (says a laiio London paper) arranged for'an opera com pany; numbering 250 persons, to lcavu Southampton for New York on Saturday. This company, which is mainly rocrultod from Covent Garden, Is the largest operatic itroupe that foa's ever left this country. 'On arriving at New York they will proceed at once to San Francisco by a special train, consisting of sleeping, kltoheu, and bag gage cars. - ? This journey will cost the impresario a? least £5000; but against this -it may- bo mentioned .that the subscription for the season in New York, where tihe company proceeds after 'Its season in the west, already amourits to £100,000. Sir. Grau finds' tha't' -it costs' an average of £10,000 a Week ito run grand opera In America, and .that despite thin fact he Is able every season -to hand to his syndlcato a very considerable profit. — Tho 'Newcastle Journal' (England), in its sketch of tho forthcoming aeries of Har

heading: Musical.
snippet: Mdlle. Antonia Dolores has appeared in three concerts at the Town Hall (Wednesday, Saturday, and yesterday), and on each occasion has delighted large audiences. The
articleText:
Musical.

Mdlle. Antonla Dolores has appeared ln three concerts at the Town Hall (Wednes day, Saturday, and yesterday), and on each occasion has delighted large audiences. Tho great soprano will give a fourth recital (a matinee) to-day.

Mr. F. R. Woodhousc, the well-known tenor, who has been unfortunate In. the matter of health, Is at least fortunate in possessing the sympathy of troops of friends, and there is little doubt that the benefit entertainment which is being pro moted on his behalf will result in a well deserved success. The affair will take place at the Town Hall on Saturday even ing, the 27th inst. The gathering is aptly described as 'A Night in Bohemia,' and boucmians in all branches of art will con tribute to a programme of a unique and novel character. Ready responses to assist therein have been received from all tho best vocajlsts, Instrumentalists, elocutionists, sketch artists, &c, at present In Sydney, so that an entertainment comprising the best vocal and instrumental . music, pleasantly varied with other interesting items, may be expected. The card of admission de signed by Mr. H. Soutar is clever and characteristic of the movement, and will doubtless be kept by patrons as a valuable souvenir. . . ? Mr. Geo. F. Pack, the popular young con ductor, who has supplied the music for the several Christmas productions at Her Majesty's Theatre for some years past, Is about leaving for England, but prior to his departure he Is to be given a farewell bene fit. This will take place at; tho Palace Theatre on tho afternoon of Thursday, tho 25th Inst. Mr. Pack, who has himself as sisted at numerous benefits, has been as sured of the ready co-operation of his fel low artists, and a great programme, drawn from Ihc various places of amusement at present open in Sydney, is in course of pre paration. The beuoSciare propoies to leave by the Afrie. The managing committee met yesterday afternoon and arranged a programmo for tho occasion, which Is certainly one of the strongest that has ever been submitted for tlhe attraction of the public. Many of the principal artists attached to the various theatres will appear by permission of their respective managers. The list includes the names of Miss Nellie Stewart, Miss Grace Palotta, Miss Carrie Moore, Mr. George Laurl, Mr. Wallace Brownlbw, Mr. Charles Kenningham, Mr. Leon Caron, Mr. Harry Rickards, Miss Neta Clarke-Leote, Miss Eugenie Duggan, and members ot Mr. W. Anderson's Lyceum Company, Mr. C. M. Rodney, Mr. G. Rivers Allpress. Mr. Harry Leston, and Mr. Charles Arnold and his English Comedy Company. Mr. Joe Brown is acting as honorary secretary of the movement.

Our Bourko correspondent, writing on the 14th inst., says: '3ourke Is to bo honored by a visit from that fine Australian soprano singer, Miss Marie Narellc, who opens in Tobin's Hall with a very strong company on May 2. The combination includes Mr. John Lemmone, the Australian flautist. Miss Narelle should meet with crowded houses. '

heading: Musical.
snippet: Miss Ada Crossley was appearing at the London Ballad Concerts at the Queen's Hall when the mall left. Miss Nellie Cooke made a big hit in
articleText:
MUSICAL.

Miss Ada Crossley was appearing at the London Ballad Concerts at the Queen's Hall when the mail left. Miss Nellie Cooke made a big hit in Mel- bourne at her concert at the Town Hall a few nights ago. One of the morning papers in its notice refers to her as the 'gifted and very promising young visitor.' My prediction that the war slump at

home would cause many artists to look abroad for engagements is already being fulfilled. Mr. John Lemmone has received news that Mr. Kennerley Rumford, a bari- tone of considerable English reputation, leaves London for Australia this month. Although this gentleman is but little known on this side of the world, his position has been firmly established in London for the past four or five years. On one of the occa- sions upon which Madame Albani and Miss Ada Crossley sang before the Queen at Balmoral, M. Wolff . (violinist) and Mi-. Kennerley Rumford appeared at the same time, and the baritone has sung through more than one season at the ballad con- certs conducted by Messrs. Boosey and Co., at St. James' Hall, at the Royal Albert Hall with Madame Patti, and at many of the great oratorio festivals. The news of his approaching departure was received by Mr., Lemmone in a letter from Mr. W. Ad- lington, one of the leading London concert

agents. It was this entrepreneur who re- cently despatched Mark Hambourg to America, where the Russian pianist has created a great impression. Mr.. Adlinglington suggests that Mr. Hambourg might re-visit Australia next August, and the return of a pianist so brilliant and highly gifted would certainly be welcomed. — South Australian 'Register.' . PHILIP NEWBURY'S FAREWELL. The Melbourne 'Age,' referring to Mr. Phil Newbury's farawell concert on Wed nesday, night, remarked : — It is close on six years since Madame Spada and Mr. Now bury made their first tow to a Melbourne audience. Things 'wore not at their bright est then, or for some time after; and tho decision he came to — to settle down in the

colonies for a time — would probably . not have been aimed at had he known a3 much as. ho found out sub sequently. For ?the ? (past year or so, however, he has been en Raged in 'run- ning' concerts on popular lines in . Sydney, these having proved even more successful than a similar, hut less . pro longed, serie.1

here, and his intended return to the ok country has been delayed and postponed from time to time on that account. Now, at length, he has made up his mind to go — if not 'where glory waits him,' at least where profitable engagements are likely to wait him, for there is no getting. away from tho fact that few tenors in England to-day aro fit to hold a candle to Philip Newbury at his best. ,'..;'
